webTitle: NatWest trades its Trophy for a menage a trois

fields.headline: NatWest trades its Trophy for a menage a trois
fields.trailText: NatWest yesterday announced a fresh sponsorship deal with the EWCB which will be worth £6m over three years, but at the same time announced that this would be the last year of the NatWest Trophy.
fields.body:
NatWest, which has backed county cricket's best-known one-day competition since 1981, yesterday announced a fresh sponsorship deal with the England and Wales Cricket Board which will be worth £6m over three years.

But it was not all good news from NatWest: it also announced that this would be the last year of the NatWest Trophy, which replaced the Gillette Cup 19 years ago. It will also end its involvement with the Under-19 side.

NatWest will sponsor England's domestic one-day internationals and a new grassroots development scheme that will work to improve practice facilities at schools and clubs and include the use of mobile, non-turf, pitches.

The ECB, which is about to introduce centralised contracts for the leading players, will be relieved to find a new sponsor for its one-day internationals. Cornhill, which has backed Test cricket in England since 1978, will be withdrawing at the end of the coming season and a replacement has yet to be found.

There is also concern about the county championship, sponsored by PPP Healthcare. It will be divided into two divisions next season but interest has already flagged. Last month the former England captain Michael Atherton said the system did not produce international-class cricketers.

England became the last of the major nations to adopt the idea of the triangular one-day tournament only two years ago, when Emirates sponsored the competition against South Africa and Sri Lanka.

From this summer, when West Indies and Zimbabwe will be the visitors, it will be called the NatWest Series. There will be 10 matches, including three under lights, of 50 overs a side spanning 17 days, with a final at Lord's on Saturday July 22.

The NatWest chairman David Rowland said: "It now makes sense to build on our sponsorship not only of the Trophy but also the World Cup."

Further damp and blustery weather here has raised doubts about today's match against Zimbabwe being played without interruption.

England, who won the first in the four-match series on Wednesday, will again consider the left-arm spinner Ashley Giles, who has played no competitive cricket on this tour, and Gavin Hamilton, whose only international appearance was the first Test in Johannesburg, in which he failed to take a wicket or score a run.

 The New Zealand captain Emily Drumm made 59 off 93 balls as England's 146 for eight was overtaken with four wickets to spare in Auckland; the home side lead 3-0 in the five-match series. In rainy Wellington, the men's one-day series against Australia got off to a false start when play was abandoned with the tourists 119 for one after 23 overs.

webTitle: Premier clubs fork out £11m to pay off TV double act

fields.headline: Premier clubs fork out £11m to pay off TV double act
fields.trailText: The Premier League has agreed a hefty £11m compensation package with the two television consultants controversially hired by its former chief executive Peter Leaver.
fields.body:
The Premier League has agreed a hefty £11m compensation package with the two television consultants controversially hired by its former chief executive Peter Leaver.

Sam Chisholm and David Chance were on such a lavish salary package, which could have earned them £40m, that when the clubs found out 13 months ago their services were immediately dispensed with.

However, talks on a severance deal were fraught with disagreement and the complication of Chisholm and Chance filing a breach-of-contract lawsuit. The agreement of a severance deal yesterday avoided the case coming to the high court on Monday. Although the £11m will come out of Premier League funds, it will effectively cost each of the 20 clubs £550,000.

All the Premier League's chairman Dave Richards would say on the matter yesterday was: "We are very pleased that his matter has now been put to rest."

The deal was rubber-stamped at a meeting of Premier League clubs yesterday, at which it was also agreed to ask Uefa for a fourth Uefa Cup place for English football. One place currently goes to the FA Cup winners, one to the Worthington Cup winners and one to the fourth-placed team in the Premiership.

The normal criterion for a country being given an extra place is the recent record of its clubs in European competition. Although Manchester United are the European champions, the record elsewhere is not strong. However, the Premier League will argue it deserves an extra place because it is Europe's most successful league in terms of wealth and popularity.

If Uefa rejects the request, the Premier League is likely to try to persuade the governing powers that it should be given the Worthington Cup winner's European place.

The Worthington Cup was due to lose its Uefa Cup place at the end of this season. However, a one-year extension is expected. But the Premier League has asked for a meeting with the Football Association and the Football League to discuss what happens after that. In the meantime the Premier League clubs say they will continue to compete in the Worthington Cup.

The meeting also agreed in principle to nominate Rich- ards as the independent chairman of the Premier League. This will almost certainly mean him resigning as chairman of Sheffield Wednesday.

 Burnley's Turf Moor ground has been sold out prior to Ian Wright's debut against Wigan tomorrow. The Lancashire club have sold more than 12,000 tickets since signing Wright from Celtic this week and expect a 22,500 capacity crowd.

fields.headline: Collymore's antics cost him £30,000
fields.standfirst: Leicester's wayward striker shrugs off a torrent of criticism
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore may have talked himself into further trouble last night after being told in no uncertain terms that Leicester City would terminate his contract if he brought more damaging publicity to the club.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore may have talked himself into further trouble last night after being told in no uncertain terms that Leicester City would terminate his contract if he brought more damaging publicity to the club.

Collymore reacted to being fined a club-record £30,000 for the escapades that have shamed his new employers by insisting he was merely "having a laugh" when he let off a fire extinguisher, covering 40 guests with foam and causing £700 worth of damage, during their mid-season break to the Spanish resort of La Manga.

Leicester's manager Martin O'Neill had made it clear he was prepared to take the ultimate sanction should Collymore's self-destructive streak resurface during the remaining 16 months of his contract. He has also ordered him to take part in six months of community service, including visits to hospitals, old people's homes and schools.

However, the apparent lack of contrition displayed by Collymore in attempting to dismiss his behaviour as the norm is certain to intensify O'Neill's anger only a week after offering the controversial 29-year-old a chance to salvage his career.

"Maybe in the circumstances I will hold up my hands and say it was naivety but at the end of the day I haven't killed anybody," said Collymore. "OK, I let off a fire extinguisher and it was a mistake. I will take the fine and I apologise to the manager.

"But I was just having a laugh with the lads. I feel bad that everyone has jumped on the bandwagon and it has caused embarrassment to the club. I fully accept the fine but a million players have done it and a million more will in the future. It seems there are certain high-profile players who cannot have fun these days. The bottom line is that everyone knows the stories and everyone knows about Stan Collymore, when I just want a laugh with the lads. The alternative is to sit at home, not go out and not enjoy the best years of your life."

Collymore let off the fire extinguisher after several hours of drinking with his new colleagues in the Piano Bar of the five-star Hyatt Regency Hotel. The incident led to the entire Leicester squad being thrown out and banned less than 24 hours after arriving at the 1,400-acre complex for a three-day break as part of their preparations for the Worthington Cup final against Tranmere Rovers.

"In football parlance Stan is now on a yellow card. That means if anything else happens he'll be in serious danger of losing his job," said O'Neill.

"When I signed Stan I always felt he would be involved in an incident that would make me wonder if it was a sackable offence, perhaps after six or seven weeks but definitely not just five or six days.

"No doubt there are a lot of people saying 'I told you so' and I could not argue with them at the moment. If he gets that red card, then I will have to say I have definitely failed.

"I signed Stan because he is a talented player who has been wasting every single Saturday of his life for the last 12 months. These events suggest that maybe I need my head examining but I still believe he was a risk worth taking. This is his last chance and there is still an opportunity for him to prove everyone wrong."

O'Neill, who had been due to join his team a day late, called them home immediately after the club's assistant manager John Robertson interrupted his breakfast on Wednesday morning with a telephone call which began with the words: "You won't be happy with this."

He has warned several other players about their conduct, as well as admonishing Robertson for his lack of supervision. The estimated £16,000 costs of the abortive trip, which include the bill for the damage caused, will be deducted from the wages of everyone involved and plans for an end-of-season break in the Caribbean have been scrapped.

A week earlier O'Neill had hailed Collymore's signing from Aston Villa as the final chance for the player to re-establish himself after the off-field problems that have plagued his turbulent career. Collymore is still having counselling for clinical depression and O'Neill hopes his new signing will benefit from the community-based work. "It will do him good to see how the other half live. If it widens his eyes to other people's predicaments, he will be all the better for it," said O'Neill. "It's an idea of mine, although it may not work."

fields.headline: Chelsea search for missing Babayaro
fields.trailText: Chelsea's tumultuous week has been further disrupted by the disappearance of their Nigerian international Celestine Babayaro, who has not appeared at the training ground since Nigeria's defeat in the African Nations Cup final on Sunday.
fields.body:
Chelsea's tumultuous week has been further disrupted by the disappearance of their Nigerian international Celestine Babayaro, who has not appeared at the training ground since Nigeria's defeat in the African Nations Cup final on Sunday.

Chelsea, who had expected him to return on Monday, have sent a fax to the Nigerian Football Association pleading with it to find him and send him back to England. The club have been unable to contact the 21-year-old since he left for the tournament six weeks ago.

He has been named in Gianluca Vialli's squad to face Gillingham in the FA Cup on Sunday but Chelsea's manager said Jon Harley, who has played at left-back in Babayaro's absence, would keep his place in the team.

"We expect Baba back any time," said Vialli. "It could be tomorrow, it could be next month. We're not sure where he is but officially he's in Nigeria."

Babayaro, who moved to Stamford Bridge for £2.25m from Anderlecht in June 1997, is likely to be disciplined for his vanishing act and faces a fight to win his place back in the Chelsea starting line-up, given the emergence of Harley and the return to fitness of Graeme le Saux.

He incurred the wrath of Jo Bonfrere, Nigeria's Dutch coach, when he arrived two days late for a training camp in Malaga before the tournament. The excuse was that there had been no direct flights from London to the Spanish resort and so he and his international team-mate, Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu, had to go via Madrid.

Chelsea have requested personal hearings for both the club and Dennis Wise over the misconduct charges brought by the Football Association after the tunnel brawl after their 3-1 win against Wimbledon on Satur day. Wise, an alleged instigator of the fight, faces a separate misconduct charge.

 Leeds , Arsenal, Newcastle and possibly even Liverpool will attempt to lure the French international midfielder Olivier Dacourt back to England before next month's transfer deadline. David O'Leary, the Leeds manager, watched the former Everton player appear for Lens on Wednesday.

fields.headline: Crackdown 'must not shackle England'
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan yesterday defended his decision to retain Dennis Wise in the England squad when the Chelsea captain faces a misconduct charge from last Saturday's rumble in the tunnel at Stamford Bridge.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan yesterday defended his decision to retain Dennis Wise in the England squad when the Chelsea captain faces a misconduct charge from last Saturday's rumble in the tunnel at Stamford Bridge. The England coach pointed out that Wise was innocent until proven guilty.

Keegan was challenged to explain why, with so many footballers making the wrong sort of headlines, he had kept faith with the 33-year-old Wise, who has been sent off 11 times in his career and this season alone has received eight yellow cards and two red.

"My job is to pick the best players I have available," he insisted. "If something happens to Dennis Wise in the future, that may affect his England position. But I don't know what happened at Chelsea last Saturday and it would be wrong to prejudge the matter."

Earlier this season Keegan decided against calling up Wimbledon's Ben Thatcher after the defender caught Sunderland's Nicky Summerbee with an elbow to the face. Yesterday he explained the apparent inconsistency by pointing out that Wise was already a member of the England squad.

Keegan has seen Paul Scholes and David Batty sent off during his nine games in charge. "Our discipline off the field has been very good," he said, "but once they get on to the field you can't do much about it.

"You want the players to give 110% and sometimes they will break the rules. But while I accept that a player can be dismissed for two mistimed tackles, there is no excuse for being sent off for dissent."

Keegan warned that domestic disciplinary crackdowns must not put England at a disadvantage against the rest of Europe. "We have to make sure we are in line with everyone else and not just punishing ourselves," he said.

webTitle: 'Excuse me, sugar puff, but aren't you tactically naive?'

fields.headline: 'Excuse me, sugar puff, but aren't you tactically naive?'
fields.standfirst: Sweet-talking Keegan holds nothing back in an impressive radio debut
fields.trailText: Vivek Chaudhary hears sweet-talking Keegan hold nothing back in an impressive radio debut.
fields.body:
King Kevin reclined on his studio throne, adjusted his headphones and prepared to address his loyal subjects on the most important football issues of the day. The England team had just been announced, preparations had to be made for next week's important friendly and footballers were once again hitting the headlines for all the wrong reasons.

For the first time ordinary England fans would have a chance to address Kevin Keegan directly on his own phone-in show, but for once the national team coach was slightly lost for words. "Sugar puffs," asked one irate fan, "How can you justify advertising sugar puffs?"

"I didn't know the questions would be as difficult as that," replied a slightly bemused Keegan, without going on to explain his former commercial links with the Honey Monster.

"Antihe... antihe... antithesis... how do you pronounce it?" asked Gary Newbon, the presenter of Keegan's phone-in show on Talksport radio. "And I'm a public-school boy."

Keegan reminded us that he wasn't. "And the last time I said it I got pasta in an Italian restaurant."

Sugar puffs and pasta aside, Keegan appeared as relaxed as ever in the first of five hour-long shows on Talksport that will allow football fans to call up the England manager and raise their concerns about the state of the game.

Peter from Manchester was the first caller, with a question about whether more young players should have been selected for next week's match against Argentina.

"I honestly believe that you can't look at a player's birth certificate when selecting a team," replied Keegan, aged 49.

Not surprisingly, most of the questions centred on Keegan's team selection and England's Euro 2000 prospects. Why was Dennis Wise in and Joe Cole left out? Who should play alongside Alan Shearer? Who should be England's next goalkeeper?

Keegan was candid and for some of his players it would have made uneasy listening: time was running out for Cole for Euro 2000, the Tottenham goalkeeper Ian Walker was no longer automatic third choice, and Teddy Sheringham needed more regular first-team football if he was to be considered for England.

Fortunately for the fans, Keegan's refreshing approach offered a rare opportunity to address an England coach and get a frank response. Sometimes a bit too frank, perhaps, or some would say naive.

"What are our chances for Euro 2000?" asked one caller.

"We can win it," Keegan predictably replied.

"Aren't you tactically naive?" asked Paul from London.

"They are always going to find some area in which they think you are vulnerable," claimed Keegan. "It goes back to Newcastle and losing the championship. We almost did it with an attacking team but because we didn't they said tactically it was naive. I now know that, but you can't plan for things in football."

Financial details of Keegan's deal with Talksport remain a secret and no date has been set for his second show, which may prove to be particularly interesting if England fail to impress against Argentina.

For once, however, the fans ended up hearing it first-hand from the horse's mouth.

webTitle: Gorman faces Commons ban over property cover-up

fields.headline: Gorman faces Commons ban over property cover-up
fields.standfirst: Committee rules MP abused her position and intended to deceive parliamentary watchdog over ownership of homes and offshore trusts
fields.trailText: The maverick Tory MP, Teresa Gorman, is facing one of Parliament's most serious punishments -            a one-month suspension from the Commons - for repeatedly covering up her substantial business            interests from scrutiny by MPs or the public.
fields.body:
The maverick Tory MP, Teresa Gorman, is facing one of Parliament's most serious punishments - a one-month suspension from the Commons - for repeatedly covering up her substantial business interests from scrutiny by MPs or the public.

A report published yesterday by the Commons standards and privileges committee said that she `intended to deceive' parliament's senior watchdog body over her ownership of properties in south London and Portugal which were hidden in offshore trusts. She is also accused of contempt of the House of Commons and of abusing `her position as an MP' to smear accusers who gave evidence against her.

Yesterday Mrs Gorman, recently barred by her own party from the shortlist for London mayoral candidate, said: `I totally reject the findings of the committee. Since my election I have been disposing of my outside interests to concentrate on my job.'

She branded the committee's procedures as `unfair' and said they `inevitably' led to injustice.

In her report Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commisisoner for standards , says Mrs Gorman failed to provide sufficient evidence to her that she has paid all her taxes on the secret property deals. She was then found to have improperly contacted witnesses about her secret property deals during the investigation.

Ms Filkin said: `Mrs Gorman provided seriously misleading and inaccurate information to the committee on standards and privileges, the chairman (Robert Sheldon MP), the registrar of members' interests, Roger Willoughby, and me''. She added that Mrs Gorman `neither fulfilled the registration requirements nor observed the principles of honesty and accountability which it requires'.

MPs are particularly incensed about Mrs Gorman's repeated refusal to disclose information about three offshore companies. She provided `evasive answers or no answers at all.' The information was only obtained by writing to the Guernsey-based trusts. They were also angry about her denial that she had ever owned property in south London where a Mr South was a tenant, and her claim that his sworn statement that he was her tenant had been `falsified for a cash payment' procured by the Mirror. She later had to admit this was wrong.

The MPs say: `We consider that Mrs Gorman abused her position as a MP.' They conclude: `During our inquiry we have been gravely concerned by Mrs Gorman's untruthfulness, her failures to provide the commissioner with information, and false accusations she has made against others. We regard these matters as more serious than the failure to register or declare interests which were subject of the original complaint. They call into question the sincerity of the apology she made to the house (over a pervious failure to declare a directorship)'.

Mrs Gorman said last night: `I totally agree with the Neill committee (on standards in public life) report ... which recommends that the chairman (of the standards and privileges committee ) should not come from the government party, there should be equal representation of parties on the committee, and there should be an appeal procedure before an independent judge and senior figures from the Commons.

`Judge for yourself whether this committee is independent or if it is a tool of the Labour party spin doctor industry,' she said.

Last night the commissioner pointed out that Mrs Gorman would have no right of an appeal under Lord Neill's proposals because there was no dispute over facts.

webTitle: Sketch: Tess and the happiness of a middle-aged man

fields.headline: Sketch: Tess and the happiness of a middle-aged man
fields.trailText: February 18 2000: The shadow education secretary and the porn star
fields.body:
Theresa May arrived for education questions in the Commons. She's the Tories' shadow minister, and like most of her colleagues, is largely unknown to the public.

However, there is a soft porn star, who appears on a cable channel called Granada Men and Motors (or Boys and Boobs as it should be called) and so is slightly better known. Her name is also Teresa May, spelled without an `h'.

Apparently this has caused some confusion, with phone calls and letters being forwarded to the wrong Tess.

One protested in a recent radio interview: `I was disgusted at the sleazy world the letters revealed. My namesake was asked to expose herself in public, to do things with men that most of us wouldn't consider in the privacy of our own homes, and to force herself into weird, unnatural positions for the cameras.

`She was told that it would make `a lot of middle-aged men very happy'. Thank goodness I'm not a Tory MP.' I myself am not acquainted with the thespian Ms May's oeuvre, but from my limited knowledge of porn films, they are all much the same. Typically a woman is in bed with her lover. They copulate. He goes to work and the pool maintenance man comes round. They copulate. He goes next door, where he finds a housewife sunbathing topless ... You get the idea.

So the plot hardly exists, the dialogue is both banal and predictable. Which makes it almost identical to parliamentary questions.

The trouble is that once an event as dull and workaday as education questions takes on an erotic tinge, it becomes hard to make serious and sober political judgments. For instance, sitting on the second row, behind the Tories' first team, was John Redwood, now himself a humble backbencher, with no more standing or prestige than Michael Fabricant.

On the front bench sat the newly promoted John Bercow, the Tory rightwinger with the phantom rottweiler on a piece of string. I should have been reflecting that there was something quite grotesque about the fact that William Hague has room for Bercow in his team, but none for Mr Redwood. Instead, I could only think that Mr Bercow looked like the heroes of those chirpy 60s British sex films which generations of furtive schoolboys used to watch: Education Spokesmen on the Job, for example:

`'Ere, darlink, wanna get acquainted wiv my differential top-up?' (Education questions are conducted almost entirely in jargon. Speaking about schools with specialist status, Mr Blunkett promised to `cascade both their resources and their work outwards', whatever that might mean.)

Finally Theresa May rose to complain that the government had failed to fund the teachers' pay award. It was, she trembled, `the mathe matics of the madhouse! `This government is all mouth and no delivery!' she added, as I silently shouted: `trousers, the correct phrase is `no trousers'.'

Mr Bercow's moment came next. Why should grammar schools be forced to become non-selective because of `10 local malcontents'? he asked.

Estelle Morris, the minister, seized on this. `Aha, the new Tory word for `parents' - they are `malcontents'!'

Mr Bercow looked glum as his phantom rottweiler slumbered beside him. The four female Labour education ministers then filed out for the obligatory orgy scene - yes, yes, I did make that up.

fields.headline: Art mouse
fields.standfirst: A master is found, a monk has his wings clipped, and a man has his trough nicked
fields.trailText: A master is found, a monk has his wings clipped, and a man has his trough nicked
fields.body:
Renaissance rodent
The art world was in a state of high excitement this week following the discovery of a lost Renaissance masterpiece hanging in the corridor of a Suffolk mansion. The Madonna and Child by Cimabue, thought to have been painted around 1274, was found at Benacre Hall, Southwold, by experts from Sotheby's, who were valuing the Hall's contents following the death of its owner, Sir John Gooch. "It's a discovery of enormous significance," said Old Master specialist Richard Charlton-Jones. "It's one of only seven or eight independent panel paintings by Cimabue that survive, and the only one in private hands. It's a picture of the greatest rarity and beauty." The painting, which measures only ten inches by eight, will go under the hammer in July, when it is estimated it will fetch in excess of £2m. Whilst art experts are licking their lips, however, reaction amongst local villagers has been slightly more muted. "I thought a Cimabue was like a sort of gerbil," commented one Southwold resident. "When I heard they'd found one up at the hall I said they'd better call Rentokil." East Anglian Daily Times

Monk flunk
It's been a week of mixed fortunes for Magnificent Men and their Flying Machines. In Bognor Regis it has just been announced that the prize money for this year's Birdman competition, in which contestants battle it out to see who can fly the farthest after launching themselves off the end of Bognor Pier, will be a whopping £25,000. Not such good news from Malmesbury, though, where plans to re-enact one of the earliest recorded instances of human flight have been scuppered because of high insurance premiums and complaints from English Heritage. Almost 1000 years ago, in 1010 AD, a Benedictine monk named Eilmer attached a pair of home-made wings to his arms and leapt from the tower of Malmesbury Abbey, gliding for some 660 feet before crashing to earth and breaking both his legs. His feat, which entered the history books as the first known example of an Englishman flying, was re-enacted in 1962 and 1976 with the help of a safety wire. Plans to do so again this year as part of Malmesbury's millennium celebrations have been dashed because of the huge cost of insuring the stunt, and concerns by English Heritage that it might damage the Abbey's exterior. Eilmer enthusiasts are now exploring the possibility of using a dummy to re-create their hero's flight, or even a hologram. "You can get a sex-change on the National Health," complained one man, "But you can't dress up as a monk and jump off a tower with wings on your arms. It's outrageous."
Chichester Observer and Somerset Online

Trough travails
Scunthorpe, that Eden of Humberside, has been suffering of late at the hands of a phantom pig-trough-thief. The troughs in question are ornamental ones which have been stolen at night from gardens in and around the town. So many have now been taken that police are talking of a pig-trough-stealing epidemic. The first reported incident occurred at the beginning of February, when a 2ft high concrete trough with moulded pig-snouts along the side disappeared from a garden on the Isle of Axholme. Since then, barely a night has gone by without at least one more trough disappearing, including one from a house in Crowle that weighed the best part of half a ton. 'I can't sleep at night knowing my pig-trough might be in danger,' admitted one terrified owner. 'It's the centrepiece of my garden. Without it the place would look bare. The sooner they catch this monster the better.' Police are convinced that a professional gang are behind the thefts, although no arrests have so far been made. 'They're almost certainly stealing them to sell on,' said one insider. 'Although it's possible they've just got extremely large appetites.'
Scunthorpe Evening Telegraph

Tomato retch-up
The world is full of strange afflictions and phobias, but few can be as distressing as that suffered by 7-year old James Coles, of Cheltenham, who is violently sick whenever he sees or smells ketchup. Such is his sauceophobia that siblings Charlene, 15, and Christopher, 12, have to eat their meals at different times to spare him the torment of watching them smother their chips and fish fingers in viscous tomato relish. Trips to the local McDonalds, meanwhile, invariably end in disaster, with James vomiting uncontrollably at the mere sight of their industrial ketchup dispensers. He has visited numerous doctors and specialists, but so far none have been able to suggest a cure for his disorder. "The only similar thing I've dealt with is a man who hated whelks," said one expert. "Unfortunately he's in prison now after trying to blow up his local fishmongers."
Gloucestershire Online

Letter of the week
We recently had the misfortune to be graced with the presence of certain lowlifes who decided to help themselves to some our belongings. This isn't the first time we have had visitors, but it is the first time they actually entered our home.
In the last 18 months we have had our car broken into twice, the garage twice (on one occasion actually taking the doors off) and more recently, someone entered our home at around 10pm on Thursday.
The frightening thing was, they did this while my wife was in the bath, the lights on and the telly blaring away. To think that this scumbag was in the house at that time has now scared my wife to death! Just how hard-necked are these burglars becoming? To walk into an occupied house, at that time of day without a thought, are they prepared to deal with being confronted by the occupier, and if so, what are they prepared to do?
Things have just got out of hand now and as we are getting no help or protection from the police, it would appear that drastic measures are now required.
The other annoying thing about this is, not only are these people reaping the rewards from the sale of our belongings, the insurance companies are also reeling it in. Despite having a blemish free driving record of 22 years, my premium is through the roof.
Even though I am paying extra for protecting my no claims bonus I am still being personally penalised because of someone who thinks he has the right to something I have paid for through my sheer hard work.
On top of that, the amount of money we have had to spend on beefing up our security, not to mention the loss of earnings through time taken off work is horrendous. They say that there are no funds available for extra policing yet we still seem to find the money for monstrosities such as the Millenium Dome.
Andrew and Helen Fraser
Bolton Evening News

webTitle: How the secret service conspires for good PR

fields.headline: How the secret service conspires for good PR
fields.standfirst:
Download the National Audit Office report(pdf)
MI5 and MI6 in costs cover-up
MI5
Overdue and over-budget: the buildings that didn't quite make it

Security editor Richard Norton-Taylor explains how the secret services react to bad publicity
fields.trailText: One of the first things recruits to the Security Service - more commonly known as MI5 - are told is not to expect a good press. Similar advice is given to recruits to its sister service - the Secret Intelligence Service, or MI6.
fields.body:
One of the first things recruits to the Security Service - more commonly known as MI5 - are told is not to expect a good press. Similar advice is given to recruits to its sister service - the Secret Intelligence Service, or MI6.

"You know we are doing a vital job which by necessity must be secret. We cannot trumpet our success". That's the kind of thing staff are told.

But this apparently stoical, care-free, approach to an inevitably hostile media is far too simplistic. MI5, which is desperately trying to recruit people from a wide range of backgrounds, betrays a certain sensitivity in its recruitment ads. A recent one in the Guardian states: "Many people have preconceptions about the service. Don't make assumptions about us. Send for our information pack or look at our website at www.mi5.gov.uk and find out more".

Actually, MI5 and MI6 get a pretty good press, especially from the tabloids which tend to portray them as exotic defenders of the realm fighting a war against terrorists, drug-traffickers, money-launderers, and preventing such dictators as Saddam Hussein getting their hands on nuclear, chemical and biological weapons.

But secrecy leads to lack of accountability and to cover-ups. Thus the damning report published yesterday (and censored for over five years), by the National Audit Office, parliament's financial watchdog.

The report reveals how MI5 and MI6 conspired with senior Whitehall officials to cover up a huge overspend on their new headquarters, the combined cost of which rose to £547 million, more than twice the original estimate. It makes clear that secrecy surrounding the projects was used to cover up incompetence rather than genuine security needs.

Cover-ups almost invariably get found out, eventually. When they do, the story becomes a "scandal". MI5 and MI6 steel themselves, invariably brushes them off, and say "it all happened a long time ago".

But they also take proactive measures. They plant favourable stories in the media to favoured journalists on an "off the record" base, with the source usually disguised as "British/western security/intelligence officials". The advice to recruits belies a far more sophisticated handling of the media than it suggests.

Meanwhile, the saga about the rocketing costs of the new MI5 and MI6 headquarters provide ample evidence that the security and intelligence agencies should not be excluded - as the government insists - from the proposed freedom of information act. The cover up had nothing to do with protecting national security.

fields.headline: London museum in crisis
fields.trailText:
The Science Museum in London is in 'crisis talks' with the government over
funding, with fears that either free admission for all, some of the expanding
museum's facilities, or jobs will have to be sacrificed to meet a cash
shortfall.
fields.body:
The Science Museum in London is in 'crisis talks' with the government over funding, with fears that either free admission for all, some of the expanding museum's facilities, or jobs will have to be sacrificed to meet a cash shortfall.

The museum administration declined to comment yesterday for fear of jeopardising delicate negotiations with the culture minister, Chris Smith, and his civil servants.

But one source close to the museum told the Guardian that, based on the government's initial grant offer for the next financial year, the institution would face a £4 million shortfall - even if it kept charging adults, as it does now.

There are concerns that redundancies might be the only way to bridge the gap, although no plans for cuts are thought to have been drawn up yet.

There was anger that the government was holding back on support for the Science Museum, the national repository of the country's scientific heritage, when it could afford a £32 million loan for the ailing Dome, the source said.

The museum trustees have refused to fix a budget for 2000-01 on the basis of the government's initial proposals, complaining of a lack of clarity over Mr Smith's intentions on free admission.

'There are crisis talks going on with the government literally daily, trying to sort this out,' said another source, adding that the stumbling block was less free admission than grants for the running costs of a huge new extension to the museum due to be unveiled on June 27.

The £50 million Wellcome Wing, built with cash from the Wellcome Foundation and the Heritage Lottery Fund, will increase the museum's public space by almost a third and include an IMAX cinema.

fields.headline: Jude awakening
fields.standfirst: His Dickie Greenleaf in The Talented Mr Ripley is an arrogant playboy, but in real life Jude Law is just a highly confident movie star - with an Oscar nomination. He talks to Emma Brockes
fields.trailText: His Dickie Greenleaf in The Talented Mr Ripley is an arrogant playboy, but in real life Jude Law is just a highly confident movie star - with an Oscar nomination. He talks to Emma Brockes
fields.body:
There is a widely held view that if Jude Law had been born in America, he would be where Matt Damon is now - a box office name you don't have to fish about in your memory to recognise. He is cut, after all, in the Hitler Youth mould of the American male lead: firm tits, stone jaw and the sort of petulant screen charm that flushes away disapproval with sheer gut fascination.

It is easy to watch him in his role as Dickie Greenleaf, the arrogant playboy in The Talented Mr Ripley for which he has just won an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor, and imagine that it is an exaggerated version of himself - charming, beautiful, imperially conceited. But at six o'clock on a Wednesday evening, standing in a puddle two miles from Berlin, it is a vision that is hard to sustain.

"Raff, Raff, don't get in a tizz." He is consoling his two year old son Rafferty, who is screaming at the thought of travelling into town in a different car from daddy. Law has been out here, in Berlin's abandoned Russian army barracks, filming scenes for Enemy at the Gates. "Don't cry, bubba," he says, picking the boy up and offering him a fistful of comics. "Daddy's following right behind you."

The boy, angel-haired like a fresco cherub, is momentarily distracted by a platoon of extras marching past in the direction of Red Square, a to-scale reconstruction built on waste ground. It's here that Law and Joseph Fiennes are daily playing Russian soldiers in Jean-Jacques Annaud's new film which is set during the battle of Stalingrad in the second world war. The film, which also stars Ed Harris and Rachel Weisz, is the true story of a duel between a Russian sniper and German officer.

It is dark now, wet from the snow machine and about minus five degrees. The SS men have retired to their trailers and two German drivers, waiting to take us back to the city centre, are shooting air guns at each other and shivering at the weirdness of the scene before them. "There are black shirts - SS men - marching about," says one. "It is very strange, very strange to see."

It couldn't be further from the scenes that Law, from next Friday, can be seen enjoying in The Talented Mr Ripley, the Anthony Minghella film that so meticulously recreates 1950s Italy that with every shot you expect Audrey Hepburn to come scooting round the corner, Tony Curtis in pursuit. "I was hugely seduced by the era," says Law, when Rafferty, whose mother is the actress Sadie Frost, has agreed to go in the car with his grandparents.

Law's voice is hoarse from shouting at SS men and he has a little moan about doing interviews after a long day's shooting. It is only a lapse in his charm, however. He takes talking seriously. "Before the film, my image of the 50s came out of the Levi's ad. But it was an era of naive rebellion, when young people started expressing new found philosophies about having a good time, without using the shock tactics that came with the 60s."

Law's character in the film, the son of an American shipping magnate living in louche style on the Italian coast, shocks in the same way that Gatsby did: by showing how bad behaviour is excused, and by extension enabled, by beauty. Dickie Greenleaf is loved, hated and indulged in equal measure because he is the person who everyone wants to be. "I don't judge the characters I play," says Law. He is interesting on Greenleaf, since his public profile shares some of his characteristics. "When I first read the part I did what I think it is natural in Britain to do: I recoiled from him as this spoilt, golden boy. But Anthony won me over. I am fascinated by the challenge of trying to make nasty characters likeable and vice versa, because everyone is made up of all those facets."

Law's initial dismay at the part may also have come from the fact that he dies half way through the film. "Before I went through it with Anthony, I hadn't seen how the part of Dickie resonates throughout the whole film. But he is always there, in a sense." This sounds a bit like the school teacher trying to persuade little Johnny that the donkey really is a pivotal part in the nativity play and every bit as important as Joseph - except that Law's performance is dazzling enough to do just as Minghella promised, and keep the audience thinking about him throughout the film. It brings home that while his roles in the science fiction films Gattaca and eXistenZ were played with conviction, this is the first time Law has really looked like a star.

The irony is that in terms of his background, the 27 year old really has more in common with the Matt Damon role, Tom Ripley, the ordinary Joe with the talent for mimicry. Law's parents are both retired teachers from South London and he was educated at a comprehensive school before the bullying got too bad and he was transfered to a private one in Dulwich. "We have all been in positions where we've been Tom Ripley - where we've hated ourselves and wanted to be someone else. But it was more interesting for me to play Greenleaf and to assume all these airs and graces, rather than to draw on my own demons."

Admittedly, his demons aren't that ferocious. The tenor of his upbringing was such, says Law, that his confidence is mistaken for arrogance. He doesn't think he is better than anyone else, he just knows who he is and what he does best.

"I remember the first school play I did when I was six. It wasn't a case of me looking at the other kids and thinking that I was better. It was just that I immediately understood it, the concept of creating an imaginative scenario. I took it very seriously. I probably drove people mad."

He was emboldened by the relationship he had with his parents - a very adult one that included going regularly to the theatre and talking about the plays they had seen. "Perhaps that's what made me seem cocky at school. But I always assumed that I would get what I wanted in terms of my acting. Not that I was going to be a star or anything, but I didn't see why I should do that British thing of playing down my ambitions. 'You can't be an actor,' they said to me at school. 'Why not?' I said. It's a cliché, but that's how it was."

Confidence is in his make-up, he says, and so is thoughtfulness. "I have always been someone who can't do something that I know will hurt others. Whether success will breed arrogance I don't know, but I'll never deny what I can do and I'll never knowingly upset someone."

The success of his school plays encouraged him to join the National Youth Theatre where, at 13 years old, he met Jonny Lee Miller, now one of his best friends and a partner in Natural Nylon, the production company they own with Sean Pertwee and Ewan McGregor. At 16, he left school with his parents' blessing and won a small part in the Granada soap, Families, before getting a breakthrough role in Les Parents Terribles. When it transferred from the National Theatre to New York, Law won a Tony nomination for best supporting actor and the film roles followed.

"The plan was always to go to university and train to be an actor after that," he says. "But I didn't enjoy the institution of school. I like the accumulated knowledge and the minds of good teachers, but I hated rules and regulations. It's the same on set. If you're not having a good time, why are you standing there doing it? It's your life."

He loves to tackle a thick reading list before starting a new project. On eXistenZ, a film about a virtual reality game, the director David Cronenberg had Law reading Dostoevsky and Kierkegaard as well as putting in some essential hours playing Tomb Raider. For Enemy at the Gates he is ploughing through Russian history books.

His parents have flown out with Rafferty to congratulate him on the Oscar nomination, something he is "thrilled" about naturally, and has been keeping his mind off as a grace too many to wish for. Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of Miramax, is thrilled also and we have to stop on the way to the set to buy Law a bottle of Dom Perignon in Weinstein's name.

He won't be seduced into moving to the States with the movie movers and shakers, however, and has Rafferty enrolled in a state school in north London, where he and Sadie intend to stay. He is not the kind of movie dad who disappears for nine months at a time. As on set, he knows his own value at home. "There's no need to go to Hollywood. I have all my friends around and I know how it feels to be a kid growing up here. Besides, meetings can be held in London." Modest, see?

 The Talented Mr Ripley opens on February 25.

fields.headline: Yorkshire chief scorns web craze
fields.standfirst:
Many banking-related offerings 'will turn out to be short-lived'

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: As banks and other financial services companies rush to launch stand-alone internet operations one plain-speaking Yorkshire building society chief yesterday dared to suggest that the present craze for net-based banking products would wane.
fields.body:
As banks and other financial services companies rush to launch stand-alone internet operations one plain-speaking Yorkshire building society chief yesterday dared to suggest that the present craze for net-based banking products would wane.

David Anderson, chief executive of Yorkshire building society, said the organisation had decided against going down the separately branded online business route, and said that many of the banking-related internet offerings flooding on to the market would turn out to be "relatively short-lived".

The UK's fourth largest society is not complacent about the challenges posed by the new technology: yesterday it announced the creation of 200 new jobs over the next 12 months to support an expansion of e-commerce activities.

But Mr Anderson said it wanted to use the net as another distribution channel for its existing products, rather than launching an online range.

Mr Anderson said the Yorkshire believed the internet would be important in the future but the society would not sacrifice its face-to-face contact or its branch network.

"You have to be there, but it is actually about delivering long-term value and not short-term, loss-leading products. There is no long-term value in some of the internet offers - the pricing isn't sustainable."

Yorkshire's rivals have all rushed to launch net operations. Mr Anderson poured scorn on his competitors, saying: "The falling share price has created the pressure on everyone to try and demonstrate they can be a dot.com stock, as it were.

"We don't have to bolster our share price and so we don't have to be seen to be an internet bank. This fashion for internet-based products will wane." The Bradford-based building society has a website but is not interactive. As part of its e-commerce expansion it said it would be building this up to allow online application for mortgages and other products by the end of the year.

Announcing its 1999 results, the society said that by cutting its pre-tax profits by 15%, from £68.6m to £58.3m, it was able to hand back about £90m to members in the form of higher savings rates and lower mortgage costs.

The building society's membership grew by almost 300,000 - the biggest increase in its history - despite the fact that for almost two years it has forced new savers to sign away to charity the right to any future windfalls.

webTitle: Interactive hits the market with a bang

fields.headline: Interactive hits the market with a bang
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Sony)
Freeserve)
fields.trailText: Interactive Investor International, a personal finance website, soared in value to £550m on its stock market debut yesterday - even though it had sales last year of just £2.6m and made a loss of £6.3m.
fields.body:
Interactive Investor International, a personal finance website, soared in value to £550m on its stock market debut yesterday - even though it had sales last year of just £2.6m and made a loss of £6.3m.

Shares in the company began trading at 150p and finished the day at 335p, earning its 35-year-old founder and 15% shareholder Sherry Coutu a paper fortune of nearly £100m. But scooping the jackpot is Hollinger Telegraph New Media, a sister company of the Telegraph newspaper, whose £5m investment 15 months ago (topped up by loans last year) is now worth £156m.

The share offer was 26 times oversubscribed, with 82,000 small investors - a record for a UK internet float - applying for shares. But yesterday they bombarded the firm's chat rooms and bulletin boards with angry emails after allocations were scaled back to a flat 145 shares. By the end of yesterday's trading each parcel of shares was worth £485.75, a profit of just £268.25. For the 240 investors who applied for £50,000 or more worth of shares the news was even worse - they will not receive any stake and their cheques will be returned to them.

Many had expected windfalls of £1,000-£2,000 from the float. Small investors were particularly furious that 80% of the shares were set aside for institutional investors, even though the vast majority of applicants were the firm's own customers, who use the site to swap tips and information on hi-tech shares. Many threat ened to quit the site and switch to the firm's main rivals, Hemscott and Motley Fool.

But Interactive Investor's chief executive, Tom Carruthers, said the proportion of shares set aside for retail investors was higher than in other net flotations. "We believe this [20% allocation] is entirely appropriate and reinforces our ongoing commitment to our users. In addition, we believe this proportion is significantly higher than in previous internet IPOs in the UK."

Interactive Investor has 389,000 registered users for its service, which allows individuals to identify, compare and monitor financial products. Around half of its £2.6m revenues last year came from advertising and fees from product providers who obtain customers through the site. The other half came from consultancy fees from designing and building an online capability for other financial services providers.

"The market is valuing the company appropriately considering that we have the largest number of users and the longest running personal finance website in the UK," said Mr Carruthers, who holds a 3% stake in the company through option schemes.

webTitle: Blunt warning from Greenspan on booming demand

fields.headline: Blunt warning from Greenspan on booming demand
fields.trailText: US Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan yesterday delivered an uncharacteristically blunt warning that American interest rates may need to rise "substantially" in order to contain booming demand.
fields.body:
US Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan yesterday delivered an uncharacteristically blunt warning that American interest rates may need to rise "substantially" in order to contain booming demand.

In an address to Congress, he implied the task of slowing the economy was becoming urgent; otherwise huge imbalances could derail record-breaking expansion. "The federal open market committee will have to stay alert for signs that real interest rates have not yet risen enough to bring the growth of demand into line with that of potential supply - even should the acceleration in productivity continue," Mr Greenspan told the banking committee of the House of Representatives.

His comments pulled the rug from under the bond market and the Dow Jones industrial average, which had been rising on the back of benign industrial inflation figures earlier in the day.

But the Nasdaq composite index smashed through the 4,500 barrier for the first time on the assumption that technology stocks are generally immune to interest rate rises.

The tech-weighted index was trading up 97 points, or 2.20%, at 4,525 in early after noon trading. Mr Greenspan said he expected lots of volatility in hi-tech stocks.

American interest rates have already risen four times since June last year, and few economists believed that they had peaked at 5.75%. But Mr Greenspan's comments were more hawkish than expected.

David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G Lanston in New York, said they implied the key federal fund's lending rate would increase twice more this year, each time by a 0.25%.

Among the imbalances identified in the US economy are a yawning trade deficit, heading towards 4% of output, an overvalued stock market and high levels of consumer debt.

The US labour department reported that its producer price index was unchanged in January and that the core PPI - without more volatile food and energy - fell by 0.2%. Wall Street will look to the consumer price index today for another indication of inflationary pressures in the American economy.

"There is no question that the PPI was good," said Thomas Galvin, investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette. "Greenspan seems to have wanted to take the punch bowl away from the party. That ... obviously reduced enthusiasm after the PPI report."

In an address to Congress, he implied the task of slowing the economy was becoming urgent; otherwise huge imbalances could derail record-breaking expansion. "The federal open market committee will have to stay alert for signs that real interest rates have not yet risen enough to bring the growth of demand into line with that of potential supply - even should the acceleration in productivity continue," Mr Greenspan told the banking committee of the House of Representatives. His comments pulled the rug from under the bond market and the Dow Jones industrial average, which had been rising on the back of benign industrial inflation figures earlier in the day. But the Nasdaq composite index smashed through the 4,500 barrier for the first time on the assumption that technology stocks are generally immune to interest rate rises. The tech-weighted index was trading up 97 points, or 2.20%, at 4,525 in early after noon trading. Mr Greenspan said he expected lots of volatility in hi-tech stocks. American interest rates have already risen four times since June last year, and few economists believed that they had peaked at 5.75%. But Mr Greenspan's comments were more hawkish than expected. David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G Lanston in New York, said they implied the key federal fund's lending rate would increase twice more this year, each time by a 0.25%. Among the imbalances identified in the US economy are a yawning trade deficit, heading towards 4% of output, an overvalued stock market and high levels of consumer debt. The US labour department reported that its producer price index was unchanged in January and that the core PPI - without more volatile food and energy - fell by 0.2%. Wall Street will look to the consumer price index today for another indication of inflationary pressures in the American economy. "There is no question that the PPI was good," said Thomas Galvin, investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette. "Greenspan seems to have wanted to take the punch bowl away from the party. That ... obviously reduced enthusiasm after the PPI report."

webTitle: Time to move on, says Macpherson

fields.headline: Time to move on, says Macpherson
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Lawrence: special report
Race issues in the UK: special report Macpherson one year onLawrence report author hopes corner is turned, despite rightwing backlash
fields.trailText: Perhaps it is not surprising that Sir William Macpherson of Cluny, 27th chief of his clan and a former member of the SAS, is fond of military analysis. He does not want to say anything "too incendiary" for fear of whipping up unnecessary controversy. But he is obviously fed up with the "sniping".
fields.body:
Perhaps it is not surprising that Sir William Macpherson of Cluny, 27th chief of his clan and a former member of the SAS, is fond of military analysis. He does not want to say anything "too incendiary" for fear of whipping up unnecessary controversy. But he is obviously fed up with the "sniping".

Sir William has kept his own counsel at his 15th century home, Newton Castle, since the publication of his seminal report into the Stephen Lawrence murder inquiry almost 12 months ago.

He has chosen next week's anniversary to make what will be his final pronouncement on the inquiry, his rightwing critics and his hopes for the way race relations will develop in the future.

While most of what he says is measured and he insists he is happy with the "generous acceptance" of his report in most quarters, certain issues have irritated him beyond constraint.

He says senior officers in the Metropolitan police must stop talking about the "grieving process" that officers have gone through over the past year. "The Lawrences grieve and they will never stop grieving because they lost their son. A police force doesn't grieve. The police have taken a blow, they've got to get over it. Putting it in military terms, if a regiment has been castigated for getting something wrong, what sort of set up would it be if a year later they were still complaining against conclusions properly made against them? They have to get on with it. I would like to hear someone say, 'that's all behind us now. Let's get cracking together'.

"I would like to think that's the way I would have dealt with it if I was in charge. It makes me sound like an old fossil but perhaps I am."

Stop and search is another vexing issue. He says it is "an absurd over-simplification" to link a fall in stop and searches with the rise in street crime. And he has no truck with those in the media and the police who blame his report for causing officers to use the tool more carefully.

One Daily Telegraph writer recently said Sir William, who will be 75 later this year, had "blood on his hands" because the police did not dare stop and search for fear of being branded racist.

"We pointed out the discriminatory nature of stop and search. It's up to the police to look at it and get it right. Were we to say nothing about it or to ignore the problem that exists and the unrest in the black community? If the police are holding off because they are afraid of being called racist that is not the fault of the re port. The report didn't cause the problem, it highlighted the problem.

"The sooner they act properly and do their stop and searches properly the better. It rankles with me that I am being made responsible for the police stopping doing their job properly."

Sir William says he is "surprised, disappointed and momentarily angered" by the rightwing backlash to his report. He knows he could have sued the Daily Telegraph for that article ("without any question at all"), but does not want to be drawn into a game of what he calls "insult tennis".

Sir William stands by all 70 of his recommendations but wishes he had expanded on three of the most contentious; a review of the law regarding double jeopardy, which could open up the possibility of suspects being tried for a second time if compelling fresh evidence emerged; consideration that the use of racist language and the possession of offensive weapons at home could be prosecuted; the inquiry's definition of a racist incident as any "which is perceived to be racist by the victim or any other person".

The first two could only apply in exceptional cases, he said. The idea he was advocating 'big brother' policing of dinner party conversations was ridiculous. "Maybe we didn't spell it out enough. The review of double jeopardy is not a zany proposal. It was not plucked from the top of my head. It was positively suggested by lawyers involved in the case [Imran Khan and Michael Mansfield]."

He said the video footage which showed some of the Lawrence murder suspects swearing and boasting of attacking black people had been shocking.

"That sort of mix of violence and racism combined - it should be possible to do something about it." He remembered that detectives found a claw hammer head attached to a dog's lead at the home of one of the suspects, David Norris.

"That is an offensive weapon. What else could it be used for? I didn't expect that these recommendations would be picked up and pilloried. They were based on the evidence we heard. Anyone who had been there and paid proper attention to the evidence would have sympathy for the recommendation to be made."

Sir William admitted he has only been keeping a cursory eye on progress made to implement the inquiry findings. He had had enough and wanted to return to retirement.

He firmly believes the report remains a blueprint for the future and that the Metropolitan police and the home office are forging ahead.

"There is good reason to look forward with optimism and I do."

He describes Sir Paul Condon, the former commissioner, as a "courageous and dedicated man", and has faith in his successor, Sir John Stevens.

The danger he believes may be that other institutions - the media, industry and business - are not looking hard enough at themselves to identify overt or unwitting racism.

He now intends to enjoy continuing his retirement with his wife Sheila, playing golf and not feeling like a sitting target.

"I will not say another word after the anniversary. I did my best to reach honourable conclusions. I have been surprised and disappointed that I have been attacked personally, but it is water off a duck's back.

"It's time to take things on. I hope the corner has been turned."

webTitle: Stop whining, Lawrence judge tells Met

fields.headline: Stop whining, Lawrence judge tells Met
fields.standfirst: Macpherson rounds on critics and urges police to change societyStephen Lawrence: special reportRace issues in the UK: special report Macpherson one year on
fields.trailText: Sir William Macpherson, the judge who conducted the inquiry into the bungled Stephen Lawrence murder investigation, said yesterday it was time for the police and his rightwing critics to stop "whining and complaining" about the findings of his report and forge ahead to change society.
fields.body:
Sir William Macpherson, the judge who conducted the inquiry into the bungled Stephen Lawrence murder investigation, said yesterday it was time for the police and his rightwing critics to stop "whining and complaining" about the findings of his report and forge ahead to change society.

In an interview with the Guardian to mark next week's anniversary of the inquiry's publication, Sir William, 74, said talk of a grieving process - often used by the former commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, Sir Paul Condon to explain a lack of morale in the force - had to stop.

"The Lawrences grieve and they will never stop grieving because they lost their son. A police force doesn't grieve. The police have been castigated. They have taken a blow, they've got to get over it. They've got to get on with it." Although he praised the Met and the home office for accepting the report's 70 recommendations, he said he had been disappointed and surprised by the personal attacks on him launched by the rightwing media, and seemed frustrated he had been blamed for the surge in street crime which coincided with a drop in the number of stop-and-searches last year.

"We pointed out the discriminatory nature of stop-and-search. It's up to the police to look at it and get it right. The report didn't cause the problem. It highlighted the problem. Were we to ignore the facts and figures?"

He said he had received hate mail at his castle home in Perthshire following the publication of the report last February, but the "revolting" letters and the "beastly" carping from some commentators had not affected him.

"I am not going to whinge. I stand by every word of the report.

"I stand by every recommendation. They were all based on the evidence that was presented to the inquiry."

Sir William's comments provoked a waspish response from the Metropolitan Police Federation, which represents rank-and-file officers.

Its chairman Glen Smyth said Sir William should recognise that many officers had suffered appallingly since Stephen Lawrence's murder. "He should get in touch with me and I'll introduce him to some of the officers who had nervous breakdowns. These men have been through a lot. Many, many positive things have come out of the Macpherson inquiry but it was not a perfect report and what he says is not always right. I wish he would accept that."

Mr Smyth said the former high court judge was "an upper class person from a privileged background who had never been a police officer and who had no idea what it was like to conduct a murder inquiry."

He added: "He only sees things from one side. His intransigence diminished the good that can be done. There have been so many losers and so few winners out of all of this."

Sir William said he was confident that there was a strong will among politicians and the police to push ahead with his reforms and was extremely optimistic about the future.

He admitted the inquiry had "opened his eyes" in the way that black and Asian people were treated in society. He said he had never been racist himself, overtly or unwittingly.

"I hope not. It's perfectly possible. Everyone has to guard against it."

fields.headline: England scrape basement battle
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain may have been smiling, but this wasn't funny. Set 132, England turned a cakewalk into a dog's dinner. It was one victory that certainly left a bitter taste in the mouth.
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain may have been smiling, but this wasn't funny. Set 132, England turned a cakewalk into a dog's dinner. It was one victory that certainly left a bitter taste in the mouth.

With England 120 for 5 and plenty of overs remaining, the Fat Lady had already folded away her songsheet. England, however, were singing from an entirely different one and contrived to lose four wickets for five runs, leaving Darren Gough and Alan Mullally to cobble together the remaining seven. It's a good job Mullally's temperament reacts as little to what's going on around him as his batting, otherwise England would have achieved their worst result of the winter so far - worse even than their failure to chase 150 against South Africa in the final of the triangular tournament on Sunday.

Six England players brought about their own downfall. Nick Knight and Nasser Hussain may have been unlucky with their dismissals, but Graeme Hick, Darren Maddy, Vikram Solanki (again), Craig White, Chris Read and Andy Caddick should have known better. As the required run-rate - which never touched three all innings - dropped, the panic grew. It was a masterclass in woolly thinking.

England's batting deflected attention from another controlled and incisive display with the ball. In seven of their eight completed one-dayers so far this winter, England have bowled first and limited the opposition to totals of 184, 204-7, 211-7, 161-9, 149, 194-7 and now 131. This time they had White to thank. Finding movement and bounce from just short of a length, he claimed 5-21 to record the third-best ODI figures for England and hollow out the heart of Zimbabwe's fragile batting. White is beginning to look the part as England's second-change bowler, although, at No.6, he is still at least one place too high in the batting order.

England's record against Zimbabwe now reads won five, lost six. So with two games in this strangely low-key series to go, England can overtake them by next Wednesday. But it's hard to get too excited: on the evidence so far, and ignoring Kenya and Bangladesh for the moment, this really is a battle at the basement of the one-day league.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: IRA suspect killed lawfully, inquest rules

fields.headline: IRA suspect killed lawfully, inquest rules
fields.trailText: A suspected IRA terrorist shot dead during a police raid in West London was killed lawfully, an inquest jury ruled today.
fields.body:
A suspected IRA terrorist shot dead during a police raid in West London was killed lawfully, an inquest jury ruled today.

Diarmuid O'Neill, 27, was shot six times after armed police burst into his Hammersmith hotel room in September 1996.

The attack was the culmination of a three month surveillance operation that linked suspected IRA quartermaster O'Neill to six tons of explosives found in London.

Officers targeted O'Neill and his accomplices after a series of explosions in London and Manchester. Police feared the terrorist cell was preparing to detonate a huge lorry bomb somewhere in central London.

In a briefing before the raid, officers watched a video of the Docklands bombing and heard a recording of an IRA suspect vowing to shoot officers who tried to arrest him.

The conversations between O'Neill and Patrick Kelly were recorded after a bugging device was hidden in O'Neill's car.

Michael Mansfield QC, representing the victim's family, told the jury that police had made a "catalogue of errors" during its raid. The police had intended to use a skeleton key to get in to room 303 of the Glenthorne Road Hotel, but when it didn't work they were forced to use a battering ram. The ram did not open the door but punched hole in the middle, through which the police fired 10 rounds of CS gas. Many of the police officers were not wearing masks which led to scenes of chaos.

The officer who fired the shot which killed O'Neill told the jury he believed his life had been in danger. Officer Kilo told the jury that he had pushed open the door he had seen a figure in front of him. He admitted his vision had been badly affected by the CS, but said he had no choice but to shoot after the suspect failed to show his hands.

Officer Kilo had told the hearing: "His body language suggested he was holding a weapon. He was bristling. This was a man who was going to kill me."

O'Neill, who was dressed only in his underpants, died in the room where no weapons were found. Speaking afterwards, O'Neill's father Eoghan said he was "disappointed" with the verdict and was considering an appeal.

He said: " The police were deaf, blind and dumb. They should never have gone in there with the gas. My son would still be alive if they had not gone in with CS gas."

He continued: "The coroner asked before the inquest but was refused, that a public inquiry be ordered by the home secretary as the issues raised were so difficult and important."

"Now that this inquest has finished," he said, "we suggest that a different form of public inquiry be held which can investigate all recent fatal shootings by armed police in order to ensure that lessons are learned, whether or not the police voluntarily agree."
