webTitle: Threat to shut down Sellafield N-plant

fields.headline: Threat to shut down Sellafield N-plant
fields.standfirst: Safety inspectorate finds build-up of dangerous liquid waste
fields.trailText: A government safety inspectorate is threatening to shut the largest nuclear facility in the country, at Sellafield, if the state-owned company does not clear a backlog of dangerous high level nuclear waste.
fields.body:
A government safety inspectorate is threatening to shut the largest nuclear facility in the country, at Sellafield, if the state-owned company does not clear a backlog of dangerous high level nuclear waste.

In one of three damning reports on the British Nuclear Fuels plant in Cumbria due to be published today, the nuclear installations inspectorate will say it is not satisfied with progress on clearing the backlog, despite repeated warnings to the company.

The three reports question the lack of a safety culture in BNFL: on the backlog of high level waste; an increase in safety related incidents in 1999 which led to a full scale audit of operations; and the falsification of data on fuel dispatched to Japan on armed ships.

Ministers are incensed by the political embarrassment caused by the falsification of plutonium data, which led the Japanese government to demand that mixed uranium and plutonium fuel delivered to its utilities should be returned to Britain.

BNFL repeatedly denied that the data had been falsified, but an investigation by the nuclear chief inspector, Laurence Williams, shows that falsification was widespread, and blames the management culture. The jobs of John Taylor, BNFL chief executive, and that of Chris Loughlin, the board member responsible for the mixed fuel, are both said to be in jeopardy.

Ministers had hopes of raising £1.5bn by selling 49% of BNFL before the election, but seem to have dropped the plan because of the inspectorate's criticism. Reprocessing is profitable for the company, but produces large quantities of liquid waste; the inspectorate threatens to stop the work if rapid progress is not made towards an original target of clearing the backlog of all high level waste by 2015.

For more than 40 years high level liquid waste has been stored in tanks at the Sellafield plant under constant cooling. In 1990 a plant was built to convert 1,300 cubic metres of the waste in 21 tanks into 8,000 glass blocks - though these will still have to be cooled for a further 50 years before being safe to dispose of.

The plant, costing £240m, failed to function correctly, and in the first two years output was limited to 110 containers a year from two production lines. Modifications improved the plant to 300 containers a year, but it was still not enough to clear the backlog, and there have been further problems since.

There has been political pressure from the Irish government to catch up because it fears its population could be caught in the fall-out if the tanks burst or explode, as happened in a Russian reprocessing plant. Papers released to the Guardian under the Irish freedom of information act show that, to deal with the backlog, a third production line was ordered at a cost of a further £300m and should be completed this year.

The problem for BNFL is that the amount of high level liquid waste continues to increase faster than it can deal with it. In 1993 the second £1.8bn reprocessing plant, called Thorp, started producing yet more waste. It is this plant that the inspectorate has threatened with legal sanctions if the backlog is not cleared.

The papers reveal that Ireland is so sensitive about this subject that the issue was raised with Tony Blair by the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, at a meeting in Dublin in November 1998, and followed up with meetings between Joe Jacob, the Irish minister of state, and Michael Meacher, the environment minister. The Irish government's position was that not just a third but a fourth vitrification plant should be built.

The inspectorate report due today states that on both safety and political grounds the continuing backlog is unacceptable.

In a statement yesterday BNFL said it could not comment on the report in detail. but it had safely stored highly active liquids at Sellafield for 40 years. There had been operating difficulties which the company had spent significant time and money to resolve. The company was confident it would achieve the target of reducing this waste to "buffer levels" by 2015.
fields.bodyText: A government safety inspectorate is threatening to shut the largest nuclear facility in the country, at Sellafield, if the state-owned company does not clear a backlog of dangerous high level nuclear waste. In one of three damning reports on the British Nuclear Fuels plant in Cumbria due to be published today, the nuclear installations inspectorate will say it is not satisfied with progress on clearing the backlog, despite repeated warnings to the company. The three reports question the lack of a safety culture in BNFL: on the backlog of high level waste; an increase in safety related incidents in 1999 which led to a full scale audit of operations; and the falsification of data on fuel dispatched to Japan on armed ships. Ministers are incensed by the political embarrassment caused by the falsification of plutonium data, which led the Japanese government to demand that mixed uranium and plutonium fuel delivered to its utilities should be returned to Britain. BNFL repeatedly denied that the data had been falsified, but an investigation by the nuclear chief inspector, Laurence Williams, shows that falsification was widespread, and blames the management culture. The jobs of John Taylor, BNFL chief executive, and that of Chris Loughlin, the board member responsible for the mixed fuel, are both said to be in jeopardy. Ministers had hopes of raising £1.5bn by selling 49% of BNFL before the election, but seem to have dropped the plan because of the inspectorate's criticism. Reprocessing is profitable for the company, but produces large quantities of liquid waste; the inspectorate threatens to stop the work if rapid progress is not made towards an original target of clearing the backlog of all high level waste by 2015. For more than 40 years high level liquid waste has been stored in tanks at the Sellafield plant under constant cooling. In 1990 a plant was built to convert 1,300 cubic metres of the waste in 21 tanks into 8,000 glass blocks - though these will still have to be cooled for a further 50 years before being safe to dispose of. The plant, costing £240m, failed to function correctly, and in the first two years output was limited to 110 containers a year from two production lines. Modifications improved the plant to 300 containers a year, but it was still not enough to clear the backlog, and there have been further problems since. There has been political pressure from the Irish government to catch up because it fears its population could be caught in the fall-out if the tanks burst or explode, as happened in a Russian reprocessing plant. Papers released to the Guardian under the Irish freedom of information act show that, to deal with the backlog, a third production line was ordered at a cost of a further £300m and should be completed this year. The problem for BNFL is that the amount of high level liquid waste continues to increase faster than it can deal with it. In 1993 the second £1.8bn reprocessing plant, called Thorp, started producing yet more waste. It is this plant that the inspectorate has threatened with legal sanctions if the backlog is not cleared. The papers reveal that Ireland is so sensitive about this subject that the issue was raised with Tony Blair by the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, at a meeting in Dublin in November 1998, and followed up with meetings between Joe Jacob, the Irish minister of state, and Michael Meacher, the environment minister. The Irish government's position was that not just a third but a fourth vitrification plant should be built. The inspectorate report due today states that on both safety and political grounds the continuing backlog is unacceptable. In a statement yesterday BNFL said it could not comment on the report in detail. but it had safely stored highly active liquids at Sellafield for 40 years. There had been operating difficulties which the company had spent significant time and money to resolve. The company was confident it would achieve the target of reducing this waste to "buffer levels" by 2015.

webTitle: Beyond the Fringe, Private Eye and Not Only... But Also

fields.headline: Beyond the Fringe, Private Eye and Not Only... But Also
fields.trailText: AN OLD STORY
fields.body:
AN OLD STORY

"Help the aged, please don't put them in a home!" sang floppy-haired pop fop Jarvis Cocker from The Pulp. That's at least one person who'll be happy with the news that Newcastle United have given Bobby Robson, 67 today, a 12-month rolling contract with no expiry date. Although approximately 36,834 regulars at St James Park may be quite pleased as well.

The generous contract rewards the Bobster for turning Newcastle from an inept laughing stock rooted to the bottom of the league into one of the sexiest outfits in the Premiership - no mean feat with a team that includes Duncan Ferguson and Nobby Solano. Newcastle's board issued a statement which explained how Bob has earned his reward - they're "delighted with what Bobby has achieved in such a short period".

Gentlemanly words indeed. Until you read on. "We look forward to working with him to bring us the success that the Newcastle supporters deserve," they continue, in the most blatant example of bandwagon jumping the Fiver has seen for years. Do you think they're after some of Bob's credit just in case the Toon win the FA Cup? Howay, the very thought!

WHERE ARE YOUR MANNERS?

Some poor bloke is having to haul himself out of bed on Sunday morning just to provide you with live minute-by-minute coverage of Leeds v Manchester United. He'll probably have a hangover as well. So the least you can do is follow every kick at http://www.footballunlimited.co.uk.

GET CELESTINE

Chelsea still haven't found Celestine Babayaro, who has gone AWOL since Nigeria were defeated by Cameroon in the final of the African Nations Cup. The Chelse have given his London pad a bell - no answer - and faxed the Nigerian FA in Lagos - no dice. So where is he?

James Sanders thinks he might know his whereabouts: "Celesline - as he calls himself, on account of not being able to cross a T, let alone a ball - is being kept away from Stamford Bridge by a group of deeply satisfied Chelsea supporters. Satisfied that is, with young Jon Harley."

Rick doesn't agree. He thinks Stan Collymore may be the root of the problem, as he reckons Babs was last spotted in La Manga. By Rick's account, Celestine is "now encased, mummy-like, in fire extinguisher foam".

And the improbably named Matthew Cock adds a bit of bull when he explains that, "During one of his celebratory back-flips, Celestine momentarily escaped the earth's gravitational pull." It's unlikely, but thanks for that, Mr Cock.

Other places Fiver readers have spotted Babayaro are: Manly beach in Sydney, Bangor High Street, the Duck & Ferret, the Vatican, the Tesco cafe in Cambridge, the Andes, Goldigger's Nightclub in Cheltenham and "down the back of the sofa". Rather spookily, if you plot all these places on a map of the world and join the dots up, you get a picture of Ken Bates. The mystery deepens...

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I haven't had a good Saturday night since we beat Tottenham in December. When you win, you know you can go out and enjoy yourself. I haven't been going out on Saturday nights." - Poor Bryan Robson, who must be gasping for a Middlesbrough victory.

KEEP UP WITH THE CUP

This week's biggest game is in the Premiership. But seeing as Manchester United ignored the FA Cup, we're going to ignore them. So quarter-final weekend it is. Mind you, come Sunday morning, we'll be tuned in to events at Elland Road like everyone else - but don't tell anyone or we'll sound like hypocrites.

Bolton v Charlton (Saturday) Bolton's Ricardo Gardner and Mark Fish are back from international duty, and Mike Whitlow and Dean Holden return from suspension. Mark Kinsella is back for Charlton, which should make up for the enforced absence of recent signing Mathias Svensson, who is cup-tied. This match guarantees a Nationwide presence in the semi-finals, so please note how we have treated the tie with the gravitas it warrants. [Nice excuse - Fiver ed.]

Chelsea v Gillingham (Sunday) Seeing that Celestine Babayaro is gadding around somewhere, Jon Harley continues to deputise. He may be the only defender in Chelsea's team, as Frank Leboeuf is suspended, Emerson Thome is cup-tied and Graeme Le Saux, Jes Hogh and Albert Ferrer are all knackered. Hilarity awaits! Meanwhile, Gills striker Carl Asaba may be on the bench after a long-term hernia injury, while Adrian Pennock and Mark Saunders are expected to ignore slight knocks just so they can be patronised by pundits and papers alike.

Everton v Aston Villa (Sunday) Enckelman. He sounds a pan-European long-haired lounge singer from the Sixties. But he's not. He's a Finnish Under-21 international goalkeeper called Peter, and he may replace Villa's hapless flapper David James, who has a thigh strain. Meanwhile, Gustavo Bartelt, on loan from Roma, may make his first start in a Villa shirt. The home side welcome back David Unsworth - well someone has to be glad to see him.

Tranmere v Newcastle (Sunday) Talented young Irishman Alan Mahon may not make the game after picking up a bit of ankle-knack against Wolves. David Kelly, Graham Allen, Gary Jones and Gareth Roberts all return, but Clint Hill, Steve Yates and Wayne Allison are missing for one reason or another - injuries, being cup-tied, you know the sort of thing. Shock news for the Toon - Duncan Ferguson is injured!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Everton are interested in Numancia midfielder Txomin Nagore, according to Opta Soccer. However, Nagore is likely to rejoin Numancia's parent club, Athletic Bilbao.

Newcastle are interested in Lens midfielder Olivier Dacourt.

Southampton are now favourites to sign Rangers defender Colin Hendry.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Four members of the Newcastle youth academy have been involved in a serious car crash. Kevin Wealleans, 18, is critically ill with serious internal injuries after the car he was driving hit another vehicle after crossing the central reservation on the A189 near Cramlington, Northumberland. Ryan Hogg, 17, and Paul Dunn, 17, were also admitted to hospital in Ashington but were described as being in a stable condition. A fourth player, Jonathan Mann, 17, was released from hospital after being treated for minor head wounds.

Dundee United manager Paul Sturrock today confirmed he is staying at Tannadice. Sturrock hinted he was thinking of resigning after the CIS Cup semi-final defeat by Aberdeen but has changed his mind. He said: "On Sunday I was ready to go. But I feel we have committed ourselves to young players and others and it would be unfair to walk out on them and the fans who have been supportive."

Jorge Cadete has said goodbye to his Benfica team-mates and will fly in to complete his switch to Bradford early next week.

Chelsea, West Ham, Aston Villa and Middlesbrough have all put their names down as prospective entrants for this summer's Intertoto Cup.

Lou Macari has brought a wrongful dismissal claim against Stoke nearly three years after his resignation. Stoke are "vigorously defending" the claim.

The German Soccer Federation has announced that the World Cup 2002 qualifier between Germany and England on September 1 2001 will be played in Munich's Olympic Stadium.

Argentina squad to face England: Goalkeepers: German Burgos (Real Mallorca), Pablo Cavallero (Espanyol). Defenders: Roberto Sensini (Lazio), Roberto Ayala (Milan), Jose Chamot (AC Milan), Javier Zanetti (Inter Milan), Mauricio Pochettino (Espanol), Rodolfo Arruabarrena (Boca Juniors), Nelson Vivas (Celta Vigo). Midfielders: Ariel Ortega (Parma), Cristian Gonzalez (Valencia), Gustavo Lopez (Celta Vigo), Juan Sebastian Veron (Lazio), Diego Simeone (Lazio), Claudio Husain (Velez Sarsfield). Strikers: Claudio Lopez (Valencia), Gabriel Batistuta (Fiorentina), Hernan Crespo (Parma).

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Friday Night's All Wright (10.30pm)

Thank God this is only on once a week.

Friday Night's All Wright (11.30pm)

Aaaaarrrrrrrrgggggghhhhhhhhhh!!!!!!!!!!

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)

A programme which, if it was religious, knows only one god.

Sky Sports 2: Friday Night Football (7pm, 12midnight, 4.30am)

Huddersfield v Manchester City. Half time entertainment: Joe Royle reads from the collected works of Andrea Dworkin.

Hold The Back Page (11pm, 3am SS1)

Four journalists in a room. They realise there are no canapes. They argue.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Sport (7pm)

"This gantry is so warm! The view is so spectacular! The football is so skilful!" After years of commentating, the cold finally went to Alan's head.

fields.headline: The best flu scene
fields.standfirst: Topsy-Turvy
fields.trailText: The opening night of Princess Ida, Gilbert and Sullivan's latest comic opera. Bed-ridden with influenza, his face flushed and swathed in scarves, Sir Arthur Sullivan (Allan Corduner) sits bolt upright, ringing a small bell with all the strength his virus-wracked body can muster. As he struggles to his feet, his butler Louis (Dexter Fletcher) rushes in.
fields.body:
The opening night of Princess Ida, Gilbert and Sullivan's latest comic opera. Bed-ridden with influenza, his face flushed and swathed in scarves, Sir Arthur Sullivan (Allan Corduner) sits bolt upright, ringing a small bell with all the strength his virus-wracked body can muster. As he struggles to his feet, his butler Louis (Dexter Fletcher) rushes in.

"Sir Arthur, what are you doing?" he exclaims. "You must get back into bed!"

"No, Louis," splutters Sullivan, "it is not possible."

Louis attempts to steer his master back to bed.

"LOUIS!"

Cut to Louis, downstairs in the kitchen of the house. He turns to a maid.

"Hot coffee please, very strong."

Cut to Sullivan in his dining room, still swaddled but now in a chair and sipping coffee. Then to the composer struggling down his hallway, half-dressed and with a look of fierce intent on his face. Then cut once more to Sullivan in obvious discomfort, his nose and eyes growing redder by the second, seated in a horse-drawn carriage. Eventually it pulls up outside the Savoy Theatre. Inside, the staff look on in shock as Sullivan enters; someone hands him a drink.

"Thank you."

Just as the orchestra are poised to strike up, Sullivan appears before them, baton in hand. The crowd erupt in wild applause.

See also: The Princess Bride, The Taking of Pelham 1-2-3, They Go Boom

Don't see also: Doctor In Love

Pointless trivia: Allan Corduner starred as First Class Steward Henry Etches in the Broadway run of Titanic: The Musical

fields.headline: London thrills me
fields.standfirst: Think Milan is where all the hottest style trends start? Think again. Fashion editor  Laura Craik  pays tribute to the diverse talent on display at London Fashion Week
fields.trailText: Think Milan is where all the hottest style trends start? Think again. Fashion editor Laura Craik pays tribute to the diverse talent on display at London Fashion Week.
fields.body:
"How did you become a fashion editor?" is a question I am asked more than is seemly. What they really mean is: what on God's earth qualifies me to comment on clothes and suggest what people should wear? Good dress sense? A keen eye? An art school education? A way with words? A brass neck? I don't know. Maybe I should have been a teacher.

All fashion folk are scared of being divulged as frauds and never more so than during London Fashion Week. London throws up so much diverse talent, with such enthusiasm, that it's easy to get carried away and start proclaiming a sow's ear is a silk purse. This is why you hear loud and purposeful remarks such as: "I hated them last season but I love them now." Or: "Truly cerebral, though the Prada referencing was a bit heavy." Everyone tries to convince everyone else they know what they're talking about.

It was an exciting season, or "vintage London", as one buyer remarked. We laughed, we cried, we clapped tremendously. Hurrah! The British Fashion Council had invited some lesser-known designers on to the official schedule and the five days were all the more lively for this. Boudicca's folded, draped, military-inspired vision came to Kensington's West Lawn tent for the first time, proving that the avant-garde doesn't turn into a pumpkin when it leaves EC1. Round the corner in a scout hall was Dai Rees, who showed neutral heavy knits with outsize cable details, stiff tweed skirts with embossed panels and dramatic leather millinery.

A short taxi ride away was Marcus Constable, who put out an incredibly slick collection, given that this was his first show. The invitations were library tickets, the inspiration sexually frustrated librarians. Long-haired models in knee-length boots, bottle-green culottes and buttoned-up blouses sashayed down the carpet. Long pleated belts made from fake hair were an imaginative touch.

"Daddy, who were The Clash?" said the ticket to Luella's show, setting the scene far better than a page-long press release about "the raw energy of the peasant folk of Bali" ever could. Luella managed something very rare indeed: she sent out a collection that was different and exciting. Black V-necks, white Aertex shirts and black pencil skirts shot through with Lurex thread looked not just mod but modern. Of course, "mod" always did mean modern, but who'd have thought a movement that started in the 60s could look so right for now? The ultra-tidy, scruffy-round-the-edges mod/punk aesthetic is the only one that hasn't been plundered recently: those who say Milan is where trends start should watch this space and see if the Italians follow Luella's lead. Maybe, in a few years' time.

Shelley Fox put on a great show: it began with four men spinning plates and ended with distressed sequin dresses in burnished copper and brown. To the heart-rending strains of Are You Lonesome Tonight, Fox had her cunning way with geometric shapes and clever detailing, in felted wool dresses, the skirts multi-layered, the bodices cascading with bunched-up petals. Brown leather coats with tie belts and narrow shoulders looked supple and sharp.

Jasper Conran and Betty Jackson are positively old-skool compared with new designers like Luella, Constable and Fox. One wonders how many of the young guns will still be around next decade. It's a tough old world. Conran had a bit of an Yves moment, with mannish pinstripe suits, stiff white shirts and black ties tucked into trouser waistbands. There was also an abundance of leather nappa: floor-sweeping white coats and black full-skirted halterneck dresses looked light and sensuous.

Jackson was also nappa-happy: red was her colour of choice for wide-sleeved leather blouson jackets with pussy bows, soft calf-length boots which wrinkled at the ankle and thick belts with heavy buckles. With a nod to the 80s, she put out iridescent halterneck dresses and tight jeans with a paint-splatter print.

Alexander McQueen went all tribal for autumn/winter: African head-dresses, thick wooden bangles and heavy astrakhan or rabbit skin combined with giant chunky knits and horsehair in a raw, vicious collection full of rich, contrasting textures. This was a lion of a show - possibly too savage at times, unless you have a penchant for long silver spikes that hold your lips back in a perpetual snarl. My favourite was a beaded dress with a swishing horsehair skirt, though it's the bumster jeans, three-quarter-length frock coats and wide-legged grey trousers that will actually make it into Harvey Nicks, more's the pity.

What's the opposite of McQueen? Clements Ribeiro. They never frighten the horses and they certainly wouldn't use horsehair. You wouldn't be arrested in CR, but you might be wolf-whistled. This season's collection had a disco feel, with fantastic glitter shoes and boots, chiffon skirts with glittery flowers stencilled on top and rainbow-striped Lurex jumpers. Camel coats with voluminous sleeves and thin tie belts provided neutral contrasts. These are designers with a great sense of colour: too much is never enough.

Like Clements Ribeiro, Tracey Boyd's show was sponsored by Top Shop. Both do lines for the mammoth high street chain: now it was payback time. Boyd's show was a mixed bag, but cherry red corduroy trenchcoats, peach Lurex sweater dresses and cord A-line skirts stood out - as did the cashmere knits. Respect to Boyd for the Top Shop link-up, which shows sound business sense. As does Elspeth Gibson, whose range of toiletries, alongside her Sweetpea range of childrenswear for Debenhams, is a clever diversification. In what was one of Gibson's more commercially risky shows, burgundy velvet pantaloons were combined with purple cashmere jumpers, while lacy tops were paired with soft tweed pencil skirts and matching fedoras.

A world apart from all of this, though, is Hussein Chalayan: a magician and a genius. He turns chairs into dresses and tables into skirts. He builds clothes like an architect builds houses, mindful of all their corners. Let's put it plainly, in cabbie-speak: "There were these four chairs, right, on this stage, and they just sat there like props throughout the show, until at the end, these four birds started unfastening the covers and putting them on. Then - I'm telling you - the chair legs and bases folded up into wooden suitcases!"

In addition to the furniture alchemy, there were stiff black suits with corrugated collars, their borders trimmed with thin white piping; beige shearling coats with mitten-shaped pockets and red bell-shaped, box-pleated corduroy skirts worn with floral-sprigged blouses which swung off the body. It was an amazing show: as complete, controlled and perfect as a Shakespearean sonnet.

I'm sorry there isn't enough room to review everyone. This week made me proud to be British. British designers - so little money, but so much style.

A brass neck? I don't know. Maybe I should have been a teacher. All fashion folk are scared of being divulged as frauds and never more so than during London Fashion Week. London throws up so much diverse talent, with such enthusiasm, that it's easy to get carried away and start proclaiming a sow's ear is a silk purse. This is why you hear loud and purposeful remarks such as: "I hated them last season but I love them now." Or: "Truly cerebral, though the Prada referencing was a bit heavy." Everyone tries to convince everyone else they know what they're talking about. It was an exciting season, or "vintage London", as one buyer remarked. We laughed, we cried, we clapped tremendously. Hurrah! The British Fashion Council had invited some lesser-known designers on to the official schedule and the five days were all the more lively for this. Boudicca's folded, draped, military-inspired vision came to Kensington's West Lawn tent for the first time, proving that the avant-garde doesn't turn into a pumpkin when it leaves EC1. Round the corner in a scout hall was Dai Rees, who showed neutral heavy knits with outsize cable details, stiff tweed skirts with embossed panels and dramatic leather millinery. A short taxi ride away was Marcus Constable, who put out an incredibly slick collection, given that this was his first show. The invitations were library tickets, the inspiration sexually frustrated librarians. Long-haired models in knee-length boots, bottle-green culottes and buttoned-up blouses sashayed down the carpet. Long pleated belts made from fake hair were an imaginative touch. "Daddy, who were The Clash?" said the ticket to Luella's show, setting the scene far better than a page-long press release about "the raw energy of the peasant folk of Bali" ever could. Luella managed something very rare indeed: she sent out a collection that was different and exciting. Black V-necks, white Aertex shirts and black pencil skirts shot through with Lurex thread looked not just mod but modern. Of course, "mod" always did mean modern, but who'd have thought a movement that started in the 60s could look so right for now? The ultra-tidy, scruffy-round-the-edges mod/punk aesthetic is the only one that hasn't been plundered recently: those who say Milan is where trends start should watch this space and see if the Italians follow Luella's lead. Maybe, in a few years' time. Shelley Fox put on a great show: it began with four men spinning plates and ended with distressed sequin dresses in burnished copper and brown. To the heart-rending strains of Are You Lonesome Tonight, Fox had her cunning way with geometric shapes and clever detailing, in felted wool dresses, the skirts multi-layered, the bodices cascading with bunched-up petals. Brown leather coats with tie belts and narrow shoulders looked supple and sharp. Jasper Conran and Betty Jackson are positively old-skool compared with new designers like Luella, Constable and Fox. One wonders how many of the young guns will still be around next decade. It's a tough old world. Conran had a bit of an Yves moment, with mannish pinstripe suits, stiff white shirts and black ties tucked into trouser waistbands. There was also an abundance of leather nappa: floor-sweeping white coats and black full-skirted halterneck dresses looked light and sensuous. Jackson was also nappa-happy: red was her colour of choice for wide-sleeved leather blouson jackets with pussy bows, soft calf-length boots which wrinkled at the ankle and thick belts with heavy buckles. With a nod to the 80s, she put out iridescent halterneck dresses and tight jeans with a paint-splatter print. Alexander McQueen went all tribal for autumn/winter: African head-dresses, thick wooden bangles and heavy astrakhan or rabbit skin combined with giant chunky knits and horsehair in a raw, vicious collection full of rich, contrasting textures. This was a lion of a show - possibly too savage at times, unless you have a penchant for long silver spikes that hold your lips back in a perpetual snarl. My favourite was a beaded dress with a swishing horsehair skirt, though it's the bumster jeans, three-quarter-length frock coats and wide-legged grey trousers that will actually make it into Harvey Nicks, more's the pity. What's the opposite of McQueen? Clements Ribeiro. They never frighten the horses and they certainly wouldn't use horsehair. You wouldn't be arrested in CR, but you might be wolf-whistled. This season's collection had a disco feel, with fantastic glitter shoes and boots, chiffon skirts with glittery flowers stencilled on top and rainbow-striped Lurex jumpers. Camel coats with voluminous sleeves and thin tie belts provided neutral contrasts. These are designers with a great sense of colour: too much is never enough. Like Clements Ribeiro, Tracey Boyd's show was sponsored by Top Shop. Both do lines for the mammoth high street chain: now it was payback time. Boyd's show was a mixed bag, but cherry red corduroy trenchcoats, peach Lurex sweater dresses and cord A-line skirts stood out - as did the cashmere knits. Respect to Boyd for the Top Shop link-up, which shows sound business sense. As does Elspeth Gibson, whose range of toiletries, alongside her Sweetpea range of childrenswear for Debenhams, is a clever diversification. In what was one of Gibson's more commercially risky shows, burgundy velvet pantaloons were combined with purple cashmere jumpers, while lacy tops were paired with soft tweed pencil skirts and matching fedoras. A world apart from all of this, though, is Hussein Chalayan: a magician and a genius. He turns chairs into dresses and tables into skirts. He builds clothes like an architect builds houses, mindful of all their corners. Let's put it plainly, in cabbie-speak: "There were these four chairs, right, on this stage, and they just sat there like props throughout the show, until at the end, these four birds started unfastening the covers and putting them on. Then - I'm telling you - the chair legs and bases folded up into wooden suitcases!" In addition to the furniture alchemy, there were stiff black suits with corrugated collars, their borders trimmed with thin white piping; beige shearling coats with mitten-shaped pockets and red bell-shaped, box-pleated corduroy skirts worn with floral-sprigged blouses which swung off the body. It was an amazing show: as complete, controlled and perfect as a Shakespearean sonnet. I'm sorry there isn't enough room to review everyone. This week made me proud to be British. British designers - so little money, but so much style.

fields.headline: Here's looking at you, kids
fields.standfirst: It's show time and they're right there in the front row, inches from the models, noting down every detail of the designers' newest inventions ... but what are they wearing?  Jess Cartner-Morley watches the watchers
fields.trailText: It's show time and they're right there in the front row, inches from the models, noting down every detail of the designers' newest inventions ... but what are they wearing?
fields.body:
It looks like an easy life, doesn't it? But consider: how do you dress for the most important week of the season, in an industry in which the phrase "It's what's on the inside that counts" refers to whether the sushi roll canapés are salmon or vegetarian? You think it doesn't matter what you wear during London Fashion Week? How wrong can you be: in the eyes of the fashion crowd, darling, it's all that matters.

But fashion folk are not always as easy to identify as you might imagine. The hardcore fashionistas, who wear sunglasses at night and airkiss taxi drivers, might stand out a mile, but there are legions of others who, to the untrained eye, look perfectly normal . This is partly because of the quirkiness of London fashion. In New York, the sleek, groomed, matching-logoed fashion crowd are fairly homogenous, but the London pack is more diverse, the tribal markings more obscure.

You see, it's not a simple matter of looking fashionable. There are other factors at play here, the first of which is Seasonal Confusion. To most people, it's late winter, or possibly early spring, depending on whether your glass is half empty or half full. But in fashion terms, there are three seasons jostling for wardrobe space. There's the season the real world is still in, but for which the shows took place a year ago (autumn/winter 1999/2000) - Ali McGraw, hippy chic and ponyskin. There's the season that's just beginning, but for which the shows took place six months ago (spring/summer 2000) - hotpants, pussycat bows and snakeskin. And there's the season at which the clothes now on the catwalks are aimed (autumn/winter 2000/2001) - which looks set to be about leather, fur, sexy boots and looking grown-up. Put the three together and you can see why fashion folk often end up looking odd (not to mention inappropriately dressed for the weather).

The second factor to throw a spanner in the works is old-fashioned vanity. Total absence of this is rare and in the fashion world is the mark of the true obsessive: those who will wear the ugliest clothes (bloomers, clogs, that kind of thing) just because they were on the catwalk. But most fashion addicts care at least as much about looking good as looking fashionable, and are well aware that the two are not the same at all. This is why some trends just don't catch on - note the general unwillingness to swap last season's delicious spindly heels for the stack-heeled numbers with which designers are now trying to woo us.

And there is the status issue at play. Nothing so simple as just having the most expensive clothes: they've got to be the most exclusive clothes. When Miuccia or Tom send out not-yet-available items to the favoured few, they serve as medals demarcating the officer class. Even better is to have designers send gifts to your child: photographer Juergen Teller and his stylist wife Venetia Scott showed how it's done when they turned up at the Lizzy Disney show in New York with their tiny daughter carrying her Pokemon toys in a bag from the not-even-launched-yet Marc Jacobs range.

The current London fashionista look, therefore, goes something like this: ponytail, dark blue jeans (a London obsession), high-heeled shoes in any colour but black (a few pairs of the new minimalist Nike Air Cross and Jennifer Saunders' silver pair were the only trainers on show), something chiffon (those who haven't yet made it to Prada/River Island to buy a blouse have been improvising with a scarf tied tightly around the neck in the manner your gran recommended for sore throats), a pale coat, something in Burberry check and a Louis Vuitton bag.

The real characters and eccentrics of the industry, of course, dance to their own tune and some of the most experienced fashion editors have given up chasing their own tails and float serenely on a cloud of neutral cashmere and leather. London's fashion crowd are engaged in a love-hate relationship with the new, prim handbagged bourgeois chic. The on-site Max Factor nail bar has been doing a roaring trade in French manicures and classic reds, while at the Vidal Sassoon salon, Gianni is booked solid but has done as many mohicans as sleek blow-dries.

London's most distinctive looks are still going strong. Sam Robinson of London boutique The Cross still carries off perfectly the bohemian Fendi bag, silk flowers in hair look, while the Portobello Slag - fishnet tights, bright tarty shoes, turned-up jeans, an armful of bracelets and (real or fake) tattoos - is still much in evidence, now with the addition of the soon-to-be-massive Charlie's Angels-influenced flicked fringe.

A little-known feature of the twice-yearly fashion show tour of New York, London, Milan and Paris is that the audience become noticeably more alike as the days and weeks draw on. Displaced from home environments for a month, the urge to fit in becomes more pressing. If everyone around you every day has exactly the same bag, then after a week or two you start to miss it when you're in your hotel room at night. This desire by osmosis, though clearly mad, is unavoidable. And that's the scary part: if you spent four weeks doing this, you'd end up spending £300 on a Louis Vuitton handbag, too.

fields.headline: The Insider
fields.standfirst: She goes to the parties so you don't have to
fields.trailText: She goes to the parties so you don't have to.
fields.body:
So, you thought fashion folk were too shallow and image-obsessed for real emotion? So did we. But then we went to the It Magazine party at Harvey Nichols' Foundation Bar and found the assembled throng in romantic mood, endearingly tipsy and smooching to the strains of Barry White. Instead of rubber-necking and sipping low-cal champagne (OK, I made that up, but if it existed you know they'd serve it), party-goers including Jarvis Cocker and friends indulged in those old-fashioned pastimes of having fun, dancing and snogging. It was enough to bring a tear to your eye, especially if you were feeling a bit Valentine's Day over-emotional.

The Matthew Williamson aftershow party, however, quickly dispersed any feelings of warmth towards the fashion fraternity. The venue was Rock, the new bar/club venture on the Embankment from Sloane party king Piers Adams, which held its official opening party two nights later. There was no public snogging here, though, quite possibly because most guests were so unbelievably slimy that the necessary friction would have been impossible to achieve. These were the only men in London who still think a suit and a cigar is a good look, leching over models too young to know better. One of the Williamson PR girls was even overheard in the loos describing the crowd as "a bit corporate". And if you think I'm being mean, guess who the obligatory celebrity was? Bryan Adams. I'm not kidding.

Who ate all the sushi at Evisu's 10th anniversary party? The sumo wrestlers. This was just one of the many ways in which the evening careered into surreal territory: the mini crazy golf course, over-run by young men in extremely baggy jeans trying to be laid-back but unable to control their male competitive instincts, was another. And the mini bowling range provided further proof, after the ubiquitous Prada bowling bag and model Carmen Kass's broken wrist, that bowling is the new snowboarding.

fields.headline: Most wanted:  Autograph by M&S
fields.trailText: Julien MacDonald cobweb knit dress, £100? Three-quarter-sleeve shirt by Katharine Hamnett, £35? No, you're not dreaming: you're in Marks & Spencer.
fields.body: Julien MacDonald cobweb knit dress, £100? Three-quarter-sleeve shirt by Katharine Hamnett, £35? No, you're not dreaming: you're in Marks & Spencer. To lure style aficionados back into stores, the beleaguered high street giant is launching Autograph, a designer diffusion womenswear collection which will be stocked in mini-boutiques in 13 stores nationwide from March 2 (enquiries 0171 268 1234). MacDonald, Hamnett and Betty Jackson have designed distinct ranges - delicate knits and colourful eveningwear from MacDonald, simple chic from Hamnett, strong leather and linen from Jackson. With prices from £25 and the most expensive item in the range a deliciously soft knee-length leather coat by Betty Jackson for £450, bet it's not long until you're signing your autograph on your credit card slip.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  Burberry checks
fields.trailText: Today, Burberry is hotter than a hot thing: with designer Robert Menichetti at the helm, its classic appeal and his savvy design talent have combined to produce a bevy of beautifully made clothes that satisfy fashion's current obsession with heritage.
fields.body:
Charity shopping with mother some years ago, we both found a Burberry mac. I conceded it to her. "Are you sure? It's in mint condition," she cajoled. "Too frumpy for me," I replied loftily, as you do when you're 18. Now, I'm asking her to dig it out. Today, Burberry is hotter than a hot thing: with designer Robert Menichetti at the helm, its classic appeal and his savvy design talent have combined to produce a bevy of beautifully made clothes that satisfy fashion's current obsession with heritage. The company is 143 years old.

Which is why all of Trendy London has chosen the Burberry check over CD, LV, YSL or CC as its logo of choice during Fashion Week. True, the Burberry check isn't strictly a logo, but its recognisable pattern fulfils the same function: it screams allegiance to one label. On bucket hats, capes, umbrellas, skirts, scarves, bags and shoes, it's clear we all check for the check. The Burberry mac is back, too. Epaulettes, once a dirty word, are now sprouting on the shoulders of the great and the good. But what bargain-obsessed Britain should love most about the label is its price. With Burberry bikinis for £29 and silk dresses for £150, even the most tight-fisted style aficionado can hardly complain. Although we're sure they will.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Brad Pitt and Leonardo DiCaprio upset the Academy; Bond to stay British; Matrix may be shot in London; Mancunian popstars get Souped up, and Sandra Bullock "young, energetic and curvy" enough to play Lara Croft
fields.body:
 Brad Pitt and Leonardo DiCaprio have upset the directors of this year's Academy Awards by declining an invitation to attend the ceremony. Husband and wife team Richard and Lili Zanuck had hoped to lure the stars for the gong-fest to add a little extra sparkle to the show, but as they haven't been nominated for anything this year the Hollywood hunks are refusing to attend. A miffed Richard Zanuck says, "It's disturbing that stars who are neither nominated nor presenters don't show up. The show is what we do and we celebrate movies at the Oscars in an entertaining way. The Academy is their friend. I remember going to the Oscars with my parents when everybody in the industry went, because it was their show."

 The British film industry no doubt breathed a deep sigh of relief yesterday when it was announced that the next James Bond film will be made in Britain. Alarm bells rang when the German city of Cologne offered the use of its new state-of-the-art studios to the makers of 007 for free, intensifying fears that Britain was losing lucrative studio deals to other countries which were prepared to offer greater incentives. But Pinewood said yesterday that all their studios had been booked by the 007 production company, Eon, and that work on Bond, which is the studio's biggest money-spinner, would begin in November.

 The rumour that the next Matrix will be shot in London has gained further momentum. A contributor to Dark Horizons has seen a storyboard of a chase sequence around Zion's 'Core Conscience', which he claims "bears more than a passing similarity to Big Ben". He also reports that the producer has been telling directors Larry and Andy Wachowski and the crew to make the two new Matrix films bigger and better than the first, "no matter how much it costs". But there may be disappointment for Carrie Ann Moss fans, according to an effects designer the actress will only be in part of the second film as her character is "absorbed and displaced in a temporal reality" which Nero (Keanu Reeves) has to find by re-entering the matrix itself.

 A bevy of Mancunian pop stars have signed up to star in a tale of gangland drug-dealing. Shaun Ryder and Rowetta from the Happy Mondays, Aziz Ibrahim from the Stone Roses and ex-Smiths guitarists Andy Rourke and Mike Joyce are all to play "ne-er do wells" in a film called Social Soup, NME.com reports. All involved in the project are still reading scripts for the parts, but it's believed that Aziz - now frontman in his own band - will play a gangland drugs boss. Shaun Ryder, who previously starred opposite Ralph Fiennes and Uma Thurman in the flop that was The Avengers, is also up for a major part, but according to a friend of the singer he's having a few problems with the script. Not with his character's motivation, just with his own. Says his friend, "Shaun's definitely up for a part in the film, he just needs to read the script. The only trouble is that he's been asleep every time they've asked him to look at it."

Casting couch

 Sandra Bullock is to play cyber-babe Lara Croft in a real-life feature of the popular computer game, Tomb Raider. A spokesman for Paramount, which opted for Bullock over Liz Hurley, Demi Moore and Catherine Zeta-Jones, said, "She really does fit the bill as a young, energetic and curvy actress." Filming will take place at Pinewood later on in the year.

 Brad Bird who directed the critically acclaimed but not very popular animated version of Ted Hughes's The Iron Giant is in negotiations with Pixar - the creators of the phenomenally successful Toy Story - to direct his next feature there. The film is most likely based on Bird's own script, The Incredibles, about a family of super heroes.

Shaun Ryder and Rowetta from the Happy Mondays, Aziz Ibrahim from the Stone Roses and ex-Smiths guitarists Andy Rourke and Mike Joyce are all to play "ne-er do wells" in a film called Social Soup, NME.com reports. All involved in the project are still reading scripts for the parts, but it's believed that Aziz - now frontman in his own band - will play a gangland drugs boss. Shaun Ryder, who previously starred opposite Ralph Fiennes and Uma Thurman in the flop that was The Avengers, is also up for a major part, but according to a friend of the singer he's having a few problems with the script. Not with his character's motivation, just with his own. Says his friend, "Shaun's definitely up for a part in the film, he just needs to read the script. The only trouble is that he's been asleep every time they've asked him to look at it." A spokesman for Paramount, which opted for Bullock over Liz Hurley, Demi Moore and Catherine Zeta-Jones, said, "She really does fit the bill as a young, energetic and curvy actress." Filming will take place at Pinewood later on in the year.  Brad Bird who directed the critically acclaimed but not very popular animated version of Ted Hughes's The Iron Giant is in negotiations with Pixar - the creators of the phenomenally successful Toy Story - to direct his next feature there. The film is most likely based on Bird's own script, The Incredibles, about a family of super heroes.

fields.headline: Ford axes 1,500 jobs at Dagenham
fields.trailText: Ford, the world's second largest car company, delivered a heavy blow to its troubled Dagenham plant in Essex with a decision to axe 1,500 workers from its flagship operation.
fields.body:
Ford, the world's second largest car company, delivered a heavy blow to its troubled Dagenham plant in Essex with a decision to axe 1,500 workers from its flagship operation.

Nick Scheele, Ford's European chairman, said the real case of the cuts was supply and demand of vehicles. But he said it would be foolish to deny that industrial relations problems and a planned strike by white collar staff had not played a part. Ford's biggest UK plant has been plagued by pay disputes and allegations of racism and British car exports have also been hurt by the strength of the pound.

Dagenham, which employs 8,000 workers, will only produce cars on a single shift, instead of the present two shifts, later this year. The plant, where the top-selling Fiesta is built, has been on restricted schedules for well over a year. Mr Scheele said the situation could not continue, citing a deep structural problem at the plant.

The cuts at Dagenham came after another radical review that subjected Ford's low-margin European operations, including its biggest UK plant. Ford last year had only paltry returns of $28m on sales of $30bn. The US car giant employs 350,000 employees worldwide, including more than 26,000 in Britain. Ford's main plants in the UK are Dagenham, Bridgend, south Wales, and Halewood, Merseyside.

Daily production of the Fiesta at Dagenham will more than halve from the present 1,200 to around 560 under the changes announced today.

Mr Scheele said Ford would offer "substantially more" than the statutory minimum redundancy and introduce an immediate special voluntary separation package at Dagenham. He told reporters in London that the strength of sterling had a "modest" effect but was only secondary.

"This move is a significant step towards resolving our capacity imbalance but we will continue to look at all aspects of our European operations," Mr Scheele said, adding that Dagenham had been running substantially below capacity with significant down (non-production) time for many months."

The down time had cost Ford around £20 million last year and would cost a further £22.5 million unless action was taken this year, Mr Scheele stated. "We have concluded that we can fulfil the demand for Dagenham-sourced vehicles with one shift, and this system will be an improvement on the current less stable production situation."

Dagenham has been operating on an effective four-day week for the past 18 months because of a fall in sales in Europe.

Union leaders expressed dismay at the job losses and demanded assurances that Dagenham's long-term future was secure. Duncan Simpson, national officer of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said: "These job losses are a bolt out of the blue and will send shock waves through the workforce. Ford must now deliver concrete assurances over Dagenham's long term future and show that this announcement is not a signal that the plant is being run down."

Unions complained that Dagenham was bearing the brunt of Ford's restructuring plans and said other European factories should take their share of the "pain".

fields.headline: Unison backs Livingstone
fields.trailText: The country's biggest union gave a boost to Ken Livingstone's bid to become Labour's candidate in the race for London mayor today as the contest remained on a knife edge.
fields.body:
The country's biggest union gave a boost to Ken Livingstone's bid to become Labour's candidate in the race for London mayor today as the contest remained on a knife edge.

Unison will cast all its votes for Mr Livingstone after 6,705 of its members gave Mr Livingstone 68% of the vote. Frank Dobson won 16% and Glenda Jackson got 13% of the vote.

Mr Livingstone also won 63% of the votes from the eastern region of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union, compared with 19% for Ms Jackson and 17% for Mr Dobson, the prime minister's preferred candidate.

The eastern region of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union also backed Mr Livingstone by a margin of nearly two to one. 63% backed , compared with 19% for Ms Jackson and 17% for Mr Dobson, the prime minister's preferred candidate.

These victories are worth more than 6% to Mr Livingstone in Labour's electoral college. The MP for Brent East has now won the support of most major unions and looks set for a comfortable victory in the union section of the college.

He has consistently received more than 60% of the vote among those unions that balloted their members. This is believed to be the majority he needs among Labour members to offset Mr Dobson's certain victory in the MPs, MEPs and Greater London Assembly candidates and win the party's nomination.

Ballots closed on Wednesday and the result is expected to be announced on Sunday.

The third candidate Ms Jackson is widely seen as the rank outsider. However, her supporters could well tip the balance in favour of the other two candidates as under the voting system if no one candidate wins a majority in the first ballot, the third place candidate drops out.

The second choice votes of that candidate's supporters are then redistributed between the top two candidates to decide the ultimate victor.

webTitle: Michael Mann's the man for the job

fields.headline: Michael Mann's the man for the job
fields.trailText: Director Michael Mann has announced that he is interested in a number of high-profile projects, and because of the success of The Insider, which recently got an Oscar nomination, he might just be the man to do all of them
fields.body:
Director Michael Mann has announced that he is interested in a number of high-profile projects, and because of the success of The Insider, which recently got an Oscar nomination, he might just be the man to do all of them.

Mann is vying with Spike Lee for the rights to shoot the Mohammed Ali biopic, starring Will Smith. The film has been languishing in development limbo since last autumn when Smith's collaborator, director Barry Sonnefeld, decided against making the film about the former heavy-weight boxer. Columbia Pictures says its shortlist comprises of Mann and Spike Lee, who has just signed to direct a film version of the comedy stand-up tour Kings of Comedy for MTV Films. But according to the Hollywood Reporter, Curtis Hanson, who won an Oscar for his screenplay adaptation of LA Confidential, is also in the running. A decision is expected soon.

Further down the road is another contested biopic, Mann's long-in-development version of the life of the late billionaire, Howard Hughes. The screenplay is up against a number of other potential Hughes projects, but Mann's co-developer, Leonardo DiCaprio, does give his version the immediate edge. Mann has also succeeded in aligning the star of The Beach to a number of other projects, including The Inside Man, the true story of a police union corruption scandal.

Mann has also met up with Brad Pitt with a view to casting him as a master sniper lured out of retirement only to be betrayed in Shooter, an adaptation of Stephen Hunter's novel Point of Impact. In addition, Mann is working on a film about the drugs trade with Armageddon screenwriter, Shane Salero, as well as working on an adaptation of Stephen Pressfield's novel Gates of Fire, about the Spartans' defence of Thermopylae against invading Persian forces in 480 BC. It could be a very busy year for Mr Mann if he wins that Oscar on March 26th.

webTitle: Academy not so cool about Ain't-It-Cool News

fields.headline: Academy not so cool about Ain't-It-Cool News
fields.trailText: Harry Knowles, the geek behind movie website Ain't-it-Cool News has confirmed his position as Hollywood's number one pain in the butt
fields.body:
Harry Knowles, the ginger geek behind movie website Ain't-it-Cool News has confirmed his position as Hollywood's number one pain in the butt.

The gossip columnist, who uses an army of loyal spies to get the low-down on the industry long before the top studio executives do, posted an alleged list of the Oscar semi-finalists on Monday, the day before the nominations were announced.

Yesterday, the executive administrator of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences, Ric Robertson, said the organisation had traced the source of the leak. The list printed by Knowles, which he claimed was an official voting list, was in fact part of a list of guesses made by ABC.com staff in preparation for going online with the actual nominations. A member of the team had apparently come up with a list of possible nominees and used his home computer to test the site being prepared for Tuesday's announcement.

On the site, Knowles said the list came from "deep within the halls of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences''. But although Ain't-It-Cool News had listed eight nominees in each category, saying it was a preliminary list from which the finalists would be chosen, many actual nominees were missing.

Now Robertson is set on discovering "how Knowles knew to hack into that particular database" before deciding whether to take legal action.

webTitle: Why has Britain escaped its neighbours' disease?

fields.headline: Why has Britain escaped its neighbours' disease?
fields.trailText: In Britain, as on the continent, sleaze became a political issue in the 1990s. Indeed, it is widely thought to have been one of the factors responsible for the downfall of John Major's government.
fields.body:
In Britain, as on the continent, sleaze became a political issue in the 1990s. Indeed, it is widely thought to have been one of the factors responsible for the downfall of John Major's government.

Three senior Conservative politicians, the cabinet minister Jonathan Aitken, and the junior ministers Neil Hamilton and Tim Smith, were found guilty of serious financial improprieties, and their political careers ended as a result.

In 1994, following allegations that two Conservative backbenchers, David Tredinnick and Graham Riddick, had accepted money for asking parliamentary questions, public disquiet led to the formation of a standing committee on standards in public life.

Yet from a continental perspective, these scandals must appear almost inconsequential. British sleaze has on the whole been confined to those not in the political front rank.

Moreover, sleaze in Britain, since the days of Lloyd George, has never involved senior government ministers, much less heads of government. There has been nothing like the massive money laundering and misuse of patronage of which Helmut Kohl, François Mitterrand and Bettino Craxi have been accused.

So why are we so comparatively free of sleaze?

Britain is often seen as a political system dominated by the party. Yet in truth, party patronage pays a much smaller role here than it does on the continent.

In Italy the "southernisation" of the civil service resulted in 350,000 people being recruited through patronage between 1973 and 1990, as compared with 250,000 recruited by a competitive examination.

In Austria - an extreme example - public posts, including teaching appointments, have long been divided among the two main parties, the Social Democrats and the People's party. Indeed, popular resentment of this practice was one of the main factors responsible for Jörg Haider's rise to power.

In Britain, by contrast, there is a firm line demar cating political authority, derived from success in competitive elections, from administrative authority, derived from success in competitive examinations. The civil service remains a career service, founded on the values of political neutrality and impartiality.

Special advisers - who comprise about 70 of the 2,500 senior civil servants - have no executive authority; while appointments to quangos, which are by and large semi-official bodies without executive powers, are generally short-term.

As a result, political parties can do little to reward their supporters; a seat in the House of Lords or an honour is perhaps the most that can be offered.

Tony Blair, however, is divesting himself of patronage in the House of Lords by placing the nomination of cross-bench peers into the hands of an independent appointments committee.

The proposals of the committee on standards in public life, currently the subject of legislation to introduce greater transparency in party funding, are also likely to limit the scope of patronage.

Sunlight, said the US supreme court justice Louis Dembitz Brandeis, is the best disinfectant.

With much to teach our counterparts on the continent, how sad it is that successive Eurosceptic governments have weakened our regional prestige.

Vernon Bogdanor is professor of government at Oxford university. His book Devolution in the United Kingdom, was published last year by Oxford University Press

webTitle: The mighty fall as continent fails to stem tide of corruption

fields.headline: The mighty fall as continent fails to stem tide of corruption
fields.standfirst: Party funds illicit gifts fuel claims by Eurosceptics of a rotten EU
fields.trailText: The men and women who were reshaping the continent look self-consciously at the camera in those photographs from the European summits of the past two decades.
fields.body:
The men and women who were reshaping the continent look self-consciously at the camera in those photographs from the European summits of the past two decades.

Helmut Kohl, chancellor of Germany for most of that period, was usually in the middle somewhere, along with his fellow European political heavyweight from France, François Mitterrand. Many others were on the fringes, jostling to get near the big two, such as Bettino Craxi, Italy's then prime minister.

And now their reputations are tarnished. Mr Kohl, the central figure in the push for European integration, could face a jail sentence for his Christian Democrats' £14m slush fund; part of it was allegedly provided by Mr Mitterrand, with the illegal tactics justified as a means to an integrated Europe.

The list of those once at or near the centre of power in Europe, but now in disgrace, is long: Willy Claes, Felipe Gonzales, Giulio Andreotti, Silvio Berlusconi, Edith Cresson. Craxi, who helped push Margaret Thatcher into the single currency, died last month in exile in Tunisia, afraid to return to Italy to face trial for the suitcases of money handed over by businessmen to party officials.

The explosion of corruption allegations, especially in the past month, has provided the Eurosceptic press in Britain - mainly the Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph - with an opportunity to present the EU project as fundamentally rotten. But the explanation for the rash of scandals is much wider and more complex.

Michael Pinto-Duschinsky, an academic who is writing a book on party funding across the world, said one of the main reasons for the digression was the end of the cold war in 1989.

Since the removal of the perceived communist threat, there has been a period of introspection, a closer examination of democracy, with the public less forgiving of practices to which they might have turned a blind eye during the cold war.

"The paradox was that as democracy was spreading throughout the world with victory over communism, there was a lot of discontent with democracy," said Mr Pinto-Duschinsky. "That was very interesting, and we were looking at sources of discontent. Corruption related to financing of politics was a major source of that."

Most of the cases to surface in the past year have been related to party financing rather than personal gain or cronyism. One of the few exceptions involved Mrs Cresson, the former French prime minister accused of helping a dentist friend secure a lucrative EU job.

The scrabble for party funding has become even more frenetic as party memberships across Europe have declined, and reliance on business has grown. Almost simultaneously, the media has stepped up its scrutiny of funding sources.

Spending on election campaigns has multiplied. While no party or individual comes near matching spending in the United States, costs have spiralled as the sources of revenue, hampered by tighter bans on foreign donations, have diminished.

One of the biggest drains on expenditure can be television, with the most extreme example in the US, which has no free public broadcast and no ban on paid advertising. In Britain, by contrast, free broadcasts are combined with a ban on political advertising.

The system in many other European countries is closer to the US: Germany provides free broadcasts but no ban on paid adverts, and Italy is similar, allowing three public broadcasts for each party, while combnining this with a free-for-all in buying political advertising.

Corruption is as old as poli tics and has been endemic in countries such as Italy since its birth. But the big surprise in the past few months has been the German slush fund.

Its emergence is in part a consequence of Mr Kohl's party having been, like the Tories in Britain, in power too long and becoming too careless, with the line between what is legal and what is not having faded with success.

Efforts to tackle corruption have included the public funding of political parties: Italy introduced public funding in 1974 after an extended run of scandals; there is also public funding in Germany. But in both Italy and Germany, private funds still end up sluicing around in election campaigns.

Keith Ewing, professor of public law at King's College, London, who flew yesterday to Valencia to discuss funding issues with academic counterparts from France, Germany and Spain, saw control of spending, rather than the sources of funding, as the crux of the problem.

"What the recent experiences show is the need to have tough rules regarding spending activity by parties and the need to ensure they are effectively enforced," Mr Ewing said.

But he acknowledged there could be problems ahead; the European convention on human rights being incorporated into British law opens the way for a challenge to the ban on paid political advertising.

It has become almost accepted wisdom that Britain, in spite of Neil Hamilton and Jonathan Aitken, is less corrupt than elsewhere in Europe. But Mr Pinto-Duschinsky challenged this: "It was concealment in Britain rather than lack of corruption. It was politics as a club that prevented it coming out."

Although there have been disclosures since the 1997 general election about the role of Michael Ashcroft in Tory funding and Bernie Ecclestone in Labour funding, the Conservatives were largely successful at keeping the sources of their donations secret for decades.

Geoff Martin, the British representative of the European commission, appalled by British rightwing press coverage of the scandals in Europe, said: "A sanctimonious attitude from this country does not grace Britain in the eyes of other countries. It is all very well to be holier than thou after the horse has bolted."

Additional research by Laura Milne

Efforts to tackle corruption have included the public funding of political parties: Italy introduced public funding in 1974 after an extended run of scandals; there is also public funding in Germany. But in both Italy and Germany, private funds still end up sluicing around in election campaigns. Keith Ewing, professor of public law at King's College, London, who flew yesterday to Valencia to discuss funding issues with academic counterparts from France, Germany and Spain, saw control of spending, rather than the sources of funding, as the crux of the problem. "What the recent experiences show is the need to have tough rules regarding spending activity by parties and the need to ensure they are effectively enforced," Mr Ewing said. But he acknowledged there could be problems ahead; the European convention on human rights being incorporated into British law opens the way for a challenge to the ban on paid political advertising. It has become almost accepted wisdom that Britain, in spite of Neil Hamilton and Jonathan Aitken, is less corrupt than elsewhere in Europe. But Mr Pinto-Duschinsky challenged this: "It was concealment in Britain rather than lack of corruption. It was politics as a club that prevented it coming out." Although there have been disclosures since the 1997 general election about the role of Michael Ashcroft in Tory funding and Bernie Ecclestone in Labour funding, the Conservatives were largely successful at keeping the sources of their donations secret for decades. Geoff Martin, the British representative of the European commission, appalled by British rightwing press coverage of the scandals in Europe, said: "A sanctimonious attitude from this country does not grace Britain in the eyes of other countries. It is all very well to be holier than thou after the horse has bolted." Additional research by Laura Milne

fields.headline: Politicians feeling the heat
fields.trailText: President Boris Yeltsin became mired in a corruption scandal when US and Italian press alleged last year that he and his family had accepted a $1m kickback from a building firm for awarding it Kremlin restoration contracts.
fields.body:
President Boris Yeltsin became mired in a corruption scandal when US and Italian press alleged last year that he and his family had accepted a $1m kickback from a building firm for awarding it Kremlin restoration contracts.

Kosovo Albanian millionaire Bexhet Pacolli, head of the Mabetex building firm, was alleged to have paid the money into a Budapest bank for the personal use of Yeltsin and his daughters, Tatyana Dyachenko and Yelena Okulova.

Acting President Vladimir Putin signed a decree promising Yeltsin immunity from prosecution. Amelia Gentleman, Moscow

Helmut Kohl, Germany's "reunification chancellor", is the main obstacle to resolving the scandal tearing his country's political base.

Kohl, who led the Christian Democrats until stepping down after his 1998 general election defeat, has admitted taking up to £670,000 in secret party donations. But he will not identify the source, which is threatening to drag out the affair as prosecutors try to discover who he is protecting - and why. He denies the money was for government favours.

Up to £20m may have passed through party slush funds under his leadership. John Hooper, Berlin

Edith Cresson may be a scapegoat for a leftwing culture of cronyism as she faces possible corruption charges linked to her term as an EU commissioner. Paying friends from public funds was done by all French parties but reached a peak under President François Mitterrand.

A former prime minister, she was appointed to Brussels in 1995 - one of many Mitterrand favourites to get top jobs or sinecures - and appears to have given friends the same largesse. Under suspicion, she was deserted by other Socialists, mindful of a purity campaign led by Lionel Jospin. Paul Webster, Paris

Michael Ashcroft, the Conservative treasurer, has been the focus of the most controversial British party funding row in years.

A British-born businessman, he became a citizen of Belize and made a fortune there. He has admitted giving the Tory party £3m in the past three years, effectively bankrolling it.

He has done nothing illegal, but as a bill was being drafted to ban foreign donations, it was embarrassing for the Tories to be funded by a foreign citizen.

William Hague recommended him for a peerage but he was turned down by the honours scrutiny committee. Ewen MacAskill

Silvio Berlusconi, Italy's former prime minister and media magnate, has wriggled free from a prison sentence for illegal party financing but the affair is still undermining his efforts to regain his old job.

The Forza Italia leader was sentenced to two years and four months, but the slow appeals process ensured that judges threw out the conviction in October.

Yet the suspicion of corruption has spawned other allegations. Last month a Milan court overturned a jail term for false accounting, but he still faces other charges of false accounting and bribing tax inspectors. Rory Carroll, Rome

fields.headline: Sellafield
fields.standfirst: More about the British nuclear industry
fields.trailText:
Isn't Sellafield just another nuclear power plant?
Oh no. It's the site of the world's first commercial scale nuclear power station, Calder Hall, opened by the Queen in 1956, and it generates enough electricity to supply a city the size of Leeds. Sellafield also has a host of other plants, including two reprocessing plants - one to reprocess the waste from the old so-called Magnox nuclear power stations and one, Thorp, to reprocess spent fuel from the newer privatised plants at home and abroad.
fields.body:
Isn't Sellafield just another nuclear power plant?
Oh no. It's the site of the world's first commercial scale nuclear power station, Calder Hall, opened by the Queen in 1956, and it generates enough electricity to supply a city the size of Leeds. Sellafield also has a host of other plants, including two reprocessing plants - one to reprocess the waste from the old so-called Magnox nuclear power stations and one, Thorp, to reprocess spent fuel from the newer privatised plants at home and abroad.

What exactly is reprocessing?
When nuclear stations produce electricity plutonium and uranium are left as a by-product. Sellafield reprocesses that - it dissolves the plutonium and uranium in nitric acid which itself produces a whole lot of liquid waste - more than it can get rid of. It then recovers the plutonium and uranium and makes mixed oxide fuel with it - Mox - a major new business for Sellafield.

Who buys Mox?
Mainly Japan. But also Switzerland and Germany

So why is Sellafield back in the news?
A government safety inspectorate is threatening to shut Sellafield down because of its safety record.

What do you mean?
There is a huge backlog of dangerous high-level nuclear liquid waste at the plant, an increase in safety-related incidents in 1999, and data on fuel dispatched to Japan on armed ships has been systematically falsified.

Why all this high-level nuclear waste?
Nuclear waste remains dangerous for around 250,000 years

Can you do anything about it?
Turn it into glass blocks and cool it for 50 years and then store it deep underground for at least 200,000 years.

Sellafield seems to have always had a bad reputation
Yes - in the 1980s it even changed its name from Windscale because of the public image.

Is nuclear power unpopular everywhere?
Certainly in the West, where no one is planning new nuclear stations. But no one is shutting them down either. Sweden was the first country in 1980 to decide not to build new ones and declared it wanted to live without nuclear power altogether. So far it has failed to shut one station.

How much electricity does nuclear power produce?
20 % of electricity worldwide. France is the most dependent on it - 78% of its electricity comes from nuclear stations. In Belgium it is 60%, Switzerland 39%, Germany 36%, Sweden 46% and in the UK, 27%.

Why is nuclear power so unpopular here?
Originally because of its close connection with nuclear weapons. The original stations were built not to produce electricity but to make plutonium for nuclear weapons. But the public weren't told that straight away - in fact not until the 1980s. The industry's early habit of lying made people sceptical and suspicious. Add to that the sometimes irrational fear of radioactivity and the appalling results of the Chernobyl accident and the dislike expands into a wish the industry would just go away.

What other fears have there been around Sellafield?
More than a third of plutonium pumped into the Irish sea from Sellafield over the past 40 years is said to be missing. Plutonium dust washed inshore is thought to potentially cause cancer and birth defect clusters.

What does the government want to do with BNFL?
Sell it. British Nuclear Fuels Limited is the largest state-owned industry, making £200 million a year in profit. But it is also Britain's most unpopular company. Last August the government announced the sale of 49% of the company. But before the company can be part-privatised it has to satisfy safety and economic conditions, which is why today's reports are worrying for the government. In fact its privatisation plans have now had to be put on hold.

How much does BNFL own?
It owns the site at Sellafield; a nuclear fuel complex at Springfields, near Preston; eight Magnox nuclear fuel stations: Calder Hall plus Sizewell A (Suffolk), Bradwell (Essex), Dungeness A (Kent), Hinkley Point A (Somerset), Oldbury (Glos), Wylfa (Angelsey), and Chapelcross (Dumfries); nuclear research labs in Berkeley, Glos; and a water-power station at Maentwrong, Wales. BNFL employs 20,000 people.

Have there ever been any disasters?
Well, there have been near misses. In the 1970s Sellafield had an accident in a plutonium handling compartment and enough of the metal was spilt in a lump to start a nuclear reaction. Quick action by staff prevented a disaster.

How does a nuclear reaction work?
Plutonium and uranium are not inert. Constantly in a state of change, they fire off radioactivity and the atoms bombard each other and everything around with neutrons.

So what should you do?
Never allow more than a few pounds of plutonium and uranium to lie around. Left alone it will react and form a critical mass, heat up and glow, producing massive quantities of radioactivity. This is what happened in an accident in Japan last year.

What was Chernobyl all about?
The same sort of thing. But the lump spilt in 1986 was twice the size of the Japanese piece, around 30-40 kilos. The uranium fuel rods got so hot that in a few seconds the top of the reactor was blown off.
