webTitle: Brussels strives to wipe slate clean of scandal

fields.headline: Brussels strives to wipe slate clean of scandal
fields.standfirst: Every day seems to bring a new revelation of corruption in one of the continent's capitals. Guardian writers unravel the webs of deceit
fields.trailText: Europe's leaders yesterday began trying to rebuild faith in the continent's political institutions, battered by the biggest spate of scandals since the second world war.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Europe's leaders yesterday began trying to rebuild faith in the continent's political institutions, battered by the biggest spate of scandals since the second world war.

Still in shock from the worst of them, Germany's Christian Democrats (CDU) launched a search for a new leader untainted by the £14m slush fund scandal that threatens to destroy the party in the polls.

In Brussels the European commission confirmed that its reform white paper will be launched on March 1.

Tony Blair is likely to discuss reform when he meets the commission president, Romano Prodi, in Brussels next week.

The devastating revelations in Germany follow a series of financial scandals that have rocked political parties in France, Italy, Russia and many other continental countries.

Although the scandals are not related, a trend is emerging across Europe of irregularities in party funding that are damaging the reputations of the continent's political leadership.

Neil Kinnock, the European commission vice-president given responsibility last September for reform of the body, said last night: "Britain has taken its major steps to deal with the issue of standards in public life in recent years, with the Nolan and Neill committees. Other European countries are also dealing with it."

He added: "In the commission reform strategy I have proposed a European committee of standards in public life to ensure that the European public can have fresh confidence in all of the situations of the European Union.

"It wouldn't guarantee perfection. It would help to promote probity everywhere."

Leading conservatives in Germany urged the CDU to take its time choosing a successor to Wolfgang Schaüble, who stood down on Wednesday.

The refusal of the former chancellor and long-time CDU leader Helmut Kohl to say who gave him the money has tarnished his reputation as a European statesman.

In a separate scandal, Edith Cresson, a former French prime minister, is to be questioned by Belgian police over corruption allegations. EU insiders say the commission's decision to strip Mrs Cresson of diplomatic immunity underlines what is at stake.

"If the issue goes off the boil, then resistance to the proposed reforms could get stronger," an official warned. "There is massive political pressure for the commission to change. Publicity helps."

Mrs Cresson, a former European commissioner, has denied any wrongdoing.

France has also seen scandals involving tainted blood, the former finance minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn and the former foreign minister Roland Dumas.

One of the keystones of Mr Kinnock's reform package is an inter-institutional committee on standards in public life - designed to ensure that the commission, the EU council of ministers and the European parliament all live up to the sort of criteria laid down by the Nolan commission on public standards in Britain.

Mr Kinnock said: "Obviously, dirt in public life is despicable anywhere - but there's no 'country of origin' stamp on it. The essential requirement is to combat sleaze so effectively that it is deterred."

Some MEPs fiercely resist attempts to look at their generous expenses and allowances.

The EU's anti-fraud office, Olaf, now has operational independence, but there are still concerns in Strasbourg about it becoming too powerful a watchdog.

Brussels is the capital of Belgium as well as of Euroland, and the host country has had its share of sleaze-related embarrassments.

Last week a former minister, Alain van der Biest, was given a year's suspended sentence after being found guilty of fiddling travel expenses and awarding a contract to close friends.

fields.headline: England saved by last pair
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe 131
England 134 for 9
England won by one wicket
fields.trailText: In a quite incredible finish to the second one-day international at Bulawayo, England have beaten Zimbabwe by one wicket, to go 2-0 up in the four-match series. Set 132 for victory, England were coasting to victory at 120 for 5, but four wickets fell for five runs and it was left to the final pair of Darren Gough and Alan Mullally to scratch together the winning runs. A win may be a win, but this was a poor effort by England.
fields.body:
In a quite incredible finish to the second one-day international at Bulawayo, England have beaten Zimbabwe by one wicket, to go 2-0 up in the four-match series. Set 132 for victory, England were coasting to victory at 120 for 5, but four wickets fell for five runs and it was left to the final pair of Darren Gough and Alan Mullally to scratch together the winning runs. A win may be a win, but this was a poor effort by England.

Amid all the excitement it was easy to forget the outstanding contribution of man of the match Craig White, who followed figures of 5-21 with a crucial 26. White's best day in an England shirt began when he got rid of ZimbabweÕs danger man, Neil Johnson, for 30, caught at midwicket by the ubiquitous Nasser Hussain to leave Zimbabwe 60 for 2 (Alistair Campbell had already perished, caught by Graeme Hick in the gully off Andy Caddick for 6). White, helped by a fruity pitch, proceeded to cut a swathe through ZimbabweÕs fragile middle order.

Stuart Carlisle was his second victim, caught behind for 31 as he tried to cut a ball that was too close to him (76 for 3), and White then dismissed both the Flower brothers in the space of four runs: Andy edged a ball that left him and was spectacularly held by Chris Read for 3, diving high to his left to cling on one-handed (80 for 4), before Grant was bowled for 2 by one that nipped back (84 for 5).

White then claimed his first five-wicket haul in ODIs by having Dirk Viljoen caught behind for a 20-ball 2, and Zimbabwe were in desperate trouble at 98 for 6. It was soon 98 for 7 when Murray Goodwin pulled Mullally straight to Hick at square-leg, and, although the tail resisted for a while, Zimbabwe were eventually dismissed for 131 with three balls of their 48 overs remaining, Ealham finishing the job by bowling Gary Brent (10) and Henry Olonga (0) with successive deliveries.

A total of 132, even on this pudding of a pitch, should not have stretched England. But when has that ever stopped them making a hash of things? They lost Nick Knight for 0, given out caught behind off Heath Streak in the first over (although replays suggested he the noise may have been bat against pad), and Nasser Hussain, leg before to Streak for 2 as he pushed forward. That made it 6 for 2, and suddenly 132 was looking a mile away.

Graeme Hick and Darren Maddy took the score to 30, before Hick perished to a needless pull at a delivery from Streak that was too full and top-edged a simple catch to Andy Flower behind the stumps for 13. The required run-rate (2.75 at the start of the innings) seemed to pass England by, and Maddy followed, pulling Gary Brent straight to Henry Olonga at deep backward square-leg for 13 to leave England 58 for 4. Where calm heads were required England were playing as if they needed 300.

Vikram Solanki played another innings that summed up his embryonic international career so far: studded with shots that revealed a rare talent (such as the rasping, wristy pull for four off Brent), it again came to a self-induced end as he tried to sweep Grant Flower and got a top edge to Streak, running back at square-leg. His innings of 24 may have been his best effort yet for England, but they needed him to go on. Now they were in trouble at 73 for 5.

But White and Ealham began to turn things round, with Ealham slog-sweeping Viljoen's left-arm spin for six, and White driving Streak through the covers for four the ball after England's hundred had come up.

England were doing it easily, and required just 12 more with plenty of overs to spare, when things began to go horribly wrong. White slashed Olonga straight to Goodwin in the covers for 26 (120 for 6), before Chris Read, impatient after failing to score from his first 10 balls, pulled his 11th, from Brent, tamely to Craig Wishart, the substitute fielder at square-leg. England were 124 for 7, yet remained favourites. But Ealham then went lbw, playing around a slower ball from Brent for 32 (125 for 8), and Caddick followed almost immediately, bowled off stump for 0 by Viljoen as he advanced down the wicket. It was unbelievably dense cricket: from nowhere England had lost four wickets for five runs and had turned sure-fire victory into potential defeat.

But Gough worked Brent fine on the legside for four, and, from the final ball of the next over, Mullally took a single to keep the strike. Two to win, one to tie. Two balls later, Mullally edged Brent to third man for four, and England had crept ignominiously to victory. Never before has a total of 131 looked so forbidding.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

His innings of 24 may have been his best effort yet for England, but they needed him to go on. Now they were in trouble at 73 for 5. But White and Ealham began to turn things round, with Ealham slog-sweeping Viljoen's left-arm spin for six, and White driving Streak through the covers for four the ball after England's hundred had come up. England were doing it easily, and required just 12 more with plenty of overs to spare, when things began to go horribly wrong. White slashed Olonga straight to Goodwin in the covers for 26 (120 for 6), before Chris Read, impatient after failing to score from his first 10 balls, pulled his 11th, from Brent, tamely to Craig Wishart, the substitute fielder at square-leg. England were 124 for 7, yet remained favourites. But Ealham then went lbw, playing around a slower ball from Brent for 32 (125 for 8), and Caddick followed almost immediately, bowled off stump for 0 by Viljoen as he advanced down the wicket. It was unbelievably dense cricket: from nowhere England had lost four wickets for five runs and had turned sure-fire victory into potential defeat. But Gough worked Brent fine on the legside for four, and, from the final ball of the next over, Mullally took a single to keep the strike. Two to win, one to tie. Two balls later, Mullally edged Brent to third man for four, and England had crept ignominiously to victory. Never before has a total of 131 looked so forbidding. Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Hague uses new technology for old money

fields.headline: Hague uses new technology for old money
fields.standfirst: Keep the Pound
fields.trailText: William Hague today launched a website to bolster his "keep the pound" campaign, in which the Tory leader is taking his anti-euro message to the voters on the back of a flat-bed lorry.
fields.body:
William Hague today launched a website to bolster his "keep the pound" campaign, in which the Tory leader is taking his anti-euro message to the voters on the back of a flat-bed lorry.

Unveiling his new internet venture at Logical Support Services in the West Midlands, Mr Hague contrasted his "unrehearsed, unspun common sense" with "packaged politicians like Tony Blair who never leave the M25, never depart from the rehearsed script, never leave the clutches of their speech-writers and spin doctors and media handlers."

"What you'll get from me on this campaign, be it via the Internet, the newspapers, television or in person, is the plain, unrehearsed, unspun common sense that the British people deserve - the common sense that will save our currency and save our country," he said.

Mr Hague also made a bid for more than just the support of Conservative voters, claiming that the true view of the single currency held by many Labour and Liberal Democrat supporters is not voiced by their parties.

"I am speaking for all people, regardless of which party they normally support," Mr Hague said, outlining his campaign itinerary which will see the "keep the pound truck" visiting Woking, Great Yarmouth, Dingley Dell in Kettering, Winchester, and North Devon.

Mr Hague's website makes his self-styled homespun campaign a technological step beyond former Conservative leader John Major, who successfully resorted to a "soapbox" during the 1992 general election campaign.

The somewhat spartan site lists "who's for the pound", naming four "prominent business supporters", including Lord Hanson, Ruth Lea, the institute of directors' head of policy, and Luke Johnson, chairman of the Belgo Group.

It also publishing a raft of unflattering polling evidence and facts about the euro, as well as a letters page vociferously against joining the euro.

"Keep trucking William, you're doing a Sterling job," says one of the letters, quoting the News of the World.

webTitle: Iran's reformers expected to win parliamentary elections

fields.headline: Iran's reformers expected to win parliamentary elections
fields.trailText: Iranian reformers brimmed over with confidence at the prospect of taking control of parliament away from Islamist conservatives in today's vote.
fields.body:
Iranian reformers brimmed over with confidence at the prospect of taking control of parliament away from Islamist conservatives in today's vote.

The poll is widely seen as a referendum on the rule of President Mohammad Khatami, the Iranian Gorbachev, after decades of fundamentalist government following the 1979 Iranian revolution.

"We predicted before the election that the (reformers) would win a majority and according to our evidence today it seems we were right," said Mohammad Reza Khatami, brother of the president and head of the reform ticket, before casting his vote.

If his prediction turns out to be accurate, it will be the first time in two decades that reformers will have a majority in the powerful but traditionally conservative parliament. At stake were 290 seats in the next parliament, to convene in May. The hardliners have a slight majority in the outgoing house.

Victory for the reformers would confirm Iran's steady move away from the fundamentalist state envisioned by ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, when he overthrew the Shah 20 years ago. Victory for the reformers would also strengthen President Khatami, who came to power in 1997 on promises of more individual freedoms.

"Parliament has an extraordinarily important position in the Islamic republic especially now that the country has started a new era. The more people vote today, the more the parliament comes to represent their will," Mr Khatami said.

Analysts say a higher turnout will mean more votes for the reformers. But the conservatives hold one trump card against the forces of change: Iran's supreme leader and the ultimate power in the country, Ali Khamenei, the hardliners' main backer. He voted in a mosque near his office in central Teheran.

Making clear what was at stake, he said on state radio: "This is a significant election and I want you to be careful. Elect those who will be helpful to you and to Islam."

Despite the absence of opinion polls, the reformers are expected to do well because of popular weariness and frustration with the restrictions of clerical rule. Liberals have promised to work towards greater press freedom and respect for the rule of law.

Some have suggested that Iranians should decide in a national referendum whether or not to establish ties with the United States. The US broke off relations two decades ago when Iranian students seized their Tehran embassy and held 52 Americans hostage for more than a year.

After 21 years of Islamic rule, the country's younger generation complains the strict regime has failed to bring jobs and prosperity. More than half of Iran's 62m people are under the age of 25. About 20m of them are in high schools and universities, the motors for change in Iran.

Even if they win, reformers would face many hurdles, including the conservative Guardians Council that must approve all legislation passed by parliament, and Ayatollah Khamenei, who has absolute veto power.

The hardliners also control the judiciary and other key institutions such as radio and television as well as the armed forces. But even some of them have begun to acknowledge they must take the current tide of change into account.

fields.headline: Road ragers in the sky
fields.standfirst: Delays, cramped accommodation, lousy air quality, poor service, smoking bans... It's not surprising that passengers turn to drink - which is when the real problems begin
fields.trailText: Delays, cramped accommodation, lousy air quality, poor service, smoking bans... It's not surprising that passengers turn to drink - which is when the real problems begin
fields.body:
Airlines and their long-suffering customers are reporting a steep climb in air rage incidents, most of them drink-related. Not surprisingly, a large proportion of the high-altitude high jinks take place on flights within and from the USA with its huge aviation industry. But British flights too are increasingly affected. Last year saw several high-profile incidents, including a transatlantic flight diverted when a party of London-based Irish travellers became drunk and disorderly. Then there was the case of a British Airways manager who was suspended when she struck a cabin attendant who refused her drink. The then transport minister John Reid spoke of introducing a new air-rage criminal offence, after another stewardess was attacked and badly wounded. In Canada too there is talk of new stiff penalties for rowdy or violent passengers. And in Australia, no fewer than 600 incidents were reported last year.

Some more recent examples
Some incidents are apparently sparked by mundane problems, familiar to nearly all regular air travellers. One case reported from America stemmed from an interminable delay in takeoff, when passengers were cooped up in their aircraft on the tarmac for four hours, without food, drink or information. Mass unrest is less common than individual misbehaviour, as in the scary case of the convict who recently went beserk on a flight, attacked the crew and tried to open a door in mid-flight.

The causes
The psychology of air rage is a new and fast-growing area of study, and there are almost as many explanations as examples . Most analysts of the phenomenon blame alcohol, but there is a growing school of thought which points the finger at the airlines themselves. In their zeal to cut costs, they cramming ever more passengers into their aircraft, while trimming back on cabin crew, training, and quality of service, all of which increases passenger frustration. In addition, there is mounting concern in the USA about another cost-cutting exercise which could seriously harm passengers' health: cabin ventilation.

Poor air in the air
Modern aircraft are equipped with sophisticated air conditioning devices - but running them at optimum capacity burns up valuable aviation fuel. Many airlines routinely instruct their flight crews to run the systems on minimum settings. Campaigners for improved air quality claim that this can lead to irritability, disorientation, and allergenic reactions.

Passenger complaints
In the USA, the soaring number of passenger complaints across a wide across a wide range of issues, is reflected in a rash of new internet sites devoted to rubbishing the airlines and demanding better service. One of the most outspoken is Airlinessuck.com, which is stridently calling for an air passengers' Bill of Rights. American travel agents are also active in the campaign for travellers' rights. On the specific issue of air rage, there is even a Sky Rage Foundation, which issues a regular - and rather frightening - newsletter.

The airlines' response
Cabin and flight crews, who are in the front line of the battle against disruptive and dangerous in-flight behaviour, have called for stiffer penalties against offenders. Managements have also called for legislation - while ritually denying that cost-cutting practices have contributed to the problem. But there are some signs, in America at least, that the airlines are at last responding to a growing backlash of customer dissatisfaction and rising Congressional concern. Some major lines have announced concessions to the most frequent complaint of all, and are removing seats to make more room for their customers.

webTitle: Sellafield given two months to reform itself

fields.headline: Sellafield given two months to reform itself
fields.standfirst: More about the British nuclear industry
fields.trailText: The government has given British Nuclear Fuels two months to prove they can change unsafe management practices at Sellafield exposed by three safety reports published today.
fields.body:
The government has given British Nuclear Fuels two months to prove they can change unsafe management practices at Sellafield exposed by three safety reports published today.

Energy minister Helen Liddell said she was "incensed" at how things had gone so badly wrong at Sellafield and instructed BNFL's management to devise "comprehensive and radical suggestions for change" at the plant, the largest nuclear facility in the country.

"The HSE Executive's reports document serious management failures," said Mrs Liddell. "I have asked him for comprehensive and radical suggestions for change, which will deliver the management that the company needs within two months."

"The review should regard no one and no level of the organisation as out of bounds," she added.

The nuclear installations inspectorate reports criticised "systematic management failure" which allowed the falsification of fuel data and quality assurance records.

Poor design of the Cumbria plant, the tedium of the job and the ease with which the computer dating logging systems was manipulated were all blamed for the problem, which dates back to 1996.

But the report said that although data was falsified it would have no effect on the safety of fuel in a nuclear reactor.

The damning 40-page report castigates BNFL for a lack of "proper safety culture within this plant".

"There can be no excuse for process workers not following procedures and deliberately falsifying records to avoid doing a tedious task. These people need to be identified and disciplined," the report concluded. "However, the management on the plant allowed this to happen and since it had been going on for over three years must share responsibility."

Five process workers have been sacked over the falsification. BNFL today accepted its responsibilities following the report, but it is not expected to sack any executives.

BNFL admitted the reports had been "damaging" and said actions were already under way to improve the safety culture.

Brian Watson, head of the Sellafield site, said: "Our response is that safety is and remains the company's top priority and of course we take these reports extremely seriously."

Mr Watson said he could not comment on whether any executives would have to resign or be sacked over the problem but added he did not anticipate any further dismissals of process workers.

Environmental campaign group Greenpeace called for the government to end nuclear re-processing at Sellafield.

"The whole plutonium business is rotten to the core," said spokesman Peter Roche.

fields.headline: The Macpherson experience
fields.standfirst: Vikram Dodd, who covered the Macpherson inquiry for the Guardian and the Observer, recounts his impressions here
fields.trailText: The small band of journalists who regularly covered the Stephen Lawrence inquiry had never known a story like it.
fields.body:
The small band of journalists who regularly covered the Stephen Lawrence inquiry had never known a story like it.

Following the twists and turns in the convoluted drama that emerged piece by piece proved compelling and draining. We sat in the press room one day and confided in each other that this story had eaten its way into our psyche.

Myself and the others would wake up in the middle of the night having dreams about what was being unearthed. I remember going for a week's holiday in Barcelona and being woken up at 5am by some small detail popping into my mind. I would try and explain to friends in the pub the minutiae of what was being exposed, and even the most generous and interested would slowly nudge me towards talking about football.

The conclusion reached by the inquiry chairman Sir William Macpherson would be seismic: namely that police prejudice against black people was so ingrained that it contributed to allowing racist murderers to get away with their crime.

It would take some time to realise that what we were witnessing was historic. No direct evidence of racism ever emerged; it never does in these cases.

One by one officers involved would walk into the witness box, and more often than not, leave worse for the experience.

Every day was full of drama as police officers made admissions, some which, although they were too obscure to make the headlines, contributed to a growing picture pointing to blunders that would tarnish the worldwide reputation of Scotland Yard.

There were days of intense melodrama dominated by the two days the five prime suspects testified. That led to the inquiry chamber being stormed and a mini-riot as they left.

The inquiry took place in the surreal setting of Hannibal House, housed in the birthday-cake pink Elephant and Castle shopping centre.

For me the inquiry kicked off in surreal fashion. The day before it started, I co-wrote a story in the Observer newspaper. We had checked Sir William Macpherson's record on race cases and what we had found so alarmed Neville Lawrence that he and his wife Doreen wanted him removed as chair.

The inquiry began with Macpherson denouncing the Observer for its story. I sat and watched as my professionalism and accuracy were trashed. The inquiry was adjourned while the Lawrences saw the home secretary. As would often be the case, the inquiry started with melodrama that turned into mayhem.

A week later, with Jack Straw having given Macpherson his full backing, the first evidence was heard.

What was clear was that the police had no idea how to handle the questioning they faced. They had simply never been exposed to real accountability, to having to justify every decision. Some tried bluster, others outrage at their honour being questioned. Few, it seemed to those watching, tried undiluted candour.

A senior Scotland Yard officer told me during the early days of the inquiry that they could not say that Stephen's murder was racist.

The Met's top brass headed by the then commissioner Sir Paul Condon held out against the tide of evidence that racism had blighted the murder investigation for so long that it became almost embarrassing to watch.

Parts of the evidence nearly moved me to tears. The statement of Duwayne Brooks, who was with Stephen when he was stabbed, set out what the two friends had done on the last day of Stephen's life. It was the normal teenage stuff, playing video games, going around town, but as with most things in this inquiry, it was the weight of detail that proved so telling, that created such a sense of bathos.

Outside the chamber, Doreen and Neville Lawrence struggled to keep their emotions in check. Neville would sometimes be so angry at the police's evidence, he would leave the chamber muttering under his breath, "That man's a liar". The sadness in Doreen's eyes seemed to grow as the inquiry wore on.

A year on and the debate rages about whether the Stephen Lawrence inquiry made any difference to race relations in Britain.

There is one undeniable change. For years black and Asian people had been saying they received a second-rate service from the police, that they were over-policed as suspects and under-policed as victims.

After the Macpherson report, there is no excuse for anyone claiming they are ignorant of the discrimination at the heart of the criminal justice system, no excuse for the culture of disbelief that greeted the experiences of black and Asian Britons who found they were repeatedly being let down by the people from whom they needed help most.

It was a black woman who travelled across London to attend the inquiry who best set out the challenge facing Britain in the wake of Macpherson's findings. She said: "Black people don't need an inquiry to tell us the police are racist, we know that. But if the inquiry finds that, will white people care?"

I don't know, I still don't know.

Special report
Macpherson report: one year on

fields.headline: No more charges against Shipman
fields.trailText: Harold Shipman, Britain's worst serial killer, will not face further charges for the alleged murder of 23 additional female patients.
fields.body:
Harold Shipman, Britain's worst serial killer, will not face further charges for the alleged murder of 23 additional female patients.

According to David Calvert-Smith, director of public prosecutions, a second trial against Shipman would be too difficult due to the huge publicity surrounding the case.

Shipman, who has already been imprisoned for the murder of 15 of his female patients, is believed to have committed a total of 146 murders in his 20-year career as a medical doctor in Hyde, near Manchester.

Greater Manchester police say they have enough evidence to charge Shipman with the murders of another 23 women.

The families of his other suspected victims have agreed that a second trial could not take place.

webTitle: Mervyn King sceptical about internet's effect on economy

fields.headline: Mervyn King sceptical about internet's effect on economy
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Mervyn King, the deputy governor of the Bank of England, yesterday dismissed the notion that the internet was transforming the performance of the British economy,
fields.body:
Mervyn King, the deputy governor of the Bank of England, yesterday dismissed the notion that the internet was transforming the performance of the British economy,

While insisting he had an open mind about its potential impact, Mr King said there was little hard evidence to conclude that net had improved the underlying growth rate.

"Don't jump to conclusions, just because some people are starting to use the internet, that this is a dramatic change," said Mr King. Rejecting the argument that the economy had entered a new commercial era, Mr King said: "We are not living on a different planet."

American economist Paul Romer first floated in 1983 the "new growth theory" which recognised that tech nology - and hence new ideas - was a force comparable to labour and capital that could be cultivated to increase growth.

In America, new economy gurus claim the net has boosted productivity, allowing the economy to grow much faster without running into the buffers of inflation.

But Mr King said there had been no comparable rise in productivity in the UK to justify a looser monetary policy.

He said it was possible retail margins would be squeezed by the extra competition associated with the net, but there was nothing to suggest that this would be a lasting effect.

Internet booksellers tended to be cheaper than those in the high street, but once post and packaging was taken into account there was not much differ ence in price. Moreover, high street booksellers had the advantage of selling on demand, whereas net customers had to wait for purchases to be delivered.

On productivity, Mr King said it could be that the UK was lagging three to four years behind the US because net usage was less widespread, or productivity gains were restricted to small sectors of the economy and did not show up in aggregated data. "We don't know the answers to these questions," said the deputy governor. He said the internet was not the only innovation that we had seen in the past 100 years. There had been many; each one unique - factories had had to be redesigned before electrification had its full effect.

webTitle: Cherie Blair plays tea and sympathy card in wrangle over increased staff

fields.headline: Cherie Blair plays tea and sympathy card in wrangle over increased staff
fields.trailText: Cherie Blair yesterday launched a charm offensive to head off a Tory MP's criticism that she has quadrupled the staff of her office in Downing Street. She said it was because of her bulging mailbag and social engagement calendar.
fields.body:
Cherie Blair yesterday launched a charm offensive to head off a Tory MP's criticism that she has quadrupled the staff of her office in Downing Street. She said it was because of her bulging mailbag and social engagement calendar.

The prime minister's wife, obviously furious that she is being accused of spending taxpayers' cash on party-going and answering fan mail, offered Andrew Tyrie, MP for Chichester, the chance to bring three children from his constituency to a Downing Street tea "to see the results of the social office's hard work".

Her surprise intervention followed a row last week at the Commons public adminstration committee when Mr Tyrie accused her husband of adopting a "presidential lifestyle" by dramatically increasing No 10's staff, including creating an office for his wife.

The MP wrongfooted the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, who admitted he knew nothing about Mr Blair's bulging staff and is now committed to providing the first ever rundown of the PM's closest appointments.

In her letter, Mrs Blair confirmed that the staff had increased from the one part-time secretary who helped Norma Major to four people.

"Tony and I feel strongly that all members of the public who write to No 10 should receive a reply."

The letter adds: "We now host around 20% more social events here, many for charity." The most popular party was "our monthly children's tea."

This idea arose from the large number of children who wanted to look around No 10.

She then offered the MP the chance of bringing three Chichester children between the ages of nine and 13 on March 30. Last night Mr Tyrie said he would accept but would continue to investigate Downing Street's pay bill.

Downing Street's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, told lobby journalists Mr Tyrie had bombarded the cabinet secretary with "inaccurate questions". Mr Campbell's partner, Fiona Millar, oversees Downing Street's social programme.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText:
Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15

Harvey Nichols, 107-111 Briggate, Leeds. Tel: 0113 204 8888.
fields.body:
Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15

Harvey Nichols, 107-111 Briggate, Leeds. Tel: 0113 204 8888.

The northern outpost of southern style, and pretty damn smart it is, too - all brightness and airiness, wood, chrome and fancy lighting. And that's inside as well as out. What's more, it's cheaper than the London branch: £12.50 for two courses, £15 for three and lunch, which means it's a bit of a bunfight at that time of day. But the food's sexy, zippy and of the moment - Italian inclined, with pasta, risotto and polenta to the fore, and roasted veg and prosciutto, Parmesan and balsamic vinegar not far behind. There's also a touch of Asia here and there. Wines pricey. Service slick.

Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Art's Cafe, 42 Call Lane, Leeds. Tel: 0113 243 8243.

This is where the barman of the hyper-trendy Po Na Na bar goes to eat. Sensible bloke: £5 "lunch plates" - grilled salmon, anchovies, fishcake, couscous, salad and bread; or courgette fritters, hummus, braised mushrooms, couscous, marinated vegetables, salad and bread. The menu proper will take you through the 15-minute barrier, but with mackerel fillet with caramelised onions and roast pepper (£4.25) and baked Gorgonzola polenta with braised mushrooms and fresh herbs (£7) or marinated lamb leg steak with braised lentils and herb butter (£8) you may be tempted. Champion puddings, including hazelnut meringue with berry compote and cream (£3.50).

On the menu: verjus

What is it? Green juice. Vert meaning green, jus meaning juice

Green juice of what? Crab apples, unripe apples or sour grapes.

They don't sound the sexiest of fruits. How wrong could you be? Crab apples and their juices were a mainstay of chefs in the middle ages. The Iranians have always treasured verjus, under the name of abghooreh, and the Lebanese know it as hosrum.

And its time has come again? So it would appear. The techno- meisters of the modern kitchen are dashing verjuice or verjus on things instead of vinegar or lemon juice.

Can I make my own? Sure can, dude. Just bung the appropriate sour fruit into a juicer, and hey presto, you got verjus. Or verjuice.

www.shopsmart.com. UK-based independent "portal" site, which means that it doesn't sell anything itself but points you in the right direction. This is more than a list of online food stores, however - there are forthright opinions on the sites featured (all are listed for free, on merit).

Pros: One of the most reliable ways to track down grub on the net; sites are tested and graded according to strict criteria, including security and user-friendliness. Shopsmart scores highly on the latter itself.

Cons: The handy PriceScan, which hunts down the cheapest price for your choice of books, CDs, etc, isn't yet available on the food site.

Soon: next stop - Europe.

Cheat's kitchen

Quick lamb cous-cous

1 Cook boil-in-bag cous-cous (approximately one minute).

2 Spoon the cooked cous-cous into a ring on a plate.

3 Top with a generous slice of plain slow-roasted lamb.

4 Spoon over the heated contents of a carton of Covent Garden spinach, chickpea and coriander soup, with extra tinned chickpeas and dried apricots.

5 Decorate with a few fried or toasted almonds and fresh coriander.

Penny Smith, Retford, Notts.

webTitle: John Lennon's piano to sell for £1m online

fields.headline: John Lennon's piano to sell for £1m online
fields.trailText: The piano on which John Lennon composed Imagine is to be sold for around £1m, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The piano on which John Lennon composed Imagine is to be sold for around £1m, it was announced yesterday.

The upright Steinway, which was in Lennon's Ascot home, could become the most expensive item of pop memorabilia. It will be auctioned on the new eOffer internet site, set up by Fleetwood Mac star Mick Fleetwood and auctioneer Ted Owen, which is to be launched next month.

The piano was unveiled to the public yesterday at the Beatles Story museum at Liverpool's Albert Dock. Insured for £3m, it is being kept under 24-hour guard for its eight-month stay at the exhibition.

Although the white piano featured in the Imagine video is arguably more famous, the wood-finish pi ano is the one on which Lennon crafted the song.

Mr Owen said: "The memorabilia market has recently shown some spectacular results, with Eric Clapton's guitar going for half a million pounds.

"The [piano's] owner is a private collector and he's had it for nearly 10 years. He feels, like we do, that it needs to be in a museum and that's why it's being shown at the Beatles museum until October 9 which would have been Lennon's 60th birthday.

"We would like to see some national body or museum putting money forward to buy it."

This year marks the 20th anniversary of Lennon's death outside his New York home at the hands of obsessed fan Mark Chapman.

Imagine, originally recorded in 1971, reached number one when it was rereleased shortly after Lennon's death. The song was voted the UK's favourite lyric in a poll last year and the second greatest song of the millennium. Public affection for it led to a re-release just before Christmas and it went to number three in the charts. The Imagine album was reissued on Monday.

webTitle: The lying Dutchman: how a crime writer confessed to his wife's murder

fields.headline: The lying Dutchman: how a crime writer confessed to his wife's murder
fields.standfirst: After his wife went missing, Richard Klinkhamer wrote a book on seven ways to kill your spouse. Then it turned out he really had
fields.trailText: After his wife went missing, Richard Klinkhamer wrote a book on seven ways to kill your spouse. Then it turned out he really had
fields.body:
A year after his wife disappeared without trace in 1991, Richard Klinkhamer, a Dutch crime writer, visited his publisher. He had with him a manuscript which, under the circumstances, seemed a little macabre. Not to mention highly suspicious.

The novel, Woensdag Gehaktdag (a Dutch saying which translates as Wednesday, Mince Day), was a grisly, detailed exploration of seven ways in which Klinkhamer could conceivably have killed his wife, Hannelore. In one of the scenarios set out in the book, he disposes of her body by pushing her flesh through a mincer and feeding it to the pigeons.

When Hannelore Klinkhamer, known as Hanny, went missing from the marital home in the Groningen province in the north-east of the Netherlands nine years ago, her husband was the prime suspect. However, police inquiries were fruitless.

The police questioned Klinkhamer at his home, one of a tiny cluster of houses near the hamlet of Ganzedijk. He denied killing her. They put him in a cell. He denied it again. They searched the house. They searched the garden. Nothing was found. Sniffer dogs searched the garden; the police dug up the garden. A Royal Dutch airforce F-16 flew over the garden with infra-red scanners. Nothing was found.

However strong the authorities' suspicions, there could not be a murder inquiry without a body.

Klinkhamer lived on at the house for several years, writing and drinking heavily. But slowly the suspicion that he had killed his missing wife began to filter out beyond the close-knit community. Details of the manuscript - which his publisher, Willem Donker had rejected as too gruesome - began to surface in the Dutch underground press.

Television programmes started to invite Klinkhamer to make guest appearances. There was an interview with him on Birds of Paradise, a series about eccentrics. In 1997, Klinkhamer moved to Amsterdam, to the Bijlmermeer district, with a new girlfriend. There he surfaced on the literary party circuit, apparently enjoying his new position as a minor cult figure among second-tier crime writers.

Meanwhile, new people moved into the house he had shared with Hanny. In time, they sold up to a couple with children who decided to make alterations to the 200ft garden - getting rid of the tatty shed, for instance.

Then, two weeks ago, they hired a digger. While breaking up the concrete laid on the floor of the shed, the workmen turned up a skull, buried in a piece of clay a few metres below the surface. They went on to uncover a skeleton which a forensic scientist quickly identified from dental records as the remains of Hanny Klinkhamer.

That evening, Richard Klinkhamer, 62, was arrested in Amsterdam. Next day he confessed to his wife's murder and he is now awaiting trial in prison in Leeuwarden, in the north-west of the country.

The present owner of the house seems irritated by the events. "I've had nothing but trouble with this house," she says. The garden has been completely dug up and the spot where Hanny's body was discovered is marked by a thin pole, waving in the wind. A cement mixer whirrs and builders move around the garage and the green two-storey house. Can we come and see the garden? "Only if you are willing to pay 500 to 600 guilders. If you pay the money, you can come in; if you don't, you can leave."

But others who knew Hanny have been paying their respects in various ways. On Wednesday, a small gathering of her colleagues and friends met in Ganzedijk and laid flowers for Hanny, who had been a paediatric nurse at a hospital in Winschoten, half a dozen miles away.

Yesterday, offical tributes appeared in local newspapers. She has been buried, her friends say, somewhere quiet and beautiful. "She was a nice, intelligent woman. Everyone was very fond of her," says Harry Wieters, a near neighbour. It was Harry's wife, Marieke, an old friend of Hanny's from Amsterdam, who first introduced her to Ganzedijk.

According to Dutch newspapers, Hanny's early life was marred, with eerie coincidence, by the murder of her mother. On July 15 1957, when she was just nine, Hanny discovered the dead body of her 46-year-old mother, Maria. She had been thrown downstairs by Hanny's father who then killed her with a hammer. Where he is now, or even if he's still alive, is not clear.

Years passed and eventually Hanny rang her friend Marieke to report that she had met an entertaining, funny man named Richard Klinkhamer in Amsterdam. He was 10 years older and divorced, but she was in love. "She was obsessed by Klinkhamer," says Harry Wieters. Hanny wanted to marry Klinkhamer and bring him to Ganzedijk to start a new life and, in 1978, they moved to the area.

Things seemed to go well at first, but then Klinkhamer, who was a former foreign legionnaire, sometime auditor and part-time author, began to drink heavily. He would hit Hanny and when he did, she would go to stay with other people. "I have seen her with blue marks on her body," says Wieters.

Klinkhamer's writing career, however, began to take off. His first book, Obedient as a Dog, drew heavily on his experiences in the French Foreign Legion. The first thing they teach you, he said, is how to kill somebody; the second, how to dispose of a body properly. He later had a collection of short stories published, entitled Hotel Red.

Like Hanny, Klinkhamer had an Austro-German background. During the war, he once told Willem Donker, that his mother had had an affair with an SS officer. He was in Austria with her when it was liberated by the Russians; he remembers that she was raped. On their return to Holland, his mother's head was shaved - the standard punishment meted out to women who had had liaisons with Nazis during the occupation. "It was a very dark chapter of the liberation," says Donker. "Later, he said, she had to make a living so she did for money what she had done for love during the war."

Klinkhamer, according to Donker, had Nazi sympathies, although other acquaintances reject this. One of his books, Kruis of Munt (Heads or Tails), is a "faction" about the SS. His reasons for killing Hanny will probably never be known but alcohol may have been a factor. In the weeks leading up to her death, as their relationship deteriorated, he was drinking huge quantities of beer on his own at home.

What is known, if Klinkhamer's account can be trusted, is how Hanny was killed. On January 31 1991, when she was 43 - three years younger than her mother when she was murdered - Klinkhamer beat her to death with what the police believe to have been some kind of wooden bat or handle. Then he dug a hole in the shed, dumped her in it and filled it with concrete. He used compost to disguise the smell of the rotting corpse. Six days later, he reported her missing, claiming that he had found her red bicycle at a nearby train station. At last, police launched an investigation.

Friends of Hanny's, including the Wieters, reported the couple's domestic quarrels to police. "I was quite certain that he did it but police couldn't prove it," Harry Wieters says. "It was not very professional what the police did. He was more intelligent than the police."

Donker describes the local police as "incompetent". But Peter Boomsma, spokesman for the regional police force at Groningen, says: "We didn't find anything so we couldn't charge Klinkhamer."

Oddly, there are plenty of neighbours who are still willing to speak well of him, despite his crime. "Richard Klinkhamer was an eccentric man but in our eyes a good man," says Coos Molenaar, who lives opposite. "Many times here he drank with us. He loved his life, he loved to write books. He built in his garden, big monuments. He never talked about his wife."

Had Donker agreed to publish Klinkhamer's blueprint for murder, Wednesday, Mince Day, he might have been discovered more quickly. As it was, Donker, a small but respected publisher who pops up at London trade fairs from time to time, didn't like the book, but suggested that Klinkhamer turn two chapters into a crime novel. This he did and the book that resulted, Ransom, sold around 2,000 copies, reasonable for the Dutch market. In Ransom, a man pretends to have stolen paintings from the Rembrandthuis gallery in Amsterdam, but, in fact, has hidden them in the gallery.

Having read the original book, however, Donker suspected Klinkhamer might have killed his wife and asked him. "It's not yet the time to talk about it," was the cryptic answer. Had the killing remained secret for another nine years, Klinkhamer could not have been prosecuted under the Dutch statute of limitations law. However, during his last years of freedom, he could hardly have done more to attract suspicion to himself, other than erecting signs to his wife's grave. "Everyone is able to murder someone, somewhere, suddenly," he would hint.

John Schoor, a journalist with De Volksrant, a Dutch newspaper, went to visit Klinkhamer's home with his girlfriend and left convinced that he had been passing time with a killer. "He was really working with the fear of people. He made a lot of jokes about dark things, death. It was spooky."

Once, while digging a hole in his garden, Klinkhamer pointed out to neighbours that it was big enough to accommodate a body. "He loved the notoriety," says Donker. "But at the same time, he told me his wife was the greatest love of his life."

In Holland, the gruesomely delicious irony of a crime writer killing his wife and then writing about it has led to public speculation that he killed her to write the book. But neighbours, his publisher and even friends of Hanny will have none of it.

"That's what people say, I am convinced not," says Donker. "I think the murder was an accident and then he got nervous and thought, my God, how can I get rid of the body? And then he put it under the shed."

As is the way of these things, Donker has now revised his opinion about Wednesday, Meat Day, and has already asked Richard Klinkhamer, through his solicitor, whether he would now like it to be published. But now, with a life sentence looming, Klinkhamer has declined.

While breaking up the concrete laid on the floor of the shed, the workmen turned up a skull, buried in a piece of clay a few metres below the surface. They went on to uncover a skeleton which a forensic scientist quickly identified from dental records as the remains of Hanny Klinkhamer. That evening, Richard Klinkhamer, 62, was arrested in Amsterdam. Next day he confessed to his wife's murder and he is now awaiting trial in prison in Leeuwarden, in the north-west of the country. The present owner of the house seems irritated by the events. "I've had nothing but trouble with this house," she says. The garden has been completely dug up and the spot where Hanny's body was discovered is marked by a thin pole, waving in the wind. A cement mixer whirrs and builders move around the garage and the green two-storey house. Can we come and see the garden? "Only if you are willing to pay 500 to 600 guilders. If you pay the money, you can come in; if you don't, you can leave." But others who knew Hanny have been paying their respects in various ways. On Wednesday, a small gathering of her colleagues and friends met in Ganzedijk and laid flowers for Hanny, who had been a paediatric nurse at a hospital in Winschoten, half a dozen miles away. Yesterday, offical tributes appeared in local newspapers. She has been buried, her friends say, somewhere quiet and beautiful. "She was a nice, intelligent woman. Everyone was very fond of her," says Harry Wieters, a near neighbour. It was Harry's wife, Marieke, an old friend of Hanny's from Amsterdam, who first introduced her to Ganzedijk. According to Dutch newspapers, Hanny's early life was marred, with eerie coincidence, by the murder of her mother. On July 15 1957, when she was just nine, Hanny discovered the dead body of her 46-year-old mother, Maria. She had been thrown downstairs by Hanny's father who then killed her with a hammer. Where he is now, or even if he's still alive, is not clear. Years passed and eventually Hanny rang her friend Marieke to report that she had met an entertaining, funny man named Richard Klinkhamer in Amsterdam. He was 10 years older and divorced, but she was in love. "She was obsessed by Klinkhamer," says Harry Wieters. Hanny wanted to marry Klinkhamer and bring him to Ganzedijk to start a new life and, in 1978, they moved to the area. Things seemed to go well at first, but then Klinkhamer, who was a former foreign legionnaire, sometime auditor and part-time author, began to drink heavily. He would hit Hanny and when he did, she would go to stay with other people. "I have seen her with blue marks on her body," says Wieters. Klinkhamer's writing career, however, began to take off. His first book, Obedient as a Dog, drew heavily on his experiences in the French Foreign Legion. The first thing they teach you, he said, is how to kill somebody; the second, how to dispose of a body properly. He later had a collection of short stories published, entitled Hotel Red. Like Hanny, Klinkhamer had an Austro-German background. During the war, he once told Willem Donker, that his mother had had an affair with an SS officer. He was in Austria with her when it was liberated by the Russians; he remembers that she was raped. On their return to Holland, his mother's head was shaved - the standard punishment meted out to women who had had liaisons with Nazis during the occupation. "It was a very dark chapter of the liberation," says Donker. "Later, he said, she had to make a living so she did for money what she had done for love during the war." Klinkhamer, according to Donker, had Nazi sympathies, although other acquaintances reject this. One of his books, Kruis of Munt (Heads or Tails), is a "faction" about the SS. His reasons for killing Hanny will probably never be known but alcohol may have been a factor. In the weeks leading up to her death, as their relationship deteriorated, he was drinking huge quantities of beer on his own at home. What is known, if Klinkhamer's account can be trusted, is how Hanny was killed. On January 31 1991, when she was 43 - three years younger than her mother when she was murdered - Klinkhamer beat her to death with what the police believe to have been some kind of wooden bat or handle. Then he dug a hole in the shed, dumped her in it and filled it with concrete. He used compost to disguise the smell of the rotting corpse. Six days later, he reported her missing, claiming that he had found her red bicycle at a nearby train station. At last, police launched an investigation. Friends of Hanny's, including the Wieters, reported the couple's domestic quarrels to police. "I was quite certain that he did it but police couldn't prove it," Harry Wieters says. "It was not very professional what the police did. He was more intelligent than the police." Donker describes the local police as "incompetent". But Peter Boomsma, spokesman for the regional police force at Groningen, says: "We didn't find anything so we couldn't charge Klinkhamer." Oddly, there are plenty of neighbours who are still willing to speak well of him, despite his crime. "Richard Klinkhamer was an eccentric man but in our eyes a good man," says Coos Molenaar, who lives opposite. "Many times here he drank with us. He loved his life, he loved to write books. He built in his garden, big monuments. He never talked about his wife." Had Donker agreed to publish Klinkhamer's blueprint for murder, Wednesday, Mince Day, he might have been discovered more quickly. As it was, Donker, a small but respected publisher who pops up at London trade fairs from time to time, didn't like the book, but suggested that Klinkhamer turn two chapters into a crime novel. This he did and the book that resulted, Ransom, sold around 2,000 copies, reasonable for the Dutch market. In Ransom, a man pretends to have stolen paintings from the Rembrandthuis gallery in Amsterdam, but, in fact, has hidden them in the gallery. Having read the original book, however, Donker suspected Klinkhamer might have killed his wife and asked him. "It's not yet the time to talk about it," was the cryptic answer. Had the killing remained secret for another nine years, Klinkhamer could not have been prosecuted under the Dutch statute of limitations law. However, during his last years of freedom, he could hardly have done more to attract suspicion to himself, other than erecting signs to his wife's grave. "Everyone is able to murder someone, somewhere, suddenly," he would hint. John Schoor, a journalist with De Volksrant, a Dutch newspaper, went to visit Klinkhamer's home with his girlfriend and left convinced that he had been passing time with a killer. "He was really working with the fear of people. He made a lot of jokes about dark things, death. It was spooky." Once, while digging a hole in his garden, Klinkhamer pointed out to neighbours that it was big enough to accommodate a body. "He loved the notoriety," says Donker. "But at the same time, he told me his wife was the greatest love of his life." In Holland, the gruesomely delicious irony of a crime writer killing his wife and then writing about it has led to public speculation that he killed her to write the book. But neighbours, his publisher and even friends of Hanny will have none of it. "That's what people say, I am convinced not," says Donker. "I think the murder was an accident and then he got nervous and thought, my God, how can I get rid of the body? And then he put it under the shed." As is the way of these things, Donker has now revised his opinion about Wednesday, Meat Day, and has already asked Richard Klinkhamer, through his solicitor, whether he would now like it to be published. But now, with a life sentence looming, Klinkhamer has declined.

webTitle: Boro fighers can earn Robbo a reprieve

fields.headline: Boro fighers can earn Robbo a reprieve
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man who knows a bloke who knows the trainer's wife, gives you the full SP on this week's football
fields.trailText: Mike Hodgkinson, our man who knows a bloke who knows the trainer's wife, gives you the full SP on this week's football.
fields.body:
Of all the places the fainthearted should definitely avoid this week, Middlesbrough's training ground must rate as the most fearsome. Bryan Robson was the exact opposite of a wuss on the pitch, and in his mission to field "11 fighters" against Coventry on Saturday he'll be dishing out a generous measure of grief - which means his depleted, demoralised and de-Gazza'd side should force the draw.

The Boro faithful will not be expecting much from their makeshift midfield but may have their hopes of some kind of result boosted by the form of striker Andy Campbell, who got the nod to play for England Under-21s against Argentina next Tuesday. The lad done extremely well during the recent absences of first choice hitmen Hamilton Ricard and Brian Deane.

There was a time, not so long ago, that a win at the Riverside was the toughest nut to crack in the Premiership, but Robson now knows that if doesn't return to those days fairly sharpish his head will roll - despite the continued front-of-house support from chairman Steve Gibson. Boro have won only one league game since the end of October and have greasy-poled down to 16th in the Premiership. Nul points from Coventry - to be followed swiftly by visiting Leeds - and more than one voice will be chanting for the final curtain. It's in situations like these that hard-case managers bring out the best in their players so, all things considered, the battling draw looks like the safest bet.

Bolton are warming up for their potentially epic quarter final FA Cup tie with Charlton by sneaking off to a secret location, which means either that they want to escape all unnecessary distractions or that they're practising free kicks so devious that they border on the supernatural. The former seems more likely but the Lancashire side may need a bit of hocus and plenty of pocus to get past Alan Curbishley's men.

Charlton will start barely a whisker shy of full strength on Saturday as Tuesday's record-breaking win against Fulham brought with it no new injury worries. The return of Mark Kinsella looks likely even though Andy Todd is ruled out of the clash with his former club by suspension. The visitors are more than likely to start favourites and can be backed to win with confidence.

There's another tempting away win on the cards in Huddersfield where Manchester City can continue their push for automatic promotion by seeing off the home side. However, one man who could make life difficult for Joe Royle's men is Zico, the 23-year-old midfielder from Thailand who pinched his name from the Brazilian legend. Until he scored three against York on Tuesday it seemed he had inherited little of the original Zico's talent, but now that he has answered his critics we could see much more from him. A first-scorer wager on him is in order, but for the victory stick with City.

Recommended treble

Middlesbrough v Coventry - draw

Bolton v Charlton - away win

Huddersfield v Manchester City - away win

fields.headline: Pass notes: Agatha Christie
fields.trailText: Age: 109, were she still alive.
fields.body:
Age: 109, were she still alive.

What, you mean she's dead? Good God! Whom do you suspect? Well, every single one of you in this 1920s country house (conveniently surrounded by thick footprintless snow, which eliminates anyone from the village) had reason to murder her.

Think, man! Actually, Britain's reclusive first queen of crime - born Torquay, 1890, died the bestselling novelist in English, outstripped in sales only by W Shakespeare - didn't die in circumstances as suspicious as those investigated by her detectives, Hercule Poirot and Miss Marple. But that's not to say various shady figures don't stand to make a killing out of her.

I knew it! The brigadier stood to make thousands from her demise! The parson was acting strangely too, come to think of it. An amusing speculation. Those in the money this time will be Hollywood and Christie's estate. After decades controlling film-makers' use of her novels, the estate is to loosen its grip.

I must say I had noticed something . . . suspicious about filmed Christie stories. An admirable deployment of the leetle grey cells, mon ami. Every picture - Murder on the Orient Express, Death on the Nile etc - has pretty much been forced to lift dialogue and period setting from the books.

But however did you find out? Let's put it down to intuition. Oh, and the fact that Mathew Pritchard, the author's grandson, told Daily Variety: "Everyone uses the excuse of the millennium for changing what they do, so why not? My grandmother wrote some wonderful books and we think her adventure stories and whodunits provide infinite possibilites for imaginative filmmakers."

Such as? Bruce Willis as Hercule Poirot in a remake of Death on the Nile set in a dystopic late 21st-century New York, entitled Homicide on the Hudson, perhaps?

Do say: This is a marvellous opportunity to bring Christie's work to an entirely new audience.

Don't say: Mechanical plots and wafer-thin characterisation? Hollywood will never stand for it.

West Ham have received special permission from the FA to sign a goalkeeper on loan from another Premiership club. Out-of-favour Spurs keeper Espen Baardsen is Harry Redknapp's number one target.

Daily Star Preston are hoping to sign former Dundee winger Ian Anderson, now at Toulouse.

Stockport are on the verge of signing Bury striker Ian Lawson for £400,000, beating off a bid from Sheffield United.

fields.headline: Job hunting
fields.standfirst: ... to save you the bother of reading them
fields.trailText: ... to save you the bother of reading them
fields.body:
30 Minutes...Before Your Job Interview, by June Lines (Kogan Page, £3)
Congratulations, you've got an interview. Are you terrified? If so, don't worry: half an hour alone with this book will "cure those pre-interview nerves". It all boils down to common sense, so just relax. An old school or regimental tie is normally a safe bet as far as dressing goes, and deodorant can only be a good thing.
Don't: pester your interviewer for travelling expenses before they've been offered. You might appear rude.

Buy it at BOL

The Perfect CV, by Max Eggert (Random House Business Books, £6.99)
The raison d'être of the CV is to secure an interview. That really is the only reason it exists. We all have an opinion on how a CV should be written, and "if you laid us out end to end we might go to the moon and back". But don't do that. Work on your CV instead. And don't be lazy when planning your resumé -just think of the poor soul who has to read 750 CVs week in, week out. Be snappy, be positive, be unique.
Don't: try to be cute, chatty or funny.

Buy it at BOL

36 Steps to the Job You Want, by Malcolm Hornby (FT/Prentice Hall, £13.99)
Are you a frog or are you a pike? Frogs are adaptable but allow themselves to be boiled alive because they are not motivated enough to jump out of ponds. Pikes have a tendency to hit their heads against glass partitions while trying to eat minnows, and then starve to death when the glass is removed. So don't be a frog or a pike. Choose a mentor, choose your goals, be proactive, and capitalise on your strengths.
Don't: Try any of the animal experiments at home.

Buy it at BOL

Great Answers to Tough Interview Questions, by Martin John Yate (Kogan Page, £8.99)
Make no mistake: "They" are creatures utterly devoid of pity. "They" will use your insecurities and weaknesses as weapons against you. "They" are interviewers. And you may be rest assured that they will ask you "tough, sneaky, mean, and lowdown questions" designed to destroy you. Fight back and prepare for every eventuality from the "wet fish handshake" to the nightmare "Why were you fired?" query.
Don't: wear make-up if you're a man.

Buy it at BOL

Write Your Own CV, by John Clarke (Right Way, £3.99)
The 21st-century job market is a hostile place: unemployment levels are high, technology is advancing at an unprecedented rate and humans are finding themselves replaced with computers on a daily basis. All in all, then, a decent CV might not be a bad idea. And, as each one of us is unique, each CV should be unique. So sell yourself as a specialist, and be sure to tell the truth, whether you are an estate agent or a dancer.
Don't: sound like a politician.

fields.headline: Herbert Schiller
fields.standfirst: Intellectual scourge of media manipulation and sceptic of the information revolution
fields.trailText: Some commentators may be enthused by the internet, the spread of new technologies, or simply the pleasures of soap opera, but for Herbert Schiller, who has died aged 80, the $100bn alliances between the likes of America On-line, Times Warner and EMI were of greater consequence. They symbolised a world of information dominated by consumerist values and commercial principles. Alongside Noam Chomsky, Schiller occupied a premier position as a critic of American media practice and policy.
fields.body:
Some commentators may be enthused by the internet, the spread of new technologies, or simply the pleasures of soap opera, but for Herbert Schiller, who has died aged 80, the $100bn alliances between the likes of America On-line, Times Warner and EMI were of greater consequence. They symbolised a world of information dominated by consumerist values and commercial principles. Alongside Noam Chomsky, Schiller occupied a premier position as a critic of American media practice and policy.

From the late 1960s, he persisted in emphasising the significance of age-old capitalist activities. He pioneered the political economy approach, insisting on the primacy of business imperatives in the realm of information. One of his abiding themes was the dangers of corporate takeovers of public institutions limiting possibilities of expression, submerging the majority in escapist entertainment and dulling the critical imagination.

Born in New York and raised there during the depression, Schiller retained his passion for the city - and his radicalism. He spent the last 30 years of his life in southern California, but regularly returned to his home city. The hard times of a decade when his father was unemployed remained an abiding influence.

He studied at City College, New York, alongside a cohort which included Melvyn Lasky, Seymour Lipset, Irving Kristol and Daniel Bell. He took a master's degree at Columbia and a doctorate from New York university. During the second world war he was a military economist, and, in defeated Germany, his observation of the curtailment of de-Nazification - with the cold war and the need to re- establish business confidence - left an indelible impression. He married Anita, a research librarian, in postwar Paris.

During the 1950s, Schiller taught economics to artists at New York's Pratt Institute of Art, keeping a low profile during the McCarthyite hysteria, when he held several part-time jobs and had a young family to support. He moved to the University of Illinois and, in 1969, to the University of California, San Diego, where the German Marxist philosopher Herbert Marcuse and the black American communist Angela Davis were teaching radical ideas. Schiller established a communications programme and made his department one of the best regarded in the world.

Handsome, tall and angular, he was a magnetic speaker. Arms flailing, and possessed of a passionate but sardonic humour, he lectured at his best without notes. This talent was wonderfully exploited in a Public Service Broadcasting television series, Herb Schiller Reads The New York Times, in which he presented an alternative account of the day's news straight to camera. By the 1980s, student radicalism in southern California had ebbed, yet he still enthralled undergraduates; they would applaud his classes - before going on to jobs at the likes of Disney or MTV.

Schiller travelled extensively, holding visiting positions in Amsterdam, Tampere in Finland, and Paris. He was in constant demand as a star speaker, a skill that contributed to his influential role in Unesco debates, where the free-flow-of-information doctrine began to be seen as a pro-west ideology. This criticism was a factor in the American and British withdrawal of financial aid from Unesco in the mid-1980s.

Schiller wrote for many publications, including Le Monde Diplomatique in France and the Nation in the US. Mass Communications And American Empire (1969) and The Mind Managers (1973) are probably his best-known studies. They stressed the propagandistic dimensions of mass media, and even the disguised ideology underlining the National Geographic magazine.

Schiller stood against information society utopians. Whenever business leaders enthused about new communications, he argued, they were selling wares rather than improving the knowledgeability of the public. In Culture Inc (1989), he highlighted the corporate invasion of public spaces. He warned that, as the sponsor came to dominate the means of expression, so information was increasingly treated as a private rather than a public good, with an associated decline in challenging ideas and reliable information, displaced by "infotainment". He also underlined in Who Knows? (1981) and Information Inequality (1996) the divisions that accompany the "information revolution" - low-income consumers receive a glut of "garbage information" that "tells them everything about anything of no significance", while the privileged get premier information services.

Schiller enjoyed the irony of living in a small but lovely house in La Jolla, an affluent Pacific coast town. Enthusiastic walkers, he and Anita relished their nightly walks through vacant streets amidst the armed response signs, electronic alarm systems, and the automobile - which ensured a thoroughly privatised existence.

Schiller is survived by his wife and two sons.

Frank Webster

Herbert Irving Schiller, critic and sociologist, born November 5 1919; died January 29 2000

During the second world war he was a military economist, and, in defeated Germany, his observation of the curtailment of de-Nazification - with the cold war and the need to re- establish business confidence - left an indelible impression. He married Anita, a research librarian, in postwar Paris. During the 1950s, Schiller taught economics to artists at New York's Pratt Institute of Art, keeping a low profile during the McCarthyite hysteria, when he held several part-time jobs and had a young family to support. He moved to the University of Illinois and, in 1969, to the University of California, San Diego, where the German Marxist philosopher Herbert Marcuse and the black American communist Angela Davis were teaching radical ideas. Schiller established a communications programme and made his department one of the best regarded in the world. Handsome, tall and angular, he was a magnetic speaker. Arms flailing, and possessed of a passionate but sardonic humour, he lectured at his best without notes. This talent was wonderfully exploited in a Public Service Broadcasting television series, Herb Schiller Reads The New York Times, in which he presented an alternative account of the day's news straight to camera. By the 1980s, student radicalism in southern California had ebbed, yet he still enthralled undergraduates; they would applaud his classes - before going on to jobs at the likes of Disney or MTV. Schiller travelled extensively, holding visiting positions in Amsterdam, Tampere in Finland, and Paris. He was in constant demand as a star speaker, a skill that contributed to his influential role in Unesco debates, where the free-flow-of-information doctrine began to be seen as a pro-west ideology. This criticism was a factor in the American and British withdrawal of financial aid from Unesco in the mid-1980s. Schiller wrote for many publications, including Le Monde Diplomatique in France and the Nation in the US. Mass Communications And American Empire (1969) and The Mind Managers (1973) are probably his best-known studies. They stressed the propagandistic dimensions of mass media, and even the disguised ideology underlining the National Geographic magazine. Schiller stood against information society utopians. Whenever business leaders enthused about new communications, he argued, they were selling wares rather than improving the knowledgeability of the public. In Culture Inc (1989), he highlighted the corporate invasion of public spaces. He warned that, as the sponsor came to dominate the means of expression, so information was increasingly treated as a private rather than a public good, with an associated decline in challenging ideas and reliable information, displaced by "infotainment". He also underlined in Who Knows? (1981) and Information Inequality (1996) the divisions that accompany the "information revolution" - low-income consumers receive a glut of "garbage information" that "tells them everything about anything of no significance", while the privileged get premier information services. Schiller enjoyed the irony of living in a small but lovely house in La Jolla, an affluent Pacific coast town. Enthusiastic walkers, he and Anita relished their nightly walks through vacant streets amidst the armed response signs, electronic alarm systems, and the automobile - which ensured a thoroughly privatised existence. Schiller is survived by his wife and two sons. Frank Webster Herbert Irving Schiller, critic and sociologist, born November 5 1919; died January 29 2000

webTitle: Who will win Labour's mayoral nomination?

fields.headline: Who will win Labour's mayoral nomination?
fields.trailText: Where are we?
fields.body:
Where are we?

The Labour ballot to choose its candidate for London mayor closed on February 15. The party has announced it will not announce the result until early on Sunday afternoon, ostensibly to give the three candidates time to query the complex process by which the vote is calculated. It also gives the media several days in which to indulge in frenzied speculation.

Who is winning?

The only indication of the result so far comes from the unions which have announced the results of their ballots or the way their block vote will go. In total, the union and affiliate organisations make up one third of the electoral college (with MPs and Labour members forming the other two thirds).

The Labour party will not reveal the exact share of the vote each union commands, because if one decides to abstain it will affect every other organisation's share of the electoral college. The following calculations are Guardian estimates.

The union votes declared so far

Frank Dobson has been backed by the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, Labour students and the CWS (south London co-op). He has also picked up a share of votes from the GMB, the TSSA, Usdaw and the Fabian Society, giving him 8.99% of the total vote so far.

Ken Livingstone has the support of the Transport and General Workers' Union, the Transport Salaried Staffs' Association, the Communication Workers Union, the Fire Brigades Union, the CRS (north London co-op), the Surrey CWS (Croydon co-op) and Aslef train drivers. He also has won support from a majority of GMB members, TSSA, Usdaw and the Fabian Society, giving him 16.6% of the electoral college so far.

It is estimated by the Guardian that Mr Livingstone will win about 23.5% of the total vote via the unions, Dobson will pick up around 9.4% of the total vote in this sector, and Glenda Jackson will win just 0.4%.

What about the MPs' vote?

The MPs, MEPs and Greater London Assembly candidates' vote is easier to predict, as most MPs have gone on record backing one of the candidates. Believed to enjoy the support of 43 MPs and all the MEPs and GLA candidates in the ballot, Mr Dobson will gather most of his share of the vote here, winning a further 27.9% of the electoral college. Mr Livingstone is likely to win just 4.5% of the college here, Ms Jackson 1%.

How will the Labour members' vote?

The first two sections of the electoral college will probably give Mr Dobson a head-start. According to Guardian calculations, he needs 37.8% of members' votes to win the electoral college outright, while Mr Livingstone needs 65.9% of members' votes to win the electoral college outright. If either MP fails to win that number of votes, the second-choice votes of those who initially backed Glenda Jackson will decide the election.

The results from unions which balloted their members are one indication of how ordinary people may be voting. Here, Ken Livingstone has consistently enjoyed more than 70% of the vote which, if repeated in the Labour members section, would see him crowned the clear winner.

But, even if Labour members are far from impressed with Millbank's attempts to thwart Mr Livingstone's candidacy and Tony Blair's appeals to back Mr Dobson, they are likely to have a stronger sense of loyalty to the leadership line than many union members.

The final result?

Too close to call. Log in here on Sunday afternoon to find out.
