webTitle: Heseltine warns pound campaign will not win votes

fields.headline: Heseltine warns pound campaign will not win votes
fields.trailText: Michael Heseltine last night fired a shot across the bows of the Tory leadership when he warned that William Hague's Keep the Pound campaign would fail to win any votes at the next election.
fields.body:
Michael Heseltine last night fired a shot across the bows of the Tory leadership when he warned that William Hague's Keep the Pound campaign would fail to win any votes at the next election.

The former deputy prime minister, who is to take part next week in a campaign against Tory Euro scepticism, echoed Tony Blair's view that the next election will be decided on bread and butter issues.

Speaking on BBC1's Question Time, Mr Heseltine said: "The main policy is not going to be save the pound because my own judgment is that there's not a lot of votes - moving votes - in the issue of Europe. That's why you get these derisory turnouts when it comes to European elections. The big issues at the next election will be what they always are - the economy, education, health."

His intervention will hardly come as a surprise to the Tory leadership which has reluctantly come to terms with the fervently pro-European views of the former deputy prime minister. Mr Heseltine is one of the few Tory "big beasts" left in the Commons and is a leading member of the Britain in Europe group which will launch a pro-European cam paign next week under the slogan Out of Europe Out of Work. But there will be irritation with Mr Heseltine at Central Office for dismissing Mr Hague's new Keep the Pound campaign just days after its launch.

The criticisms by Mr Heseltine echo warnings from Tory pollsters that the party's stance on Europe is backward-looking. The research, which was carried out before last summer's Euro elections, said voters were unlikely to change allegiance over the single currency because domestic issues are seen as more important.

Mr Hague believes the Tories' victory in last June's election shows his opposition to the single currency is a vote winner. Critics within the party point out the turn-out of less than 10% was so low that it was wrong to draw firm conclusions from the result.

John Maples, recently sacked by Mr Hague as shadow foreign secretary, warned this week that the Keep the Pound campaign could undermine the Tories at the next election if the Mr Hague decides to rule out a referendum on the euro in the next parliament.

"If he does that we will have a dead fox at our feet," Mr Maples wrote in the Times. "We need to set another one running now."

fields.headline: Teachers reject performance pay boycott
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: David Blunkett, the education secretary, yesterday got the green light for introducing performance pay in schools when the largest of the teaching unions dismissed a proposal for a boycott.
fields.body:
David Blunkett, the education secretary, yesterday got the green light for introducing performance pay in schools when the largest of the teaching unions dismissed a proposal for a boycott.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said it would offer guidance for members trying to pass a performance test that could bring them an extra £2,000 a year from September - and give support to any whose applications were rejected.

The union remains opposed to the government's decision to judge teacher's performance against the results achieved by their pupils. But its executive agreed by 21 votes to 19 that it could not ask members to forgo extra income in pursuit of this principle.

The decision cleared the way for Mr Blunkett to send out application forms over the next few weeks for teachers in England, at or above the £23,000 classroom maximum, to seek a performance review from their head.

The National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers has also disputed the plan for appraising staff, but its general secretary, Nigel de Gruchy, has indicated he would not stand in the way of members claiming extra money.

The Association of Teachers and Lecturers told its members they had "nothing to fear" from performance assessments, and the headteacher unions have accepted the scheme.

The government is providing £1bn over the next two years to fund performance increases, and Mr Blunkett expects a majority of experienced teachers to get them. Heads will be asked to judge whether staff deserve to pass a performance "threshold" to move on to a higher pay scale, rising to £30,000.

Mr McAvoy said: "The union continues to oppose payment by results, which is part of the threshold process. But it recognises that if the government imposes its will on the profession, many union members will seek to avail themselves of the additional £2,000.

"It is right for any trade union to give support to its members in such circumstances and that is what we intend to do ... The NUT has never sought to deny members financial benefits."

Mr McAvoy, however, criticised ministers for imposing "an invidious scheme" without listening to reasoned argument about the damage he said it would cause.

A union spokeswoman denied that the announcement was a u-turn. At the last annual conference, delegates instructed the executive to "prepare for industrial action up to and including strike action, should the government impose any of its proposals for performance-related pay".

That industrial action was taking the form of a boycott of annual appraisal - which was different from assessment against a new pay threshold, she said. "The battle is not over. We have fought and won before against payment by results, and we will win again. The system is not conducive to improving education. It is divisive and unfair."

The decision to support teachers applying for performance pay came after leftwing members of the union's executive narrowly failed to win backing for a boycott. They may seek to revive the proposal at the union's annual conference at Easter.

Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, said: "We welcome the NUT's decision. This is a huge opportunity for teachers, not a threat."

webTitle: Damp-eyed Ofsted shows its caring side

fields.headline: Damp-eyed Ofsted shows its caring side
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: After years of cultivating a tough image as the hammer of incompetent teachers, the office for standards in education was struggling to come to terms yesterday with the case of an inspector who was reduced to tears by the sheer inspirational brilliance of a deputy head.
fields.body:
After years of cultivating a tough image as the hammer of incompetent teachers, the office for standards in education was struggling to come to terms yesterday with the case of an inspector who was reduced to tears by the sheer inspirational brilliance of a deputy head.

The inspector - whose identity was being closely guarded by Ofsted to avoid professional embarrassment - was overcome with emotion during a lesson for four-year-olds at Christ Church primary in Hampstead, north London.

"This should not have come out publicly. This doesn't mean we are going soft," said the inspectorate's spokeswoman.

The incident occurred last month when the inspector, a former headteacher in her late 50s, attended a literacy hour being taught by Mark Stubbings, the deputy head.

Mr Stubbings said: "I was being very positive with the children, giving them a lot of praise. There was one boy in particular who managed to answer some quite difficult questions correctly. She said later she could see his self-esteem rise as he did so."

The inspector gave the lesson a top grade and told Mr Stubbings not to leave the profession. "Coming from an Ofsted inspector, it just blew me away. She had tears in her eyes as she said it and she was obviously very choked up," he said.

The case is a far cry from the normal run of inspections, described by Tim Brighouse, chief education officer in Birmingham, as a "reign of terror".

But yesterday Linda Carter, headteacher of Christ Church primary, said she was delighted with Ofsted's friendlier face.

 Ofsted announced the appointment of Stephen Grix, a sixth form college principal in Walthamstow, north-east London, as head of inspection for post-16 education. Mr Grix, 43, left school at 15 with no qualifications and started work in 1971 as a bricklayer.

webTitle: Bullied girl taken home by mother

fields.headline: Bullied girl taken home by mother
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A 13-year-old girl who was assigned her own "bodyguard" to protect her from school bullies was yesterday taken home by her mother after a further incident at her Nottingham comprehensive.
fields.body:
A 13-year-old girl who was assigned her own "bodyguard" to protect her from school bullies was yesterday taken home by her mother after a further incident at her Nottingham comprehensive.

The mother of Amie Salmon said her daughter would remain out of the school until the headmaster had taken steps to exclude the gang of girls who had bullied her for almost a year.

Yesterday Tim Moralee, headteacher of Glaisdale school, defended his decision to offer her the protection of a form tutor, which he claimed was a temporary measure until a full inquiry into the bullying took place.

But Amie stayed at school for just 90 minutes yesterday morning before ringing her mother in tears and asking to be collected. Mr Moralee confirmed that she was approached by one of the girls in the gang of up to 15 teenagers.

Mr Moralee said: "We have put in place a system where she can go to a tutor whenever she feels the need. We are obviously taking a very sympathetic line with her while we investigate any allegations against other pupils." He hoped the investigation would be completed in the next few days.

Mrs Salmon said: "Amie will not be going back until the girls that have been bullying her are gone. I am sure that they will be excluded."

fields.headline: One More Kiss
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A bittersweet drama, competently put together, boasting honest performances from good actors - and yet somehow it never manages to be plausible for a single moment
fields.body:
One More Kiss, directed by Vadim Jean, is a bittersweet drama, competently put together, boasting honest performances from good actors - and yet somehow it never manages to be plausible for a single moment as a reflection of real lives or real emotions. Valerie Edmond is Sarah, a feisty, bonny, glossy-haired young woman who relinquishes her high-powered job in New York and comes home to a small Scottish village because she has brain cancer and wishes to spend the few months she has left in the company of Sam (Gerard Butler), her old lover. But Sam is now happily married to Charlotte (Valerie Gogan), who is understandably bewildered and resentful about this intrusion from the past.

One More Kiss could have been a subtle, interesting movie about the duel between Sarah and Charlotte for Sam's affections. Instead, it becomes a tiresome account of Sarah's irrepressible, life-affirming Pollyanna spirit, which in particular involves putting some oomph back into her gloomy old dad (James Cosmo), who spends his time slumped in an armchair, not appreciating the precious gift of life. The movie's view of death is immature and incoherent, culminating in Sarah's chirpy videoed address to those attending her funeral, in which she tells them not to think of her death as a gloomy "end", but to rage, rage against the dying of the light.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Mickey Blue Eyes | Never Been Kissed | Prague Duet
fields.trailText: Mickey Blue Eyes | Never Been Kissed | Prague Duet
fields.body:
Mickey Blue Eyes
Rental
Universal Pictures Cert 15
***

Those of you who could barely raise a smile on behalf of Notting Hill will, I think, find an acceptable amount of chucklement from Hugh Grant's rather nifty new comedy. You'll probably know that it's Hugh meets the mob, but careful plotting and some inspired moments make it considerably funnier and less stereotyped than the high concept suggests.

Old floppy - his hair gets a plot mention of its own for the second film running and may soon have its own agent - is an auctioneer who is about to propose to his girlfriend (Jeanne Tripplehorn) although he has yet to meet her father (James Caan). First he meets Vinny, Carmine and Louie. "Mostly family then?" he enquires, with unknowing accuracy.

Caan plays a rare comedy role against expectation (he's more Soprano than Corleone this time) and the film quickly gets you on its side with a superbly realised spiralling scene in a Chinese restaurant where Grant tries to arrange a proposal through a prearranged fortune cookie. The minor mobsters, led by a scene-stealing veteran Burt Young, come closer to parody than Caan but only James Fox, as a silly-arse Englishman, is allowed to take it too far by director Kelly Makin, from TV's Kids in the Hall.

There's fun to be had as the gangsters use Grant for money-laundering by selling hideous paintings through his auction house and the "fahgeddaboudit" scene (as Caan gives Grant elocution lessons to try to pass muster as a mobster) has been much parroted around the office.

The elaborate ending nearly becomes one wedding and four funerals. It's energetic and amiable and the cast looks like it had a good time. In tone, it's a bit like The Freshman, Brando's Godfather pisstake and not a bit like the unwatchable Mafia!, thank God. Mickey Blue Eyes fits my Hugh Grant theory that he's at his best in fish-out-of-water roles designed for maximum embarrassment. Just in films, obviously.

Never Been Kissed
Rental
Fox Pathé Cert 12
**

I was getting so used to the high standard of high-school comedies after Rushmore, 10 Things and Cruel Intentions that this rather mundane distant relative of As You Like It came as a bit of a shock. Drew Barrymore is the gauche copy editor at the Chicago Sun-Times who is sent to do an undercover exposé of high-school life, which also gives her a second chance to be a more popular student after being known as Josie Grossie first time round.

Barrymore is a bit of a chameleon and proves she can do mousy as convincingly as she can vamp it up (as in Poison Ivy) but there's little attempt to make the set-up believable and she's not given much to work on. Raja Gosnell's film remains resolutely on a traditional sit-com level and feels overblown at 107 minutes. David Arquette, taking a vacation from the Scream series, plays her brother. If I see one more film centring on the prom, I may do a series of screams myself.

Prague Duet
Rental
Warner Home Video Cert 15
***

Gina Gershon is an American academic abroad who finds herself meeting some extremely hard-drinking and hard-smoking Czechs and falls in love with a dissident writer who is charismatic, very hairy and a potential minister of culture - not improbable in a country where the president is a former dissident playwright.

Old floppy - his hair gets a plot mention of its own for the second film running and may soon have its own agent - is an auctioneer who is about to propose to his girlfriend (Jeanne Tripplehorn) although he has yet to meet her father (James Caan). First he meets Vinny, Carmine and Louie. "Mostly family then?" he enquires, with unknowing accuracy. fields.headline: You Only Live Once
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is virtuoso film-making in the service of a riveting story: a classic
fields.body:
The National Film Theatre's Fritz Lang season continues with his unmissable 1937 thriller, You Only Live Once. It stars Henry Fonda as Eddie Taylor, the ex-convict trying to go straight but inexorably sucked back into a life of crime by an unforgiving society and the ill-fated, well-meaning interventions of his young bride, Joan (Sylvia Sidney), who eventually joins him in a prototypical Bonnie-and-Clyde dash for freedom.

The movie combines the lineaments of a noir thriller with those of a classical tragedy: Eddie is brought low by a malign, inscrutable fate, which dictates that it seems to be this sweet-natured woman's love for him that will enforce a series of events leading to his violent death. But it is precisely this violent end that is the true sacrament of their marriage, which, in its poignancy and intensity, transcends anything in the bourgeois, homebody lives they had promised themselves.

Eddie is a "three-time loser": a former armed robber with three convictions; a fourth would mean life. He is paroled because the district attorney (Barton MacLane) has a hopeless tendresse for his secretary, Joan, Eddie's fiancée - one of the many black comic ironies that underscore this picture. Eddie loses his truck-driving job because he's out looking for the perfect cottage for them; they are turfed out of a honeymoon hotel because the proprietor recognises him, and then he is implicated in another bank job, which raises the spectre of the electric chair - and Lang keeps us in the dark about his innocence. This is virtuoso film-making in the service of a riveting story: a classic.

fields.headline: Gary Sinyor
fields.trailText: What was the first film you saw?
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw?

The Ten Commandments. Growing up in Manchester then suddenly seeing this guy wandering around the desert, made it visually and devotionally like nothing I'd experienced before.

What's your favourite film?

The Godfather Part II because of what he does with Michael Corleone, who has the potential not to follow that tragic route. And I can watch When Harry Met Sally, The Graduate and Midnight Express any time of the day or night.

What was the last film you walked out of?

An offensive Turkish film called No Mercy, No Future in 1982, which is about a woman in Germany who thinks that if she sleeps with lots of Turkish men she'll become the Messiah. I left during a bloody sex scene after one of her abortions. The only other film I've walked out of was Jarman's Sebastiane. Latin-speaking people throwing frisbees is quintessentially boring.

What's your most erotic movie moment?

When Nicole Kidman tries to seduce that young boy in To Die For. Every guy in the cinema was thinking: "I wish that had happened to me when I was a teenager."

What's the most annoying habit in a cinema?

In America, the guy who sat next to me in Star Wars - The Phantom Menace, ate an entire meal. He had this Mexican burrito in a plastic container and every 10 minutes he'd take a huge bite.

When did you last snog in the cinema?

Never, because I'm watching the film. I'm happy to hold hands or to hug or to offer tissues for comfort, but the idea of going to the cinema as a sexual experience is beyond me.

What's your favourite snatch of dialogue?

In Bananas, when Woody Allen gets off a plane as the South American dictator wearing a false beard, there's a completely gratuitous scene between him, the US ambassador and a translator. They all keep repeating the same lines. It's so ridiculous it's wonderful.

Which actor would you most like to be?

Al Pacino. I once met him in a room with 2,000 people, but there was only one person there.

Which actress?

Katharine Hepburn or Audrey Hepburn. They had class, which is something missing from cinema today. When you watch the award ceremonies, they all look like beautiful girls with big chests who've somehow made it. Meg Ryan is a modern exception.

When did you last hide under your seat?

Scream 1. I spent the whole film screaming.

Last time you cried?

I cried in Frank Darabont's The Green Mile, when Tom Hanks, the chief warden on death row, is going to talk to one of the murderers about his last hour. My favourite crying moment is in The Elephant Man when John Hurt recites the psalm and you realise how awful his life has been.

Are you a big Buster Keaton fan?

No. There's a certain amount of slapstick I can take, but it's limited. I thought what Keaton did in Seven Chances was impressive, but I have no real desire to see it again. Although one critic said we remained very faithful to Seven Chances, The Bachelor wasn't intended as a remake.

 Gary Sinyor directed The Bachelor, which is released today.

fields.headline: A face in the crowd
fields.standfirst: Being John Malkovich is about ownership of the self and celebrity, says Charlie Higson. But you're probably just reading this because you recognise his name off the TV, aren't you?
fields.trailText: Being John Malkovich is about ownership of the self and celebrity, says Charlie Higson. But you're probably just reading this because you recognise his name off the TV, aren't you?
fields.body:
As any internet user knows, there are countless sites devoted to shots of celebrities in the nude and there's possibly an even bigger number of celebrity fakes sites. A celebrity fake is where you take the head of a starlet and, via the unending magic of computers, stick it on the body of a porn model. Isn't technology wonderful? So what if Meg Ryan has never done an explicit sex scene? So what if Jennifer Aniston has never shown the world her breasts? You can find endless shots of them performing outré sex acts.

It's a big industry, celebrity fakes, and the craft that goes into some of these pictures is extraordinary. Obviously it's mostly women but there are a few men - David Duchovny and the blokes off Star Trek are particular favourites.

You'd have to search far and wide, though, for a celebrity fake of John Malkovich. He's not exactly in the top 10 sex gods list, though I do remember several female acquaintances getting quite hot and bothered over his stage appearance in Burn This. But, let's face it, he's not boy band material, even the gawky ugly one that's there to make the others look prettier, not with his "male pattern baldness, and too prominent brow" (a line from his new film, Being John Malkovich). The reason I bring this up is that there's a scene in Being John Malkovich that's unsettlingly reminiscent of celebrity fakes sites.

The film is the surreal new instant-cult, movie from rock video director Spike Jonze (pronounced Jones, and not to be confused with the other Spike Jones, who made wacky comedy records in the 40s and 50s.) The scene involves Malkovich, who plays himself, ending up in a world entirely populated by John Malkoviches. That's to say there are voluptuous women with stuck-on Malkovich heads, young men with Malkovich heads, old men, hell, there's even a dwarf. Is it the ultimate existential nightmare? Is it a telling indictment of celebrity culture? Or is it just a funny scene with some neat computer-generated visuals?

It's that type of film, you see, you can never work out if it's really, really, profound or just mucking about. It will, I'm afraid, generate a forest of comment in serious papers, like this one, with too many sections to fill, What is the nature of celebrity? What is the nature of self? And how does the weird relationship between fan and celebrity work? You can look forward to loads of articles like the ones we had to endure when The Truman Show and EdTV came out. Oh, Christ, I'm writing one now...

So... Being John Malkovich. Some people are going to claim this is one of the finest films ever made - dark, funny and strange - others will want to throw rocks at the screen. A brief outline of its plot should let you know which camp you're more likely to pitch your tent in, so here it is: "Man finds secret portal to the inside of John Malkovich's head." Or, in the words of its director, "The film is about New York City, a puppeteer, a tragic marriage, a chimp, a boss, a receptionist, another woman, an actor, the New Jersey Turnpike and a plate of lasagne."

Still not sure? Well, how about this. John Cusack, the "hero", a down-at-heel street puppeteer, takes a filing job on the 7½th floor of an office block, where the lift stop between levels, the ceilings are half height and everyone walks in a crouch. Funny or stupid? It's destined to be one of those revered cult movies that exist somewhere on the fringes between surrealism and science fiction, - like Eraserhead, Brazil, Repo Man, Pi and their ilk.

I enjoyed the film. It's nothing like most American films being made these days, but it didn't totally win me over, but then I'd had a wisdom tooth out on the day I saw it. Sorry, you really don't want to know about me, you want to know about the film. Or do you?

Are you reading this because you're interested in Being John Malkovich, or because you saw that it was written by Charlie Higson, a name you vaguely recognise off TV? Why? I mean, why, really, is the opinion of a celebrity more valid than anyone else's? When I was younger, reading the NME was de rigueur, and you'd be constantly amused by the parade of idiotic pop stars being asked their opinions on politics and world affairs. They just play guitars, for God's sake, how can they be expected to sort out the problems in Northern Ireland?

Just the other night, Geri Spice was on TV gallivanting around the world emoting at this and that for the United Nations. Why? What does celebrity mean in the modern world? Who is John Malkovich? Why would anyone want to be him? And what exactly is a "portal" to the inside of his head? Well, it's this, like, you know, sort of tunnel thing, and when you, like, er, go into it, you get to look out of John Malkovich, you see what he sees, feel what he feels, for about 15 minutes before being spat out and dropped by the side of the road.

I'm glad we've cleared that up.

So, that's what the film's about, then, but what's it about? At the risk of being pretentious, it's about the ownership of the self, and the idea that celebrity is a commodity. There, I've said it. I mean, obviously, for most people watching, it's not about that at all - it's about "a secret portal to the inside of John Malkovich's head." But when the Guardian's paying you, you are compelled to fork over all those modern obsessions like stalking, docu-soaps, Stars in Their Eyes, Ali G and celebrity fakes. I don't need to go into any of that here now, because you already know what I'd say; that we are living in a world where there has been a catastrophic blurring of the line between ordinary people and celebrities.

So how does Malkovich fit into all this? Why was he picked to be the subject of this film? The film-makers claim they used him partly because he has one of those names that the more you say it the funnier it sounds, and the less meaning it has, but he was an inspired choice in many other ways. You might think, "Why John Malkovich? Why not a bigger star?" John Cusack, and definitely Cameron Diaz (who plays his wife) are better known to cinemagoers than Malkovich, so why not "Being John Cusack"? No, it doesn't work, does it? Where's the fun in visiting John Cusack?

There's something so right about Malkovich. He's one of those actors that most people know but can' t always quite place; he's been in some big movies but never as "The Star". And he's also seen as being a bit pompous and serious, a proper actor, a stage actor. He's great to take the piss out of, and he wouldn' t mind me saying that because he spends this whole film taking the piss out of himself, in a very un-American way.

When Cusack first "enters him", we find him to be a slightly sad and lonely figure living all alone in an ascetic apartment. The first person he meets is a limo driver who knows him but can't quite place him. And this happens over and over again, even the main protagonists of the film don't really know who he is, they just respond to the fact that he's famous, and that's all that's important. Soon there's a queue of people lining up to pay to enter Malkovich, but for at least one of them, he wasn't their first choice of celebrity to visit. After a while the various visitors to Malkovich aren' t even bothered about who he really is anyway; they use him as a puppet to act out their own fantasies and desires.

The real Malkovich slowly disappears, and you end up feeling sorry for the poor man. He has become nothing more than a vessel for the other characters' obsessions, a commodity, an object to be used just as other celebrities' bodies are used in celebrity fakes sites; it doesn't matter that it isn't real. By the end of the film he becomes "the Malkovich vessel".

And that's what a star is, a vessel for our own projections and fantasies. A living embodiment, a voodoo doll for our desires. Stories have always existed to be told around the fire in the safe confines of the home. Nowadays, films and television create alternative lives for us, we watch soap operas instead of connecting with other people. We play computer games in which we become the characters. We do nothing. We live through the stars. And the stars become the roles they play.

Who knows the names of the characters played by most stars in their films? No one. We go to see "a Clint Eastwood movie" or a Tom Cruise film. The character on the screen, the star, and your image of the star are one and the same thing. The only person who knows different is the star himself. And who cares what they think?

Stars are public property. There is a feeling that if you go on television, then you are owned by the viewers, you owe them something. "Hey, we watched you, you came into our homes, you belong to us." We've all experienced that moment when you're walking down the street and you pass somebody familiar off the TV screen, and, before you clock who it really is, you nod and say hello, just to be polite, because after all you know this person. And then you realise that of course you don't know them. But sometimes they nod back.

The fan controls the star.

Film stars belong to us. Celebrities end up being horribly familiar and God-like at the same time. In the olden days, mad people thought God was talking to them. Nowadays mad people believe that Elvis is talking to them, or Jodie Foster, or John Lennon. Why do fans who get totally obsessed with a celebrity end up wanting to kill them? Do they blame the celebrity for their obsession, or do they set murder as the ultimate form of control?

I don't think this is in any way a new phenomenon; we've always had a controlling relationship with our gods and heroes. Look at the myths of ancient Greece. Somebody made them up. They grew like exotic coral around the bare bones of history. Over the years they were added to, embellished, changed for the story-tellers' needs. The gods were there to be used for human ends. To make a point.

Did they really believe that on top of Mount Olympus, a cosmic soap opera was being enacted? You might say that our modern heroes, soap actors, LA film stars, footballers and TV chefs are not cut out for godlike status, but let's not forget that the classical gods were a pretty scummy bunch of murderers, cheats and womanisers, petty-minded, jealous, childish and vengeful, and the so-called heroes weren't much better: Hercules killed his wife and family in a drunken rage, Theseus was thrown off a cliff, and Jason ended up sad and lonely after Medea killed their children.

Celebrities are meant to fuck up, to blow it all, to marry the most beautiful starlet in the world and then cheat on her, to become alcoholics and drug addicts, to kill people, to go into rehab, to go into prison, to go mad. They do it all for us, so that we don't have to.

 Being John Malkovich is released on March 17. It has three Oscar nominations: direction, screenplay and supporting actress (Catherine Keener).

The real Malkovich slowly disappears, and you end up feeling sorry for the poor man. He has become nothing more than a vessel for the other characters' obsessions, a commodity, an object to be used just as other celebrities' bodies are used in celebrity fakes sites; it doesn't matter that it isn't real. By the end of the film he becomes "the Malkovich vessel". And that's what a star is, a vessel for our own projections and fantasies. A living embodiment, a voodoo doll for our desires. Stories have always existed to be told around the fire in the safe confines of the home. Nowadays, films and television create alternative lives for us, we watch soap operas instead of connecting with other people. We play computer games in which we become the characters. We do nothing. We live through the stars. And the stars become the roles they play. Who knows the names of the characters played by most stars in their films? No one. We go to see "a Clint Eastwood movie" or a Tom Cruise film. The character on the screen, the star, and your image of the star are one and the same thing. The only person who knows different is the star himself. And who cares what they think? Stars are public property. There is a feeling that if you go on television, then you are owned by the viewers, you owe them something. "Hey, we watched you, you came into our homes, you belong to us." We've all experienced that moment when you're walking down the street and you pass somebody familiar off the TV screen, and, before you clock who it really is, you nod and say hello, just to be polite, because after all you know this person. And then you realise that of course you don't know them. But sometimes they nod back. The fan controls the star. Film stars belong to us. Celebrities end up being horribly familiar and God-like at the same time. In the olden days, mad people thought God was talking to them. Nowadays mad people believe that Elvis is talking to them, or Jodie Foster, or John Lennon. Why do fans who get totally obsessed with a celebrity end up wanting to kill them? Do they blame the celebrity for their obsession, or do they set murder as the ultimate form of control? I don't think this is in any way a new phenomenon; we've always had a controlling relationship with our gods and heroes. Look at the myths of ancient Greece. Somebody made them up. They grew like exotic coral around the bare bones of history. Over the years they were added to, embellished, changed for the story-tellers' needs. The gods were there to be used for human ends. To make a point. Did they really believe that on top of Mount Olympus, a cosmic soap opera was being enacted? You might say that our modern heroes, soap actors, LA film stars, footballers and TV chefs are not cut out for godlike status, but let's not forget that the classical gods were a pretty scummy bunch of murderers, cheats and womanisers, petty-minded, jealous, childish and vengeful, and the so-called heroes weren't much better: Hercules killed his wife and family in a drunken rage, Theseus was thrown off a cliff, and Jason ended up sad and lonely after Medea killed their children. Celebrities are meant to fuck up, to blow it all, to marry the most beautiful starlet in the world and then cheat on her, to become alcoholics and drug addicts, to kill people, to go into rehab, to go into prison, to go mad. They do it all for us, so that we don't have to.  Being John Malkovich is released on March 17. It has three Oscar nominations: direction, screenplay and supporting actress (Catherine Keener).

webTitle: From the Edge of the City

fields.headline: From the Edge of the City
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: There is something a little naive and redundant about the movie, with more than a few urban youth cliches - but there are interesting moments as well
fields.body:
Like Ana Kokkinos's recent Head On, From the Edge of the City, directed by Constantinos Giannaris, is about fractured, alienated identity in modern Greece: urban identity, national identity and sexual identity.

It centres on Sacha (Stathis Papadopoulos), an ethnic Greek from the Black Sea area whose forbears were ethnically cleansed by Stalin and who returned to Greece from Kazakhstan in 1990 following the collapse of the Soviet Union, speaking a Greek-Russian hybrid. He and his contemporaries get by with casual jobs, turning tricks with older Greek men, doing drugs - and Sacha gets involved in the exploitation business, buying a "share" in a desperate Russian prostitute, with whom he falls in love.

Set against the parched, unforgiving landscape of suburban Athens, Giannaris's film is humid and clamorous, dramatising the incidental human aspect of these huge historical forces, while showing how weirdly ignorant of history his characters are. Sacha and his friends at one point argue about what happened in Chernobyl and agree it was where America dropped the atom bomb. There is something a little naive and redundant about the movie, with more than a few urban youth cliches - but there are interesting moments as well, particularly Sacha's surreal dreams, both of his own childhood and of his future traditional Greek wedding, enacted in a strange, silent cornfield.

fields.headline: Secrets and librettos
fields.standfirst: Mike Leigh's first period piece is perfectly respectable, but  it's no Life is Sweet, says Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A little unsatisfying all round, though there are some richly enjoyable set-pieces and performances
fields.body:
Topsy-Turvy really is a notable, even a remarkable, development for director Mike Leigh. It is a historical costume drama about the fraught working relationship of WS Gilbert and Sir Arthur Sullivan in the creation of their genteel, imperishably popular operettas - the principals played with marvellous gusto by Jim Broadbent and Allan Corduner, and Sullivan's music richly and affectionately rendered in the score by Carl Davis.

Broadbent is the Victorian literary workhorse, harassed husband, and all-round curmudgeon, gruffly heedless of his wife's frustrated maternal needs. Corduner is the worldly but highly-strung composer, frequenting Parisian brothels, maintaining an American mistress and longing to escape the middlebrow embrace of the D'Oyly Carte company to write something really great.

Here they are: the rows, the tantrums, the Guinness-and-oyster suppers, the box-office nightmares, the curtain-call triumphs, the monocles and the mutton-chop whiskers. With its bone-china epigrams on and off stage, nothing could be further from a contemporary realist comedy devised through improvisation; this is a film billed as being "written and directed by Mike Leigh" and whatever happened in rehearsal, written is undoubtedly how it seems.

Playing the D'Oyly Carte stalwart Richard Temple, Timothy Spall gets a big laugh with his chiselled epigram counselling against the eating of shellfish: "I had an aunt choke on a scallop at Herne Bay!" When one actor, Durward Lely (Kevin McKidd) stroppily protests that he never goes without a corset on stage, Gilbert twinklingly inquires: "What - never ?" And when Gilbert and his wife visit a Japanese exhibition, which is shown as inspiring The Mikado, his wife claims to have seen three-minute Japanese ladies there and, with no more of a hint than that, we can flatter ourselves that we can see the unconscious germ of creation.

Here is the playfulness and allusiveness of a Tom Stoppard or a Peter Shaffer, and it is very writerly. (There is even a chaotic Mikado rehearsal scene in which one actor is wearing a bowler hat and another snaps: "A nice mess you've got us into!" Is Leigh suggesting the unconscious G&S procreation of another great music-hall double act? We are deep in Stoppard country now.)

Where the looser, improvisational current of Mike Leigh's style survives in Topsy-Turvy is in its resistance to a linear narrative. This is a modern-seeming collection of "scenes from the life", covering the eventful, but relatively short span in the G&S career, from the premiere of Princess Ida in 1884 to the genesis and eventual first night of The Mikado one year later. (We do not, for example see WS Gilbert's death from a heart attack in 1911, having reputedly rescued a woman from drowning in a lake in his country estate in Harrow - I would pay good money to see Jim Broadbent play that sensational scene.)

Like Churchill's pudding, Topsy-Turvy seems to be without a theme. At first, it looks like it's going to be about Sullivan breaking up the double act because he wants greater things and cannot bear working with the same old stuff from Gilbert, the facile paradox, the clockwork plot reversal: the usual topsy-turviness. But then Gilbert comes back on board for The Mikado, which, although brilliant and sprightly, does not obviously answer Sullivan's objections. That consideration is never mentioned again, and there is no agonised conflict between High Art and lucrative middlebrow hackwork.

Sullivan also begins the film very unwell, evidently reliant on gruesome injections; but soon he's right as rain, and the whole idea of secret illness and addiction behind the creative greasepaint is cursorily transferred at the end to the actor and humorist George Grossmith (Martin Savage), who, with a fastidious, rather Holmesian wince, reveals a forearm covered in needle wounds.

Are we perhaps being invited to see the simpering good taste of operetta as the flip-side of the Victorian stews, à la Ronald Pearsall's The Worm in the Bud? Not really, no. Sullivan cavorts with some topless French filles and Gilbert is accosted by a shrieking tart in an alley, but here, too, there's nothing to go on. The words and music of the light opera are not made to offer much in the way of ironic commentary on the mentality of the age.

In fact, it is possible to spend two hours and 40 minutes waiting for this film to start: and I couldn't help wondering if we really needed every bit of those long rehearsal scenes.

In pictures such as Life is Sweet and Secrets & Lies, with their access to more unassuming, ordinary lives, far away from the melodramatic stage of the Savoy theatre, Leigh's meandering course adds up to something substantial by the final credits. There is a gradual accretion of emotional power and sensibility, a realisation that we have come through something together with the characters. But that is dependent on ready sympathy and an immersion in everyday life - or, at any rate, a recognisable version of the everyday - and the glittering exotica and Victoriana of Topsy-Turvy resists this.

Ultimately, it is a little unsatisfying all round, though there are some richly enjoyable set-pieces and performances, particularly from Shirley Henderson, who has a marvellous feline cunning and sensuality as the tippling actress Leonora Braham.

fields.headline: Beach blanket Babylon
fields.trailText: Avoid big movie premieres in Hollywood. Chances are you'll be blinded by the flashbulbs and TV cameras lining the red carpet, and deafened by the starstruck yells of idiot tourists and the growls of gridlocked limo-drivers. "Yo, that's him! " "Aw, bullshit. That tuxedo's still got the Salvation Army delousing powder on it." At which point, fearful of being lynched for my sartorial shortcomings, I quicken my pace up the catwalk.
fields.body:
Avoid big movie premieres in Hollywood. Chances are you'll be blinded by the flashbulbs and TV cameras lining the red carpet, and deafened by the starstruck yells of idiot tourists and the growls of gridlocked limo-drivers. "Yo, that's him! " "Aw, bullshit. That tuxedo's still got the Salvation Army delousing powder on it." At which point, fearful of being lynched for my sartorial shortcomings, I quicken my pace up the catwalk.

Inside things are rarely any better. All us riff-raff must wait until the stars and their bleating retinues have been shepherded into their roped-off Celeb-Quarantine Pen midway up the centre aisle. The lights dim only after they've completed such post-graduate studies and avant-garde experiments as are necessary to redefine the phrase "fashionably late". In the cheap seats meanwhile, we sweat and curse and seethe.

As Nathanael West wrote (of the waves at Venice Beach) in The Day of the Locust: "After you've seen one, you've seen them all." Same with premieres. Less than a page after he writes those words, West's dyspeptic portrait of 1930s Hollywood climaxes with a gigantic riot-cum-lynching at the gala premiere of a Gary Cooper movie. "At the sight of their heroes, the crowd would turn demoniac. Some little gesture, either too pleasing or too offensive, would start it moving and then nothing but machine guns would stop it."

West's riot is sparked by a man named, of all things, Homer Simpson. He stomps a 10-year-old boy to death on Hollywood Boulevard as a huge and increasingly demented crowd congregates outside Grauman's Chinese Theater ("Kahn's Persian" in the novel). When the novel's protagonist Tod Hackett, a studio set designer, also gets caught up in the crazed mob, he has a vision in which a huge mural that he's painted on his apartment wall comes violently to life in his mind (his leg's broken, he's hallucinating).

As Joan Didion has pointed out, the painting conjoins in a single image the two greatest fears that have beset Angelenos since the 1920s: incineration and civil unrest. Tod's painting, a madhouse-Goya nightmare of flames, anguish and mayhem, is called The Burning of Los Angeles.

Two weeks ago I suddenly found myself in possession of two tickets to the world premiere of The Beach, starring Leonardo DiCaprio, at Mann's Chinese Theater. So my date (we'll call her The Girl of the Golden West) and I dined at Hollywood's oldest restaurant, the 81-year-old Musso & Frank's, just as Tod does in the novel before his own considerably more terminal premiere.

We ate what Tod ate - "a steak and a double Scotch", plus another double Scotch - and to amuse myself, I slipped the waiter a five-spot and told him it was Golden West's birthday. If you do this, your after-dinner coffee will be enlivened by the magically surreal sight of Musso's ancient, uniformed waiters shuffling toward you en masse bearing a slice of cake with a single lighted candle, and singing "Happy Birthday" in the grimmest, most funereal baritones. In the heart of Hollywood, home of the invisible face-lift and the miracle arse-tuck, there's no tonic more revivifying than the sight of Death's legions marching towards you so unsteadily.

And that, ladies and gentlemen, was the sum of our entertainment that evening. Perhaps it was optimistic of me to crave a wholesale breakdown of social controls and the onset of raw public mania on Hollywood Boulevard. I was privileged to view the 1992 LA Riots from the roof of my building in Koreatown, where I then lived, so technically I've seen The Burning of Los Angeles actually come phantasmagorically to life once already, and to desire it twice would perhaps be greedy.

Not much came to life onscreen in The Beach, that's for sure, certainly nothing I found very entertaining. At one point The Girl of the Golden West - who was breast-fed suntan oil and saltwater - leaned over and whispered loudly, "This movie's got, like, zero sand up its butt-crack," a review I simply cannot improve upon.

It's been fun predicting which way Leonardo DiCaprio would jump after his post-Titanic ascent into the $20m-per-movie stratosphere. Much has been made of his wish to alienate his bobbysoxer demographic, and yet retain the respect of people who thought he was a great young actor from the moment he bulldozed Robert De Niro offscreen in This Boy's Life. But for the moment he's trapped in a Michael J Fox holding-pattern, waiting for his teenage face to catch up with his adult talent. One day DiCaprio will stand tall in the ruins of his beauty, with Titanic's pubescent adherents by then in junior college, and he'll finally be able to resume the serious business of being a pretty fine actor, instead of a fine, albeit pretty one.

The Beach may well scare off the wussier elements of Seventeen magazine's subscription base. Scaring up business may be another matter. The Beach only hit second place - $15.3m was very disappointing given the perceived pulling-power of the lead - and failed to dislodge Scream 3 from its topmost perch. Come the Presidents' Day long weekend, all the stale Christmas blockbusters will be retired to make way for the next round of big releases, and The Beach may well be swept away in the deluge.

After the movie, as we bobbed along in the exiting crowd, I flashed back, Tod Hackett-style, to an afternoon last spring on a deserted beach in southern Baha, a thousand miles south of where I'm sitting. My old friend Robert, visiting from London and glad to be away from it all, wrapped what must have been the day's twentieth Bebop B&H. He squinted into the powerful sun, taking in the howling wall of waves a hundred yards away (wave-wise, by the way, Nathanael West was all at sea) and the miles of bare sand, and said, "You know what phrase I'm just so fucking sick and tired of hearing? This one: 'You just have to read The Beach.'"

And in the crowd, as we were borne (ceaselessly, backwards) by the currents of Leo's Bimbo Inferno toward Hollywood Boulevard - the one with all the Broken Dreams - I zapped back to the present and thought, "No, no, no. You just have to read The Day of the Locust..."

fields.headline: Body Shots
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A boring, derivative, deeply dishonest film you should cross the street to avoid
fields.body:
Try to imagine Friends crossed with The Accused, as if in some terrible genetic experiment, and you will have some sense of what Body Shots is like: a boring, derivative, deeply dishonest film you should cross the street to avoid. Ostensibly, this is a cool, wised-up, zeitgeisty bulletin from the Sex War front line - what it's like "out there", dating, where post-feminist girls want uncomplicated sex just as much as the boys, but hey, when and where do the hapless guys cross the line and end up in court?

It's an everyday story about the gritty reality of eight pretty young white people in Los Angeles - four girls and four guys going out on the town and ready to party. This means drinking a lot and getting laid (no drugs though).

There are various dodgy, uproarious encounters in bars and clubs, bisected with "thematic" sketches and pieces to camera about what men and women want from sex these days. Then we get on to the main event. One of the boys, Penorisi (Jerry O'Connell), a gargantuan football-playing jock, is accused of raping one of the girls, Sara (Tara Reid), a cute young blonde resembling Pamela Anderson's great-niece. But was it rape or just a one-night stand gone sour?

We get the he-said-she-said routine, and both versions are dramatised as soft-core tits-and-ass flashbacks on screen. (Oddly, though, the cops seem uninterested in the fact Penorisi was witnessed beating the living shit out of a bouncer just before the incident. A material point of evidence, surely, bearing on the defendant's propensity for violence? But mentioning it would disturb the prim sexual symmetry of The Rape Issue.)

So what really happened? We don't know. The film declines to show us, preferring instead to retreat into pusillanimous pseudo-objectivity. The unmistakeable take-home message is that rape is a matter of opinion. This dire film, exec-produced by Michael Keaton and scripted by David "American History X" McKenna, adds up to a fatuous and very unoriginal cop-out.

There are various dodgy, uproarious encounters in bars and clubs, bisected with "thematic" sketches and pieces to camera about what men and women want from sex these days. Then we get on to the main event. One of the boys, Penorisi (Jerry O'Connell), a gargantuan football-playing jock, is accused of raping one of the girls, Sara (Tara Reid), a cute young blonde resembling Pamela Anderson's great-niece. But was it rape or just a one-night stand gone sour? We get the he-said-she-said routine, and both versions are dramatised as soft-core tits-and-ass flashbacks on screen. (Oddly, though, the cops seem uninterested in the fact Penorisi was witnessed beating the living shit out of a bouncer just before the incident. A material point of evidence, surely, bearing on the defendant's propensity for violence? But mentioning it would disturb the prim sexual symmetry of The Rape Issue.) So what really happened? We don't know. The film declines to show us, preferring instead to retreat into pusillanimous pseudo-objectivity. The unmistakeable take-home message is that rape is a matter of opinion. This dire film, exec-produced by Michael Keaton and scripted by David "American History X" McKenna, adds up to a fatuous and very unoriginal cop-out.

fields.headline: The Brethren, by John Grisham
fields.standfirst:
(Century, £16.99), digested in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: A Russian communist threatens America. America elects a president who organises bombings around the world. He is blackmailed because he is gay, but then marries his assistant. It all works out fine in the end, though, and America lives happily ever after.
fields.body:
Finn Yarber, Hatlee Beech and Joe Roy Spicer are ex-judges, AKA the Brethren, now incarcerated in prison. The Brethren while away their sentences making a quiet fortune through blackmail. "They were, after all, convicted felons, and if they could quietly pick up some cash on the outside then everyone would be happy." Their trick is to put an ad in the lonely hearts column of gay mag Out and About. "Ricky" and "Percy" write to secretly gay - and wealthy - older businessmen, preferably married with children, as this makes extracting cash from them a lot easier...$100,000 a pop.

In the big outside world, the CIA have discovered one Natli Chenkov, hardline Russian communist and according to Teddy Maynard, head of the CIA, "the most dangerous man in the world". Maynard explains: "If we are unprepared, then we could well have a war. If we are strong, we avoid a war. Right now the Pentagon could not do what it did in the Gulf war in 1991."

But Maynard's plan is to field a presidential candidate with one aim - not lowering taxes, cutting the crime rate or unemployment. Instead the candidate must promise to double the defence budget. Aaron Lake is the answer to Maynard's prayers - he's a congressman with "dark blue eyes, square chin, really nice teeth". He is intelligent, but more importantly, his past is clean and Maynard knows he is electable. Lake thinks the idea is "wonderful" and starts choosing his vice-president. Maynard guarantees the campaign money and declares: "By the time November gets here, the American voters will be so terrified of Armageddon they won't care how much you've spent. It'll be a landslide."

Then the American embassy in Cairo is bombed, killing 80 people, including the ambassador and his wife. Lake makes speeches about compassion to the nation, but is as tough as hell about the defence budget. His popularity escalates.

But Maynard discovers that Lake unfortunately has a secret - he is gay and he has written to "Ricky". Maynard must prevent a scandal (he's had quite enough dealing with Clinton). Trevor, the Brethren's lawyer, is paid $2m to keep quiet about the secret, but he flees. Maynard "seethes". "His agency had toppled governments and killed kings, yet he was constantly surprised at how little things got botched." Trevor is shot. The Brethren are then also paid $2m each and released from jail on condition that they stay out of the US for at least two years.

Scare over, Maynard advises Lake to get married to better his image. Jayne Cordell, his closest adviser, "needs to drop 15 pounds" but "she'd make a fine First Lady". Lake wins a landslide victory in the presidential election. The CIA discover that the Brethren are still up to their old tricks, practising extortion in Europe: "You gotta keep busy," concludes Finn Yarber.

And if you really are pressed - The digested read, digested:A Russian communist threatens America. America elects a president who organises bombings around the world. He is blackmailed because he is gay, but then marries his assistant. It all works out fine in the end, though, and America lives happily ever after.

fields.headline: Flight of fancy
fields.standfirst:
Webber weaves his magic

London fashion week: special report
fields.trailText: British designer Tristan Webber yesterday showed his sixth London collection, under the title C9H13NO3 - the chemical formula for adrenaline.
fields.body:
British designer Tristan Webber yesterday showed his sixth London collection, under the title C9H13NO3 - the chemical formula for adrenaline.

The show's three themes - fright, fight and flight - represented the body's changing skin patterns during the release of adrenaline. With the lights dimmed, the show began with a single model wearing a white boned top with glowing green fibre-optic lights sewn into the back, followed by another wearing a green mesh top and mask.

Webber, 28, successfully combined leather, mohair and cashmere. Slashed jersey tops in cream teamed easily with red leather skirts, sheepskin coats and blue mesh trousers. Lime green dominated, with hipster trousers, translucent dresses and glittery tops. Webber added fuel to the fur debate with fur-patched tops and a reversed fur coat, which some people started to applaud - then soon realised not too.

London Fashion Week has been noted for its inclusion of young designers, many of whom have been given a slot on the official roster for the first time after Marks & Spencer sponsored six "new generation" designers.

The store made another bid to turn around its dismal profits by launching its Autograph collection yesterday. The collection is designed by top British names including Betty Jackson, Katharine Hamnett and Julien Macdonald.

The range will go on sale in 13 high profile stores nationwide and three in Europe on March 2. Clothes will be sold from special "capsule boutiques" within the stores, designed to create an environment similar to that of an exclusive boutique. They will feature spacious changing rooms with night and day lighting and comfortable sofas for long suffering husbands.

Up to 200 Marks & Spencer sales staff across the country have received training on "personal shopping" so they can advise customers on clothes to suit their colouring, body shape and lifestyle.

webTitle: Canadian Jews bar Haider from Holocaust museum

fields.headline: Canadian Jews bar Haider from Holocaust museum
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider, the leader of Austria's far-right Freedom party, has been prohibited from touring Montreal's Holocaust Centre during an unannounced private visit to Canada.
fields.body:
Jörg Haider, the leader of Austria's far-right Freedom party, has been prohibited from touring Montreal's Holocaust Centre during an unannounced private visit to Canada.

Moshe Ronen, the president of the Canadian Jewish Congress, said that the country's Jewish community was concerned about Mr Haider's visit and questioned his motives in asking to tour the centre.

"Our advice to the museum was not to accommodate this bizarre request," Mr Ronen said. "They did not accommodate the visit."

He said that Mr Haider - a "cynical manipulator of public opinion" - carried the legacy of Adolf Hitler "wherever he goes".

Mr Haider told the Montreal Gazette newspaper that he had been invited in December to a wedding by the Tash Hasidic community, an ultra-orthodox Jewish sect that traces its history to the Austro-Hungarian empire.

"We are invited to come here and to meet people from the Jewish community," he said. "We have good links to them."

It was unclear what Mr Haider's itinerary was, though he hinted that he planned to go on to Toronto. The Canadian minister of foreign affairs, Lloyd Axworthy, said yesterday that Canada had received no advance notice that Mr Haider would be arriving on Tuesday.

"Certainly there was no indication from the Austrian government or embassy that he would be coming," Mr Axworthy said. "Anybody can get on a plane and arrive in Canada, and if they have a proper passport they are given entry."

Several countries, including Canada, have protested since the Freedom party became part of Austria's coalition government on February 4. Israel withdrew its ambassador from Vienna, and the Israeli interior minister, Natan Sharansky, banned the populist leader from entering the country.

Mr Haider has praised Hitler's "orderly" economic policies and described SS veterans as honourable. He has apologised for remarks that offended Jews, but many say that his anti-immigrant rhetoric deliberately evokes Austria's pro-Nazi past.

On Wednesday, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, said Mr Haider would never persuade the world that his views were not racist.

In a speech welcoming the German president, Johannes Rau, to Israel's parliament, Mr Barak said: "It was not the slips of the tongue that shocked us. "It was the opinions, the true, racist and anti-democratic opinions that Jörg Haider may try to refrain from expressing openly from now on."

The president of Austria, Thomas Klestil, is to visit the European Union headquarters in Brussels on March 8, though bilateral relations are frozen between Vienna and other EU capitals, officials said yesterday.

fields.headline: Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: • One of this year's more unlikely literary triumphs falls victim to its own success. Several readers who have visited Amazon's web site recently expressed surprise on finding, alongside stuff about Harry Potter and Delia Smith, a rousing four stars and a dozen solemn reviews for a title called A Hand in the Bush: The Fine Art of Vaginal Fisting (Greenery Press). A week ago, Deborah Addington's manual stood at number four in Amazon's 'Hot 100', but then it sold out and its unavailability sent it down the charts.
fields.body:
 One of this year's more unlikely literary triumphs falls victim to its own success. Several readers who have visited Amazon's web site recently expressed surprise on finding, alongside stuff about Harry Potter and Delia Smith, a rousing four stars and a dozen solemn reviews for a title called A Hand in the Bush: The Fine Art of Vaginal Fisting (Greenery Press). A week ago, Deborah Addington's manual stood at number four in Amazon's 'Hot 100', but then it sold out and its unavailability sent it down the charts.

My colleague Richard Adams finds Amazon somewhat unhelpful, but my friend Ann Widdecombe is more forthcoming. "This is a terrible story which points to the need for utter vigilance on the part of parents and schools," she says. Her spokesman adds that Ann has been researching this "complex and difficult question" and will make a policy announcement soon. We count the minutes. Anyone disappointed by the book's unavailability, meanwhile, will thank Amazon for recommending alternative titles, such as The Ultimate Guide to Anal Sex for Women.

 Moving away from smut, the FT's television critic Chris Dunkley tells how scandalised he was by a joke our most beloved Mo Mowlam told on Graham Norton's brilliant Channel 4 show last Friday night. It concerned the failure of men to find the clitoris, and with apologies to Mr Dunkley we enjoyed it very much. As, I am sure, did Ann Widdecombe, who's an absolute demon for those clitoral rib-ticklers. Incidentally, within the last week both current and former New Labour ministers have expressed to me their disgust at the way Mr Tony's gang have viciously smeared Mo. No doubt she can take it, but it is something many others will not forget for a long time.

 A group nomination for February's PC Brains goes to Essex police. In the hours after the Afghan plane landed at Stansted, coppers set about ensuring that the visitors were adequately fed. Now then, who knows what to do about feeding a plane load of Muslims? Any ideas? No? Well, Essex police cracked it at once, reports the Jewish Chronicle, and rang Reubens, the well-known kosher restaurant in Baker Street, to order 80 sandwiches. In truth there is a close similarity between how kosher and Halal meat is slaughtered, although religious scholars would point out it is unusual for Jewish butchers to pray to Mecca first. Still, we look forward to news of the first salt beef bar in Kabul.

 I am shocked by mutterings about the three days it is taking to count the London mayoral ballot papers creating the possibility of fraud. How utterly absurd. After all, if Sunderland South could declare its general election result within an hour of the ballot closing after counting 67,000 votes, of course it takes three days to sort Dobbo out from Ken. When will these whingers and sneerers leave New Labour high command alone?

 Tremendous news on the sponsorship front. The sensational new Volkswagen Beetle promised to us last year by Wayne Bruce, then the caped crusader of the VW press office (but promoted to head of publicity for Seat after becoming a household name in the Diary) is on its way. Wayne's successor Kate Thompson says the car, in a "bright colour", will arrive on March 20. Kate seems to think we can only have it for a week. Bless her heart, if that's what she wants to believe, who are we to disabuse her?  Two week after asking Diary readers not to abuse the freepost address set up in Scotland by opponents of section 28's abolition, Royal Mail staff dealing with letters to the Keep the Clause campaign (supported by the Daily Record and Stagecoach's owner Brian Souter) have been issued with protective gloves. A series of "offensive items", sent to the freepost address in Perth, are responsible. Poor show.

webTitle: Drug firms laying claim to our genes

fields.headline: Drug firms laying claim to our genes
fields.standfirst:
Building blocks of life hold the keys to cures and the pharmaceuticals sector smells money

Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: The drug industry is facing one of its biggest controversies in years - whether a company can seize ownership of a gene. The concept sounds bizarre - after all, a gene is an intrinsic part of the human body, in the same way as an arm or a leg - or so research bodies like the Wellcome Institute say.
fields.body:
The drug industry is facing one of its biggest controversies in years - whether a company can seize ownership of a gene. The concept sounds bizarre - after all, a gene is an intrinsic part of the human body, in the same way as an arm or a leg - or so research bodies like the Wellcome Institute say.

These building blocks of life have emerged as the key to curing diseases - and the world's drugs companies can smell money. Biotechnology firms in Britain and the United States have already convinced the authorities to grant them patents over dozens of genes, and the race is on to secure hundreds more.

This week, Maryland firm Human Genome Sciences said that it had secured rights over CCR5, which scientists have identified as the "docking point" used by the Aids virus when it enters the body. The potential earnings are huge - HGS can stake a claim to any Aids medicine targeting the gene no matter who develops it. The news acted like a steroid on the share price, which leapt 50% in two days.

Craig Rosen, the company's vice-president for research and development, said: "We have spent a lot of time and money identifying this gene. This is a whole new target area for research and if some other company wanted to work on it, we would expect them to come to us."

The scientific establishment is not impressed by such moves. The Wellcome Institute, one of Britain's wealthiest scientific powerhouses, recently condemned "opportunistic and inappropriately broad patents" filed on genetic data.

Things are reaching a head because of the progress of the Human Genome Project - a global effort to map the human genetic make-up. New genes are identi fied every month and within three years, scientists believe they will be able to see all 33m letters in the human alphabet.

Once this "map" is available, doctors will be able to compare it to the genetic make-up of patients suffering from particular illnesses. By finding variations, they will see how diseases work.

One of the first British companies to patent a gene was the intellectual property specialist BTG, which owns Factor Nine - a crucial component in blood clotting. BTG's chief executive Ian Harvey said: "We have something which some people think is wrong."

BTG has licensed Factor Nine to six companies, which are competing to produce artificial versions of it in the lab. One of these is PPL Therapeutics, the company behind the cloned sheep, Dolly.

Mr Harvey says products based on the gene have already saved thousands of haemophiliacs. He says that without patent protection no company would have carried out the necessary work.

"Genetic institutions would not invest hundreds of millions of dollars into something which could be copied," he said.

His view is echoed by BTG's patent attorney Keith Percy, who says many objections are based on emotive language: "There's nothing mysterious about a gene. It's just a complicated chemical."

He says it is incorrect to suggest that BTG owns the gene. "This is a fallacy we see time and time again. What we own is the right to exploit it."

Such companies claim that genes are so difficult to identify that they constitute inventions rather than discoveries. So far, the patent authorities have agreed. Their criteria is that an invention must be new and must have industrial applicability. A spokesman for the UK patent office says: "If you find something in nature, then finding some way to separate it and to make it into something useful can be an invention." The issue could well turn into a political hot potato - it has already been raised in the House of Commons and on the floor of Congress in the US.

Andrew Millar, chief executive of Oxford Gene Technology, said: "It's not the ultimate knowledge. The genome map is like a map showing the shape of a country, but not all the towns or cities within it."

In most cases, it will be many years before medicines based on patented genes reach the market. How easily companies can defend their "ownership" of genes is likely to remain doubtful until then.

fields.bylineHtml: Andrew Clark and James Meek

fields.headline: Johnson warns on governance
fields.standfirst: Investment groups without e-commerce strategies risk breaching standards, says controversial Belgo owner
fields.trailText: E-finance: special report
fields.body:
Luke Johnson, the controversial restaurant and net entrepreneur, has written to Britain's most powerful investor groups warning them that companies which do not have an e-commerce strategy should be ruled as "in breach" of best corporate governance standards.

The multimillionaire playboy businessman is calling on the large pension and insur ance funds to demand information from companies about how they intend to use and exploit the internet. If they regard the web as an irrelevance, he argues, they should spell this out to shareholders.

Mr Johnson's enthusiasm for tip-top boardroom standards, however, is almost entirely at odds with the performance of his major stock market vehicle, the restaurants group Belgo, whose recent annual report fell distinctly short of cur rent corporate governance recommendations. At Belgo - which runs mussels and chips bars along with eateries such as The Ivy - Mr Johnson, the chairman, draws no salary.

But he, along with Marc Jonas, the senior non-executive director and a longtime associate, have been granted options over 5% and 3% respectively of the company.

According to the Belgo report, the options were awarded at the discretion of the remuneration committee, which is made up of Mr Johnson and Mr Jonas.

Sir Adrian Cadbury urged that remuneration committees should be independent nearly 10 years ago. In contrast, Belgo's crucial audit committee also consists solely of Mr Jonas and Mr Johnson.

It has apparently taken the Association of British Insurers and the National Association of Pension Funds - whose members speak for about two thirds of all shares - by surprise that Mr Johnson has become a corporate governance crusader. His letter to both organisations called on companies to produce an e-commerce statement or be found in breach of standards.

Richard Regan, head of investments for the ABI, said: "It was pretty heavy stuff to talk about 'breaching' standards."

Although the ABI and NAPF receive regular complaints about governance issues, they were surprised at Mr Johnson's intervention. Both organisations are understood to have responded robustly to his recent proposals.

The investment groups admit there are serious governance issues which are raised by e-commerce and the wave of start-up companies that instantly hit the market as big players. They responded that companies which regard the web as having relevance to their business should explain their thinking to shareholders. Those which regard the web as a side issue should also be prepared to explain their stance.

But Mr Regan said the prescriptive stance proposed by Mr Johnson ran the risk of introducing a "box ticking" exercise - rather than opening the way for any real communication relating to the new media between companies and their shareholders.

Mr Johnson's combination of the crucial boardroom com mittees at Belgo is not his only contravention of best governance practice.

The board admits that only one of its two non-executive directors is independent - but which one is unclear.

Mr Jonas's potential 3% stake means it is unlikely to be him, but the other non-executive, Erich Booth, chief financial officer of Belgo's joint venture partner and a 20% shareholder. Mr Johnson was unavailable for comment yesterday.

fields.headline: 365 puts up the million marker
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Datanet
fields.trailText: 365 Corporation has passed the 1m registered users mark and is likely to buy in more through acquisition, the company said yesterday.
fields.body:
365 Corporation has passed the 1m registered users mark and is likely to buy in more through acquisition, the company said yesterday.

However, the growth has been accompanied by mounting losses. The online sports and entertainment content provider had 1,031,282 users in December, a 32% increase on September, according to chief executive Dan Thompson.

The acquisition of sports content firm Datanet, concluded earlier this month for £31m, raises user numbers to 1.4m. BT Cellnet has agreed to distribute the combined group's content to its mobile phone customers.

In the quarter ended December 31 1999, operating losses before provisions for national insurance contributions (NIC) on share options were £2.185m, compared with £371,000 during the same period last year. Had NIC been factored in, losses would have been £8.5m.

Finance director Martin Turner said the growth in the group's internet revenues, which climbed 57% to £460,000 during the quarter, made him optimistic that losses would soon be recovered. "The division is operating with very, very high gross margins," he said.

Turnover grew 13% to £5.5m during the quarter.

Shares in 365 Corporation have climbed around 20% since Christmas but their performance has been lacklustre compared to other operators in the internet sector.

One analyst said the company's strategy of developing content for converging media had not been properly understood and valued by the market.

Last night the shares softened 1p to 223.5p.

Since coming to market in December, 365 has bought Datanet and a US rugby site, as well as set up a TV division called 365Television to produce documentaries.

fields.headline: Bizzbuild value put at £50m
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bizzbuild.com, the e-commerce development and management company advised by Durlacher, is likely to be valued at £50m when dealings start next month.
fields.body:
Bizzbuild.com, the e-commerce development and management company advised by Durlacher, is likely to be valued at £50m when dealings start next month.

The offer price was set at 250p per share yesterday. The company plans to raise £6.2m to fund ongoing working capital requirements and increase its stake in Value-Direct, an online retailer of electrical products and domestic appliances.

Bizzbuild plans to concentrate on setting up, investing in and developing companies that want to build pan-European internet ventures.

Value Direct has been trading since January 1995 and last year achieved a turnover of £6.6m, a 98% increase on 1998. Bizzbuild plans to increase its investment in the company to £4.1m.

"With the positive preliminary response to this offer, bizzbuild.com will be well placed to achieve its objective of developing new and existing e-commerce business," said chief executive Ivan Sellers.

The company expects to launch three or four new businesses in 2000 and is recruiting project managers to set up and run them.

fields.trailText: Former England football captain David Platt and Italian player Roberto Baggio have taken undisclosed shareholdings in a global soccer website in return for endorsements.
fields.body:
Former England football captain David Platt and Italian player Roberto Baggio have taken undisclosed shareholdings in a global soccer website in return for endorsements.

www.goalnetwork.com is the brainchild of Alan Rothenberg, organiser of the 1994 World Cup in the US and head of FIFA's 2006 World Cup site election committee. Mr Rothenberg is chairman of the company, and Baggio, Platt and former US soccer player Alexi Lalas receive small shareholdings in return for publicising the site. The Kraft family, of cheese fame, is also an investor.

Content will be provided by a worldwide network of journalists and edited by Keir Radnedge, executive editor of World Soccer magazine.
