webTitle: Sema strategy rewarded with 28% profit rise

fields.headline: Sema strategy rewarded with 28% profit rise
fields.trailText: Sema, the Anglo-French computer services group, yesterday showed its decision to focus on the fast-growing mobile phone and e-business sectors has paid off.
fields.body:
Sema, the Anglo-French computer services group, yesterday showed its decision to focus on the fast-growing mobile phone and e-business sectors has paid off.

Its 1999 pre-tax profits rose 28% to £95.9m on turnover 23% up at £1.41bn. Its order book stands at a record £2bn.

The group also announced that it had won a contract to provide and run the systems for Ze Project, an internet-based financial services venture from the private stable of Bernard Arnault, the French businessman who heads the Louis Vuitton Moët Hennessy luxury goods combine.

Ze Project aims to offer a full range of financial services online to several million European customers within three years.

Sema said it would be paid according to Ze Project's "level of activity", a business model which, it said, is becoming popular in the US and UK.

Pierre Bonelli, Sema's chief executive, said the group had achieved continued growth in its core markets as well as "the benefits of our strategic focus on high-growth new technology areas and markets".

The past year had seen the start of SemaVision, a software package designed for the telecom industry. SemaVision customers included Vodafone and Telecom Italia Mobile.

"In addition we have experienced a huge growth in the demand for our e-business expertise and services," Mr Bonelli said. "The record strength of our order book further underpins our prospects and global opportunities for 2000 and beyond."

The group said its core busi ness had won a number of big contracts last year with clients such as the Labour party, Cable & Wireless and the Metropolitan Police.

Sema said it was still looking to acquire a company in the North American telecommunications market but would not rush into a purchase.

Corporate communications director Marie-Claude Bessis explained: "We are still looking to acquire a company in the US but we will take our time because we want a perfect fit and we want to find a company that can bring us a value comparing to what we do.

"We are looking very carefully, and will only acquire a company with a perfect fit. It's not a question of price."

 Europe's information and communication technology industries grew more quickly than US counterparts in 1999, the European Information Technology Observatory said yesterday. The outperformance was likely to continue, but in the long term Europe's progress was threatened by a shortage of skilled IT workers.

European ICT firms grew by 12% in 1999, while their US competitors grew 8.1% over the same period, it said.

"Europe proved to be the most dynamic region and this trend is expected to continue in 2000 and 2001, albeit less strongly," said chairman Bruno Lamborghini.

fields.headline: Chandra
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: When is a shell with virtually no assets worth nearly £19m? When it says it wants to be an internet company as in the case of Aim-listed Chandra.
fields.body:
When is a shell with virtually no assets worth nearly £19m? When it says it wants to be an internet company as in the case of Aim-listed Chandra.

Shares in the company were suspended yesterday afternoon after a 15% jump to 360p and the company admitting it had entered into heads of agreement over a deal which would constitute a reverse takeover by an unnamed suitor.

Four weeks ago, when the shares were trading at 251p, the Guardian revealed that the company in question was Groovetech, a dance music website and Seattle-based radio station.

Ronnie Wood of the Rolling Stones is a shareholder and his manager, the entertainment lawyer Nick Cowan, is the major investor.

Groovetech's core business is online dance communities and webcasting live DJ sets.

Chandra said yesterday that the potential acquisition would be financed by an issue of new shares.

It appears that Chandra's share price has got a little bit ahead of itself even if it does plan to build itself into a larger group. Those who bought in at the November float price of 80p won't be too worried.

Investors who bought in at the top should take comfort from the appearance of Nigel Drummond on the board. Nigel is brother of Jason Drummond, one of the net's most successful and level-headed young entrepreneurs who has built Virtual Internet into a £164m business.

Virtual was taken to market by the same sharp group of investors who set up Chandra. If Nigel and Groovetech turn out to be anything like Jason and Virtual, Chandra late-comers will be fine.

fields.headline: Stepstone is given £365m tag
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Stepstone, the Nowegian on-line recruitment company planning to float in Oslo and London, has been valued slightly below original expectations at £365m.
fields.body:
Stepstone, the Nowegian on-line recruitment company planning to float in Oslo and London, has been valued slightly below original expectations at £365m.

Adviser Morgan Stanley Dean Witter was expected to value the company in excess of £400m but a spokesman for Stepstone emphasised that £365m was based on a mid-point figure and the company is raising £65m, which is more than first predicted.

The grey market expects the company to be valued in excess of £400m at the end of its first day's trading.

The offer is for 54m ordinary shares at an indicative price range of 152p to 190p. Applications for shares can be made through www.stepstone.co.uk and must be received by February 28. Pricing is expected on March 1 with dealings set to begin the next day.

Giles Clark, chief executive of Stepstone, said: "Stepstone's strategy is to become the leading pan-European online recruitment and career portal. Going public enables the company to build its European brand awareness further, enlarge its customer base, accelerate end-user traffic whilst continuing to enhance site functionality and features."

Stepstone operates in the UK, Norway, Denmark, Sweden, Germany, France, Belgium and Italy, and claims it is market leader by revenue. Turnover in 1999 was £7m and there was a net loss of £15m. In January it had about 1.9m user sessions, 1,100 companies as annual contract advertising customers, and some 170,000 cvs and 63,000 jobs listed.

fields.headline: Flotations fuel Durlacher's continental drift
fields.standfirst:
Web investment firm 'ready to go it alone'

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Durlacher, the internet investment company behind Autonomy and 365 Corporation, expects six companies in which it has equity stakes to list on European stock markets within the next five months.
fields.body:
Durlacher, the internet investment company behind Autonomy and 365 Corporation, expects six companies in which it has equity stakes to list on European stock markets within the next five months.

Expansion in Europe has been made a priority as the company looks to build its portfolio of investments on the continent.

Chief executive Geoffrey Chamberlain, speaking at yesterday's half-year results meeting, refused to name the companies likely to float. Durlacher has stakes in software company Zeus Technology, online CD retailer Boxman and Online Travel, which are all understood to be drawing up plans for listings.

Mr Chamberlain said that Durlacher will take controlling stakes in companies for the first time. He said it has bought 83% of Kvault Software, a company that develops technology spun out of Compaq Computers to sort unstructured corporate data, and 65% of 45one.com, a business-to-business technology news and analysis website based in London, New York and silicon valley.

"There is a clear audit trail of Durlacher's capability of building significant companies and we will now look to have more of a financial interest in the future," he said.

"We have served an apprenticeship for five years and will make more investments by ourselves now. This may well lead to a strategy of retaining control of start-ups post flotation that should boost market value."

However, Mr Chamberlain said European expansion was the company's highest priority. "The Durlacher model evolved over the years will be rolled out into the continental marketplace through a combination of organic growth and acquisitions. There are more exciting prospects in Europe than ever before."

Durlacher was one of the best performing stocks on the London market last year rising more than 6000% and the former private client stockbroker is now valued at £2.1bn.

Investor demand was fuelled largely by the success of intelligent software company Autonomy, which is now capitalised at more than £2bn on the Easdaq market, and the flotation of sports and entertainment content provider 365 Corporation.

Durlacher makes money from selling research, consulting, broking, market-making and online services. However, the most lucrative source of revenue comes from the sale of equity stakes in fast-growth companies.

Almost half of pre-tax profit in the six months to December 1999 came from the sale of £2m worth of shares in 365. Investors are banking on the companies ability to continue to find the internet winners of tomorrow. It has 30 investments in early stage software and new media companies.

Turnover for the half year to December 31 rose 125% on the previous year to £11.6m, while pre-tax profit climbed 850% to £5.1m. Net assets climbed from £4.3m to £31.7m. No dividend was proposed. January trading was a record month in terms of turnover and profits.

Durlacher has made a great play of predicting the future of technology and director of research Andy Bottomley yesterday identified application service providers, business-to-business trading hubs, interactive television and knowledge management software as the hot new investor areas.

Separately Durlacher also announced a new private wealth management service for entrepreneurs who have made fortunes out of internet companies.

Shares closed up 55p at £39.72p.

Almost half of pre-tax profit in the six months to December 1999 came from the sale of £2m worth of shares in 365. Investors are banking on the companies ability to continue to find the internet winners of tomorrow. It has 30 investments in early stage software and new media companies. Turnover for the half year to December 31 rose 125% on the previous year to £11.6m, while pre-tax profit climbed 850% to £5.1m. Net assets climbed from £4.3m to £31.7m. No dividend was proposed. January trading was a record month in terms of turnover and profits. Durlacher has made a great play of predicting the future of technology and director of research Andy Bottomley yesterday identified application service providers, business-to-business trading hubs, interactive television and knowledge management software as the hot new investor areas. Separately Durlacher also announced a new private wealth management service for entrepreneurs who have made fortunes out of internet companies. Shares closed up 55p at £39.72p.

webTitle: Financial rivalry will go to the wire

fields.headline: Financial rivalry will go to the wire
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: In a stock market where the internet has torn up all the valuation rules, Interactive Investor International, which made its £550m debut yesterday, has more substance than most.
fields.body:
In a stock market where the internet has torn up all the valuation rules, Interactive Investor International, which made its £550m debut yesterday, has more substance than most.

In net years iii is old, having started in late 1994. Its user base is the biggest among the personal finance websites, with 389,000 individuals registered.

The company is not just benefiting from internet euphoria, it is at the very heart of it, too. Its users are the new army of small investors who have leapt on to the hi-tech share trading bandwagon and use the iii chat rooms and bulletin boards to swap investment tips, dubious or not. They are also behind the phenomenal increase in stock exchange trading volumes that has left internet stockbrokers such as Halifax and Barclays stockbrokers groaning under the strain of new business.

More than 80,000 people scrambled to buy shares in iii, so little wonder that it was oversubscribed 26 times.

It leaves the aftermarket for the shares looking healthy. There are still few signs of institutional investor fatigue on e-shares, with yesterday's jump in Halifax's share price evidence of the City's continuing obsession with anything carrying an e-halo. Institutions still under-own tech shares, and when indices such as Techmark 100 rebase in three months' time, possibly to include iii, more investors will be pulled in.

But it still stretches credibility that the company can satisfy yesterday's valuation. iii's sales last year were a paltry £2.6m - less than one-twohundredth of its debut stock market value. Around half of its revenues come from advertising to its admittedly high net worth individuals and from fees earned each time they request a product brochure from a life, pension or investment provider.

But even if that is multiplied by five times next year, it would give iii revenues of just £7.5m, about enough to wipe out last year's losses, and less than its accumulated debt. Financial intermediaries don't make money handing out brochures, they make it from commission on selling products, which iii does not do.

One strength is the media muscle of 30% owner Hollinger, which owns the Telegraph newspapers. But the Telegraph titles have shown little support for their younger sibling, and the options for cross-promotion between old and new media look slim. But the biggest risk for iii is from the traditional financial institutions. Halifax is belatedly waking up to the net, and Abbey National is not far behind. Prudential, with its Egg site, has taken a strong lead. When it comes to selling life, pensions and investment products, iii will be hard put to withstand such competition.

webTitle: Can these two rescue the dome?

fields.headline: Can these two rescue the dome?
fields.standfirst:
The big ideas: Reverse crowd flows, little signs for little folk and...

The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Roland Rat rescued GMTV, now Pierre-Yves Gerbeau is pinning his hopes of saving the Millennium Dome on a couple of "muppets".
fields.body:
Roland Rat rescued GMTV, now Pierre-Yves Gerbeau is pinning his hopes of saving the Millennium Dome on a couple of "muppets".

Coggsley and Sprinx, two obscure cartoon characters, are the twin pillars on which the Frenchman plans to turn around the troubled tourist attraction.

Everyone laughed at Roland Rat, but the former Disney executive, who was drafted in 10 days ago after the sacking of the dome chief executive Jennie Page, said that the cuddly stars of the ITV series Timekeepers Of The Millennium - which was shown before Christmas - were his secret weapons: the Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck of the dome.

"I want Coggsley and Sprinx to be little fixes that have to go through the brain of everybody," he said. "I want them everywhere."

With the press gathered to hear his "big ideas", he revealed he would be lowering the signs "so the little folks like me can see them", making people walk around the dome clockwise, rather than anti-clockwise - feng shui is not thought to be a factor - and ensuring everything inside the zones worked.

More big name celebrities was also part of his masterplan and to prove the point he disclosed that the Queen of Denmark visited the dome yesterday. "My bow was great," he added.

Her appearance came hot on the heels of a visit by the Duchess of York, Keith from Boyzone and Patsy Palmer, better known as Bianca from EastEnders. "They all say to me, 'this place is amazing. We should have known about it before,'" he said.

Whatever about his ideas, and lingering unanswered questions about his record at Disneyland Paris, Mr Gerbeau proved himself to be a showman yesterday, speaking non-stop for 30 minutes and enthusing at regular intervals: "We can do it!"

At one point he declared, "Let's hit the roof, we're shooting for 10m people. It's gonna happen."

Mr Gerbeau claimed no credit for the recent upturn in attendances, and predicted that next Saturday he would have to turn people away. Visitor numbers were up 30% last week on the last week in January.

He said the dome's vast central arena, which is currently empty for most of the day, would become a "permanent showcase with little stages and the show rehearsals going on there throughout the day."

The much-criticised maps of the dome will also be redrawn and management flattened in line with Disney's. "My philosophy is that the customer is king," he said.

He categorically ruled out cutting admission prices, though he said he was looking at introducing a "happy hour" ticket for afternoon visits, and giving a 25% discount on repeat visit tickets bought in the dome. Mr Gerbeau said he also aimed to double the amount visitors spent at dome by aiming merchandise more directly at children.

However, last night his changes were dismissed as a "hill of beans" by the Liberal Democrat spokesman on the dome, Norman Baker.

"The dome is in need of a full engine refit," he said, "not just some fiddling with the spark plugs."

fields.headline: Purse versus wallet
fields.standfirst: Making mothers better off will help children and save more marriages than giving morality lessonsChancellor's pre-budget speech: special report lessons
fields.trailText: Making mothers better off will help children and save more marriages than giving morality lessons.
fields.body:
Marriage madness is in the air, fantasy politics from the dottier forces of conservatism. Of course, schools can't teach children to get married, nor can governments prod unwilling adults to the altar. Campaigners for financial marriage incentives bizarrely believe that people entering ruinous divorces - losing their homes and a large slice of income - will suddenly change their minds if offered a puny marriage allowance.

But there is one thing the government is about to do which might just help some parents stay together. Gordon Brown is about to redistribute large sums of money from fathers to mothers in a wallet to handbag transfer. It was whispered in one short line in his last budget and it will emerge in full in next month's, though probably not spun in quite those terms. (Governments have always been uneasy about overtly taking from men to give to women.)

Here's the story. Arm sharply twisted by a caucus of Tory female high flyers, Nigel Lawson reluctantly brought in women's independent taxation. Households would no longer be taxed together, but each partner would be treated separately. It made a great many already well off couples a great deal richer. It was bonanza time in households with two high taxpayers, widening the wealth gap between haves and have-nots in a country increasingly divided between two-earner and no-earner families. Rich women's politics triumphed over class politics - a mistake, but now probably irreversible.

This liberation from tax was not much use to poor women who earn too little to pay any or to women on benefits. The social security system stayed unreformed, treating women in couples as men's chattels. After computing the incomes of both partners and the number and ages of children, all entitlements are paid to the man. The mother has no independent right (except in rare cases where she's nominated instead). The giro goes to the father, stepfather or to a male cohabitee (any man who stays three nights a week).

What effect does that have on poor families on benefit? It explains why they divorce and separate in far higher numbers than the better off. A woman on her own with her children claims all the benefits, including rent and council tax. Where women control the purse strings, research shows they spend far more on the household, food and children than when men control the money. Research on divorcing women living on benefits shows how much richer they feel once they control all their own money. Men who keep more than a very small sum from the family benefit giro can leave women and children virtually destitute. Those worried about saving marriages have had nothing to say about a system which obliged many mothers to abandon men in order to feed their children.

In justice, poor women should have had the same financial liberation as well-off women, with a benefits system as blind to their cohabiting arrangements as the tax system now is. But disaggregating family incomes on social security would be phenomenally expensive: the tax bonus rich couples got from the state was welcomed, but a similar windfall for the poor would be politically unacceptable because it would be a new work disincentive. However, the chancellor is about to do the second best thing: family income will still be computed together but the mother will for the first time collect all the entitlement for herself and her children. Her partner will only collect his own personal allowance. Since all the growth in the social security system is to be increasingly piled onto the new integrated children's credit, most family money will rest in the far safer hands of mothers. It will put right the mistake made when family credit (paid to mothers) was ditched in favour of working family's tax credit (paid into men's pay packets for couples).

A joint treasury and social security committee has been working out how to combine tax and benefits - something that should have been done 50 years ago. By 2003 the new working family tax credit will have been abolished in favour of a far more subtle and finely tuned mechanism designed to eliminate the big barrier preventing parents taking jobs. Integrated child credit will be a completely secure and permanent cushion to support poorer children. It will not vary when either parent moves in or out of work. It will iron out the glitches that make parents, especially single mothers, afraid to take a job for fear of weeks without benefit if the job fails. It's a kind of junior citizens income, but neatly targeted at lower earners, making it worth risking a temporary job - the best route to a permanent one - by keeping families afloat through bumpy times.

Will this achieve Labour's promise to abolish child poverty? It's a well-honed silver chute to pour money straight to poor children, but it depends how much money goes down it. Abolishing poverty isn't just a matter of direct funds but how much money goes to all the other poverty-busting schemes. Will the economy and employment stay buoyant? Will schools turn out no more future parents doomed to fail? Sure Start, for babies at risk, must work and it may take 10 years before we know if Blunkett's babies will succeed. Ending poverty remains a breathtakingly ambitious endeavour.

It depends most of all on creating a long-term public will to do it. So far Labour has not done much to persuade the electorate what public money can do in these times of affluence. There is a limit to how much money can go to children through social security if Labour keeps promising to cut the DSS budget. Increasing it might be a better boast. But just as they tax by stealth, so far they have been paying out by stealth too: all Brown's generous new benefits have been relabelled as tax credits and no longer appear on the DSS budget but are hidden away in inland revenue accounts. It won't work. The Daily Mail and the Tories will insist on counting these into the overall social security bill. In the end, just as you need sustainable economic growth, so you also need sustainable public support for what you are doing. Not enough money can be stealthily spent on poverty programmes: the public has to be proud of what is being done in its name.

That is the big question for the next election. Labour has the Tories skewered on their daft low tax pledge: Hague's tax guarantee is easily bounced back as the Tory cuts guarantee. But Labour needs to say publicly that more spending, a lot more, is required. That will mean more taxing, which requires people to be persuaded that well-spent tax pounds can buy richer things than the pounds in their pocket. The first place to begin is with national insurance contributions: this is the budget to remove the NI artificial ceiling which allows the rich to pay a smaller share of their income than everyone else. It would raise a splendid £4.8bn - serious money to put towards that difficult, multi-faceted poverty pledge.

fields.headline: Russian forces seal off Grozny
fields.standfirst:
Chechen capital becomes no-go zone as troops are accused of torturing and killing civilians

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Russian forces are to start sealing off the Chechen capital today in the latest attempt to stamp their authority indelibly on the rebel republic at the expense of thousands of civilians who have been uprooted from the destroyed city.
fields.body:
Russian forces are to start sealing off the Chechen capital today in the latest attempt to stamp their authority indelibly on the rebel republic at the expense of thousands of civilians who have been uprooted from the destroyed city.

While streams of refugees wend their way back to Grozny to discover the fate of their houses and belongings, Russian officers signalled that the city was to be made a no-go area indefinitely and that no one would be allowed to return home.

There were also growing reports of Russian abuse, rape, torture and executions of civilians and suspected guerrillas. The World Organisation Against Torture issued a statement in Geneva yesterday saying that the "filtration" centres where captured Chechens are held are "concentration camps where Russian soldiers are committing the worst atrocities, in all impunity, against their prisoners".

Moscow has backpedalled on reported pledges to allow independent scrutiny of conditions in Grozny and in the camps. Sergei Yastrzhembsky, the Kremlin's main spokesman on the war, said Grozny - which once had a population of 400,000 and was by far the biggest city in the region - was being closed to civilians for security reasons.

"No date has yet been set for admitting civilians back into the city," Mr Yastrzhembsky said, contending that the main reason for restricting access to Grozny was "to prevent the possible deaths of civilians upon returning to the city".

But Russian military officers told the Interfax news agency that denying access to Grozny residents was to prevent guer rilla fighters from infiltrating their way back into the ruins in order to stage ambushes against the garrisoned Russian troops.

It is unclear what will happen to the thousands of civilians still in Grozny, most of them elderly and ethnic Russians rather than Chechens, who are eking out a wretched existence among the rubble.

The Russians may evacuate remaining residents forcibly to refugee camps, though having survived almost six months of unremitting Russian bombardment already, many are reluctant to abandon their destroyed homes.

Nikolai Koshman, who is the Kremlin's political administrator for occupied Chechnya and the official charged with overseeing the reconstruction effort, said this week that Grozny "must have the status of a closed city".

He made it plain that Moscow had no intention of rebuilding the city its forces have been attacking since last October, the second bombardment in five years.

Since last year Mr Koshman has been drafting plans to close Grozny as the Chechen capital, transferring the regional seat of power to the much smaller town of Gudermes, to the east.

Grozny - which is a Russian name rather than a Chechen one, meaning terrible or awesome - was built by the tsarist empire in the early 19th cen tury as a regional oil centre.

The Russian forces were humiliated there by Chechen rebels during the last war in 1996 and the shattered city now stands as unwelcome testimony to the brute force deployed by the Russians to try to tame the separatists. The degree of destruction means that many of the buildings are structurally unsound and will need to be demolished.

Mr Yastrzhembsky said Russian government "funeral teams" were scouring the ruins "looking for human remains ... That is also part of the effort to clean up Grozny."

The Russians also say that the thousands of rebel fighters who fled the city two weeks ago, seeking refuge in the southern highlands of Chechnya, mined and booby-trapped Grozny before leaving. The Russians have 500 sappers in Grozny clearing roads and buildings of mines. They also say there are still about 300 guerrillas lying low, ready to stage ambushes.

The prospect of outside observers checking the veracity of the Russian claims evaporated yesterday, despite the statement hours earlier from Lord Robertson, the Nato secretary-general, who said that the Kremlin had agreed to allow in independent investigators.

Following talks with acting president, Vladimir Putin, on Wednesday, Lord Robertson said: "The president will be appointing an ombudsman, an international person of authority, who will look into complaints of human rights abuses in Chechnya."

But Moscow is denying access to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and has just refused to allow Mary Robinson, the United Nations human rights rapporteur, to visit the region or to send an envoy.

The ICRC declines to comment publicly on its findings of humanitarian abuse, but Mrs Robinson cited the ICRC as reporting that tens of thousands of civilians in Grozny had been left without water, food, power and medical care.

"Civilians faced 'a catastrophic situation'," she said, while Russian forces were violating the Geneva conventions governing conduct in war.

Following talks with acting president, Vladimir Putin, on Wednesday, Lord Robertson said: "The president will be appointing an ombudsman, an international person of authority, who will look into complaints of human rights abuses in Chechnya." But Moscow is denying access to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and has just refused to allow Mary Robinson, the United Nations human rights rapporteur, to visit the region or to send an envoy. The ICRC declines to comment publicly on its findings of humanitarian abuse, but Mrs Robinson cited the ICRC as reporting that tens of thousands of civilians in Grozny had been left without water, food, power and medical care. "Civilians faced 'a catastrophic situation'," she said, while Russian forces were violating the Geneva conventions governing conduct in war.

webTitle: Surgeon cleared over removal of womb

fields.headline: Surgeon cleared over removal of womb
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A consultant gynaecologist was yesterday cleared of serious professional misconduct after the General Medical Council found insufficient evidence to support allegations that he performed a hysterectomy unnecessarily and without a patient's consent.
fields.body:
A consultant gynaecologist was yesterday cleared of serious professional misconduct after the General Medical Council found insufficient evidence to support allegations that he performed a hysterectomy unnecessarily and without a patient's consent.

Caroline Richmond, a 58-year-old medical journalist from Battersea, south London, discovered her healthy ovaries and womb had been removed during a minor operation in 1992. Ian Fergusson, a senior consultant at Guy's and St Thomas's hospitals in London, admitted removing Ms Richmond's ovaries without her consent but denied removing her womb without consent and operating without sufficient surgical or medical justification.

He said he removed Ms Richmond's ovaries because he feared a lump he had found could be a malignant tumour, but said she had been warned of the risk of an emergency hysterectomy if the operation caused perforation to her womb. The GMC found there was insufficient evidence to show the operation had been performed unnecessarily.

After the verdict was announced yesterday in London, Ms Richmond, who is divorced and has no children, said she was devastated by the result.

"This shows that it is open season on women's bodies. A surgeon can do what he likes without prior discussion or consent," she said. "I never had a lump. The pathologist's report said that I had the bulky uterus that the hospital registrar found on my first visit.

"It makes a mockery of the whole process of consent. It means anyone going in for the most trifling operation can have their major organs removed." The GMC committee investigating the case said it had been one of the most difficult it had ever had to consider, and criticised the way Ms Richmond was counselled before the operation.

The chairman Rodney Yates said the committee recognised that these events occurred in 1992 and fortunately the procedure for obtaining consent has now been improved. Mr Fergusson told the GMC he was forced to make the decision to perform the hysterectomy in the middle of an operation to correct heavy bleeding from which Ms Richmond had been suffereing for 10 years.

Although he felt it was the best option at the time, with hindsight he said he would have woken Ms Richmond to ask her consent.

Ms Richmond said she felt she had failed in her aim to stop this happening to other women and added: "A surgeon can do what he likes to a woman without any prior discussion or consent.

"This decision makes a mockery of the process of consent. It means anyone going in for the most trifling operation can come out minus their major organs. This is the end of the road and it is very bad news for women."

Mr Fergusson apologised to Ms Richmond for the hurt he caused her. "I am greatly relieved by the decision of the council. We have all had a very stressful few days," he said.

Mr Fergusson said he always understood Ms Richmond had suffered an enormous hurt. "I acknowledge that hurt and I have felt very humbled over the years by causing it. I feel huge compassion for her and I want to apologise publicly for the stress I have caused her."

webTitle: Presidential hopefuls show interest in the world beyond

fields.headline: Presidential hopefuls show interest in the world beyond
fields.standfirst:
The US elections: special report

America's voters are now deciding the future for all of us
fields.trailText: Every four years people around the world watch with a mixture of fascination and helplessness as their future is decided in a contest in which they are disenfranchised and certain to remain so. The American president may not be as powerful as we sometimes imagine. But what he does and what he does not do can be as important to men and women in other countries as the policies of their own governments.
fields.body:
Every four years people around the world watch with a mixture of fascination and helplessness as their future is decided in a contest in which they are disenfranchised and certain to remain so. The American president may not be as powerful as we sometimes imagine. But what he does and what he does not do can be as important to men and women in other countries as the policies of their own governments.

This truth dawns afresh each time candidates for the presidency of the United States begin the process which, many exhausting months and billions of dollars later, will lead one of them to the White House. Those New Hampshire farmers, those South Carolina army veterans, those Hispanic Californian voters - they are not only deciding for America, they are deciding for all of us. The critical nature of what they decide can be confirmed by a look at the Clinton years. The combination of Clinton's faults and the irresponsibility of congress mean that many international problems that might have been solved or at least diminished are still with us. A recent Georgetown University study, analysing policy in such areas as Iraq, Haiti, Bosnia, Kosovo and toward the United Nations, concluded that the United States had failed to provide the quality of leadership required.

Clinton's worst sin in international affairs was probably procrastination, followed by over-cautiousness about what the American public would bear and by a failure to manage an admittedly difficult congress. As he tries now to put together a portfolio of achievements in foreign policy, their ambiguous nature is apparent. Progress toward peace in the Middle East and in Northern Ireland falters, while in Kosovo and Bosnia artifice does duty for genuine settlements. A blinkered pursuit of trade deregulation on American terms led to the Seattle fiasco. India and Pakistan went nuclear on Clinton's watch. Different American policies might have kept Russia on a steadier course. As it is, the spectacle of American envoys apparently trading a hands-off approach to Chechnya for Moscow's acquiescence to deployment of an American missile defence system is not edifying.

The new presidential contest seemed until recently to offer limited hope for change. But John McCain has ignited the campaign and, if he wins in South Carolina on Saturday, it might then broaden out to embrace some real discussion of America's international role. This is not because McCain is that much wiser, at least on the record, than his Republican rival, or than the Democratic candidates. All offer the same emphasis on the importance of protecting America, all tend to see dangers to America in the shape of rogue states. McCain would "roll back" those states, he said in a debate with Bush and another candidate this week. Bush, meanwhile, has said that he would "take out" Iraq's nuclear capacity if necessary. This big stick talk may be irritating but it does show the focus moving toward the question of the rights and wrongs of physical intervention. Intervention, in turn, stands as code for a general readiness to engage with the world. The will to intervene is part of that readiness, but so is an interest in policies that may avert the necessity of intervention. When the two Conservative candidates for the presidency debate whether intervention should be based only on national interest or also on values, we see the clear water between them and the isolationists in their party in congress.

New Hampshire showed Americans assigning the same importance to "world affairs" as they did to welfare and health - only taxation and "moral values" were ahead in polls. That helped McCain, not so much because of what he said, than because of what he is. America's foreign policy is embodied in a man who endured in Vietnam and who, 25 years later, argued powerfully for US action on Kosovo. Indeed, Kosovo launched McCain as a candidate. A man who has personal reason to know the costs of intervention is in a position to argue for it which others are not. More than his specific positions, however, the sense McCain gives of having a flexible mind, of being able to keep ahead of the game, may suggest to voters that he is likely to make the right choices, especially in foreign policy.

South Carolina is, as it happens, a place where these issues touch a nerve. There is the practical fact that 400,000 former military men live there, which puts defence and veteran's affairs high in public consideration. The question of which candidate will make the best commander-in-chief is not academic in a state with such strong military connections and one which is part of a region which, according to some theorists, has been consistently pro-interventionist since the revolution. The idea that America's oscillation between intervention and isolation has roots in its political geography, with the South always ready for a foreign fight and the North always anxious to avoid one, may not be wholly convincing, but there is perhaps a grain or two of truth in it. In any case, South Carolina's military bias could win the primary there for John McCain and thus transform the coming campaign.

To see critical questions for the whole world squeezed into the prism of American concerns, not to mention neuroses, is often dismaying. It would be heartening if, in political campaigning, there was more often discussion of international affairs which was not always militarised, in which the starting point was not always the security of Americans, in which the world was not routinely divided into allies and enemies. But an interest in security which grasps its international implications even if it may, for tactical reasons, not stress them too much in public is preferable to the unilateralism with which the Republicans have been flirting.

Even though McCain and Bradley have their own debts to big business, their performance, and their proposals for the reform of campaign finance have altered the world's view that the America presidency is a corporate auction. American voters have proved resistant to Bush's emphasis on tax cuts, suggesting they consider better social policies more important than extra money for the well off. The Vietnam generation from which all the presidential candidates are drawn are now having grandchildren and becoming more interested in the world in which those children will have to live. The conservative commentator William Safire has been so heartened by the prospects of the American right escaping the straitjacket of the Republican party establishment and the confines of narrow America First thinking that he ended a recent column with the phrase: "This is getting good." That may be going too far, but it could be getting better.

webTitle: Dewar acts to calm anger as Lockerbie prosecutor quits

fields.headline: Dewar acts to calm anger as Lockerbie prosecutor quits
fields.standfirst: Libya and the Lockerbie trial: special report
fields.trailText: Scotland's first minister, Donald Dewar, yesterday moved to allay fears that the prosecution of the Lockerbie bomb suspects was in disarray by quickly nominating a replacement for the man who had been due to lead the prosecution team.
fields.body:
Scotland's first minister, Donald Dewar, yesterday moved to allay fears that the prosecution of the Lockerbie bomb suspects was in disarray by quickly nominating a replacement for the man who had been due to lead the prosecution team.

In less than six weeks, Lord Hardie, the lord advocate, Scotland's senior law officer, was supposed to lead the prosecution against the two Libyan suspects at Kamp van Zeist, in the Netherlands. But he quit late on Wednesday - and appointed himself a judge.

The move prompted accusations that Lord Hardie had left the families of the Lockerbie victims in the lurch, and led opposition politicians to call for an immediate review of the way judges are appointed, particularly the notion of self-appointment.

During an angry exchange at first minister's questions, the Scottish National party leader, Alex Salmond, accused Lord Hardie of letting Scotland down in the eyes of the world. Mr Dewar dismissed this as "over-dramatic".

By yesterday morning there was growing concern north of the border that Lord Hardie's decision would leave a vacuum at the heart of the case against the Libyan suspects.

The Scottish executive denied the departure would affect the trial and Mr Dewar announced he was recommending to the Queen that Colin Boyd, the solicitor general for Scotland, should become the new lord advocate.

Mr Boyd has played a prominent role in the Lockerbie case, appearing in person for the prosecution at some of the pre-trial hearings in Edinburgh and the Netherlands.

Roseanna Cunningham, the shadow justice minister, said many people felt let down by Lord Hardie's departure. "He has been responsible for key decisions in the Lockerbie prosecution, and the least he could have done was see this very important trial through to a close," she said.

Families of those who lost their lives in the Lockerbie bombing said they were appalled by Lord Hardie's decision. Susan Cohen, from New Jersey, in the US, who lost her daughter Theodora, said: "I am appalled and amazed at a moment like this, that the lord advocate just decides to leave."

Lord Hardie recently came under fire over his role in the appointment of Scottish judges after a high court ruling that using temporary sheriffs was in breach of the European convention on human rights.

After the SNP claimed Lord Hardie had mishandled the incorporation of the convention into Scots law, the Scottish justice minister, Jim Wallace, gave Lord Hardie his backing.

webTitle: Tess and the happiness of a middle-aged man

fields.headline: Tess and the happiness of a middle-aged man
fields.standfirst: Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Theresa May arrived for education questions in the Commons. She's the Tories' shadow minister, and like most of her colleagues, is largely unknown to the public.
fields.body:
Theresa May arrived for education questions in the Commons. She's the Tories' shadow minister, and like most of her colleagues, is largely unknown to the public.

However, there is a soft porn star, who appears on a cable channel called Granada Men and Motors (or Boys and Boobs as it should be called) and so is slightly better known. Her name is also Teresa May, spelled without an 'h'.

Apparently this has caused some confusion, with phone calls and letters being forwarded to the wrong Tess.

One protested in a recent radio interview: "I was disgusted at the sleazy world the letters revealed. My namesake was asked to expose herself in public, to do things with men that most of us wouldn't consider in the privacy of our own homes, and to force herself into weird, unnatural positions for the cameras.

"She was told that it would make 'a lot of middle-aged men very happy.' Thank goodness I'm not a Tory MP." I myself am not acquainted with the thespian Ms May's oeuvre, but from my limited knowledge of porn films, they are all much the same. Typically a woman is in bed with her lover. They copulate. He goes to work and the pool maintenance man comes round. They copulate. He goes next door, where he finds a housewife sunbathing topless. You get the idea.

So the plot hardly exists, the dialogue is both banal and predictable. Which makes it almost identical to parliamentary questions.

The trouble is that once an event as dull and workaday as education questions takes on an erotic tinge, it becomes hard to make serious and sober political judgments. For instance, sitting on the second row, behind the Tories' first team, was John Redwood, now himself a humble back-bencher, with no more standing or prestige than Michael Fabricant.

On the front bench sat the newly promoted John Bercow, the Tory right-winger with the phantom rottweiler on a piece of string. I should have been reflecting that there was something quite grotesque about the fact that William Hague has room for Bercow in his team, but none for Mr Redwood. Instead, I could only think that Mr Bercow looked like the heroes of those chirpy 60s British sex films which generations of furtive schoolboys used to watch: Education Spokesmen On The Job, for example. "'Ere, darlink, wanna get acquainted wiv my differential top-up?"

(Education questions are conducted almost entirely in jargon. Speaking about schools with specialist status, Mr Blunkett promised to "cascade both their resources and their work outwards," whatever that might mean.)

Finally Theresa May rose to complain that the government had failed to fund the teachers' pay award. It was, she trembled, "the mathe matics of the madhouse! "This government is all mouth and no delivery!" she added, as I silently shouted: "trousers, the correct phrase is 'no trousers'."

Mr Bercow's moment came next. Why should grammar schools be forced to become non-selective because of "10 local malcontents?" he asked.

Estelle Morris, the minister, seized on this. "aha, the new Tory word for 'parents' - they are 'malcontents'!"

Mr Bercow looked glum as his phantom rottweiler slumbered beside him. The four female Labour education ministers then filed out for the obligatory orgy scene - yes, yes, I did make that up.

fields.headline: Absent friends
fields.standfirst: Some famous MPs rarely vote
fields.trailText: Some familiar figures have been proving elusive at Westminster. Tony Blair has turned up for only 5% of all votes since November, making him joint 622nd in a field of 659 with, among others, Robin Cook.
fields.body:
Some familiar figures have been proving elusive at Westminster. Tony Blair has turned up for only 5% of all votes since November, making him joint 622nd in a field of 659 with, among others, Robin Cook.

Gordon Brown has managed a mere 16%. Nineteen MPs have not voted at all: these include the Scottish first minister Donald Dewar, his Liberal Democrat deputy Jim Wallace, and the former Labour leader in Wales, Ron Davies.

Some prime ministers have been attached to the Commons and have kept turning up, not just to vote but to talk to colleagues and savour the atmosphere. Sadly, that is not Tony Blair's way. He neglects the Commons, no doubt thinking his time is better spent running the country. Robin Cook is often abroad. Donald Dewar has problems enough in Scotland without endless trains and planes to and from Westminster. And since Labour has such a huge majority, it is not as though every hand is needed. The problem of those who sit in two places is anyway temporary, since all are set to choose one or other address at the next election.

Whether constituents see things quite the same way is another matter. Though much business once transacted at Westminster is now handled in Edinburgh and Cardiff, the destinies of constituents still depend quite substantially on what happens in London. Years ago, there was a convention that an MP whose status changed - because he switched parties, or because he took a senior post in government - resubmitted himself to the judgment of constituents.

Most who did so were re-elected, often unopposed, though a few, like Churchill in Manchester in 1908, were rejected. To enforce that now would be impractical, as well as expensive. But its spirit deserves to survive. One MP, Cynog Dafis, Plaid Cymru MP for Ceredigion, has already decided that his two-way loyalty was short-changing electors and given up his Westminster seat. In an era which offers few plaudits to politicians, Mr Dafis deserves them.

Donald Dewar has problems enough in Scotland without endless trains and planes to and from Westminster. And since Labour has such a huge majority, it is not as though every hand is needed. The problem of those who sit in two places is anyway temporary, since all are set to choose one or other address at the next election. Whether constituents see things quite the same way is another matter. Though much business once transacted at Westminster is now handled in Edinburgh and Cardiff, the destinies of constituents still depend quite substantially on what happens in London. Years ago, there was a convention that an MP whose status changed - because he switched parties, or because he took a senior post in government - resubmitted himself to the judgment of constituents. Most who did so were re-elected, often unopposed, though a few, like Churchill in Manchester in 1908, were rejected. To enforce that now would be impractical, as well as expensive. But its spirit deserves to survive. One MP, Cynog Dafis, Plaid Cymru MP for Ceredigion, has already decided that his two-way loyalty was short-changing electors and given up his Westminster seat. In an era which offers few plaudits to politicians, Mr Dafis deserves them.

fields.headline: Diagnosing the dictator
fields.trailText: Your extracts from the medical report on General Pinochet (Mental barriers to Pinochet standing trial, February 17) inspire neither trust in justice nor confidence.
fields.body:
Your extracts from the medical report on General Pinochet (Mental barriers to Pinochet standing trial, February 17) inspire neither trust in justice nor confidence. The first, because the description of his condition recalls Josef Schwammberger, a doddery old man of 80, looking as though he was suffering from dementia, parkinsonism, or both, who, while not denying the charges against him, claimed he had no recollection of the second world war, but in May 1992 was sentenced to prison indefinitely for atrocities committed 50 years previously. Of course, the international lobby against Holocaust crimes may be more effective than that against abuse of civil rights of Chilean citizens, and he had no friends (even discredited ones) in high places to defend him.

The second, because the medical conclusions are open to question. "Multi-infarct" dementia, always a speculative diagnosis, cannot, unlike Alzheimer's disease, even be verified at post-mortem. Nowhere in the history you publish is there hard evidence that General Pinochet has cerebrovascular disease. Linda Grant (I hate him, but send him home, February 17) appears to set great store by the fact that brain scans (not referred to in your reports) "demonstrate that [he] is not deliberately deceiving the doctors". No scans can do that.

I am a consultant neuroradiologist. In 1980, I published with two colleagues one of the first papers on CT scanning in demented patients with cerebrovascular disease. There are general correlations, but these are statistical; many normally functioning people of General Pinochet's age have scans which show marked changes, and the reverse is also true.

One cannot confidently diagnose "multi-infarct dementia (or Alzheimer's disease) by imaging. Your reports do not detail the abnormal findings and neither I nor my immediate radiological colleagues are aware of the scans having been reviewed by a neuroradiologist expert in dementia diagnosis.

Thirdly, the grounds on which it is said General Pinochet would not be suitable for trial give cause for concern. Neither general debility (as in Schwammberger's case) nor deafness makes a trial impossible. One's cognitive abilities may influence the verdict or disposal, but are questionable as grounds that one should not undergo due legal process. The evidence for statements such as that "situational stress, as likely to be occasioned by trial... could accelerate the progression of vascular disease" would itself hardly stand up in court. Although there are concerns that the general could not follow a trial "his sense of humour remains intact".

British neurology is still smarting from the disgrace of Ernest Saunders' unprecedented recovery from Alzheimer's disease (diagnosed by a senior, respected consultant) after being released from prison.

One cannot imagine that the experts are supporters of General Pinochet, but one may suspect that they have bent over backwards to demonstrate that neither are they opponents. Should he recover in the clear air of the Andes, "multi-infarct dementia" may have to added to the list of reversible diseases.
Ivan Moseley
London

 It would certainly reduce prison overcrowding if all suspects who had a poor understanding of the legal system, an impaired ability to express themselves and a deficient memory of the events which led to their arrest were released.

Is Jack Straw going to apply this principle across the board or will it be limited to those, such as Pinochet, who have been involved in mass murder?
Dr Martin Juckes
Oxford
juckes@atm.ox.ac.uk

 Having Baroness Thatcher and Lord Lamont as bosom companions may have been a contributory factor in General Pinochet's mental decline.
Ivor Yeloff
Norwich
ivoryeloff@classicfm.net

 According to my wife, I would not have to stand trial for any crimes I commit.
Paul Holland
Bognor Regis, West Sussex

webTitle: Tory faces Commons ban over property cover-up

fields.headline: Tory faces Commons ban over property cover-up
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
Life in parliament: special report

Angry reaction by maverick as committee rules she abused her position and intended to deceive parliament over offshore trusts
fields.trailText: The maverick Tory MP, Teresa Gorman, is facing one of Parliament's most serious punishments - a one-month suspension from the Commons - for repeatedly covering up her substantial business interests from scrutiny by MPs or the public.
fields.body:
The maverick Tory MP, Teresa Gorman, is facing one of Parliament's most serious punishments - a one-month suspension from the Commons - for repeatedly covering up her substantial business interests from scrutiny by MPs or the public.

A report published yesterday by the Commons standards and privileges committee said that she "intended to deceive" parliament's senior watchdog body over her ownership of properties in south London and Portugal which were hidden in offshore trusts. She is also accused of contempt of the House of Commons and of abusing "her position as an MP" to smear accusers who gave evidence against her.

Yesterday Mrs Gorman, recently barred by her own party from the shortlist for London mayoral candidate, said: "I totally reject the findings of the committee. Since my election I have been disposing of my outside interests to concentrate on my job."

She branded the committee's procedures as "unfair" and said they "inevitably" led to injustice.

In her report Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commisisoner for standards, says Mrs Gorman failed to provide sufficient evidence to her that she has paid all her taxes on the secret property deals. Some of the properties were initially valued at between £50,000 and £70,000 and were later sold for between £180,000 and £400,000.

Ms Filkin upholds eight complaints against the Billericay MP. The MPs in their report uphold seven of these. These include failing to register in the Commons register of members' interests three large properties in south London between 1987 and 1994 and two properties in Portugal.

She "gave seriously misleading information in 1995 and 1999 about her connections with three offshore companies. She also found to have broken parliamentary rules by introducing a bill to repeal the rent acts without disclosing that she was a landlord. The commissioner also found that she had made false accusations against a person who complained to parliament about her - claiming he had been paid by the Mirror newspaper to make a false sworn statement. She was then found to have improperly contacted witnesses about her secret property deals during the investigation.

Ms Filkin said: "Mrs Gorman provided seriously misleading and inaccurate information to the committee on standards and privileges, the chairman (Robert Sheldon MP), the registrar of members' interests, Roger Willoughby, and me". She added that Mrs Gorman "neither fulfilled the registration requirements nor observed the principles of honesty and accountability which it requires".

MPs are particularly incensed about Mrs Gorman's repeated refusal to disclose information about three offshore companies. She provided "evasive answers or no answers at all." The information was only obtained by writing to the Guernsey-based trusts. They were also angry about her denial that she had ever owned property in south London where a Mr South was a tenant, and her claim that his sworn statement that he was her tenant had been "falsified for a cash payment" procured by the Mirror. She later had to admit this was wrong.

The MPs say: "We consider that Mrs Gorman abused her position as a MP." They conclude: "During our inquiry we have been gravely concerned by Mrs Gorman's untruthfulness, her failures to provide the commissioner with information, and false accusations she has made against others. We regard these matters as more serious than the failure to register or declare interests which were subject of the original complaint. They call into question the sincerity of the apology she made to the house (over a previous failure to declare a directorship)".

Mrs Gorman said last night: "I totally agree with the Neill committee (on standards in public life) report ... which recommends that the chairman (of the standards and privileges committee) should not come from the government party, there should be equal representation of parties on the committee, and there should be an appeal procedure before an independent judge and senior figures from the Commons.

"Judge for yourself whether this committee is independent or if it is a tool of the Labour party spin doctor industry," she said.

Last night the commissioner pointed out that Mrs Gorman would have no right of an appeal under Lord Neill's proposals because there was no dispute over facts.

The verdicts against Teresa Gorman

 Failed to register three properties in south London between 1987-94 which were let for a substantial income. Upheld by parliamentary commissioner and MPs.

Failed to register two flats in Portugal from 1987-90 and 1989-99. Upheld by commissioner, rejected by MPs.

 Gave seriously misleading information about connections with offshore companies, Partingale Holdings, Loxhill Investments and Kinloch Investments owned by Queenstown Trust. Upheld by commissioner and MPs.

 Failed to declare her landlord interests when she tabled a bill to repeal rent acts. Upheld by commissioner and MPs .

 Made false allegations against a tenant and the Mirror newspaper. Upheld by commissioner and MPs.

 Seriously misled and provided inaccurate information to MPs, chairman of the standards committee, commissioner and Commons registrar. Upheld by commissioner and MPs.

 Improperly contacted inquiry witnesses. Upheld by commissioner and MPs.

 Failed to uphold code of conduct for MPs by not being honest. Upheld by commissioner and MPs.

Commons offenders Other MPs who were handed heavy penalties

Ron Brown

The Labour MP for Edinburgh Leith was suspended for 20 days after picking up the mace and throwing it to the ground during a Commons debate on April 18 1988. He had the Labour whip withdrawn for three months and paid the estimated £1,000 repair bill.

John Browne

The Conservative MP for Winchester was suspended for 20 days in March 1990 after the select committee on members' interests upheld two allegations that he failed to declare business interests in the MPs register.

David Tredinnick

The Conservative MP for Bosworth was suspended for 20 days in July 1994 after it was revealed he had received money to ask questions in the Commons from a Sunday Times reporter posing as a businessman. Graham Riddick, MP for Colne Valley, who was also involved was given a lesser suspension of 10 days because he returned the money within a day.

Sally James

fields.headline: Better safe than sorry
fields.trailText: There are a number of serious misrepresentations in George Monbiot's article (Corporations kill and get away with it, February 17) . We agree that the law on corporate manslaughter needs to be updated and penalties for safety offences should be raised.
fields.body:
There are a number of serious misrepresentations in George Monbiot's article (Corporations kill and get away with it, February 17) . We agree that the law on corporate manslaughter needs to be updated and penalties for safety offences should be raised. Hence the forthcoming government proposals on the former, and private member's bill, backed by the government, on the latter. But to leap, as Monbiot does, to the conclusion that most accidents and ill-health are caused by greedy directors' irresponsibility, or that all should be prosecuted, is nonsense. Successful prosecutions have to be founded on evidence, not emotion, and responsibility for accidents is rarely so clear-cut as Monbiot assumes.

The health and safety executive - and the CPS in manslaughter cases - are not reluctant to prosecute. We have a published prosecution policy which we follow; we prosecute when the circumstances and evidence justify it.

And, far from "savaging" HSE, the House of Commons select committee report concludes that the HSE "effectively discharges its statutory functions". It also supports HSE's overall approach and welcomes many of its recent initiatives. Prosecution, high penalties, imprisonment of negligent individuals, all have their place in raising health and safety standards. So does sober analysis of the business case for investment in health and safety. But over-the-top sensationalism serves nobody's cause.
Jenny Bacon
Director general,
Health and safety executive

fields.headline: Open up on arms trade
fields.trailText: Robin Cook takes issue (Letters, February 16) with the Guardian's report of criticism of the government's record on arms export controls.
fields.body:
Robin Cook takes issue (Letters, February 16) with the Guardian's report of criticism of the government's record on arms export controls.

There has, as the foreign secretary points out, been some increase in openness through the provision of an annual report on arms exports. However, the report does not detail the specific type of the weapons exported, nor their value, number, or intended use. For instance, we now know that in 1998 the government licensed the export of assault rifles to Zimbabwe. We are still waiting to find out, however, if this licence was for 10 guns to be sent to arm game park war dens or 10,000 for the use of the army in regional conflicts.

In other areas progress has been more limited. Four years after the Scott report on arms to Iraq, the quadripartite select committee declared itself "dismayed" that the government has yet to introduce the new legislation the report recommended. This is urgently needed to stop arms exports and overseas deals by UK-based arms companies and brokers that undermine development, fuel regional conflict and contribute to human rights abuses abroad. Kate Allen
Amnesty International

Stewart Wallis
Oxfam

webTitle: A former victim's thoughts on tackling child abuse

fields.headline: A former victim's thoughts on tackling child abuse
fields.trailText: Of course Danny Carrick (Letters, February 17) is quite right to say the Waterhouse inquiry doesn't begin to scratch the surface of child abuse but at least, for once, there has been an inquiry, no matter how pathetic it may appear to those of us who have been abused.
fields.body:
Of course Danny Carrick (Letters, February 17) is quite right to say the Waterhouse inquiry doesn't begin to scratch the surface of child abuse but at least, for once, there has been an inquiry, no matter how pathetic it may appear to those of us who have been abused. In my day (Dr Barnardo's 1944-51) there were no effective channels of complaint and nobody inquired into anything. When I obtained my records last year they revealed my social worker (if that was what he was) saw me two days after admission and the day I left. It wasn't child care - it was child abandonment.

I've been abused by the best of them. One, a well respected lawyer, later became Tory mayor of an outer London borough. Another, a City businessman, became chairman of a renowned public company. Others attracted rave notices from theatrical journalists. These people were not staff. They were approved as "friends of the institution". Try complaining about their inappropriate behaviour in house and if the result wasn't the routine thick ear for being a "lying little tyke", it was just as likely to be a fumble up the trouser leg.

Abuse was classless, perpetrators ranging from those already mentioned to the boilerman. And that's the problem - their present day equivalents are still out there and are extremely difficult to spot. Child abuse is an activity we need to contain and if the word contain is construed as offensive, then I make no apology. Whatever various agencies claim, this evil, like war, is here to stay.
Brian C Thomas
Bexhill-on-Sea

 It is quite astonishing to find how weak the Waterhouse recommendations appear to be with regard to staff training, ie not even a proposal for a programme of professional training for all staff. Residential child care staff face one of the hardest jobs in the social care spectrum but with one of the lowest proportions of appropriately qualified staff. Aside from the NVQ vocational framework, which has been very patchy in its take-up and completion rates, there is almost nothing available for residential staff who want to pursue qualifying training.
Adrian Ward
University of Reading

fields.headline: Net effect
fields.trailText: Before the chancellor critisises British business for not making the most of the internet (BT hurt by Brown effect, February 17) he should make sure that things are working properly in his own back yard.
fields.body:
Before the chancellor critisises British business for not making the most of the internet (BT hurt by Brown effect, February 17) he should make sure that things are working properly in his own back yard. I visited the inland revenue website this week to get details about a tax booklet. I was asked to send an email to order it, which I did.

Two days later I received a one-page notification through the post (one piece of paper in an expensive A4 envelope) telling me that the booklet was out of stock but would be sent to me later. Why not tell me this by email - and save on all that paper and postage?

Should not Gordon Brown sort out the inland revenue, make them more efficient, environmentally friendly, and stop them wasting money before preaching to others?
Cllr Paul Lorber
Wembley, Middlesex
paul.lorber@brent.gov.uk

I visited the inland revenue website this week to get details about a tax booklet. I was asked to send an email to order it, which I did. Two days later I received a one-page notification through the post (one piece of paper in an expensive A4 envelope) telling me that the booklet was out of stock but would be sent to me later. Why not tell me this by email - and save on all that paper and postage? Should not Gordon Brown sort out the inland revenue, make them more efficient, environmentally friendly, and stop them wasting money before preaching to others? Cllr Paul Lorber Wembley, Middlesex paul.lorber@brent.gov.uk

fields.headline: Unnoticed
fields.trailText: A quick coda to your report (How Private Eye shook Whitehall by naming C, February 16) about my refusal to acknowledge the D notice system when I edited the CND journal Sanity in 1963.
fields.body:
A quick coda to your report (How Private Eye shook Whitehall by naming C, February 16) about my refusal to acknowledge the D notice system when I edited the CND journal Sanity in 1963. Twenty years later, as head of news and current affairs at Granada TV, I was summoned before a Commons committee enquiring into the D notice system. With the backing of Granada bosses Denis Forman and David Plowright, I told the committee Granada would not cooperate with the censorship system. In the remaining 10 years of my time at Granada, we never received another D notice.
David Boulton
Dent, Cumbria

fields.headline: Killers and victims
fields.standfirst:
Kosovo: special report

In a grimy mining town, the Serbs are getting away with murder. French troops won't stop the pogroms
fields.trailText: Albanian snipers fire at French soldiers of the Nato-led peace force in Kosovo. George Robertson, the alliance's secretary-general, promises a robust response. Other officials wonder aloud how the very people whom the troops intervened to save last year could turn their guns on their protectors. The spectre of Northern Ireland looms through the Balkan mist, while those who always said Nato's intervention was a mistake feel vindicated.
fields.body:
Albanian snipers fire at French soldiers of the Nato-led peace force in Kosovo. George Robertson, the alliance's secretary-general, promises a robust response. Other officials wonder aloud how the very people whom the troops intervened to save last year could turn their guns on their protectors. The spectre of Northern Ireland looms through the Balkan mist, while those who always said Nato's intervention was a mistake feel vindicated.

What, then, is going on? The violence is certainly the worst since the peacekeepers of Kfor entered the territory in June. Its flashpoint is Mitrovica, a grimy mining town a few miles from the Serbian border. In a thousand news stories the place is described as "the divided city of Mitrovica". The phrase is simple and, in a way, comforting. A river runs through the town. Everyone living on the south side is Albanian. The majority of those on the north are Serbs. Kfor is holding the line, sensibly reinforcing an ethnic divide which geography has decreed.

If only this were so. But Mitrovica's division is new, and the notion that its northern part always had a Serb majority is wrong. Until the Serb campaigns of ethnic cleansing last spring, Albanians formed the overwhelming majority on both sides of the river. The heartland of Serb rule was actually in the south, where the city's only Orthodox church is sited as well as the main Serb cemetery. By the same token the oldest Albanian mosque was in the north, though you would not find it today. The building was blown up and bulldozed last year, just as the main mosque of Banja Luka in northern Bosnia was "disappeared" by Bosnian Serbs a few years earlier.

So Mitrovica's division has political, not geographic origins. The city was emptied of most of its Kosovan Albanians last year. They were forced into refugee columns like the inhabitants of the rest of Kosovo. After his defeat in June, and sensing a chance to save something from the wreckage, Milosevic hoped to preserve Mitrovica, at least in part. Its closeness to Serbia made it strategically significant. The zinc and gold mines which adjoin it were top of the list of Kosovo's economic assets. Serb civilians moved quickly into Albanian flats. Serb vigilantes reinforced the bridges to prevent most Alba nians coming home. Their policy had a logic, to which the Albanians contributed. In southern Mitrovica the returning Albanians evicted the remaining Serbs and set alight the Roma quarter, charging them with being collaborators. Now refugees themselves, the southern Serbs retreated to their hoped-for fortress.

When Kfor reached Mitrovica, it had a choice. It could accept the Milosevic design or make it clear it would not tolerate partition, whatever humanitarian justification it might seem to have as a protective measure. The latter course would have meant flooding the northern part with troops and moving decisively to disarm the Serbs while also resisting Albanian revenge attacks. But, like Nato's war strategy, Kfor's peacetime policy has been excessively wary of risking its own troops' lives. It was also coloured by the fact that Mitrovica falls into the French-commanded sector of Kosovo. "Go back to Beirut in the early 1980s. The French philosophy of peacekeeping is to establish a 'green line' between the Christians and the Muslims and then just hold it," a British officer commented recently.

The French said their policy was temporary, but as the months went by despair and frustration grew in the Albanian community. Suspicion also developed that western governments wanted the threat of permanent partition as a device to stop Albanians from pushing for Kosovo's independence. Meanwhile, Serb hardliners hatched new plans. Two weeks ago they mounted attacks on the remaining Albanians in the north. At least 10 people died as gangs went from flat to flat, smashing front doors, throwing grenades, and firing at short range. It was a vicious racial pogrom, but the French troops' initial response was so weak that several UN policemen in Mitrovica, in particular a group of American officers, denounced it to reporters.

Many Albanians gave up. Close to a thousand fled the northern part of the city. Anger boiled over among the more militant who stayed behind in an enclave in the north known as Little Bosnia. They took their guns from under their beds and started firing, partly in self-defence against a new wave of Serb paramilitary grenade attacks, and partly - for the first time - at Kfor.

The situation is dire, but not yet irreparable. Beefed up by British, German, and Belgian troops, French soldiers have gone in to disarm the Albanians in the north. What they must also do is to go into Serb flats and conduct the weapons searches which they should have made long ago. They should help the Albanian refugees return before their flats are looted and burnt. They must warn off or detain the Serb paramilitaries. Mitrovica's division is not the solution. It is the problem, and unless it is reversed now, there may not be another chance.
