webTitle: The process is still alive but Peter Mandelson has fences to mend

fields.headline: The process is still alive but Peter Mandelson has fences to mend
fields.trailText: Perhaps it is one of the flaws of human nature that we often appreciate something only when it is gone. So it is with the politicians and people of Northern Ireland now. As the mood in the province sours by the hour, the players in the peace process are suddenly realising how much they had until last week - and how much has been jeopardised.
fields.body:
Perhaps it is one of the flaws of human nature that we often appreciate something only when it is gone. So it is with the politicians and people of Northern Ireland now. As the mood in the province sours by the hour, the players in the peace process are suddenly realising how much they had until last week - and how much has been jeopardised.

For the atmosphere has turned from one of gradual trust into a throwback to the bad old days of recrimination and suspicion. Until last week, those close to the Unionist leader David Trimble and his Sinn Fein counterpart Gerry Adams would quietly note how the two men had developed a working relationship. Each had realised the other was not a demon, but a politician facing difficulties and internal opposition - just like himself. Until last week, sceptics on both sides were beginning to be impressed by the 72-day-old power-sharing executive in which unionists, nationalists and republicans served alongside each other. A glimpse of a different kind of future was available - one in which two communities so long at war were beginning to see each other as partners.

That was until last Friday. On that day the secretary of state, Peter Mandelson, suspended the new executive, reversed devolution and restored the direct rule which had been in force for the previous century. Both the substance and the manner of that decision have angered republicans - and driven a wedge between London and Dublin. The result is that the highest ambition of all those involved in the peace process is simply to claw their way back to the position they were in seven days ago.

Sinn Fein's fury is directed at every aspect of the Mandelson decision. They believe it was without legal justification, in that the British government had no right to take its action unilaterally. The treaty signed following the Good Friday agreement required a joint decision by London and Dublin to collapse the executive. More passionately, they argue that it was premature since the IRA had just lodged a new position with John de Chastelain, the Canadian general in charge of decommissioning.

They say that represented a real shift by the IRA but that it was simply "binned" by Mr Mandelson. Finally, they accuse the secretary of state of pro-Unionist bias: he suspended the executive in order to save David Trimble who, in the absence of any IRA disarmament, would have been toppled at a meeting of his party's ruling council the next day.

The Unionists, of course, have no such gripe. They believe that the departure of Mr Trimble's progressive brand of unionism would simply have killed the peace process stone dead. A rejectionist successor in the Jeffrey Donaldson mould would have swiftly unravelled all the progress since Good Friday. In other words, Mr Mandelson had no alternative: he had to save Mr Trimble in order to save the peace process.

The awkward truth about Northern Ireland is that both those analyses have right on their side. Mr Mandelson was in a truly no-win situation. Whichever way he moved, he would have dealt a terrible blow to the peace proces. But this situation was partly of his own making - by effectively promising unionism last November that he would fold the executive if there were no IRA guns - and it was made worse by his timing. The secretary of state seemed too dismissive of the IRA move, as if failing to give peace one last chance. His task now is to drop the high-handed manner which has irritated many on the ground, and rebuild the mood of cooperation which was slowly taking root in the province.

webTitle: Pinochet medical reports vindicate Mr Straw

fields.headline: Pinochet medical reports vindicate Mr Straw
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: In the light of his medical report Jack Straw had no option but to excuse Augusto Pinochet extradition to Spain. No option, that is, once he had decided that he rather than the Spanish should gauge Pinochet's fitness to stand. The sooner Pinochet is stretchered off to Brize Norton and put on a plane to Chile, the better.
fields.body:
In the light of his medical report Jack Straw had no option but to excuse Augusto Pinochet extradition to Spain. No option, that is, once he had decided that he rather than the Spanish should gauge Pinochet's fitness to stand. The sooner Pinochet is stretchered off to Brize Norton and put on a plane to Chile, the better.

Of course it is open to human rights groups to continue challenging the home secretary in the courts. (It is hard to see how the Spanish, Belgian and other governments can complain, since they would also have had to assess Pinochet's fitness.) But if the case gets to the law lords, how could they conclude other than in Mr Straw's favour? To reject such a clear statement of opinion and fact by doctors would itself be unreasonable. Consultants are far from infallible. But in the light of the professional finding of "extensive damage to the brain", Amnesty and other potential appellants run the risk of painting themselves as vindictive and so damaging their moral standing.

The principle in the Pinochet case bears repeating. Human rights offences committed in one country have been made the subject of effective legal action in others and will be again. The absence of defendant Pinochet from Madrid does not diminish it. Indeed protracted British justice - a matter in which home secretaries may be too much involved - may even have embellished the claim that no country's boundaries can be opaque. Justice is procedure. Injustice is its absence, summary execution, disappearances at night, murder in cellars. Thanks to the drawn-out proceedings here, world attention has refocused on the Chilean past and so also on the role of army and right-wing forces in contemporary Chile. Perhaps Pinochet's detention was a factor in the recent triumph of the social democrats there.

But those are accidental bonuses. Pinochet allowed the Blair government to show its liberal street cred, though later it became mutely embarrassed at an affair that also held up for inspection the arrogance of law lords and the unthinking preference of home secretaries for secrecy. The leaked Pinochet medical file turns out to be cool and calm. It discusses an individual's mental state with objectivity. It is right that the need for justice to be seen to be done did in the end override the general's right to privacy. Jack Straw should never have refused to make these findings public.

fields.headline: We are winners, boasts Milosevic
fields.standfirst:
Cheers as president says his party waged a victorious freedom struggle against Nato.

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: President Slobodan Milosevic put his own spin yesterday on Serbia's disastrous conflict with Nato, declaring that it had been a triumph.
fields.body:
President Slobodan Milosevic put his own spin yesterday on Serbia's disastrous conflict with Nato, declaring that it had been a triumph.

"The name of Serbia is associated nowadays with the struggle for freedom and independence," Mr Milosevic told 2,000 delegates at a morale-boosting congress of his ruling Socialist party of Serbia (SPS) at a congress in Belgrade's Sava centre. "The SPS has succeeded in persevering in that struggle and coming out the winner."

The speech got enthusiastic applause and a standing ovation.

The congress was organised to rally support for Mr Milosevic and to raise his party's profile in a year when local elections are due. The date is expected to be set soon.

The Socialists hope to win back a number of major towns and cities where opposition parties took control in the last municipal elections in 1996.

In scenes reminiscent of the communist era, about 100 buses, packed with workers and peasants and decorated with photographs of President Milosevic, converged on Belgrade.

The congress re-elected Mr Milosevic as party president. He was the only candidate. Out of 2,314 delegates, 2,308 voted for Mr Milosevic. In the rain outside the conference centre, the crowds waited for for the president to arrive. On cue, they chanted "Slobo! Slobo!" as the Serbian leader swept into the building, surrounded by bodyguards.

"Their intention is to bring to Belgrade citizens from the interior to lend support to a regime which has brought calamity to Serbia," said Nebojsa Covic of the Democratic Alternative party.

An opposition-controlled TV station, Studio B, claimed that many firms in Belgrade had ordered their employees to turn up outside the Sava centre or face dismissal.

The police were out in force, stationed at major road intersections near the conference centre. Police officers emptied the car park outside the centre on the eve of the meeting searched the building with the help of sniffer dogs.

The opposition changed its mind after earlier calling for a counter-demonstration outside the congress, saying it feared that the Socialist party would provoke clashes.

The party congress was held under the slogan "Reconstruction, Development, Reform" - a reference to what the Socialists present as Mr Milosevic's reconstruction of Serbia following the war with Nato.

The conflict cost Serbia control of its southern province, Kosovo, which is now administered by the United Nations and policed by Nato-led forces.

Mr Milosevic was flanked at the congress by his political allies: his wife, Mira Markovic, who leads the neo-communist Yugoslav United Left party, and the Serb ultra-nationalist, Vojislav Seselj, who leads the Radical party.

International recognition was provided by delegations from more than 50 countries, including Russia, China and Iraq.

Journalists were screened at the conference centre: those from international media were admitted, but reporters from non-government media in Serbia were denied accreditation.

fields.headline: Anger in Lebanon
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Police fired tear gas and water cannon yesterday at about 2,000 students protesting outside the American embassy in Beirut against what they regard as US support for Israel's recent air strikes on Lebanon.
fields.body:
Police fired tear gas and water cannon yesterday at about 2,000 students protesting outside the American embassy in Beirut against what they regard as US support for Israel's recent air strikes on Lebanon.

The protesters threw rocks and tomatoes at the Lebanese troops and policemen who had cordoned off the embassy. They also burned an Israeli flag, chanted "Death to America" and "Death to Israel", and destroyed a drawing depicting the US flag bearing skulls instead of stars.

Witnesses said at least two students were hurt when police used batons and rifle butts to push back the demonstrators from a roadblock about 500m from the embassy compound in north-east Beirut. The confrontation lasted more than two hours.

After the students dispersed, the US embassy issued a statement saying it supported freedom of expression and assembly and had confidence in the commitment of the government of Lebanon "to preserve law and order and protect the safety of diplomatic missions and personnel".

The students also distributed leaflets calling for a sit-in today outside the offices of the US television channel CNN in Beirut, while unions called for a demonstration in the city to protest about the Israeli attacks and the US stance.

The demonstrators believe the United States backed Israel's air strikes last week which destroyed three power stations and a Hizbullah guerrilla base, and wounded at least 15 Lebanese civilians. The raids were intended as retaliation for a series of assaults by Hizbullah on a strip of land occupied by Israeli troops in southern Lebanon. Seven Israeli soldiers have been killed in the occupation zone since January 25.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, accused Hizbullah - whose recent attacks on the Israeli occupiers are believed by some observers to have Syria's backing - of being the enemy of peace and of attacking Israeli troops from positions in civilian areas in violation of US-brokered rules of engagement for the south Lebanon conflict.

Lebanon and Hizbullah have denied the charge. Hizbullah is the most active of the guerrilla groups fighting to oust Israeli troops from the zone set up in 1985 as a buffer against cross-border attacks in the wake of its invasions of Lebanon in 1978 and 1982.

Meanwhile, Lebanese leaders have condemned Israel's decision to appoint a three-person cabinet committee that has the power to order immediate strikes on Lebanon in retaliation for guerrilla attacks.

The committee is made up of the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, the foreign minister, David Levy, and the transport minister, Yitzhak Mordechai.

The Lebanese president, Emile Lahoud, described the committee as "a troika of destruction", while the prime minister, Salim Hoss, said that it "demonstrates the unlimited arrogance of Israel's power".
fields.bodyText: Police fired tear gas and water cannon yesterday at about 2,000 students protesting outside the American embassy in Beirut against what they regard as US support for Israel's recent air strikes on Lebanon. The protesters threw rocks and tomatoes at the Lebanese troops and policemen who had cordoned off the embassy. They also burned an Israeli flag, chanted "Death to America" and "Death to Israel", and destroyed a drawing depicting the US flag bearing skulls instead of stars. Witnesses said at least two students were hurt when police used batons and rifle butts to push back the demonstrators from a roadblock about 500m from the embassy compound in north-east Beirut. The confrontation lasted more than two hours. After the students dispersed, the US embassy issued a statement saying it supported freedom of expression and assembly and had confidence in the commitment of the government of Lebanon "to preserve law and order and protect the safety of diplomatic missions and personnel". The students also distributed leaflets calling for a sit-in today outside the offices of the US television channel CNN in Beirut, while unions called for a demonstration in the city to protest about the Israeli attacks and the US stance. The demonstrators believe the United States backed Israel's air strikes last week which destroyed three power stations and a Hizbullah guerrilla base, and wounded at least 15 Lebanese civilians. The raids were intended as retaliation for a series of assaults by Hizbullah on a strip of land occupied by Israeli troops in southern Lebanon. Seven Israeli soldiers have been killed in the occupation zone since January 25. The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, accused Hizbullah - whose recent attacks on the Israeli occupiers are believed by some observers to have Syria's backing - of being the enemy of peace and of attacking Israeli troops from positions in civilian areas in violation of US-brokered rules of engagement for the south Lebanon conflict. Lebanon and Hizbullah have denied the charge. Hizbullah is the most active of the guerrilla groups fighting to oust Israeli troops from the zone set up in 1985 as a buffer against cross-border attacks in the wake of its invasions of Lebanon in 1978 and 1982. Meanwhile, Lebanese leaders have condemned Israel's decision to appoint a three-person cabinet committee that has the power to order immediate strikes on Lebanon in retaliation for guerrilla attacks. The committee is made up of the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, the foreign minister, David Levy, and the transport minister, Yitzhak Mordechai. The Lebanese president, Emile Lahoud, described the committee as "a troika of destruction", while the prime minister, Salim Hoss, said that it "demonstrates the unlimited arrogance of Israel's power".

webTitle: Human rights advice to Iraq blocked

fields.headline: Human rights advice to Iraq blocked
fields.standfirst:
HM Customs and Excise
Iraq: special report

Whitehall uses UN sanctions to halt package first drawn up for UN
fields.trailText: An attempt to send documents to Iraq advising Iraqis on human rights and press freedom has been blocked by Whitehall as a result of United Nations sanctions.
fields.body:
An attempt to send documents to Iraq advising Iraqis on human rights and press freedom has been blocked by Whitehall as a result of United Nations sanctions.

A package containing the documents was sent by Article 19, the London-based anti-censorship campaign, to Mosul university in northern Iraq.

One document contains advice on access to health information, including family planning and Aids. The other is a comparative study of press freedom in democracies, originally drawn up for the UN.

In an episode of which Kafka might have been proud, Article 19 posted the package late last month. It was then returned with an anonymous notice saying it was blocked "due to international sanctions against Iraq". Customers were told that if they wished to send "goods" to Iraq they should obtain an export licence from the department of trade and industry.

The DTI said yesterday that anyone wishing to send documents to Iraq had to apply to it in writing, specifying what they were and to whom they were being sent. Alison Smith, of the department's sanctions unit, told Article 19: "A licence is required for anything going to Iraq". All applications, she said, were considered on a case-by-case basis.

The DTI added that licences were granted normally "for promoting business".

Andrew Puddephatt, director of Article 19, said yesterday: "Surely the UN's legal guarantee of the free movement of information and ideas regardless of frontiers should have some bearing on decisions taken by the UK on a UN embargo?"

He called for a thorough overhaul of the existing system which, he said, deterred all but the most determined from sending publications to Iraq".

Three years ago, the British Library told an Iraqi translator in the ministry of information and culture that it was prevented by the sanctions from sending him books, including a copy of Ulysses.

webTitle: South Africa and EU end trade row

fields.headline: South Africa and EU end trade row
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Weeks of haggling over grappa and ouzo ended yesterday when the European commission and South Africa settled a labelling row that had threatened to scupper a trade deal worth £10.6bn.
fields.body:
Weeks of haggling over grappa and ouzo ended yesterday when the European commission and South Africa settled a labelling row that had threatened to scupper a trade deal worth £10.6bn.

The South African president, Thabo Mbeki, told the commission president, Romano Prodi, that his government had bowed to an attempt by Italy and Greece to protect their famous grape skin and aniseed-flavoured spirits.

Several EU governments, including Britain, publicly criticised Rome and Athens for making an issue over the brand names. Ouzo is not even manufactured in South Africa and only 30,000 bottles of grappa are produced there each year.

"This has honestly been the EU at its very worst," said one diplomat. "Petty, small-minded and mean."

The long-delayed agreement phases out the use of the terms "grappa" and "ouzo" over five years in a dispute that the South African trade minister, Alec Erwin, called "bizarre".

Disagreement over the names held up implementa tion of a landmark South Africa-EU trade deal that was finally concluded last year after four years of tortuous negotiations.

In June 1998 Britain invited the then South African president, Nelson Mandela, to the EU summit in Cardiff to sign the accord, but it was not concluded.

The free trade agreement was supposed to come into effect on January 1, but the disagreement over wines and spirits jeopardised the overall deal, which will remove tariffs on 90% of two-way trade over a 12-year period.

The EU's failure to ratify the agreement provoked irritation in South Africa, which accused the Europeans of reneging on pledges to help rebuild their economy after the end of apartheid in 1994.

But the Europeans had long demanded that South Africa respect "traditional expressions" of their liquors.

Under the wine and spirits agreement, South Africa's wine industry was already forced to stop labelling wines as "sherry" or "port" following pressure from Spain and Portugal. Italy and Greece then jumped on the bandwagon.

fields.headline: Non-Republicans flock to McCain bandwagon
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: New evidence emerged yesterday that independent and Democratic voters are flocking to the banner of Republican John McCain in South Carolina on the eve of a party primary expected to have a decisive impact on this year's US presidential election.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Clemson, South Carolina
fields.body:
New evidence emerged yesterday that independent and Democratic voters are flocking to the banner of Republican John McCain in South Carolina on the eve of a party primary expected to have a decisive impact on this year's US presidential election.

A South Carolina poll showed the Arizona senator in a dead heat with his rival for the Republicans' presidential nomination, the Texas governor, George W Bush. Significant numbers of centrist Democrats and independents were signalling their intention to take part in the state's primary poll for Republican candidates tomorrow.

Among these cross-over voters, the poll results suggested Mr McCain has a 10% advantage over Mr Bush.

But the same poll, conducted by Clemson university, showed Mr Bush holding an 18% lead among Republican activists, who are more likely than cross-over voters to turn up for tomorrow's ballot. The study predicted "a heavy turnout favours McCain and a light turnout favours Bush".

It predicted a 2% win for Mr Bush, but the sample had a 3% margin of error.

In short, the race remained too close to call yesterday. Mr McCain is hoping for a repeat of the New Hampshire primary earlier this month, where a record turnout by non-Republicans gave him a 19% victory margin.

South Carolina is a far more conservative state, however, and Senator McCain's staff admit that he has been "haemorrhaging" support among rightwing devout Christians. The zeal of Mr McCain's opposition to abortion has been questioned by direct mail campaigns conducted by conservative pro-life groups backing Mr Bush.

But the McCain staff was hopeful that Wednesday's surprise endorsement by Gary Bauer, a religious conservative and former Republican presidential contender, would help the senator among voters on the right while he continues to woo the cross-over vote.

And the McCain campaign was also encouraged by a Gallup poll, which showed that while Mr Bush had a five-point lead over the Democratic frontrunner, the vice-president, Al Gore, Mr McCain led Mr Gore by 16 points, reflecting his cross-over appeal.

That appeal was clearly apparent in Clemson, a university town, where a young crowd of about 4,000 came to hear Mr McCain speak.

Ashley Twombley worked for the Democratic party campaign in the 1998 congressional elections, but declared himself a McCain convert. "I like someone who challenges the status quo. It's his character. He tells it like it is."

Mr McCain has even drawn some black Americans to his rallies, rare in a racially divided state. Tyres Tatun voted for the Democratic presidential candidate, Bill Clinton, in 1992 and 1996, but said he was now "older and richer" and was looking at the Republicans for the first time in his life.

Like Mr Twombley, Mr Tatun liked the Vietnam war veteran's military background.

As in New Hampshire, the South Carolina Republican primary is open to all voters, not just party members. The idea is to encourage the selection of a candidate with broad appeal rather than an ideological hard-liner pushed on the party by activists.

Mr Bush yesterday questioned the motives of Democratic voters, and suggested that they were supporting Mr McCain because they thought he would be easier to beat in the general election.

But Mr McCain countered that he was bringing Americans into the Republican fold: "If we win here, I don't really see how we can be stopped."

webTitle: Holiday that led to a living nightmare

fields.headline: Holiday that led to a living nightmare
fields.standfirst: Rachel McGee says her own stupidity caused her to get a 15-year jail term in Cuba for a drugs offence campaigners believe she did not commit
fields.trailText: What happened to Rachel McGee can be told in her own words, pieced together from letters sent home. She wrote often of her "foolishness and stupidity", she regretted taking the love of her friends and family for granted.
fields.body:
What happened to Rachel McGee can be told in her own words, pieced together from letters sent home. She wrote often of her "foolishness and stupidity", she regretted taking the love of her friends and family for granted.

The apologies were not, she insisted, admissions of guilt. They were the reflections of a bewildered young woman with time on her hands who accepted her life had gone horribly wrong. "This is a living nightmare," she said.

Not very long ago she drove a Saab convertible and lived in a nice flat in fashionable north-west London. Today she is in the Occidente women's prison near Havana, Cuba, serving a 15-year sentence for drug trafficking. British diplomats believe there was "little or no evidence against her".

Yesterday the foreign office was wary of saying anything to irritate the Cuban authorities while an appeal was pending, but the campaign and advice group Fair Trials Abroad was not so taciturn. "It looks like there has been an awful mistake," said its founder, Stephen Jakobi.

Maureen McGee, meanwhile, was trying to buoy her daughter's spirits and temper her own exasperation at a chain of events that seemed beyond their control.

Ms McGee's "mistake", if her story is to be believed, was a very familiar one in drugs cases - the offer of a cheap holiday. In October 1998 she was invited by her new boyfriend Karite Clacher, known as Remy, to join him on a three-week trip to Cuba. He offered her the £1,000 ticket for £200, saying it had been bought for his wife before they separated.

Ms McGee, who had only been abroad once, seized the opportunity. "I believe they had only known each other for a few weeks, but Rachel can be wide-eyed and easily led," said Mrs McGee, 48, who lives in east London. Her daughter had reservations. "For some reason, I didn't want to get on that plane at Gatwick," she said in one letter. "Now I know why. I never imagined in my wildest dreams something like this could happen, but it has. I wish I knew why."

She said most of the holiday was uneventful. The pair stayed in a rented apartment near the beach and mixed with two other Britons, Desmond Junior Gordon and Michelle Malcolm, friends of her boyfriend who had flown to Cuba shortly before them. The local police, however, were about to spring a trap that would change all of their lives. Following a tip-off, detectives were waiting at the Jose Marti airport in Havana for four men flying from Kingston, Jamaica, who were suspected drug smugglers.

Rendezvous

Jerome Blackwood, Nicanor Castro, Wayne Sharpe and Patrick Reid were arrested on November 16 shortly after collecting their suitcases. Hidden inside police found 15 kilos of cocaine, worth £9m on the street. The police did not charge the four because they wanted to root out their contacts on the island. Under surveillance, they were allowed to make phone calls and set up a meeting.

The court papers alleged the Jamaicans contacted Mr Gordon and that they agreed an 11am rendezvous in Havana's Hotel Libre, formerly the Hilton, three days later. Ms McGee's name was not mentioned in any of the conversations.

"She went to the bar with Remy," said her mother. "He'd told her they were meeting the other British couple. She didn't think anything of it. I think she was quite surprised to see other people there, but she wasn't suspicious."

Half an hour later Ms McGee decided to leave the group to meet two local women she had befriended earlier on the holiday. As her taxi pulled away from the hotel she saw dozens of police officers run towards the cafe and wrestle Remy and the others to the ground.

If the car had driven on she might have escaped prosecution. However, she got out and ran back. She was arrested, strip-searched and charged.

The raid was a coup for the police. Detectives discovered that the four Jamaicans knew one of the British men, and that they had cracked a drug smuggling ring with links to the US and Canada.

Although there was no direct evidence against Ms McGee, the police concluded there was a conspiracy that "suggested that all the participants knew about the drug trafficking" and that some of the cocaine was destined for Britain.

During police interviews Ms McGee denied any involvement. The Jamaicans said they had never heard of her. She pleaded not guilty, but was not given a separate trial or separate legal representation.

She was the only one of the accused who wanted to give evidence, but her state-appointed lawyer said there was no need because the police had nothing to implicate her.

In another letter Ms McGee wrote: "They are holding me here for drug trafficking, but that is rubbish. I don't know what proof they have. There can't be any. I'm guilty of being stupid, that's all."

Following a hearing on September 23 last year, the judges in the tribunal provincial popular convicted the group. Three months later Ms McGee and Michelle Malcolm, who had also pleaded not guilty, were sentenced to 15 years. The others, including the Jamaicans, received 20 years. Mr Jakobi believes Ms McGee was the victim of a miscarriage of justice.

"This seems very clearly to be a case of guilt by association. One lawyer acted for her and three other defendants. They stood in the dock together. There was clearly a conflict of interests.

"Rachel wanted to give evidence, but she could not. Testimony is always powerful evidence, and there should have been a presumption of innocence by the court. When the appeal comes, she must have her own lawyer."

Innocent

Sources at the foreign office and the embassy in Cuba believe that the court's "one in, all in" approach gave Ms McGee little chance. "There seems to be little or no evidence against her. She decided to go to Cuba at the last minute. She was in a taxi going the other way when the others were arrested."

Mrs McGee cannot afford the legal fees, but a businessman friend of the family, Farrell McHugh, has offered to help.

"I am anti-drugs and I am anti-drink," said Mr McHugh. "If I thought for a moment Rachel was involved in some kind of scam, I would say she deserves her time in jail. But I believe with all my heart she is innocent."

Embassy staff who have visited Ms McGee said she was trying to stay cheerful. "I'm getting used to the rats and lizards," she wrote recently.

"It was horrible at first but leave them and they leave you - cockroaches, big ugly ones, come up from the toilet [the hole in the floor]. I could live in a jungle after this. I've been having horrible nightmares since I came here."

With each letter, though, her spirit seemed to fade. "God knows, I really thought I was going to make it in the world. Stupid, I know, but I did. I want to come home. Why should I suffer when I have done nothing wrong?"

fields.headline: Hidden toll of rape victims
fields.trailText: Up to 295,000 women are raped or suffer other forms of sexual assault every year, according to new home office research published yesterday which reveals the hidden scale of violence against women in Britain.
fields.body:
Up to 295,000 women are raped or suffer other forms of sexual assault every year, according to new home office research published yesterday which reveals the hidden scale of violence against women in Britain.

The study says that the 6,000 cases of rape and 17,500 incidents of indecent assault reported to the police each year are a vast underestimate of the real scale of sexual violence.

It estimates that the true number of rapes and indecent assaults lies somewhere between 118,000 and 295,000.

The home office study also shows that the number of attacks by parental figures, former boyfriends or acquaintances and date rapes have increased throughout the 1990s.

Acquaintance rapes account for about 43% of all such attacks, with half involving somebody with whom the victim has known for less than 24 hours.

At the same time there has been a sharp fall in the number of rapes reported to the police which involve strangers; these now accounts for 12% of all attacks.

The research was published as the government announced a new £6m package of grants for projects around the country aimed at improving the dismal conviction rates for rape and giving better protection to women who are repeatedly beaten by their partners.

It is to be followed by a three-year £14m publicity campaign aimed at ensuring that everybody in Britain is aware of the realities of domestic violence.

Margaret Jay, the minister for women, last night said it was unacceptable that a quarter of all women would experience domestic violence at some stage in their lives and that many more women were so scared of rape or sexual assault that they were frightened to leave their homes.

"Women have a right to live their lives without violence or fear of violence," she added.

"It can have a devastating impact not only on the women themselves but their families too."

Home office ministers say that too many cases for rape and sexual assault fall through or are dropped by the crown prosecution service.

Hospitals and GPs will be expected to work with the police to gather evidence of physical injuries, to secure a better conviction rate when cases come to court.

Ministers also want schools to teach pupils on the realities of domestic violence as part of lessons about relationships, sex and parenting.

The home office research published yesterday says that the number of cases of rape and indecent assault recorded by the police is 33% fewer than the number of such crimes that women reported to them. In addition, it is well-known that rape and sexual assault are vastly under-reported crimes.

Studies have estimated that only between 10% and 25% of women who say they have been raped reported the offence to the police.

It also shows that rape is committed mainly by younger men.

The estimate of the true extent of sexual crime is born out by the British Crime Survey, which asks people about their experience of crime rather than relying on offences reported to the police. It confirms that the police crime represents only the tip of the iceberg for all sorts of offences.

The 1996 British Crime Survey reported that 4% of women said they had been physically attacked by a current or former partner in the previous year.

It also reported that 23% of all women said they had been assaulted by a current or former partner at some time in their lives.

The study says that the 6,000 cases of rape and 17,500 incidents of indecent assault reported to the police each year are a vast underestimate of the real scale of sexual violence. It estimates that the true number of rapes and indecent assaults lies somewhere between 118,000 and 295,000. The home office study also shows that the number of attacks by parental figures, former boyfriends or acquaintances and date rapes have increased throughout the 1990s. Acquaintance rapes account for about 43% of all such attacks, with half involving somebody with whom the victim has known for less than 24 hours. At the same time there has been a sharp fall in the number of rapes reported to the police which involve strangers; these now accounts for 12% of all attacks. The research was published as the government announced a new £6m package of grants for projects around the country aimed at improving the dismal conviction rates for rape and giving better protection to women who are repeatedly beaten by their partners. It is to be followed by a three-year £14m publicity campaign aimed at ensuring that everybody in Britain is aware of the realities of domestic violence. Margaret Jay, the minister for women, last night said it was unacceptable that a quarter of all women would experience domestic violence at some stage in their lives and that many more women were so scared of rape or sexual assault that they were frightened to leave their homes. "Women have a right to live their lives without violence or fear of violence," she added. "It can have a devastating impact not only on the women themselves but their families too." Home office ministers say that too many cases for rape and sexual assault fall through or are dropped by the crown prosecution service. Hospitals and GPs will be expected to work with the police to gather evidence of physical injuries, to secure a better conviction rate when cases come to court. Ministers also want schools to teach pupils on the realities of domestic violence as part of lessons about relationships, sex and parenting. The home office research published yesterday says that the number of cases of rape and indecent assault recorded by the police is 33% fewer than the number of such crimes that women reported to them. In addition, it is well-known that rape and sexual assault are vastly under-reported crimes. Studies have estimated that only between 10% and 25% of women who say they have been raped reported the offence to the police. It also shows that rape is committed mainly by younger men. The estimate of the true extent of sexual crime is born out by the British Crime Survey, which asks people about their experience of crime rather than relying on offences reported to the police. It confirms that the police crime represents only the tip of the iceberg for all sorts of offences. The 1996 British Crime Survey reported that 4% of women said they had been physically attacked by a current or former partner in the previous year. It also reported that 23% of all women said they had been assaulted by a current or former partner at some time in their lives.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Drop out barristers
fields.body:
Drop out barristers

Barristers briefed by the crown prosecution service drop out and have to hand over to a substitute in 50% of cases, a CPS inspectorate review of advocacy and case preparation said. In some cases a new barrister had to be found the night before a trial.

Judges told the inspectorate they were concerned about the quality of barristers fielded as substitutes, and saw a direct link between late drop-outs and poor case presentation. Clare Dyer.

Shipman inquiry in Manchester

The inquiry into serial-killing GP Harold Shipman is to be held in Manchester, it was announced yesterday. The decision followed a meeting today between inquiry chairman, Lord Laming, and MP Tom Pendry, whose Stalybridge and Hyde constituency includes Shipman's surgery and the homes of many of his victims.

Prescription costs up 10p

Paid-for prescriptions will cost £6 from April 1, though the government says the 10p increase (1.7%) is the lowest percentage rise for more than 20 years. Ministers have promised that the prescription price will not increase faster than inflation until at least 2002. David Brindle

Rainforest artist wins award

An Ecuadorean Indian, Ramon Piguaje, 37, who has never had a painting lesson, last night won the £10,000 Our World in the Year 2000 prize for his painting Eternal Amazon, a depiction of the rainforest in which he lives.

The shortlisted paintings in the competion will be on show at Mall Galleries, London, from February 23-26.

Arrested man takes overdose

A 40-year-old man arrested in connection with the death of a doctor who swallowed sulphuric acid has been taken to hospital in east London suffering from a suspected overdose, West Midlands police said yesterday. The man has not been named.

He was due to be questioned about the murder of Karenina Longe, 27, a senior house officer at Birmingham's Heartlands hospital, who died on February 6.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: Britain pays £1.5m to Nazi victims
fields.body:
Britain pays £1.5m to Nazi victims

Victims of Nazi persecution have so far been paid £1.5m in compensation for goods and money confiscated in Britain during the war.

Many of those who fled to Britain from Germany during the 1930s moved their assets here. But under trading with the enemy legislation in 1939 covering countries with which Britain was at war, many of those assets were confiscated as belonging to German citizens.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, yesterday announced that a panel had so far considered 300 of the 948 claims for compensation received, and concluded 160. "As a result we have been able to make payments totalling £1.5m to the victims of Nazi persecution or their relatives."

However, in a separate report the government ruled out compensation for property seized in Palestine. The trade department said that Britain, which had ruled Palestine under a mandate, had in 1950 "clearly settled" to pass on any responsibility to the Israeli government.

Up to 100 paintings and other art looted by the Nazis could be in British galleries, the arts minister, Alan Howarth, said yesterday.

His admission came as the government set up a panel to hear claims from people or their heirs who believe they had treasures stolen, and recommend compensation if necessary.

Mr Howarth said that it might also help if an account of a stolen work's history were displayed alongside it in museums.

Faulty goods cost buyers £8 bn a year

Defective goods, substandard service and poor information are estimated to be costing British consumers around £8.3bn a year, according to government research published yesterday.

The figure is around £180 a person every year, the office of fair trading said.

John Bridgeman, the director general of fair trading, said: "The research confirms what we have believed for some time, that complaints to trading standards departments - running at nearly 1m a year - represent only a fraction of overall consumer problems which are estimated to top 85m cases a year."

Second-hand cars cause the most complaints, with trading standards departments dealing with 90,000 cases last year. Next are electrical goods at 70,000 cases, home maintenance at 66,000, and clothing and fabrics at 47,000.

Food and drink top the list of unreported problems at 4.2m cases. Next come telephone and mobile phones at 3.8m, clothing, shoes and jewellery at 3.4m, gas, water and electricity at 3.4m and banking at 2.9m.

Problems with defective goods or substandard service account for nearly half of consumer problems.

These are followed by cases involving unfair selling techniques, misleading claims and misinformation, while 11% of cases involved problems with repairing faults or obtaining redress.

"This research gives some indication of the huge problem which confronts consumer protection authorities," said Mr Bridgeman.

Yesterday the consumer affairs minister, Kim Howells, announced plans to introduce legislation allowing trading standards officers to seek injunctions to stop rogue traders.

John Lennon's piano to sell for £1m online

The piano on which John Lennon composed Imagine is to be sold for around £1m, it was announced yesterday.

The upright Steinway, which was in Lennon's Ascot home, could become the most expensive item of pop memorabilia. It will be auctioned on the new eOffer internet site, set up by Fleetwood Mac star Mick Fleetwood and auctioneer Ted Owen, which is to be launched next month.

The piano was unveiled to the public yesterday at the Beatles Story museum at Liverpool's Albert Dock (above). Insured for £3m, it is being kept under 24-hour guard for its eight-month stay at the exhibition.

Although the white piano featured in the Imagine video is arguably more famous, the wood-finish pi ano is the one on which Lennon crafted the song.

Mr Owen said: "The memorabilia market has recently shown some spectacular results, with Eric Clapton's guitar going for half a million pounds.

"The [piano's] owner is a private collector and he's had it for nearly 10 years. He feels, like we do, that it needs to be in a museum and that's why it's being shown at the Beatles museum until October 9 which would have been Lennon's 60th birthday.

"We would like to see some national body or museum putting money forward to buy it."

This year marks the 20th anniversary of Lennon's death outside his New York home at the hands of obsessed fan Mark Chapman.

Imagine, originally recorded in 1971, reached number one when it was rereleased shortly after Lennon's death. The song was voted the UK's favourite lyric in a poll last year and the second greatest song of the millennium. Public affection for it led to a re-release just before Christmas and it went to number three in the charts. The Imagine album was reissued on Monday.

Student dies on tube track

The son of a well-known sculptor has died after apparently falling between two carriages of a Tube train.

London Underground is investigating the death last Saturday of medical student Edwin Doubleday, the son of John Doubleday whose works include likenesses of the Duke of Edinburgh and Sherlock Holmes.

It is understood that the 24-year-old, who was due to have completed his studies in three months, was thrown onto the track when a Central Line train lurched as it rolled into sidings. The train had just gone out of service and it is presumed Mr Doubleday did not hear three announcements advising all passengers to get off at the last stop, Liverpool Street.

Investigators are working on the theory that the young man might have tried to walk or run through the train against its direction of travel in an attempt exit on to a platform. It is thought he was standing on the metal plates between two carriages when the sudden jolt threw him on to the track.

A London Underground spokeswoman said that although no physical check was made on whether all passengers had left the train, the driver would have walked all the way through the carriages immediately after stopping in the sidings, as the train was about to resume service running in the opposite direction.

"We treat safety extremely seriously and will be looking into all aspects of this tragedy," she said.

Mr Doubleday, who lived in Manchester, was reportedly on his way to visit his family in Great Totham, near Colchester, Essex, when the accident happened.

Thieff who aided charity goes free

A "Robin Hood" yesterday walked free from court after stealing £17,000 from his employer and donating it to children's charities.

Christopher Barrington, 46, a financial controller, siphoned off the money from Direct Marketing Partnerships in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, after it stopped giving money to charity, Gloucester crown court heard.

Yesterday Judge Gabriel Hutton handed down a 12-month sentence, suspended for two years, and ordered Barrington to pay £150 costs, telling him he would not have to repay the money because he was in debt.

"I hope you have learned your lesson from your foolishness and criminal action," the judge said. "You pleaded guilty to stealing from your employer's company £17,635.58 and you say, and the prosecution cannot deny, that you received not a penny of that for your own benefit."

Barrington, of Ross-on-Wye, Herefordshire, who has five children and is a foster parent, electronically transferred the money over six months, the court was told. An audit uncovered the transactions after he left the company in July.

Barrington refused to name the charities in case they had to hand back the cash.

A statement on behalf of the company said it had a "generous charity policy" and "made charitable contributions last year and will continue to do so this year".

webTitle: Gonorrhoea rise suggests safe sex message ignored

fields.headline: Gonorrhoea rise suggests safe sex message ignored
fields.trailText: The number of cases of the sexually transmitted disease gonorrhoea has risen alarmingly by a third in the London area, it is reported today, leading to fears that safe sex is being abandoned and speculation that HIV infection will increase.
fields.body:
The number of cases of the sexually transmitted disease gonorrhoea has risen alarmingly by a third in the London area, it is reported today, leading to fears that safe sex is being abandoned and speculation that HIV infection will increase.

The incidence of gonorrhoea has been closely watched because, among heterosexuals, it appears to be spread only by unprotected sex. For that reason, it was chosen by the government as a marker for sexual behaviour and an indicator of HIV transmission in its Health of the Nation white paper in 1992.

Catherine Ison and colleagues from the Imperial College of Science and Technology in London and the London Gonococcal Working Group report in this week's Lancet medical journal an increase of 34.9% in the number of infections in the three years from 1997 to 1999.

The rise is a steep one. Between 1997 and 1998, cases rose by 12.1%, while between 1998 and 1999, they went up by 20.4%.

Gonorrhoea is the second most common sexually transmitted bacterial infection in England and Wales, after chlamydia. Nearly half of all infections are found in London. The 32 genito-urinary medicine clinics in the Thames region treated 47% of all male and 40% of all female infections in England and Wales, and 58% of all homosexually-acquired gonorrhoea infection. The researchers have been monitoring the incidence of the disease at 13 of these clinics.

Dr Ison said she and her colleagues had no easy explanation for the rise in gonorrhoea. "We don't have an answer to that," she said. "We know that the dramatic decline after the advent of Aids has been arrested and sustained over a three-year period."

Since gonorrhoea is solely passed on through sexual intercourse, "there must be unprotected sex going on," she said. But it was also possible that the organism that causes the infection had become more virulent, more transmissible or better adapted to survive.

The researchers had been surprised to find that the increase in gonorrhoea was in every age group and sexual orientation.

The 1992 Health of the Nation document set targets for reducing gonorrhoea, but these were met almost before it was published. Fear of Aids and campaigns for safe sex seem to have been the reason for a steep decline in gonorrhoea in the early 1990s. But there will be fears that complacency over Aids is leading to dangerously casual attitudes to condom use.

The government is expected to attempt to tackle this when it launches its sexual health strategy later this year.

webTitle: MI5 and MI6 in costs cover-up

fields.headline: MI5 and MI6 in costs cover-up
fields.standfirst: Secret services conspired to hide overspend on HQs
fields.trailText: MI5 and MI6 conspired in a cover-up to hide a huge overspend on their new headquarters, parliament's financial watchdog reveals in a report published today.
fields.body:
MI5 and MI6 conspired in a cover-up to hide a huge overspend on their new headquarters, parliament's financial watchdog reveals in a report published today.

The report by the national audit office - kept secret for five years - shows how MI5 and MI6, in league with the cabinet secretary, the treasury, and Whitehall's property services agency, kept ministers in the dark about the enormous increases in the cost of the two buildings.

It makes clear that secrecy surrounding the projects was used to cover up incompetence rather than genuine security needs.

Thames House, MI5's headquarters in central London, and Vauxhall Cross, the headquarters of MI6 across the river, together cost £547m, more than twice the estimate.

When ministers baulked at the rising costs after they were eventually told, MI5 and MI6 claimed that without the extra money their activities and the safety of their staff would be put at risk.

Parliamentary and treasury rules were secretly broken with officials agreeing to pay property developers and consultants in advance.

MI6 bought Vauxhall Cross - a stunning Terry Farrel-designed building on the river -before a brick was laid. MI5 bought Thames House, a listed Edwardian building on Millbank originally owned by ICI. They occupied the buildings in 1994, six years later.

The audit report says the trouble started when "heroic assumptions" were made about the cost of the buildings and the design of the interiors, not least because they did not take into account special MI5 and MI6 requirements. Some of these - including descriptions of sophisticated technology and communications equipment - have been excised from the report.

The audit report shows that MI5 spent more than £200m, four times the estimate, refurbishing Thames House and MI6 spent £75m, more than three times the first estimates, fitting up its headquarters.

It reveals that the then prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, castigated Sir Robin Butler, her cabinet secretary, for not keeping her informed about rocketing costs. Delays and repeated demands for upgrading Thames House cost taxpayers £20,000 a day. Consultancy and management fees for the building alone amounted to £37m.

The government agreed to publish the report after pressure from two former Tory ministers, David Davis, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, and Tom King, chairman of the parliamentary intelligence and security committee.

"Ministers were kept in the dark and secrecy was allowed to cover incompetence," Mr Davis said last night. Flawed purchases, he said, cost the taxpayer dear.

They also raised serious doubts about accountability. "The decision to pay quickly and in advance raised serious issues of value of money," he said. "But what is most alarming is the failure to keep ministers, and the prime minister, informed. Despite her concern at the estimated cost, the prime minister was not kept informed of the huge rise in forecast spending. This was plainly improper behaviour."

Secrecy surrounding the projects created a greater obligation on the part of those responsible to secure value for money. It was a "duty they failed to fulfil," Mr Davis said.

The report shows that concern about the cost was first raised by Robert Sheldon, the then Labour chairman of the public accounts committee, in 1992. In a report suppressed by the Thatcher government he said he was "alarmed" by the cost of refurbishing Thames House.

webTitle: Healing waters Scottish spa to be restored

fields.headline: Healing waters Scottish spa to be restored
fields.trailText: There may no longer be an audience of genteel ladies and gentlemen in top hats for its simple, if smelly, pleasures. But a Scottish spa once the toast of Victorian Britain is to be restored to its former glory.
fields.body:
There may no longer be an audience of genteel ladies and gentlemen in top hats for its simple, if smelly, pleasures. But a Scottish spa once the toast of Victorian Britain is to be restored to its former glory.

The Highland spa at Strathpeffer has lain semi-derelict for decades, but with the help of a lottery grant, there are plans to revitalise it - and the town.

The upper pump room of the spa, which nestles on the lower slopes of Ben Wyvis, will be used to tell the story of the spa and it is hoped that modern tourists will be attracted by the tales of trainloads of Victorians searching for mythical medical elixirs.

The spa became a popular resort after a certain Thomas Morrison declared in 1819 that its spring waters were "the most efficacious in the Britain".

webTitle: Scouts rebuked for boy's fatal fall

fields.headline: Scouts rebuked for boy's fatal fall
fields.trailText: A coroner said yesterday that two Scout leaders had failed to supervise properly a group on Mount Snowdon when a 10-year-old slipped and fell 600ft to his death.
fields.body:
A coroner said yesterday that two Scout leaders had failed to supervise properly a group on Mount Snowdon when a 10-year-old slipped and fell 600ft to his death.

The coroner Dewi Pritchard told the inquest in Caernarfon, Gwynedd, into the death of Jonathan Attwell, that he had been close to delivering a verdict of unlawful killing due to gross negligence, but had recorded accidental death.

The boy, from Bristol, was on his first walking expedition with the Scouts last October when he and 11 others aged up to 15 were taken on a descent of the 3,560ft mountain that was "entirely unsuitable" for such a group, the inquest had heard. He was the youngest, with no experience of mountain walking, and yet was allowed to walk at the back of the group, effectively unsupervised, on the difficult east ridge route.

All the way up the mountain, assistant Scout leader Matthew Wilson told the inquest, the deceased had seemed to be a strong walker and had no difficulty in reaching the summit. The weather was sunny and ideal for a group of inexperienced hill walkers; the inquest heard that, going up, there had always been one adult at the back of the group to make sure no one fell behind.

After lunch, Scout leader Peter Finlay showed the boys the chosen route down across scree, rocks and boulders, joining later with an easier path.

Although clear, the route they had planned took them across a loose scree scramble, parts of which could not be seen due to the steep concave slope it would take them down before joining with the easier Watkin path.

Shortly after leaving the summit, Mr Finlay, the most experienced mountaineer in the group, went ahead of three of the younger boys, allowing them out of his sight on a difficult part of the descent.

The inquest heard that it was not known how or when the boy had veered several yards from the intended route and probably slipped, falling from the east edge to his death. The first anybody knew was when one of two boys he was closest to realised he was nowhere to be seen, and raised the alarm. A mountain rescue helicopter later found him dead at the bottom of a gully.

A mountain warden, Samuel Roberts, told the inquest that the first he knew there was a boy missing was when Mr Finlay returned to the summit looking for him. Mr Finlay then guided Mr Roberts back down the route taken.

Mr Roberts told the inquest: "I would not take a group down that ridge. There are easier routes."

The coroner said that while going up the mountain the group had been organised. "Going down the slope that order somewhat disappeared. Initially Mr Finlay was the adult who was at the very back of the party. The most experienced member of the party was in the correct place.

"However, as they were going down the rough and in parts loose slope the positions changed. Mr Finlay went ahead of some of the younger members who were quite naturally at the back.

"By Mr Finlay being ahead of them, he could not have supervised them."

This lack of supervision amounted to negligence, said Mr Jones, but not to the gross negligence beyond all reasonable doubt needed for a verdict of unlawful killing. He was therefore forced to return a verdict of accidental death.

Afterwards, a solicitor acting for the boy's parents, Lyn and John Attwell, said: "This is the first opportunity to hear from the Scouts in public about what happened.

"We have been deeply disappointed with the lack of information received up to this point."

webTitle: St Paul's objects to proposed 'erotic gherkin'

fields.headline: St Paul's objects to proposed 'erotic gherkin'
fields.trailText: The dean and chapter of St Paul's Cathedral are objecting to Lord Foster's proposed giant glass tower in the City of London - on the grounds that the tower dubbed the "erotic gherkin" invited odious comparison with the cathedral's dome, and damaged its iconic status.
fields.body:
The dean and chapter of St Paul's Cathedral are objecting to Lord Foster's proposed giant glass tower in the City of London - on the grounds that the tower dubbed the "erotic gherkin" invited odious comparison with the cathedral's dome, and damaged its iconic status.

According to today's Building Design magazine the cathedral's architect, Martin Stancliffe, has written objecting to the proposal which the corporation of London's planning and transportation committee will consider next week.

The giant dome of St Paul's was one of the wonders of the world in 1710, when it was completed. Lord Foster's 180 metre tower is proposed as a new headquarters for reinsurance firm Swiss Re to replace the Baltic Exchange.

Mr Stancliffe said: "The proposed new building, while not being a true dome, will sufficiently resemble the outline of the cathedral to present a challenge."

fields.headline: Tunnellers fight to halt £90m road
fields.trailText: A council is facing a £5m bill for trying to evict "human moles" who have burrowed 20ft underground.
fields.body:
A council is facing a £5m bill for trying to evict "human moles" who have burrowed 20ft underground.

The eco-warriors have taken to the labyrinth of steel and concrete-fortified tunnels in protest at a proposed £90m dual carriageway in Essex which they fear will become an "M25 by stealth".

The five men, three of whom are seasoned tunnellers, claim to have food and water to last eight weeks and hope to beat the current record of 22 days for remaining underground, held by "Disco Dave", an activist in the protest against the second runway at Manchester airport.

But Essex county council is determined to drag the protesters out as soon as possible, even though it could cost it £5m. Around 25 activists have already been dispatched after bailiffs, armed with a court order, moved on to the site of the proposed A310 at Rettendon on February 6.

Some of the group, who set up camp last May, were pulled from trees, but the hard core retreated underground. A dozen specialist cavers and tunnellers now have to dig alongside them, or widen the passages, before they can pull them out.

Last night a spokesman for the under-sheriff of Essex admitted that the process was laborious. "We know there is one main shaft and two tunnels off it. But how long they are is a mystery, and we don't know how long this will take until we can find that out."

"Pordric", a spokesman for the activists, said the evictors had "a big shock ahead of them. The main shaft goes 16ft down, and then the tunnels lead up, go along, go down, wiggle up. The tunnels are 'worm holes' the width of a man, through which they crawl, but they're very complicated."

He said the authorities were pumping fresh air to the men - who could number more than five. They had eight weeks' supply of bottled water and other supplies. They had even constructed a toilet in a pit at the bottom of the central chamber, with air vents to the surface.

As for the residents of the traffic-congested villages to be bypassed, their tolerance has vanished.

"The protesters may have had some sympathy when they arrived to make their point," said a Rettendon villager last night. "But now everyone just wants them to go away so we can eventually get our peaceful lives back."

Meanwhile, up to 20 protesters remained under siege last night at Etheldore Heath, a second Essex environmental protest site, where security guards drafted in by a property developer have cordoned off activists and threatened to arrest supporters approaching the 8ft-high wire corral.

These eco-warriors are protesting at the construction of 60 homes on 11 acres of scrubland inhabited by rare wildlife. They claim the developers, Countryside Residential, are trying to "starve them out."

webTitle: Blair to head adoption law review

fields.headline: Blair to head adoption law review
fields.standfirst:
More about the Wales child abuse scandal
The issue explained: Children in care

Downing Street keen to make process work more smoothly
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is personally to take charge of a wide-ranging government review of adoption law in a drive to speed up the adoption process in the wake of the child abuse scandal in Welsh care homes.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is personally to take charge of a wide-ranging government review of adoption law in a drive to speed up the adoption process in the wake of the child abuse scandal in Welsh care homes.

The prime minister, keen to be seen to be acting swiftly to respond to concerns over the plight of some children in care, believes too many hurdles are placed in the way of couples wanting to adopt, leaving children to spend needless lengths of time in care.

He will chair a committee comprising the home secretary, Jack Straw, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, and the Welsh secretary, Paul Murphy, to examine the role of adoption in easing the problem, Downing Street said yesterday.

The review was welcomed yesterday by adoption bodies and social services leaders, but all warned against removing crucial checks on prospective adoptive parents.

Strict vetting procedures were specifically designed to weed out "people who are capable of perpetrating some of the evil abuse we have seen described in the Waterhouse report [on the Welsh scandal]," the Association of Directors of Social Services said last night.

Felicity Collier, director of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, praised moves to overhaul outdated adoption law, but pointed to statistics showing that only a minority of the 53,000 children in care in England are awaiting adoption, while thousands stay only briefly in care before returning to their families.

There were concerns last night among some in social services that behind the Downing Street announcement lies a furious row between the department of health and the home office over the way forward on adop tion. The DoH, which stresses that many children in care are not awaiting adoption, argues that steps already under way will ease the adoption process without compromising vetting measures, while Mr Straw is an advocate of more widespread and swifter adoption, and has called for more adoption of babies born to young mothers.

With the intervention of Mr Blair, who believes children are "best brought up in a stable relationship by a loving mother and father", it appears the home office approach has emerged victorious.

Mr Blair's review will lead to the publication of a consultation document before any new laws are introduced.

The prime minister's official spokesman pointed to an average wait of five years before adoption proceedings were completed for children over five years of age, and an average wait of eight months for newborn infants.

Adoption rates vary widely between social services departments, with some placing 31% of childen in care while for others the proportion is just 2%.

"Real hurdles are put in the way of couples who want to adopt," Mr Blair's spokesman said, disclosing that some authorities have to pay "transfer fees" of up to £12,000 to other authorities who recruit suitable adoptive parents.

There are also concerns that some departments are too dogmatic over ensuring a race or gender match between children and adoptive families.

Mr Blair has been told by officials that the number of adoptions each year has fallen from 20,000 in the 1960s and 1970s to about 6,000 per year - with half of those involving the child's own parent, or step-parent.

Adoption agencies and the DoH point out that the profile of children in care has changed radically since the 1960s, with the number of babies in care now far lower as the stigma of illegitimacy diminishes, and a consequent surplus of would-be adoptive parents.

The average age of children in care is over 10, more than 40% are aged 10-15 and fewer than 20% are aged under five.

fields.headline: Green vision for South Bank
fields.trailText: An audacious plan was unveiled yesterday to tip Jubilee Gardens, the slough of mud and building rubble on London's South Bank, on its side and slide three storeys of arts and commercial buildings underneath, transforming the existing complex into the largest arts centre in the world.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
An audacious plan was unveiled yesterday to tip Jubilee Gardens, the slough of mud and building rubble on London's South Bank, on its side and slide three storeys of arts and commercial buildings underneath, transforming the existing complex into the largest arts centre in the world.

The plan would double the size of the gardens - the last surviving open ground from the 1951 Festival of Britain site - which would be terraced over the new buildings, planted with mature trees, and modelled to include a 2,000-seater grass amphitheatre with stunning river views.

The redevelopment proposal covers the entire length of the 30 acre site, from County Hall to Waterloo Bridge. The London Eye, now expected to dominate the site for the next half century, is given pride of place in the computer graphics of the scheme.

The master plan was created by the American architect Rick Mather.

It is the third attempt in the last decade to resolve the problem of the South Bank arts complex. The site already attracts 3.5m visitors a year, not counting the National Theatre, which is not included in the plan, or the wheel, expected to sell at least 2m tickets this year.

However, local residents dismissed the plan as a "con". "Sticking a bit of grass on a roof is not preserving public open space, it's just providing a glamorous forecourt for a commercial development," said Emma Winkley, of the Waterloo Community Development Group.

The new Jubilee Gardens would be the start of a phased development retaining most of the present buildings and adding two new tall narrow "blade blocks", including residential and commercial units, which would help pay for the scheme.

The scheme would provide new homes for the British Film Institutute's cinemas and the Museum of the Moving Image, which temporarily closed last year, a new 1,500-seater classical music hall, a new flexible hall for amplified music and chamber opera, possibly to be created by demolishing the Queen Elizabeth Hall, and refurbishment of the Royal Festival Hall.

Service roads would be ban ished to one side, and a "high street" of shops and cafes created behind .

The Hayward Gallery would survive, but like all the other buildings would be remodelled to have its entrance at ground level.

Architectural competitions will be held to design individual buildings.

The South Bank chairman, Elliott Bernerd, refused to cost the scheme, but since refurbishment of the Festival Hall alone will cost up to £50m, the total cost will certainly be over £200m. Mr Bernerd said negotiations were in progress on public and private funding, but added: "We will certainly be rattling collection boxes."

The Arts Council has earmarked £25m for "an application of appropriate quality" and the heritage lottery scheme has promised £12.5m towards the Festival Hall.

The publishing millionaire Lord Hamlyn offered £17.5m towards an earlier proposal, which Mr Bernerd hopes to persuade him to invest in this one.

The previous schemes, a £151m proposal by Lord Rogers to encase the whole complex in a dome, and another by Terry Farrell which would have partly covered the site with a "glass wave" roof, foundered on cost and the need to close virtually the entire complex while work was carried out.

 The latest proposal to pedestrianise Trafalgar Square was unveiled yesterday. The plan by Lord Foster and partners would bar traffic from the space between the National Gallery and the square, but allow two-way traffic opposite.

However, Westminster council believes city-wide traffic reduction measures would have to be introduced before the scheme could work.

fields.headline: Smuggled chickens ejected from airliner
fields.trailText: Airline cabin crew reacted with understandable surprise when they discovered two live chickens on board as they prepared to take off for Malta from Gatwick. However, the pilot of the GB Airways aircraft knew the rules: he returned to the terminal.
fields.body:
Airline cabin crew reacted with understandable surprise when they discovered two live chickens on board as they prepared to take off for Malta from Gatwick. However, the pilot of the GB Airways aircraft knew the rules: he returned to the terminal.

The chickens had been smuggled aboard by a passenger in his hand luggage - evading airport security checks and an X-ray machine without so much as a warning cluck. After a search four chickens were found before the plane could leave.

No one, and certainly not the disappointed chickens, is likely to be prosecuted.

Sussex police said: "The crew discovered one passenger had two live chickens. He was with a group of seven Maltese nationals, and [at the terminal] they were asked to leave the plane. Two further chickens were found. The group had documentation to export these chickens but not by this method."

The police spokeswoman said she could not begin to explain why the seven had decided to export the birds as they did. "They were given strong advice not to attempt anything like this again," she added.

James Nicholls, spokesman for GB Airlines, said: "There are strict regulations about the carriage of animals in cabins of aircraft. We apologise to our other customers who were delayed. We are investigating with airport security to find out how this happened."

David Chappell, an animal inspector at Gatwick, said it would be impossible to prosecute the owners successfully unless it could be proved unnecessary harm had been caused to the animals.

"They were given strong advice not to attempt anything like this again," she added. James Nicholls, spokesman for GB Airlines, said: "There are strict regulations about the carriage of animals in cabins of aircraft. We apologise to our other customers who were delayed. We are investigating with airport security to find out how this happened." David Chappell, an animal inspector at Gatwick, said it would be impossible to prosecute the owners successfully unless it could be proved unnecessary harm had been caused to the animals.

webTitle: Row erupts over funding of children's social services

fields.headline: Row erupts over funding of children's social services
fields.standfirst:
More about the Wales child abuse scandal
The issue explained: Children in care
fields.trailText: The search for 28 "missing" people named in the Waterhouse children's homes report was nearing an end last night as a row blew up over government claims that it was pumping new money into children's social services.
fields.body:
The search for 28 "missing" people named in the Waterhouse children's homes report was nearing an end last night as a row blew up over government claims that it was pumping new money into children's social services.

The deadline passed at 5pm yesterday for local authorities and children's charities to check whether any of their past or present workers are among those identified in the report.

The list of former carers, teachers and residential staff - including some who are still considered a possible risk to children - was circulated by the department of health to 700 concerned agencies on Tuesday after the government ordered an urgent search.

As the hunt went on yesterday, a political storm erupted over the government's response to the Waterhouse report, with the Tories accusing ministers of "outrageous deceit" in re-announcing social services spending as "new money" to tackle children's social services.

Questioned about the report on Wednesday, the health minister John Hutton said almost £400m of "new money" was going into improving care.

In fact, the money - part of the government's three-year Quality Protects programme to boost services for children at risk or in care - was announced in September 1998 and began to come on stream last April.

The department of health last night insisted the money was "new under this government", but the Tories accused Mr Hutton of misrepresenting the funding and said the government was guilty of "fundamental dishonesty".

The Waterhouse report catalogued stories of abuse from 240 former residents of 40 children's homes in north Wales over 20 years.

In a separate case, an 82-year-old former employee of a West Midlands children's home was yesterday charged with seven counts of indecent assault against children resident in the home.

West Midlands police and social services are investigating claims that 14 staff were involved in physical and sexual abuse of boys at the Tennall assessment centre near Birmingham, which closed in 1985.

The alleged offences, reported by nine former residents, were said to have been committed between 1979 and 1984.

Not all those named on the list of 28 "missing" people are convicted paedophiles; some have been convicted of physical assaults and others have not been prosecuted for any offence. Anybody on the list found to be working with children will be instantly suspended and investigated.

Some people on the list are thought to have died, and at least one man is in his 70s, but fears remained that others could still be working with children.

 Two senior officials at a children's home were yesterday found guilty of a string of sexual assaults on boys in their care. Former deputy principal Barrie Alden, 66, and ex-housemaster John Wright, 56, abused eight boys at the council-run Ty Mawr home, near Abergavenny, south Wales, between 1966 and 1983.

Alden, from Norwich, who was found guilty of five indecent assaults, four serious sexual assaults and one gross indecency while at the home, which is now closed.

There are other abuse cases under investigation. Sentencing was adjourned until today. Both were remanded in custody.
