fields.headline: 'Just give me the porridge '
fields.standfirst: After 26 years in jail, Charles Bronson, cartoonist, poet and dangerous criminal, is given a life sentence for serial hostage-taking
fields.trailText: Charles Bronson, one of Britain's most disruptive prisoners, paid the price for the latest in a string of prison hostage-takings yesterday when he was jailed for life. Before he was sentenced for the false imprisonment of a teacher, Bronson told the judge at Luton crown court: "Just crack on and give me some more porridge ... why don't you shoot me?"
fields.body:
Charles Bronson, one of Britain's most disruptive prisoners, paid the price for the latest in a string of prison hostage-takings yesterday when he was jailed for life. Before he was sentenced for the false imprisonment of a teacher, Bronson told the judge at Luton crown court: "Just crack on and give me some more porridge ... why don't you shoot me?"

Bronson, 47, who has spent most of his adult life behind bars, claimed that he took Phil Danielson hostage at Hull prison in January last year because he was desperate to improve his conditions. He is now held in a segregation unit at Woodhill, Milton Keynes, where he is deprived of privileges, and has described his surroundings as being like a sewer.

Judge Ronald Moss praised Bronson for keeping a promise to behave during the trial, but said he could not shirk from his duty to protect the public and the prison population. "You are dangerous and unpredictable," he said.

Knifepoint

Bronson tied a skipping rope around Mr Danielson's neck and tugged him around for 44 hours at knifepoint during the siege. Mr Danielson, 37, from Bridlington, East Yorkshire, was the latest in a series of people Bronson has taken hostage or attacked in prison.

Over 26 years, Bronson has been held at more than 120 jails and has spent time at Broadmoor, Rampton and Ashworth special security hospitals. Prison service sources say Bronson, a former unlicensed boxer who holds world press-up and sit-up titles, is one of the 12 most dangerous inmates in Britain.

Bronson, who changed his name by deed poll to the star of the Death Wish films, first went to jail in 1974 when, at the age of 21, he was sentenced to seven years for armed robbery.

Since then, he has tasted fewer than three months of freedom. His sentences - he is currently in jail for conspiracy to rob - have been increased several times as the result of attacks in prison.

"Although nobody knows what is in your mind, your victims all have the same fear - that their lives are about to end," Judge Ronald Moss said. "You are dangerous and unpredictable, especially when you are upset and angry. Whilst there may not be any mental illness, there is clearly a continuing problem."

Bronson, who weighs around 14 stone and stands six feet tall, has been an imposing presence in court during the three-day trial. He was guarded by five prison officers.

Earlier, he was cleared of making threats to kill and assault after the judge ruled there was insufficient evidence. Bronson, who had denied all the charges, said he had taken Mr Danielson hostage because he feared that he was about to be moved from Hull prison, where he was happy. He was also upset about the death of his grandmother and angry because Mr Danielson had criticised a cartoon poster about Aids he had drawn. He said his head "went to pieces" but insisted that he had not hurt Mr Danielson and that they had become "friends" during the ordeal.

During the incident, Bronson, who was armed with two knives, one of them fashioned into a spear by attaching it to a broom handle, twice tried to harm himself. He smashed a bottle over his head and attempted to electrocute himself by tearing a washing machine filled with water from its socket.

Jurors heard that Bronson, a published poet and cartoonist who has won a series of prison educational awards, had lost three stones during a 40-day hunger strike last year.

Mr Danielson, a community education officer with Hull city council who was visiting Hull jail to teach another inmate when he was grabbed, said last night: "I was absolutely terrified for 44 hours. I knew how dangerous he was and that he had taken hostages before ... He still scares me to death.

"I find it incredible that a charge of ABH was dropped when video evidence was seen in court showing me being dragged around the prison with a skipping rope around my neck."

During the trial, Bronson was supported by a number of friends who are campaigning on his behalf. Freelance journalist Robin Ackroyd, who is writing a book about Bronson, said: "He took the sentence quite well in court but he will be very down. He has never been given a life sentence before and it is something he has always feared."

Publisher Stephen Richards, who has helped Bronson write two books, added: "He is not a monster, he is a sick man. He needs to be prepared for release and he deserves better treatment than he is getting."

Inside story of an eternal rebel

Charles Bronson is in danger of adding his name to the record books once again. On top of his entry for the number of hostages taken in British prisons, he may find himself holding the record for the amount of time spent served for offences committed in prison rather than outside.

In a series of illustrated letters sent over the years, Bronson expressed his raging sense of frustration at a system that he seemed unable to escape from.

The more he tried to express his anger about being contained, the more likely it became that he would be detained. Although he would have been freed years ago for the robbery for which he was originally sentenced, his inability to adjust ensured that he will now be inside for many years to come.

One of the most common images was of an explosion in his brain as he saw himself chained and behind bars. He expressed this frustration to probation officers and prison officers and it is an indication of his complex character that many of them understood and sympathised with his predicament while not excusing the explosive force he used to express himself.

His demands during one hostage-taking were for a helicopter and a cheese sandwich. The helicopter was to fly him to Cuba where he would have been able to compare beards with Fidel Castro and the cheese sandwich was in case he grew peckish on the way.

When he recently discovered his long lost son he was full of ambitious plans that would have involved the pair of them opening a restaurant together with Bronson supplying whatever security might be necessary. At last, it seemed, he had a reason to contain himself and hoped for a life outside. But once again the dark mists descended.

In the meantime, he continued with his illustrations and cartoons and had dreams of publishing a book that would warn young people about the perils of drug taking.

When he last appeared at the Old Bailey and was asked how he pleaded, he told the judge that he was "as guilty as Adolf Hitler."

It was a classic case of his hyperbolic notion of himself and his frustration with the criminal justice system that he believed had driven him mad. He felt himself to be like a character in Catch 22 - entitled to be mad by what had happened to him but too mad to be released.

After his last arrest for hostage-taking, he became silent and the letters that had been so full of enthusiasm and mordant wit - he had applied, he said, for permission to marry his blow-up doll - dried up. In the end, Bronson stands as a testimony to the failure of a criminal justice system.
Duncan Campbell

webTitle: Ahern cools row with No 10 over Mandelson's decision

fields.headline: Ahern cools row with No 10 over Mandelson's decision
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Irish premier Bertie Ahern yesterday sought to end a week-long simmering row between London and Dublin over the decision by Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, to suspend the power-sharing executive.
fields.body:
Irish premier Bertie Ahern yesterday sought to end a week-long simmering row between London and Dublin over the decision by Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, to suspend the power-sharing executive.

Mr Ahern said that he wanted instead to focus on finding a solution to the so far intractable issue of IRA decommissioning.

After Wednesday's summit at Downing Street failed to find a way forward, Mr Ahern and Tony Blair again talked on the telephone yesterday in an effort to agree a way of tackling the next stage. The Irish government is keen to avoid the expected round of inter-party talks being described as another review of the Good Friday agreement, because it feels that will hinder any chance of a speedy resolution.

Sinn Fein is expected to stay with the fragile peace process, despite its fury. As well as its anger over Mr Mandelson's decision, it was outraged at what it considered his patronising attititude at a meeting on Tuesday, shortly before the IRA's announcement that it was withdrawing from John de Chastelain's commission and rescinding its offer to move toward decommissioning, which came late on Friday.

Sinn Fein is also thought willing to allow Ulster Union ists to speak directly to the IRA, a move which would be politically dangerous for Mr Trimble. But some of his closest associates believe it could clarify the IRA's intentions, and even help foster trust.

Mr Ahern told the Irish parliament yesterday that there had been conflict between the two governments last Friday, when Mr Mandelson re-imposed direct rule in the face of the threat by the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, to resign as first minister. He said they had now agreed, with the Ulster Unionists, Sinn Fein and the nationalists SDLP, to move on.

He told the MPs: "Unilateral suspension was not something the government supported, because it was in breach of the British-Irish agreement. That happened because of the circumstances. The secretary of state acted because he believed any alternative was going to create even more difficulties."

Dublin sources and republicans claimed that there had also been disagreement on Friday between Mr Blair and Mr Mandelson over the IRA offer. Both Downing Street and the Northern Ireland office dismissed the suggestion.

A source at the NIO said: "There were different forms of words and different conditions attached to the IRA initiative floating around all day. It was impossible to pin them down."

Sir Josias Cunningham, president of the Ulster Unionists, had insisted he would put into effect a letter of resignation by Mr Trimble, dated the previous Friday, at 2pm unless there was news of a start to actual decommissioning. He was twice delayed, but insisted he would place it in the speaker's office at 5pm, so that the development caught the local evening news.

Sinn Fein, the SDLP and the Irish government have all criticised Mr Mandelson for making his suspension order because of an Ulster Unionist deadline, but he calculated that if Mr Trimble fell, the agreement was effectively finished. There is, though, no consensus on how there could be a return to devolution. A Northern Ireland office official said: "We believe we have agreed with Dublin how to tackle things. But there will be no immediate breakthrough."

Mr Trimble left for a week-long trip to the United States yesterday, where he is due to make a speech on the peace process.

William Hague was in Northern Ireland yesterday, and called for an immediate start to decommissioning.

Mary Harney, the Irish deputy premier, also argued for movement on the arms issue soon during a visit to Londonderry; she said no one in government should be able to retain a private army.

More about the Wales child abuse scandal
The issue explained: Children in care
fields.trailText: A woman care worker was yesterday suspended from her job after it was found that she was on the list of 28 "missing" people named in the report into child abuse in care homes in north Wales.
fields.body:
A woman care worker was yesterday suspended from her job after it was found that she was on the list of 28 "missing" people named in the report into child abuse in care homes in north Wales.

The unnamed woman, from the West Midlands, was working in a position which might have involved contact with children, the department of health said last night.

She was the only one found to be working with youngsters following a 48-hour search involving every local authority, health authority and NHS trust in England and Wales.

The Waterhouse report into the Welsh care scandal branded the missing 28, three of whom were women, unsuitable to work with children, and the government launched a hunt for them after the report's publication on Tuesday.

The department of health said last night that there was "no evidence that the remaining 27 are working with children in England".

Some who had slipped out of contact are convicted paedophiles and some others were accused of physical attacks. More than 700 organisations had until 5pm today to check employment records for their names. It is understood that those named have been tracked to addresses where they have lived within the past 15 months, but not all of the 28 have so far been located and questioned. Mr Hutton said last night that the search continued.

fields.headline: If apathy rules
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report

Key seats will be lost to the opposition if disgruntled traditional Labour voters stay away from the polls at the next general election
fields.trailText: Peter Kilfoyle is only the latest critic to allege the government has abandoned traditional heartland supporters in the drive to retain the allegiance of former Tory voters. A recent report from party headquarters at Millbank suggested the greatest threat to Labour at the next election is traditional Labour voters' apathy. It is not, of course, that these voters will support William Hague, rather that they will stay at home on polling day. Lamentable turnouts in the European and local elections last year, not to mention recent byelections,  have made this seem more likely.
fields.body:
Peter Kilfoyle is only the latest critic to allege the government has abandoned traditional heartland supporters in the drive to retain the allegiance of former Tory voters. A recent report from party headquarters at Millbank suggested the greatest threat to Labour at the next election is traditional Labour voters' apathy. It is not, of course, that these voters will support William Hague, rather that they will stay at home on polling day. Lamentable turnouts in the European and local elections last year, not to mention recent byelections, have made this seem more likely.

We can get some idea of the size of the potential threat to Labour of stay at homes by re-running the 1997 general election. In our simulations everything is the same as it was in the election except turnout rates of Labour voters. The illustration shows that if only 95% of the Labour voters who actually participated in that election turned out to vote the effects are fairly modest. The party would have failed to win only six of the seats it did win, including Labour ultra-marginals like Milton Keynes and Northampton South. If turnout is 85% of the actual rate however, the picture begins to look more serious. This would cost the party 38 seats, all but two of which would go to the Conservatives. Seats such as Newark, Reading West and Ilford North would be lost (or rather not won in the first place).

If turnout had fallen below 75% the government would have lost its working majority. The landslide victory of 1997 could be wiped out by the sort of electoral apathy we may already be observing in the European elections and in byelections.

These simulations assume that the Labour vote falls uniformly across the country. But that is not really the concern of critics such as Kilfoyle. Their argument is that Labour is neglecting its heartlands. If true, we should expect to see greater abstention by Labour voters in traditional Labour areas like the north-east, south Yorkshire and Wales. Paradoxically this is less of a problem for the government, since many of the seats in these areas will continue to be won, even if Labour loses a quarter of its votes. The really serious problem would arise if differential abstention were more likely to occur in Labour marginals. If this happened the threshold below which the party would lose its working majority would be raised - perhaps to 80% of the actual turnout in 1997. Everything turns on the question: what are the chances that up to 20% of Labour supporters will stay at home, particularly in Labour marginals?

Evidence of working-class discontent with the government emerged after the European elections of last year. In the monthly Gallup survey conducted in July 1999 voters were asked if they approved or disapproved of the government's record. Some 54% of middle-class voters approved (40% disapproved) whereas only 46% of working-class voters approved (43% disapproved). In the same survey some 51% of the voters in the south-east of England approved, but only 43% did so in the north and 42% in the north-west. To be fair these regional breakdowns are based on relatively small numbers of cases and the picture is somewhat mixed anyway, since 58% of the voters in Scotland approved. However, this does suggest that the government may have a problem with working-class supporters in some of its heartlands.

What can Labour do to offset such electoral apathy? The research on electoral turnout shows quite clearly that citizens are more willing to vote if an election is competitive. Thus the government may also suffer from the widespread perception that the Conservatives cannot win, which appears to make the next election a foregone conclusion. Unfortunately not much can be done about that perception short of Labour trying to boost William Hague.

Local campaigns by party activists are very important in mobilising voters. Certainly in 1997 Labour activists played a very important role in delivering the landslide election result. While the Labour leadership continues to enjoy high levels of support among these grassroots activists, they are much less happy about the government's record in delivering on the key domestic policy goals. This is a view shared with many voters.

This perception explains why the government has started to focus on policy delivery, although it is not very clear how successful this will be by the time of the next election, given the financial straitjacket placed on public spending in the first two years of power. But if it is successful it will help to motivate the activists to go out and campaign, particularly in the marginals. This will help to overcome the electoral apathy.

On the other hand there is something which the government can do more immediately. It could start to deliver on symbolic issues which may not cost money, but which Labour activists care about. For example, it is a safe bet that the great majority of activists strongly disapproved of the decisions to let General Pinochet escape justice and in the same week to let Mike Tyson into Britain. The desirability of sustaining diplomatic links with Chile and the economic welfare of small businesses in Manchester were cited as the reasons for these decisions.

The government would do well to reflect on the fact that Chilean diplomats and Manchester businessmen are not going to canvass, run committee rooms and deliver leaflets for Labour in the next election.

The party would have failed to win only six of the seats it did win, including Labour ultra-marginals like Milton Keynes and Northampton South. webTitle: New teen image is rebel with a cause

fields.headline: New teen image is rebel with a cause
fields.trailText: Teenagers are becoming more like their parents and parents more like teenagers as the traditional image of rebellious youth gives way to that of a rebel with a cause, according to a new survey.
fields.body:
Teenagers are becoming more like their parents and parents more like teenagers as the traditional image of rebellious youth gives way to that of a rebel with a cause, according to a new survey.

A poll conducted by style magazine The Face said that teenagers are now more ambitious than ever and want to make money, but that they maintain a strong social conscience and are concerned about issues such as homelessness and Aids. Thirty-two per cent of boys expect to run their own businesses and 51% believe there is still inequality between sexes, the poll showed.

"A lot of girls are quite ambitious and want to get out of small towns and make more money. Both sexes are more openly go-getting," said a spokeswoman.

The poll, in the magazine's March issue, also goes some way to maintaining the country's "Cool Britannia" image as it reveals 96% of the 1,000 teenagers questioned think Britain is a "good or OK place" to live in. And the poll showed today's youth are determined to spend their time productively, with 78% saying they want to go to university.

The poll also showed that social awareness is high among teenagers, who identify homelessness as a big problem in the UK they would like to see solved.

Over half - 53% - do not believe in God, while only 40% think Tony Blair is a fair prime minister.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Janine Gibson's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Janine Gibson's TV gossip.
fields.body:
While we wait yet another week for the government to tell us what it intends to do about the funding of the BBC, there's plenty of time to consider the finances of another major television institution.

Urgently in need of a whip-round is the show that launched a 1000 Playboy covers. Yes Baywatch, which brought us such talents as Pamela Anderson, Yasmine Bleeth, Geena Lee Nolin and Carmen Electra, is a rubber ring short of a rescue. The drama of choice for lifeguard voyeurs everywhere is facing yet another cash crisis and is - gasp - potentially beached for good. Speaking from its new home in Hawaii, the show's executive producer Greg Bonnan said he is asking the Hawaiian state government for $2.5m to solve a budget deficit which could put the show out of business.

How did things reach this pretty pass? Well, Baywatch has never been entirely secure, despite the worldwide affection for its core value of showing beautiful people running around in swimwear. When its original US network threatened the axe, the show's producers came up with the plan of funding it through its 148 overseas broadcasters. Then last year, in response to a certain lack of interest, Baywatch offered itself at auction to various tourist traps around the world. Hawaii is reported to have offered $3m to move the show, on the gamble that Baywatch Hawaii would generate around $35m of publicity.

Now, the ungrateful lifeguards are insisting that the state of Hawaii bail them out once more. "The situation is awful," says Bonnan. "If we can't get assistance, there's no chance the show is coming back. Baywatch will be out of business. Forever."

Blair, Brown, Smith & co have their hands full trying to negotiate an acceptable-to-all solution to increasing the licence fee, but does anyone spare a thought for poor old Baywatch? Apparently not.

fields.headline: Just say 'no'
fields.standfirst: Television isn't just a waste of time - it's destroying civilization as we know it. At least that's what an organisation called White Dot reckons. But do they seriously expect us to throw away the remote control for good?
fields.trailText: Television isn't just a waste of time - it's destroying civilization as we know it. At least that's what an organisation called White Dot reckons. But do they seriously expect us to throw away the remote control for good?
fields.body:
If you choose to watch Heart Of The Matter this Sunday (BBC2, 11.35pm) it will be a triumph for David Burke and the UK branch of the White Dot campaign, and simultaneously a great defeat.

It will be a victory because Burke wants you to watch the short film and studio discussion, during which he argues forcefully for you to stop watching television. And it will be a defeat because for Burke to get this message across, you will have to be watching television. In fact, the only people in Britain certain not to see the programme will be those Burke has already got his message across to. They'll be out enjoying the countryside, a good book or serious conversation.

In person, David Burke is as witty, persuasive and charming as his appearance on Heart Of The Matter suggests. (Another unavoidable irony is how comfortable and effective a TV performer he is, although, presumably, he'll never know this for himself.) He's no crank, and I doubt he has ever written angry letters to the press using green ink or a typewriter with the caps lock jammed on. His basic point is that, of our 24 allotted hours each day "we spend eight asleep, eight at work and only have eight for ourselves. And it's ridiculous to spend four of those watching this box in the corner of our rooms. It isn't real life: it's what we have instead of lives."

Burke, who lives near the South Downs, says we should all be out enjoying nature's bounty, or consuming almost any other form of entertainment than watching the TV. He blames the set for a whole range of modern ills, especially the ruination of our children. Burke points to research that suggests today's kids, despite a reputation as idle wasters and trainee criminals, are desperate to get out side and play healthily with their chums. But fear of crime, vastly exaggerated by TV news and dramas, scares their parents into keeping them indoors where they slowly turn into lethargic vegetables, capable of only watching TV, thus perpetuating the cycle.

"These people aren't your Friends or Neighbours," says Burke. "TV is not a medium, but a lifestyle, and viewers have lost the ability to imagine what other choices they have if they switch the set off." Every year, about five million people join White Dot to switch off for a week - that's five million out of the entire populations of the UK, Canada, the USA, France, Spain, Australia and New Zealand. But they'd like you to join them this year.

I think you should, but only because it's a good experience to try something different: read The Sun for a week, give up meat, stop drinking, don't use your car, sleep on the other side of the bed. Just don't do these all at once, or you'll need an evening slumped in front of the TV to recover.

But according to White Dot, TV isn't just unpleasant, it's insidious: "The most important feature of TV", says Burke, "is who controls it. It's concentrated in the hands of a few governments and a few large corporations. With this centralisation of control, who needs to burn books?"

And it gets worse: according to White Dot, new digital technologies will allow broadcasters to track exactly what we watch and for how long, and that this information, gathered against our will and without our knowing, will then be used to target advertising straight at us. Of course, supermarkets and even humble theatres have been doing the same thing for years, and I don't expect to see White Dot expanding their boycott to Asda or The Octagon, Bolton. But there is a serious privacy issue raised by modern digital media, including the web, phones and digital TV, and few would agree that the current Data Protection Act is up to the job.

The best parts of Spy TV are where Burke basically gets various marketing executive and interactive TV companies to confess, in an unguarded moment, that they can't wait to get their hands on all that data about us, what we watch and what we buy - and then use it against us. "The interactivity," says one, "will act as an automated agent, using marketing experience to sell products to you individually." And the only thing we can do to fight this, according to White Dot, is to refuse to participate: stop watching.

A minor irony is that one of the activities that Burke would rather we're doing than watching TV is surfing the internet, despite, as he says, "one cathode tube being much like another. But while the TV is passive and visual, says Burke, the internet is still mainly text-driven and invites participation, rather than just mindless consumption". And there's a third irony: despite his pleasantly persuasive nature, Burke has yet to win his wife over to the cause, so he does sleep under the same roof as a set.

So, why don't you turn off your television set and go and do something less boring instead? But don't forget to watch on Sunday.

webTitle: Who are you? What the Audi ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you? What the Audi ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: This stunning car ad simply features a man on a "wakeboard" (a sort of monoski), waterskiing and doing various impressive tricks as he speeds across the sea. Instead of being towed by a motor-boat, however, he is being pulled by a car - an Audi A6 in fact. There is no music or dodgy voiceover or anything: the powerful live-action is enhanced by just the gentle sound of the rhythmically lapping waves. "Vorsprung durch Technik", it says coolly at the end.
fields.body:
The ad: This stunning car ad simply features a man on a "wakeboard" (a sort of monoski), waterskiing and doing various impressive tricks as he speeds across the sea. Instead of being towed by a motor-boat, however, he is being pulled by a car - an Audi A6 in fact. There is no music or dodgy voiceover or anything: the powerful live-action is enhanced by just the gentle sound of the rhythmically lapping waves. "Vorsprung durch Technik", it says coolly at the end.

The jargon: Without meaning to encourage folk to actually drive their Audis around in salt-water, this "demo" commercial is promoting the car's quattro four-wheel drive system, which basically means top road-holding (and that you can take corners really fast).

Personality: The bullseye target is successful, dynamic, ambitious etc young professionals, but this spot is not forensically focusing on them - it is aimed inclusively at all men and women, says agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty, so you could be anyone... within reason.

Financial status: Audis are prestige cars, ranging in price from £18,000 to over £80,000, with the average costing around £25,000. Basically, therefore, you are earning rather more than the national average wage.

Telling lifestyle detail: Chances are you like snowboarding, climbing, wakeboarding even - in fact, any activity that is risky and stimulating. You also want a car that signals a more contemporary definition of post-millennial success than a BMW (80s Thatcherite materialism) or a Jaguar (60s old-boy networks).

Other relevant data: The wakeboarder depicted is a chap called Gavin Broadbent, who is New Zealand's wakeboarding champion. The ad was filmed in the Tasman Sea off the west coast of NZ, on a wide volcanic shelf which is just six inches deep.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: On Either Side Of The Mountain | Being Alive - Stephen Sondheim At 70
fields.body:
White River, a South African settlement near the Mozambique border, retains the firm divisions between its white and black citizens. Sue Lukhele, white and English, manages to operate On Either Side Of The Mountain (11.0am, Radio 4) both personally and professionally. Married to Bilal, a black South African, she daily commutes to teach in the rundown schools of the black township, her salary paid by White River's snooty private college.

Julia McKenzie presents Being Alive - Stephen Sondheim At 70 (10.0pm, Radio 2). Sondheim wrote his first musical at the age of 15 and seems barely to have stopped since. He attracted wide public attention with the lyrics he penned in 1957 for Leonard Bernstein's West Side Story. Five years later his own words and music for A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Forum became a smash hit.

fields.headline: Surgical solution
fields.trailText: How weird can you get? What is the most bizarre and unnatural request a human being can make without fear of prosecution? On the scale of Pythonesque freakishness made flesh, asking a surgeon to cut off one or both of your perfectly healthy legs scores pretty high.
fields.body:
How weird can you get? What is the most bizarre and unnatural request a human being can make without fear of prosecution? On the scale of Pythonesque freakishness made flesh, asking a surgeon to cut off one or both of your perfectly healthy legs scores pretty high.

But to watch BBC2's Horizon documentary Complete Obsession was to experience a strange reality shift. Because Gregg, the 55-year-old American with the lived-in face, is a heart-rendingly honest, decent, likeable guy. As one of the psychiatrists in the programme said with less than earth-shattering insight, he's nice. He walks through the sunlit city with a comfortable stride. His clothes fit. Nothing about him looks out of proportion or wrong. But he has desperately wanted, for the past 40 years, to have his right leg cut off above the knee.

And he knows what he wants is perverse. "You're sitting out there - you think it's nuts. I'm sitting here - I think it's nuts. I can't help it. It seems like my body stops at the knee of my right leg. It's just not me."

Wow. This was really hard to comprehend. You found yourself having to do a similar double-take to the one Gregg has achieved through years of wondering what the hell was wrong with him. He even trained as a psychotherapist to try to understand himself. This guy is not a sexual fantasist and he is not certifiable - a long way from it. But he wants half his leg removed - and he has done since he was 14.

Corinne wasn't raving either. She's a teacher. She's articulate and, like Gregg, incredibly earnest. Neither of them smiled and neither of them was embarrassed. Unlike the first of two psychiatrists they consulted in the UK. When Corinne told Dr Russell Reid she wanted both legs removed half way up the thigh, you could see him trying to suppress a nervous giggle. His eyebrows shot up into his hairline. "Both legs?" he asked. The whole thing seemed to be slipping into a sort of macabre comedy when he asked her whether she could make do with one amputation.

"One leg to me is the same as a no answer," she said solemnly. The psychiatrist appeared to need humour to cope. "You've clearly got your feet on the ground at the moment," he told her. "But it's a tall one." Corinne managed a smile. Throughout this interview, and the one with the second psychiatrist - the cigar-puffing Dr Richard Fox who asked whether she was a virgin - she was the one with the dignity.

This was an extraordinary portrayal of two people who are almost beyond comprehension, filmed over the course of a year as they pursued their strange goal. Psychiatrists and surgeons in the United States will not help people like them, suffering from what the psychiatrists call body dysmorphic disorder, for fear of being sued if they amputate healthy limbs.

Until January, surgeon Robert Smith would. He has seen a number of patients, referred by the two psychiatrists, and performed two amputations privately at Falkirk And District Royal Infirmary. Then last month, news of the surgery got out. Amid outrage and uproar, the NHS Trust banned further operations on healthy limbs on its premises.

Gregg's chance slipped through his fingers. He was within weeks of his amputation. We saw him angry, frustrated and finally, back in the United States, terribly upset. Corinne was refused the operation she wanted - the psychiatrists were concerned she had not told therapists of her desire to live in a wheelchair for the rest of her life.

Weird and bizarre their longings may seem, but there was no mistaking the deep-seated unhappiness of these two people. We saw both in acute misery, on the verge of tears. Their distress was moving. Smith the surgeon, walking through the Scottish woods with his dogs, was impressive. He operates, rather than have these disordered people try to maim themselves on railway lines. One of Gregg's friends died after seeking an amputation from an unlicenced surgeon.

Is surgery the answer? Smith asked the question himself and regretted that there appeared to be nothing else to help these people. In this strange looking-glass world, it was the psychiatrists who gave the least convincing account of themselves.

On the scale of Pythonesque freakishness made flesh, asking a surgeon to cut off one or both of your perfectly healthy legs scores pretty high. But to watch BBC2's Horizon documentary Complete Obsession was to experience a strange reality shift. Because Gregg, the 55-year-old American with the lived-in face, is a heart-rendingly honest, decent, likeable guy. As one of the psychiatrists in the programme said with less than earth-shattering insight, he's nice. He walks through the sunlit city with a comfortable stride. His clothes fit. Nothing about him looks out of proportion or wrong. But he has desperately wanted, for the past 40 years, to have his right leg cut off above the knee. And he knows what he wants is perverse. "You're sitting out there - you think it's nuts. I'm sitting here - I think it's nuts. I can't help it. It seems like my body stops at the knee of my right leg. It's just not me." Wow. This was really hard to comprehend. You found yourself having to do a similar double-take to the one Gregg has achieved through years of wondering what the hell was wrong with him. He even trained as a psychotherapist to try to understand himself. This guy is not a sexual fantasist and he is not certifiable - a long way from it. But he wants half his leg removed - and he has done since he was 14. Corinne wasn't raving either. She's a teacher. She's articulate and, like Gregg, incredibly earnest. Neither of them smiled and neither of them was embarrassed. Unlike the first of two psychiatrists they consulted in the UK. When Corinne told Dr Russell Reid she wanted both legs removed half way up the thigh, you could see him trying to suppress a nervous giggle. His eyebrows shot up into his hairline. "Both legs?" he asked. The whole thing seemed to be slipping into a sort of macabre comedy when he asked her whether she could make do with one amputation. "One leg to me is the same as a no answer," she said solemnly. The psychiatrist appeared to need humour to cope. "You've clearly got your feet on the ground at the moment," he told her. "But it's a tall one." Corinne managed a smile. Throughout this interview, and the one with the second psychiatrist - the cigar-puffing Dr Richard Fox who asked whether she was a virgin - she was the one with the dignity. This was an extraordinary portrayal of two people who are almost beyond comprehension, filmed over the course of a year as they pursued their strange goal. Psychiatrists and surgeons in the United States will not help people like them, suffering from what the psychiatrists call body dysmorphic disorder, for fear of being sued if they amputate healthy limbs. Until January, surgeon Robert Smith would. He has seen a number of patients, referred by the two psychiatrists, and performed two amputations privately at Falkirk And District Royal Infirmary. Then last month, news of the surgery got out. Amid outrage and uproar, the NHS Trust banned further operations on healthy limbs on its premises. Gregg's chance slipped through his fingers. He was within weeks of his amputation. We saw him angry, frustrated and finally, back in the United States, terribly upset. Corinne was refused the operation she wanted - the psychiatrists were concerned she had not told therapists of her desire to live in a wheelchair for the rest of her life. Weird and bizarre their longings may seem, but there was no mistaking the deep-seated unhappiness of these two people. We saw both in acute misery, on the verge of tears. Their distress was moving. Smith the surgeon, walking through the Scottish woods with his dogs, was impressive. He operates, rather than have these disordered people try to maim themselves on railway lines. One of Gregg's friends died after seeking an amputation from an unlicenced surgeon. Is surgery the answer? Smith asked the question himself and regretted that there appeared to be nothing else to help these people. In this strange looking-glass world, it was the psychiatrists who gave the least convincing account of themselves.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Spellbound | The Exorcist | The Driller Killer | Liar
fields.body:
Spellbound

(Alfred Hitchcock, 1945)

4pm, SkyCinema

Hitchcock's classic thriller mixes psychoanalysis and suspense. Gregory Peck is the distraught amnesiac posing as a psychiatrist, on the run for a murder he may or may not have committed, and Ingrid Bergman acquits herself as the typical Hitchcock blonde; frigid and rational until transformed by love into a swooning damsel who'll risk everything to save him. Despite a slightly anti-climactic end, the interest is sustained throughout, aided by love, psychobabble, a stirring score and Salvador Dali's unforgettable dream sequence.

The Exorcist

(William Friedkin, 1973)

10.10pm, Sky Premier

This left audiences fearing for their immortal souls. It has a grainily authentic look, as in Friedkin's French Connection. But while there may still be a little shiver as the camera edges up the stairs to Regan's room, once inside it's pure burlesque. Linda Blair is the possessed Regan; Ellen Burstyn, Max von Sydow and Jason Miller struggle with the beast.

The Driller Killer

(Abel Ferrara, 1979)

12midnight, FilmFour

Director Ferrara also stars as Reno, the crazy painter, goaded by the neighbouring, noisy punk band and the quieter mutterings of his paintings to take to murdering tramps in the streets with his electric drill. The art dealer (Harry Schultz) who stitched him up is also on the hitlist, but despite the gore-splattered reputation there's little explicit horror: this is much closer in spirit to the urban nightmare of Ferrara's King Of New York than to the one on Elm Street.

Liar

(Jonas Pate and Josh Pate, 1997)

1.15am Sky MovieMax

The Pate twins set out where The Usual Suspects leaves off, a man telling porkies in a police interrogation. He's rich, alcoholic, epileptic Tim Roth, being quizzed on the gruesome death of a woman (Renee Zellweger); the cops are Michael Rooker and Chris Penn, also troubled, shifty characters, and it's the grandstanding face-offs between the trio that lends some clout to what is at heart a rather mazy, implausible thriller.

webTitle: Lawrences scale down case against police

fields.headline: Lawrences scale down case against police
fields.standfirst: Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: The parents of Stephen Lawrence yesterday dropped their damages claim against 15 junior officers involved in the flawed murder investigation.
fields.body:
The parents of Stephen Lawrence yesterday dropped their damages claim against 15 junior officers involved in the flawed murder investigation.

Doreen and Neville Lawrence had issued writs against 41 officers, for their alleged racism, and were claiming £500,000 in damages.

They said they would press on with suing 26 senior officers, including the former commissioner, Sir Paul Condon, and launched an attack on Scotland Yard for refusing to pay compensation.

They said that their long struggle to achieve justice for their son had played a part in wrecking their marriage and left their lives in turmoil.

Mr and Mrs Lawrence said their pain had been exacerbated by the police's failure to admit fault.

A statement issued on Mr and Mrs Lawrence's behalf by their lawyer, Imran Khan, said: "It is difficult to overstate the damage and loss they have suffered over the course of almost seven years of police intransigence, errors, misconduct and racism."

On the eve of the first anniversary of publication of a report which damned the Metropolitan police as institutionally racist, the Lawrences said the force's failure to pay compensation showed it had learned nothing, the statement said.

Mr and Mrs Lawrence had dropped the claim against the junior officers to concentrate "on the more senior officers who support their actions".

Stephen Lawrence, 18, was stabbed to death by a racist gang at a bus stop in London in April 1993.

No one has been convicted of the murder and the Lawrences are also suing the five main suspects for damages.

webTitle: Refurbished Mir to offer room with a view

fields.headline: Refurbished Mir to offer room with a view
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Baked, frozen, sprayed with micro-meteorites, crashed into, punctured, burned and condemned, the Mir space station is about to be submitted to the ultimate ordeal: tourists.
fields.body:
Baked, frozen, sprayed with micro-meteorites, crashed into, punctured, burned and condemned, the Mir space station is about to be submitted to the ultimate ordeal: tourists.

Visitors will have to be rich, they will have to be fit, and they will have to have time on their hands. But the international consortium that yesterday pledged to rescue Mir from a violent retirement in the Pacific ocean said it was already talking to potential clients, and insisted the space station had enough commercial potential to stay in orbit without Russian or US government help.

The consortium, known as MirCorp, signed a leasing agreement yesterday with Mir's builders and operators, the Russian firm Energiya, to rent the 13-year-old craft to all comers who qualify.

Transferring estate agent-speak to the cosmos for the first time, MirCorp's blurb burbled: "Mir's orbit offers a unique environment that is free of the constraints of gravity and with unmatched views of the Earth and heavens."

Mir, costly to keep in space even when untenanted, was to have been dropped from orbit through the atmosphere, streaming fire, into the ocean later this year.

But Energiya, and the wider Russian scientific community, have never been comfortable with abandoning this potent symbol of the glory days of Soviet research in favour of a junior role in the western-dominated, English-speaking environment of the new international space station.

Enter MirCorp, an eclectic, diffuse alliance of Moscow-based Energiya, the US venture capital firm Gold & Appel, and other miscellaneous investors such as Chirinjeev Kathuria, head of Britain's third-biggest internet service provider, X-Stream.

Registered in Bermuda, based in the Netherlands and with the focus of its operations in Russia, Kazakhstan and space, MirCorp is confident it can raise the money to keep the space station aloft. The company says it partially financed the launch of an unmanned cargo ship to Mir earlier this month, carrying fuel and air for a manned mission in March, for which MirCorp will also help pay.

Dr Kathuria said the cosmonauts on the 45-day March mission would act in part as surveyors, working out what needed to be fixed in the elderly vessel.

He estimated that MirCorp would need to raise a further $150m (£93.3m) to keep the space station in orbit in the short term.

Dr Kathuria said he hoped shares in MirCorp - which has yet to be floated on any stock exchange - would be the pioneers in a space stock boom, like the market in internet company shares.

The company hopes to generate income by leasing Mir to commercial researchers who want to see how drugs and new materials can be made in near weightless conditions, even though Nasa and Soviet space scientists have not made breakthroughs with experiments such as these in the past. The firm also plans to launch a website showing live colour pictures of Earth beamed from cameras on Mir.

But it is the notion of space tourism that is likely to create the greatest interest among potential corporate investors and the public.

Jeffrey Manber, MirCorp's president, said one wealthy tourist was already on the waiting list.

"We are currently, and have been for some time, in discussions with one such individual. He's very excited," Mr Manber said. "He comes from a family that has some space experience. These negotiations might go somewhere."

MirCorp prefers to call its tourists "citizen explorers".

"They'll have to be very wealthy people, very adventurous people. They'll have to be people able to undergo very rigorous psychological and physical testing," Mr Manber said.

"So it's an extremely small group of people, but I think there are a lot of people out there, myself included, who would love to go."

webTitle: Committee chairman collapses with suspected heart attack

fields.headline: Committee chairman collapses with suspected heart attack
fields.trailText: The veteran Labour MP Robert Sheldon was in intensive care at a London hospital last night after collapsing with a suspected heart attack while walking to the Commons.
fields.body:
The veteran Labour MP Robert Sheldon was in intensive care at a London hospital last night after collapsing with a suspected heart attack while walking to the Commons.

Last night Mr Sheldon's constituency office said he was in St Thomas's hospital, and his condition was "very serious".

His collapse may increase pressure on elderly MPs on both sides to join the 30 or more who have said they will step down at the next general election, though some are suspected of intending to wait until the last minute to help their party headquarters to "parachute in" favoured contenders.

Mr Sheldon, 76, MP for Ashton-under-Lyne and the second oldest member of the Commons, is among those planning to quit. He has been an active chairman of important parliamentary committees since he ceased to be a treasury minister in 1979.

He was taken ill on the day that one committee he chairs - policing standards and privileges in the post-Nolan era - issued a critical report on the Conservative MP Teresa Gorman. She is 68 and has said she will retire next time.

So has Labour's Tony Benn, 74, and the Tories' Sir Geoffrey Johnson-Smith, 75, and Sir Peter Emery, 74. But the former prime minister Sir Edward Heath, who is 83 and the longest serving MP - Father of the House - has given no sign of stepping down after more than 50 years.

Piara Khabra, Labour MP for Ealing Southall, 75, has made no move. Nor has Labour's Sir Ray Powell, 71, whose seat at Ogmore, south Wales, was the subject of intense speculation in 1997 when he revealed he had been offered a peerage to step aside. He declined.

In a youth-conscious era, where £47,000-a-year MPs now have better pensions and hopes of a late career change, fewer older politicians hang around beyond 65. Those who do include "awkward squad" members Tam Dalyell and Dennis Skinner, both 67, and Gwyneth Dunwoody, 69, who has enjoyed a late flourish as chairwoman of the transport select committee.

fields.headline: Air control sell-off 'worst option'
fields.standfirst:
MPs warn of job cuts, fare rises and security risks

More about the privatisation of air traffic control
Air traffic control explained
fields.trailText: John Prescott's £1bn plan to privatise air traffic control was condemned by MPs yesterday for jeopardising safety and being the "worst possible option".
fields.body:
John Prescott's £1bn plan to privatise air traffic control was condemned by MPs yesterday for jeopardising safety and being the "worst possible option".

Gwyneth Dunwoody, chairwoman of the all-party transport committee, said the transport secretary should "very sincerely think again", as the committee's report revealed a long list of objections to the proposal, which is in transport legislation going through the Commons. The proposal was described as flawed and disingenuous.

The report said that if air traffic control (Nats) was sold to a private company, jobs would be cut, fares would rise and national security could be threatened.

The government had failed to make a positive case for a public-private partnership, and had failed to give adequate reasons for rejecting other options, such as an independent, publicly owned organisation like the post office or a trust.

In a conciliatory move, the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, said the government had not ruled out some options put forward by opponents of privatisation, including setting up a trust, "but we have to reserve the right to go for any strategic partner of our choice".

He said that it was not possible to maintain the status quo. The government was "on course" to settle questions of safety, which would never be compromised. Even the civil aviation authority, responsible for air regulation, had expressed its support for the private-public partnership.

The report said that if Nats' debt of £300m was written off by the government before the sale, the net revenue from the sale would be only £20m.

Ms Dunwoody and her colleagues were angry at the CAA's intervention. It was an economic and safety regulator, and it was not appropriate to give the impression that it backed the government's plan. If the sell-off went ahead, the committee wanted the government to ensure that no profit was made on the Nats operation.

Sir Roy McNulty, Nats chairman, welcomed the "clear statement" in the report that the status quo could not continue. He had argued consistently that it must have a new structure to enable it to exploit business opportunities.

He believed that the government's plan would maintain Nats as a world leader. He was confident that safety would remain paramount, and that the privatisation would give it all the investment it needed.

Paul Noon, leader of the air traffic controllers' union, IPMS, said the report vindicated everything staff had been saying since the the proposal was announced.

"It is surely the final nail in the coffin. Air traffic control staff don't want it, pilots don't want it and the travelling public don't want it." The government should "give in gracefully" and drop the plans.

Mr Noon is seeking a European commission ruling on whether the French or Germans could successfully bid for the company, after the treasury admitted that the government has no powers to sell off Nats to a British company with a majority shareholding. He said that if the EU ruled against the government, air traffic controllers might take the matter to the courts.

fields.headline: Remploy U-turn saves 1,000 disabled jobs
fields.trailText: More than 1,000 disabled workers have been saved from redundancy after an apparent U-turn over plans to close factories run by Remploy, Britain's largest employer of disabled workers.
fields.body:
More than 1,000 disabled workers have been saved from redundancy after an apparent U-turn over plans to close factories run by Remploy, Britain's largest employer of disabled workers.

The GMB union last night called off plans to take industrial action at nine factories threatened with closure after what it hailed as a "major breakthrough" by Remploy.

Phil Davies, a GMB national officer, said: "This is fantastic news. We consider this a major breakthrough. Both the company and the government now recognise the importance of factory employment for disabled people."

His remarks came after Remploy, which is given £94m a year by the government to employ more than 10,000 workers, announced that it was shelving plans to "merge" nine factories. The company, which was set up in 1945 to provide jobs for injured war veterans, said: "Mergers may continue to have a role in the modernisation strategy but won't be the leading element of it."

The announcement prompted a joint press statement by the GMB and Remploy, making clear that their dispute was now over. Ray Fletcher, Remploy's personnel director, thanked the GMB for its contribution to "developing this new strategy".

However, questions were being raised last night about Remploy's "new strategy" when ministerial sources said they believed that there would still be mergers.

"It is not possible to see how [Remploy] can meet its target without modernisation," one source said. This appeared to contradict a Remploy spokeswoman, who said that factory mergers "are not the main thrust" of the strategy.

Remploy's new plans appear to feature elements old elements from its original merger plans and new elements announced yesterday.

While there will be less mergers of Remploy's 87 factories, the company will still attempt to expand the Interwork system, which places disabled workers in mainstream employment.

Ministers are committed to Interwork because only 2% of workers in "supported employment" move into unsubsidised jobs.

The government spokesman, Lord Bach, recently denied there would be any job losses at Remploy. He said its new chairman, Alan Pedder, intended to increase employment to 11,000 by 2002.

This appeared to contradict a Remploy spokeswoman, who said that factory mergers "are not the main thrust" of the strategy. Remploy's new plans appear to feature elements old elements from its original merger plans and new elements announced yesterday. While there will be less mergers of Remploy's 87 factories, the company will still attempt to expand the Interwork system, which places disabled workers in mainstream employment. Ministers are committed to Interwork because only 2% of workers in "supported employment" move into unsubsidised jobs. The government spokesman, Lord Bach, recently denied there would be any job losses at Remploy. He said its new chairman, Alan Pedder, intended to increase employment to 11,000 by 2002.

webTitle: Livingstone trounces Dobson in union ballots

fields.headline: Livingstone trounces Dobson in union ballots
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's campaign to become London's mayor was given a boost yesterday when a string of ballots of union members delivered unexpectedly large majorities over his main rival, Frank Dobson.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's campaign to become London's mayor was given a boost yesterday when a string of ballots of union members delivered unexpectedly large majorities over his main rival, Frank Dobson.

Five unions announced the results of ballots of their London members, giving Mr Livingstone, the MP for Brent East, shares of the vote ranging from 60% to 80% as part of the affiliated organisations' section of the electoral college to pick Labour's candidate.

The scale of Mr Livingstone's majorities steadied the nerves of his campaign team. On Wednesday there were rumours that officials from Labour's Millbank headquarters had privately estimated that Mr Dobson would win the battle for the candidacy by 3% when the final result is announced on Sunday.

Both sides remain uncertain about who will win once votes in all three sections of the electoral college have been counted.

In yesterday's largest ballot vote result from London members of the Communication Workers' Union, Mr Livingstone picked up 11,941 votes, or 71% of the total, despite a coded letter from the union's general secretary, Derek Hodgson, warning against any return to "gesture politics".

Mr Dobson, the candidate supported by the Labour hierarchy, only managed 2,548 votes, with Glenda Jackson, the third of Labour's mayoral hopefuls, attracting 2,291.

Mr Dobson performed more strongly in the GMB general union ballot, polling 19% ahead of Ms Jackson's 13%. But Mr Livingstone still won just over two-thirds of the vote - though the GMB is dividing up its share of the electoral college on the basis of each candidate's score in the union bal lot, rather than on a winner-takes-all basis as is the Transport Salaried Staffs Association and the shopworkers' union Usdaw.

The traditionally middle-of-the-road TSSA gave Mr Livingstone 75% of the vote, compared with 13% for Mr Dobson and 12% for Ms Jackson.

Usdaw members, whose leadership backed Mr Dobson, voted 61% for Mr Livingstone, 22% for Mr Dobson and 18% for Ms Jackson. The Aslef train drivers who are included in the electoral college gave Mr Livingstone 80% support.

Mr Dobson was backed by the Fabian Society and Labour Students but with more than a quarter of the electoral college votes now declared, Mr Livingstone is leading his main rival by almost two to one, having picked up 65% of the votes announced so far.

Tomorrow, his share will almost certainly increase when Labour's largest union affiliate, Unison, announces the result of its ballot.

However, Mr Livingstone's lead is certain to be more than cancelled out by the heavily pro-Dobson votes of MPs, MEPs and Greater London Assembly candidates - leaving the individual members' section, where Mr Dobson has concentrated his campaign, with the decisive say.

To beat Tony Blair's candidate, Mr Livingstone is likely to have to win more than 60% of the votes of London Labour party members.

fields.headline: Adolf Pilch
fields.trailText: Major Adolf Pilch, who has died aged 85, was a heroic figure of the Polish underground army of the second world war. Not a dashing Pole out of romantic tradition, he was a blunt, ironic man, and a cool strategist much feared by the German and Soviet occupying forces.
fields.body:
Major Adolf Pilch, who has died aged 85, was a heroic figure of the Polish underground army of the second world war. Not a dashing Pole out of romantic tradition, he was a blunt, ironic man, and a cool strategist much feared by the German and Soviet occupying forces.

Once, when a Russian-Ukranian unit was ordered to destroy Pilch's band of partisans, the opposition suffered 250 dead and 100 wounded - against 10 Polish fatalities and 10 wounded.

During the second world war, there was no such thing in Poland as being neutral. For fear of reprisals against their families, partisans always operated under pseudonyms. Pilch took his names - Gora (mountain) and later Dolina (valley) - from the terrain around southern Poland, where he was born, in the spa town of Wisla.

Before the war, he was set to become an architect. But with the German invasion of Poland in 1939, he fled through Hungary and Yugoslavia to fight in France, then came to England to train under Maj-Gen Sir Colin Gubbins for the special operations executive (SOE). Parachuted back into Poland in February 1943, Pilch took charge of a 40-strong group of partisans, which within two months had became 400, and, by the end of the year, had grown to 1,000.

Their SOE-trained leaders were known as cichociemni - those who walk silently in the dark. First operating in the forests and marshes of north-east Poland, they specialised in sabotage and guerrilla warfare. But after most of their officers had been drawn into a "friendly-talks" trap by the Soviets, and the Russians had surrounded the partisans' camp, it was Pilch who gave the order to open fire. His unit won the day, and was thereafter known as the Doliniacy , or Dolina's Boys.

Following the north-east campaign, the unit - now including many civilians made refugees by the Russian advance - travelled in a convoy of horses and carts towards Warsaw to prepare for the uprising. The strategic point for supplying men and weapons to the fight was based in the Kampinos forest outside the capital, and Pilch was in charge of all guerrilla activity, defending the base against the Germans. Further supplemented with more civilians, including escapees from concentration camps, the Doliniacy fought, often on horseback, against German and Soviet units.

In all, Pilch fought in more than 200 engagements, never lost a battle, and was subsequently awarded four fighting crosses, the medal of Warsaw, the king's medal for courage, and Poland's highest military honour, the virtuti militari . He always led from the front, and cared inordinately for his men. "His concern for his soldiers won their lasting devotion and love; we owe him our lives," said Anna Jablonska, a fellow-member of the underground army, now in her 70s.

After Yalta, of course, with Poland under the Russian domination, Pilch was a hero who could not go home. Returned to England, he married a Polish girlfriend from before the war, settled in south London and made a considerable career as an inventory consultant.

As a staunch member of the Polish Underground Army's Ex-Servicemens' Association, he also worked to secure due recognition for his comrades - especially those tortured, executed or sent to Siberian labour camps. It was not an easy task, given the regime in Poland and the corrosive revisionism of armchair Stalinists here and elsewhere. In 1990, however, on an official visit to free Poland, Pilch was welcomed by top dignitaries, the Polish army, military bands and his old soldiers.

He is survived by his wife, Eva, and three children, Anna, Adam, Irena. Among those paying their respects at his funeral in Wandsworth were four elderly figures come specially from Poland, Dolina's Boys, holding high their underground army banner.

fields.headline: James Riddell
fields.standfirst: Pioneering ski champion who fostered sport in peace and war
fields.trailText: The champion skier and children's author James Riddell, who has died aged 90, was in at the dawn of skiing as a competitive sport and holiday industry. Like his near contemporary, Sir Arnold Lunn, he matched his adventurism on the slopes and knowledge of the Alpine countries with an elegant record of his times.
fields.body:
The champion skier and children's author James Riddell, who has died aged 90, was in at the dawn of skiing as a competitive sport and holiday industry. Like his near contemporary, Sir Arnold Lunn, he matched his adventurism on the slopes and knowledge of the Alpine countries with an elegant record of his times.

In 1929, he raced for Britain at Zakopane, Poland, in the first international downhill race, having got the reluctant backing of the International Ski Federation, and finished eighth among 60 racers. In the same year, he won the Kandahar Club's Muerren Inferno, still the longest and most demanding of amateur downhill races. He was British national champion in 1935 and vice-captain to Arnold Lunn's son, Peter, at the 1936 Winter Olympics at Garmisch-Partenkirchen.

Riddell was among the British group of sportsmen whose way of avoiding the Hitler salute was to give the Olympic salute - with right hand pushed out smartly to the side. "Some were a little too enthusiastic and there were red noses rather than red faces," he recalled. "The Germans, of course, never saw the difference."

He worked with Lunn and the Kandahar Club to overcome Scandinavian objections to downhill-only skiing: they saw the sport being as much uphill as down. Finally, Alpine skiing was admitted at Garmisch, but only on the basis of combined results in downhill and slalom, a word coined by Lunn for a race with shorter, sharper turns through gates of twin poles.

Riddell was a winter sports polymath. In 1930, he had skied at 127.96km an hour in the Flying Kilometre at St Moritz, and, moving over to its Olympic jump, vaulted nearly 50m. In the Garmisch Olympic downhill, he crashed into a tree, catapulted into a river and badly injured his back.

Educated at Harrow school, Riddell played cricket against Eton at Lord's and performed strongly for the cross-country team. At Clare College, Cambridge, he read modern languages, but the attractions of a year out proved too strong, and a travelling life in the 1930s involved gorilla and cheetah photography in the Belgian Congo and Kenya, interspersed with writing children's books and publicity activities for De Havilland, Selfridges and Fortnum and Mason.

During the second world war, Riddell was based in Jerusalem and Syria. In 1942, he was seconded to the Australian 9th Army to set up the Middle East Ski and Mountaineering School at the Cedars of Lebanon above Beirut. He was awarded the MBE for his work, teaching upwards of 20,000 soldiers the techniques of mountain mobility and survival. While working at the war office, he was pasting cuttings for a snowcraft manual when he inadvertently pasted together the head of a dog on the body of a camel. From that came the idea of "split" books for children, a series published in many languages.

In 1948, with the writer Nevil Shute, he made a six-month flight to Australia and back in a single-engine Percival Proctor monoplane. From that experience, Riddell wrote a travel book, Flight Of Fancy, and Shute the novel, A Town Like Alice. Riddell's 1957 book, The Ski Runs Of Switzerland, was the first detailed guide to Swiss resorts, followed by a similar book on Austria the following year.

He married another former ski racer, Jeannette Kessler, in 1959, and their combined knowledge of the Alps resulted in a Penguin handbook, Ski Holidays In The Alps, a source book for many skiers and travel writers. In it, Riddell wrote: "You do it because, once you have tried it and taken to it, there isn't any other game to compare with it in the world."

Riddell was president of the Ski Club of Great Britain, the Kandahar Club and the Alpine Ski Club in postwar years, and was awarded the Pery medal and Arnold Lunn medal while continuing his career as writer and traveller.

He gave up skiing in his 70s, though he often returned to Muerren, the Kandahar Club's Swiss Alpine headquarters, where he spent time painting watercolours. Although his eyesight was slowly failing, at his home near Ringwood, Hampshire, he worked on a unique ski stamp collection.

Jeannette died in 1972. He leaves a second wife, Alison, and a daughter, Jemma.

fields.headline: Ray Lamb
fields.trailText: Ray Lamb, who has died aged 91, was a major figure in postwar British and European adult education, in particular as warden of the adult education centre at Walthamstow, east London.
fields.body:
Ray Lamb, who has died aged 91, was a major figure in postwar British and European adult education, in particular as warden of the adult education centre at Walthamstow, east London.

Born in County Durham, he followed his father and most of his brothers down the pit, beginning work at Easington colliery at the age of 14. He later experienced the turbulent days, and, for the miners, the disillusionment, of the 1926 general strike.

Ray became a Quaker in his early 20s, and remained of that faith throughout his life. But it was a fellow miner and Methodist Sunday school teacher who first encouraged him to look beyond the pit. Further encouragement came from the Adult School Union, and he applied for a place at Fircroft College.

After his year there, he worked at Kingsley Hall, an educational and social service centre in London's east end. From there, he spent two years at Ruskin College, Oxford, which gave him not only the education and basic qualifications for what was to become his life's work, but also an enduring love of that city and its university.

Work was not easy to find in the 1930s. Periods of unemployment were broken by spells at Holiday Fellowship guest houses, whose philosophy of enjoyable and healthy holidays with an educational input appealed to Ray. Eventually, through Peter Scott, founder and director of the Bryn Mawr Experiment, established in South Wales to serve local educational and social needs, he was offered the job of organiser of boys' clubs. His continuing interest in adult education, however, led him to establish a branch of the Workers' Educational Association at Bryn Mawr.

Ray registered as a conscientious objector during the war, and became warden of the Walthamstow adult education centre, established and run by the (Quaker) Bedford Institute. He remained for more than 30 years, during which time the centre became a model of its kind, nurturing individual potential in a setting of comradeship and good cheer.

These basic beliefs were shared with the Educational Centres Association, of which Ray was also secretary from 1950-79. In this capacity, he developed international links, becoming especially well known in Germany, Austria and the Scandinavian countries. He was awarded the MBE in 1974.

Ray's wife Amy died in 1982, and he is survived by his two daughters.

fields.headline: George Rodgers
fields.standfirst: Devoted Old Labour MP and champion of the dispossessed
fields.trailText: Genial, modest George Rodgers, the former MP for Chorley (1974-79), who has died aged 74, had most of the virtues of the best of Old Labour. He was rooted in the Merseyside working-class, loyal to the Amalgamated Engineering Union and, above all, to the Labour party, which he served enthusiastically until he retired as its librarian in 1990.
fields.body:
Genial, modest George Rodgers, the former MP for Chorley (1974-79), who has died aged 74, had most of the virtues of the best of Old Labour. He was rooted in the Merseyside working-class, loyal to the Amalgamated Engineering Union and, above all, to the Labour party, which he served enthusiastically until he retired as its librarian in 1990.

In 1979 George coped, with heroic modesty, with the loss of his marginal seat, at a time when defeated MPs only received two months' severance pay. Having worked for 30 years as a welder, 20 of them for BICC, he could not go back to that contracting firm. His scores of job-seeking letters mostly went unanswered. He was not the sort to badger Harold Wilson, whose constituency chairman he had been, to ask the new leader, James Callaghan, for a life peerage. After his redundancy money ran out, he was six months on the dole.

He finally found a job as circulation manager of Labour Weekly at £6,000 a year. But that required him to live in pokey digs in Clapham - while his wife, Jane, remained in their council home in Huyton. The hardest thing was not being able to afford to go north every weekend to see his family. "I can't do that now. It would throw our budget right out," he said. "It's only worth my while working in London if I can send my wife £50 a week. Otherwise, I might as well be up there with her, drawing the dole."

George came by his working-class virtues naturally. He was born in Liverpool, the son of a joiner, and educated locally. During the second world war, he served in the navy (1943-46), earning decorations after dangerous Arctic convoys and on the Normandy landings.

Back home, he trained as a welder, working first for White's in Widnes, then Eaves in Blackpool, Costain's and, finally, BICC. Like most leftwing engineers, George was active both in his union and in local politics. By 1964 he was elected to Huyton local council, later becoming its chairman.

He was persuaded to go for the marginal Chorley seat, which had been tenuously held for Labour by a local sheep-farmer Charles Kenyon. He won the seat by 405 votes in February 1974, in the election which brought Harold Wilson unexpectedly back to power, and increased this to 2,713 the following October.

George was lately popular with fellow Labour MPs, becoming chairman of their north-west group. Pro-Arab and anti-common market, he pushed for industrial investment to mop up unemployment. He found the existence of the House of Lords "an offensive absurdity".

He was rooted in the Merseyside working-class, loyal to the Amalgamated Engineering Union and, above all, to the Labour party, which he served enthusiastically until he retired as its librarian in 1990. Having worked for 30 years as a welder, 20 of them for BICC, he could not go back to that contracting firm. His scores of job-seeking letters mostly went unanswered. He was not the sort to badger Harold Wilson, whose constituency chairman he had been, to ask the new leader, James Callaghan, for a life peerage.
