webTitle: Just renew and clarify your offer

fields.headline: Just renew and clarify your offer
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland: special report

If the IRA are serious, they can add the clarity the premiers want
fields.trailText: The core of the Belfast agreement was an offer of fully inclusive government in a reformed Northern Ireland, in return for a complete end to all violence and an exclusive reliance on democratic methods. This was a generous offer, unparalleled in any western democracy, enthusiastically endorsed by the great majority in Ireland, north and south.
fields.body:
The core of the Belfast agreement was an offer of fully inclusive government in a reformed Northern Ireland, in return for a complete end to all violence and an exclusive reliance on democratic methods. This was a generous offer, unparalleled in any western democracy, enthusiastically endorsed by the great majority in Ireland, north and south.

The majority in Northern Ireland were willing to countenance a range of, often painful, compromises to secure a complete end to killings, bombings, threats and intimidation. This deal always included decommissioning. The detail of when and how was omitted in recognition of the difficulty of the task facing republican leaders. We were willing to be flexible in wording to allow time and space for them to deliver.

Sinn Fein's attempt to water down their commitment to one of merely trying to persuade the IRA has been profoundly disappointing. While we understand the problems facing Mr Adams and Mr McGuinness it is entirely unrealistic to brazen out the difficulty like some schoolboy with his fingers crossed behind his back.

In these frustrating circumstances we have tried hard to be as constructive as possible. Because the Sinn Fein leadership said they needed to be in government to demonstrate the advantages of the agreement to their rank and file, we reluctantly agreed to set up the new executive in December ahead of any start to decommissioning.

As Senator Mitchell knows, this was done on the clear understanding, shared by all parties including Sinn Fein, that devolution could only be sustained for a maximum of two months without a start to decommissioning. Although many Ulster Unionists found this at least morally questionable, they nonetheless accepted David Trimble's advice in order to keep the agreement alive. Persuading a reluctant party was, however, only possible in the context of a postdated resignation letter to take effect if the republicans failed to deliver their part of the understanding.

General de Chastelain was forced to report bleakly on January 31 that no progress had occurred. Unionists had done what the Guardian and others had urged us to do since last summer. We took a serious political risk and jumped alone. With no reciprocation, and no honesty in recognising the understanding reached in the Mitchell review, there was no option but to withdraw.

Mr Mandelson did exactly the right thing in these circumstances. By suspending the new institutions of government, he saved them from potential destruction. Neither he nor Mr Blair had been able to detect anything of substance in the IRA "offer" which arrived 20 minutes after the suspension announcement and Mr Blair's repeated calls for clarity have gone unanswered.

Those who have given credence to an offer which merely said that the IRA would "consider" decommissioning in a context of the removal of the causes of conflict are guilty of naivety at best. Sinn Fein's view remains that the chief cause of conflict is what it has always been - the British presence in Northern Ireland. Unless Sinn Fein are willing to tell us something different, the obvious conclusion must be that we will wait for ever.

While Jonathan Freedland in the Guardian has reported all manner of constructive detail, the reality is that Mr Adams and Mr McGuinness have been unable to provide any details of the IRA offer in direct meetings with unionist leaders this week. Neither has General de Chastelain been able to add anything to the oblique reference in his report.

The suspicions of many were that the IRA statement was little other than a spoiler designed to confuse the media at the time of Mr Mandelson's announcement. But if the IRA are serious, they can repeat the offer and add the clarity which the British and Irish prime ministers have asked for.

Until this is done, Seamus Mallon's two questions - will they decommission and when - remain. It is surely intolerable to lead the Irish prime minister to believe last week that a major breakthrough had been made on decommissioning only to withdraw it this week. The republican movement is either willing to decommission or it is not. It cannot fool about such a serious issue and expect to retain any credibility.

I hope that a clear offer will be made so that we resume devolved government quickly. For our part we remain fully committed to inclusive government and to the Belfast agreement as a whole. We will stick to our historic compromise but it must be on the basis of an end to all paramilitarism, including the holding of illegal arms. Guns and government simply do not mix.

John Taylor is deputy leader of the Ulster Unionist party.

fields.headline: Killer inspired by film Seven
fields.trailText: A young Frenchman who dreamed of becoming a serial killer and sending a severed human head to his former girlfriend has been jailed for 30 years for murdering his first and only victim.
fields.body:
A young Frenchman who dreamed of becoming a serial killer and sending a severed human head to his former girlfriend has been jailed for 30 years for murdering his first and only victim.

Saying he was inspired by the 1995 Hollywood thriller Seven, Pierre Navelot admitted to a court that he and a friend killed a woman, but fled from her flat before decapitating her because a neighbour knocked on the door after hearing her screams.

The court in the north-eastern city of Metz sentenced Navelot to 30 years and his accomplice, Laurent Trottin, to 28 years for the murder of Alexandra Fernandez, 20.

Trottin had suggested that Fernandez, whom he knew, should be the target for beheading and helped kill her.

Navelot and Trottin were 21 and 20 at the time of the crime in January 1998.

Navelot's former girlfriend testified that when they broke up, he promised to send her "a present, like in the film Seven". He also said they should have children so he could decapitate them, he said.

In David Fincher's film, two detectives, played by Brad Pitt and Morgan Freeman, hunt down a serial killer who decapitates one of his victims and sends her head in a box to her husband.

Navelot, who had drawn up a list of about 20 people to kill, told the court that he and his friend had gone home after stabbing Fernandez and written the victim's name, followed by the number one, on the list.

Navelot told the court he had wanted to kill in order to become famous, and said he suffered from low self-esteem because he had been incontinent until his teenage years.

"You can't live just being nobody at all," he said.

webTitle: Hain accuses five of smuggling for Unita

fields.headline: Hain accuses five of smuggling for Unita
fields.trailText: Britain's foreign office minister for Africa, Peter Hain, intensified his campaign yesterday to name and shame those who break UN sanctions on rebel Unita forces in Angola: he identified five more people who, he claimed, were involved in the illegal movement of diamonds and fuel.
fields.body:
Britain's foreign office minister for Africa, Peter Hain, intensified his campaign yesterday to name and shame those who break UN sanctions on rebel Unita forces in Angola: he identified five more people who, he claimed, were involved in the illegal movement of diamonds and fuel.

Last month he took the unprecedented step of naming three businessmen as sanctions busters. One of them, Antonio Teixeira, who runs a mining company based in Johannesburg, vehemently denied the allegation in an interview with the Guardian last week. He challenged Mr Hain to repeat the claim outside the privilege of parliament.

Mr Hain named five further people yesterday in an adjournment debate on Africa. The names were sent last night to Robert Fowler, Canada's UN representative, who is the chairman of the world body's committee on Angolan sanctions. He is expected to publish a report on his findings next month.

Describing the five as people who "make money out of misery", the minister named two brothers, David and Maurice Zollman. He alleged that David Zollman, based in Rundu, Namibia, exported $4m (£2.5m) worth of diamonds for Unita to Antwerp every month, and "paid a monthly fee to Namibia officials in order to be able to operate without interference".

Maurice Zollman, Mr Hain alleged, ran a similar operation in South Africa which involved a South African pilot, Hennie Steyn. He also named Jan Joubert as a supplier of fuel to Unita's Andulo base from Gaborone, Botswana. Mr Hain alleged that the fuel was stored in Gaborone by an Irishman, Dennis Coghlan.

Mr Hain hinted at further revelations and said: "It is vital that all the governments and agencies and companies in which they operate take urgent action to stop their illegal activities."

On January 18 Mr Hain claimed Mr Teixeira, chairman of the Central African Mining Company, had been supplying diesel fuel to Unita. Yet that same day, Mr Teixeira was appointed to the board of a diamond mining company which has joint ventures with the Angolan government.

"How can I get involved with Unita when I am now in business with the Angolan government?" Mr Teixeira said in the interview.

His appointment was announced by the Canadian-based mining company DiamondWorks (now half owned by South African interests). It said it had merged with Lyndhurst Ltd, described as "a privately held UK-based mining company which is controlled by a consortium led by Mr Antonio Teixeira".

Since it was set up in 1996, DiamondWorks has attracted adverse publicity because its diamond mines and concessions in Angola and Sierra Leone were secured only after intervention in both civil wars by the now-defunct South African-based mercenary company Executive Outcomes.

A significant shareholder in DiamondWorks is Tony Buckingham, a Briton who introduced Executive Outcomes into both countries and was the force behind Sandline International, the London-based military company whose activities led to a parliamentary inquiry in 1998.

Mr Teixeira said "I can only assume that Mr Hain has been given information from the intelligence services about another man. Teixeira is a very common Portuguese name.

"But when he [Mr Hain] was in South Africa recently, he refused to see or speak to me. This has all been very damaging."

DiamondWorks' acting president, Robert Rainey, said: "The allegations are unfounded."

fields.headline: Alcohol poisoning kills Bangladeshis
fields.trailText: At least 30 people have died and more than a dozen are still fighting for their lives after drinking crude alcohol on Tuesday in the town of Feni, about 100 miles south of the capital.
fields.body:
At least 30 people have died and more than a dozen are still fighting for their lives after drinking crude alcohol on Tuesday in the town of Feni, about 100 miles south of the capital.

Local officials said the exact number of victims was unclear as relatives had either disposed of the bodies or were reluctant to disclose their identities for fear of being outcast in this predominantly Muslim country, where drinking is in theory a taboo.

The Chittagong-based Janakantha daily newspaper reported that some of the victims' relatives had attributed the deaths to heart attacks, fearing that otherwise a Muslim burial would be denied.

According to news reports, at least 70 people had fallen ill after drinking crudely distilled alcohol, which they reportedly bought from two health stores in the town.

However, only 30 of the victims were taken to hospital; one doctor said the death toll could have been lower if treatment had been given faster.

Police immediately closed the stores, arresting one person, but public anger is growing against the police for allegedly turning a blind eye to the sale of the poisonous merchandise.

A pall of gloom has descended over Feni, as in most cases those who died were the their families' sole wage-earners. The poor, especially day labourers and rickshaw drivers who can ill afford to patronise the big hotels where alcohol can be consumed in relative anonymity, usually opt for the much cheaper spirit which local stores sell as medicine.

webTitle: UN chief weeps at scene of atrocity in East Timor

fields.headline: UN chief weeps at scene of atrocity in East Timor
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: An emotional Kofi Annan was greeted with cheers and tears when he arrived in East Timor yesterday, laying a wreath at a Roman Catholic church where dozens of people were massacred last year.
fields.body:
An emotional Kofi Annan was greeted with cheers and tears when he arrived in East Timor yesterday, laying a wreath at a Roman Catholic church where dozens of people were massacred last year.

The UN secretary-general and his wife, Nane, shed tears as he laid the wreath in the town of Liquica, about 20 miles west of the capital, Dili. Some of East Timor's worst bloodshed occurred in the town before and after the territory voted on August 30 for independence from Indonesia.

Across East Timor local militias backed by the Indonesian army terrorised the majority favouring independence.

A crowd of 5,000 cheered Mr Annan's arrival for the ceremony. "It is particularly shocking to me that a house of worship should be desecrated in this manner," he told them. "I know that many more of your relatives and friends lost their lives before and after the ballot. I have only begun to see for myself how extensive the destruction was here in Liquica."

He urged Indonesia to ensure those responsible for the violence be brought to justice.

webTitle: Pregnancy ruled out by US judge

fields.headline: Pregnancy ruled out by US judge
fields.trailText: A US judge has ordered a woman convicted of endangering her unborn child by taking drugs to avoid becoming pregnant in the next 10 years.
fields.body:
A US judge has ordered a woman convicted of endangering her unborn child by taking drugs to avoid becoming pregnant in the next 10 years.

As part of her sentence, Dawn Marie Spinkle of Helena, Montana, was instructed by district judge Dorothy McCarter this week to take a pregnancy test every two months. If she tests positive, she could be imprisoned.

"I don't want another damaged baby born because we didn't do enough to supervise that woman," the judge said. "If she wants to drug herself to death, fine. But we can't have her taking drugs when she's pregnant."

Sprinkle, 29, was given a three-year suspended sentence by the same judge last year after a urine test conducted on her baby boy following his birth in 1998 showed that there were amphetamines in his system.

Prosecutors claimed that Sprinkle broke several conditions of her sentence, including not completing chemical dependency treatment, failing to pay fines and testing positive for drugs.

If she had abided by the conditions imposed by the original sentence, the conviction would have disappeared from her records.

webTitle: Revulsion in US as women vie to marry a millionaire on TV

fields.headline: Revulsion in US as women vie to marry a millionaire on TV
fields.trailText: The mystery man sits in the shadows. The prospective brides stand on a stage in wedding gowns, waiting for the proposal. And every moment the suspense builds - as do the ratings.
fields.body:
The mystery man sits in the shadows. The prospective brides stand on a stage in wedding gowns, waiting for the proposal. And every moment the suspense builds - as do the ratings.

The scene took place this week in a US television special called Who Wants to Marry a Multi-Millionaire?

As in Britain, the success of the game show Who Wants to be a Millionaire? has changed the landscape of television in the US. And the Fox network's show on Tuesday proved that variations on that theme can reach similar ratings heights.

The two-hour programme featured a parade of would-be brides competing to be chosen by a multi-millionaire, and it culminated in an on-air wedding. Some 22.8m viewers tuned in for the final half hour. This included more than a third of all women under the age of 35 watching TV in the US that night.

The show also provoked widespread revulsion - the kind that apparently helps, not hurts ratings - that women were willing to marry an unknown man on television. The day after, women around the country were discussing the programme animatedly.

Fox's website for the show (whowantstomarry.com) got so many requests from women wanting to be on the next millionaire-marriage edition that the site crashed on Wednesday afternoon.

"It took something like this to make the Miss America pageant look good to me," Patricia Ireland, the president of the National Organisation for Women, said. "At least with the Miss America pageant you get scholarship money and the guarantee of a year-long run. It perpetuates some very limited stereotypes that men are success objects and women are sex objects."

But Mike Darnell, the Fox executive who created the show, defended the concept, saying that he planned to do another show "the other way around", with a female millionaire choosing a husband.

"If you looked at these people at the end of the show, you could tell it was less about the money than it was about the relationship. If they don't get along, it won't work - no matter how much money is involved."

Fox said that a "standard pre-nuptial agreement" covering what happens to the couple's assets in the event of divorce was signed, but it would not specify its contents.

Mr Darnell said more than 1,000 women had signed up for Tuesday's show, a number that was pared down to the 50 contestants in the pageant, which was taped in Las Vegas last week. The format included parades in evening gowns and beach wear, and interview segments in which the women described their backgrounds.

The multi-millionaire, who was shown only in shadow, then pared the group down to 10, with the help of his friends and family. The 10 semi-finalists were further interviewed to bring the number down to five finalists.

The contestants then appeared in wedding gowns. The multi-millionaire made his choice, kneeling to propose. The wedding, conducted by a Nevada judge, followed.

The contestants underwent medical examinations. The winner received - in addition to the husband - a two-week holiday in the Caribbean (the honeymoon), an Isuzu Trooper car and a $35,000 (£22,000) diamond ring.

Mr Darnell said of the happy couple: "They are taking it very slow, trying to find out what their relationship will really be."

The bride was Darva Conger, a 34-year-old nurse from Santa Monica, California. The groom was Rick Rockwell, 42, a property developer who came to California intending to be a stand-up comic. Fox investigated his finances and said he had assets worth many millions of dollars.

Asked why he believed there was such willingness on the part of both single women and a single millionaire to take part in the programme, Mr Darnell said: "Obviously it's hard to meet people."

The scene took place this week in a US television special called Who Wants to Marry a Multi-Millionaire? As in Britain, the success of the game show Who Wants to be a Millionaire? has changed the landscape of television in the US. And the Fox network's show on Tuesday proved that variations on that theme can reach similar ratings heights. The two-hour programme featured a parade of would-be brides competing to be chosen by a multi-millionaire, and it culminated in an on-air wedding. Some 22.8m viewers tuned in for the final half hour. This included more than a third of all women under the age of 35 watching TV in the US that night. The show also provoked widespread revulsion - the kind that apparently helps, not hurts ratings - that women were willing to marry an unknown man on television. The day after, women around the country were discussing the programme animatedly. Fox's website for the show (whowantstomarry.com) got so many requests from women wanting to be on the next millionaire-marriage edition that the site crashed on Wednesday afternoon. "It took something like this to make the Miss America pageant look good to me," Patricia Ireland, the president of the National Organisation for Women, said. "At least with the Miss America pageant you get scholarship money and the guarantee of a year-long run. It perpetuates some very limited stereotypes that men are success objects and women are sex objects." But Mike Darnell, the Fox executive who created the show, defended the concept, saying that he planned to do another show "the other way around", with a female millionaire choosing a husband. "If you looked at these people at the end of the show, you could tell it was less about the money than it was about the relationship. webTitle: Sons of Spitting Image rant on

fields.headline: Sons of Spitting Image rant on
fields.trailText: Spitting Image, the satirical television show featuring Peter Fluck's and John Law's drooling latex puppets, is alive and kicking in Europe after falling victim at home to the dullness of British political life in the 1990s.
fields.body:
Spitting Image, the satirical television show featuring Peter Fluck's and John Law's drooling latex puppets, is alive and kicking in Europe after falling victim at home to the dullness of British political life in the 1990s.

A version in France, the Guignols d'Info, is one of the most successful shows on French TV.

The Canal Plus programme is screened five minutes before the main evening news on the TF1 channel. A latex version of the TF1 bulletin's newscaster presents the Guignols.

One episode showed Lionel Jospin, France's beleaguered prime minister, waking up one morning to a strangely peaceful desk. Everyone in the country had vanished.

The bite of Kukli, the Russian version on NTV independent television, depends on who is in power in the Kremlin. It portrayed Boris Yeltsin as drunk and authoritarian but basically a good guy. His courtiers did not get off so lightly, and occasionally the programme makers had to be reminded of the limits of the Kremlin's tolerance.

If President Yeltsin was loathed, his puppet was popular. It recently fetched £16,650 at auction in Moscow.

The politicians caught up in Germany's sleaze controversy are getting off lightly. The Spitting Image-style Hurra Deutschland is off the air, but it was a pretty tame affair.

Last year, however, Chancellor Gerhard Schröder threatened to sue a programme on the private RTL channel which implied that he was a sex fetishist.

webTitle: Carey steps into row over rebel bishops

fields.headline: Carey steps into row over rebel bishops
fields.trailText: The Archbishop of Canterbury tried last night to stem a growing split within the Episcopal church in the United States following the clandestine consecration in Singapore of two rebel American priests as bishops.
fields.body:
The Archbishop of Canterbury tried last night to stem a growing split within the Episcopal church in the United States following the clandestine consecration in Singapore of two rebel American priests as bishops.

Dr George Carey said the appointment of Chuck Murphy and John Rodgers to bishoprics within the US by the archbishops of Rwanda and south-east Asia breached Anglican rules and was illegal.

The row over the ordination last month of the two men, who are both prominent evangelicals, threatens to tear apart the US Episcopal church, which has 2.5m members.

During a presidential election year in which issues such as abortion are expected to be high on the political agenda, infighting between conservatives and liberals in the American equivalent of the Church of England would be a disaster for Anglicans worldwide and could expose rifts elsewhere.

The rebel bishops have openly attacked the US church's liberalism under such controversial leaders as the recently retired bishop of Newark, Jack Spong. They are particularly upset about the practice in some areas of consecrating same-sex marriages and ordaining openly gay priests.

Even their closest colleagues were unaware of the rebels' plans to travel to Singapore for the cathedral ceremony.

In a letter last night to bishops across the world, Dr Carey, who is president of the 70m-strong Anglican communion, claimed the appointments broke traditions of religious authority stretching back 1,800 years.

"I cannot recognise their episcopal ministry until such time as a full rapprochement and reconciliation has taken place between them and the appropriate authorities... The understanding of episcopal ministry, which appears to have allowed them to act unilaterally, without consultation, and in secret, is quite foreign to the Anglican tradition," he said.

Dr Carey's authority to discipline the rebels is extremely limited however. One church official said last night: "He has no jurisdiction, only moral authority and the ability to give firm guidance."

The Most Rev Frank Griswold, presiding bishop of the US church, said of the two rebels: "I am appalled by their irregular action and even more so by the purported crisis which has been largely fomented by them and others."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
'Stay away from Pakistan'
The Indian prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, warned the US president Bill Clinton yesterday against visiting Pakistan next month during his planned tour of south Asia.
fields.body:
'Stay away from Pakistan'
The Indian prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, warned the US president Bill Clinton yesterday against visiting Pakistan next month during his planned tour of south Asia.

In the French daily, Le Figaro, Mr Vajpayee conceded that Mr Clinton had the right to stop in Pakistan during his trip to India and Bangladesh. "But a visit to Pakistan while this country is under military dictatorship and sponsors Islamic terrorism around the world would be very badly received by Indian public opinion," he said.
Reuters, Paris

Cars ablaze in US plane crash
A cargo plane plunged into a car scrapyard in California, killing three crew members and leaving a 400m trail of burning debris.

The pilot of the Emery Worldwide flight reported that the DC-8's balance was affected when its cargo shifted shortly after take- off. Up to 200 cars - many with petrol in their tanks - were set alight when the plane crashed as it attempted an emergency landing near Sacramento.
AP, Rancho Cordova, California

Taxi drivers on the rampage
Taxi drivers smashed windscreens and pulled passengers from vehicles in South Africa yesterday in a protest against planned reforms to their industry.

The drivers caused huge jams in Johannesburg during the demonstration against President Thabo Mbeki's plan to force independent operators to trade in about 126,000 ageing minibuses for 85,000 larger, purpose-built buses.

Hundreds die in taxi crashes every year and about 1,500 have been killed in wars over the best routes.
Reuters, Johannesburg.

Mongolia hit by livestock crisis
The Mongolian government asked foreign embassies for emergency aid after unusually heavy snows and bitter cold killed at least 626,000 livestock animals.

Millions more cattle, horses, sheep, goats, yaks and camels are in danger of starving due to lack of fodder, according to officials at the state emergency commission.
AP, Ulan Bator

webTitle: Can we trust our son not to spend his £30,000 trust fund on drugs?

fields.headline: Can we trust our son not to spend his £30,000 trust fund on drugs?
fields.trailText: Our son, who is nearly 23, has had a drug problem for the past three and a half years. This has included heroin dependency and has led to two prison sentences for shoplifting. Over the past six months, he has managed to live in his own flat on state benefits and some personal savings; he does not believe he can hold down a job. So far he has not wanted to use the help offered by statutory agencies. As parents, we try to practise "tough love"; our son has abused our support many times but wants to be helped. He has two brothers who seem happy with their lives.
fields.body:
Our son, who is nearly 23, has had a drug problem for the past three and a half years. This has included heroin dependency and has led to two prison sentences for shoplifting. Over the past six months, he has managed to live in his own flat on state benefits and some personal savings; he does not believe he can hold down a job. So far he has not wanted to use the help offered by statutory agencies. As parents, we try to practise "tough love"; our son has abused our support many times but wants to be helped. He has two brothers who seem happy with their lives.

Our problem is that a family trust has been set up by grandparents from which our son could receive up to £30,000. This would be at the discretion of the trustees and has to be passed on to our son by his 25th birthday. Until now, any excess money over his basic living costs is usually spent on drugs. The trustees have asked us, as parents, for advice. Any suggestions?
Name and address withheld

Hold the money back

In August 1995, I too wrote to Private Lives asking for readers' advice on how to help our drug-addicted son (also one of three boys). Nearly five years later our son is 29 and still addicted to drugs and alcohol. He is serving a short prison sentence. After years of denying that he needs help, he now says that he wants to go to a rehabilitation centre, but the chance of a place with funding being available when he comes out of prison is remote and the chance of him staying off drugs while he waits for a place is even more remote.

The £30,000 could buy treatment for your son if and when he reaches the point of wanting to rebuild his life. It could also pay for education or training he has missed out on. It could at least offer him hope of such possibilities. (For most drug addicts the future must truly appear hopeless so how can they face it without the drugs that are their prop?) Is there any possibility of the money being kept available for this? I agree it would be disastrous for him to have it now.

I wish you all well for the future.

Keep up the tough love

Your fears are well founded. I have a brother, among several siblings, who ended up in treatment 15 years ago, in order to avoid prison (for theft, which was supporting his habit). He stopped using heroin but nothing much else changed: his friends and lifestyle remained the same, as did his attitude to money and dishonesty. This considered, he eventually appeared to get his life in order, albeit in a flawed fashion.

A year ago, some family members hinted he was using it again. This culminated in a recent confession to my mother. The purpose of the confession was to beg money to pay debts. In the preceding five years each of us had received various inheritance and trust payouts of more than £80,000 each. At the time of the first payout I had suggested to my mother that she give it to him on condition that he buy a property, but she replied that he was now in his thirties and must be treated as an adult. Her only consolation is that she knows he did not relapse because of her lack of faith in him. An expensive lesson.

Please keep up the tough love; put the money in property (tied up in trust) allowing him to benefit from it - but not spend it. If he gets through this phase, as many do, I'm sure he will be grateful that you protected his long-term interests.

He has to change first

If he is to sort himself out, the best idea would be for him to move away from the environment in which he abuses drugs. He will also need to find a job to occupy his time: being an addict is a lifestyle.

He may also be right in avoiding statutory agencies, as he is the only person who can change his circumstances. It is possible to kick your habit on your own - I did. I am now happily married and run my own business.

Give him the money

I don't see that you or the trustees have any choice. Give him the money. There is a slim chance that the responsibility of this windfall will encourage your son to use it wisely; he has shown he can act sensibly on occasion by amassing personal savings.

However, the more likely outcome is that he and his "friends" (who appear at times like this - the dealer network won't tolerate isolation) will have holes burned in their pockets until the money is gone. Only then will he have a chance of recovery because he'll be doing it for himself.

"You can have this money if you give up drugs" doesn't work when money arrives without effort. I've worked with addicts for many years - they know more than anyone that money can't buy happiness.

fields.headline: Next week
fields.trailText: My mother lived with us until six months ago when she went into a residential care home because of her dementia. While she lived in our house she had her own rooms and they are still filled with her furniture and personal belongings. My husband and I are the only people she recognises now and I am told that soon she will not even know us. Her physical state of health is quite good but both her long-term and short-term memory are very poor. She spent some time with us at Christmas but did not recognise her rooms or her belongings.
fields.body:
My mother lived with us until six months ago when she went into a residential care home because of her dementia. While she lived in our house she had her own rooms and they are still filled with her furniture and personal belongings. My husband and I are the only people she recognises now and I am told that soon she will not even know us. Her physical state of health is quite good but both her long-term and short-term memory are very poor. She spent some time with us at Christmas but did not recognise her rooms or her belongings.

The whole situation upsets me a great deal. I am torn between keeping everything as it is, which is a constant reminder of my mother's condition, and distributing her things among the family, then redecorating and using the rooms. I feel guilty about even thinking of this while she is still alive and I am not sure what the family's reaction would be if I broached the subject with them. Yet if my mother had retained her faculties, I'm certain she would have said, "Let them have what they want. They might as well enjoy it - it's of no use to me."

I'm sure other families must have faced similar circumstances. I would very much like any information on how they dealt with such a difficult situation.
M, London.

webTitle: The thin end of the potato wedge

fields.headline: The thin end of the potato wedge
fields.standfirst: TV cook Gary Rhodes serves frozen chips in one of his restaurants. The foodies are aghast. But how many other chefs are sneaking bought-in food on to the menu?  Matt Wells and  Claire Phipps investigate
fields.trailText: TV cook Gary Rhodes serves frozen chips in one of his restaurants. The foodies are aghast. But how many other chefs are sneaking bought-in food on to the menu?
fields.body:
Before Gary Rhodes extolled the virtues of perfect French fries on television, perhaps he should have checked out the cooking practices at his own Edinburgh restaurant. When a group of food executives sat down to a meal at Rhodes & Co in the Scottish capital, they were immediately suspicious that what lay before them was, well, nothing short of the real McCain.

While the casual diner might not have noticed, these fries fanatics felt cheated. No matter that the finest fillet steaks had been lovingly prepared, the accompaniment was a let down. "These looked like they had been cut in bulk on a seriously industrial scale," said one. "The chips were basically soggy and flabby."

The revelation sparked outrage among the critics. "Serving food in a restaurant which is cooked from frozen is not acceptable. That is not a restaurant, it is a heating-up house," fumed Egon Ronay. Rhodes' rivals queued up to pour scorn. "It's sad for a chef of his calibre to resort to using frozen chips," said Gordon Ramsay, holder of two Michelin stars. "It's a cop-out," blasted Ronnie Clydesdale, owner of Glasgow trend-setter The Ubiquitous Chip.

Yet Rhodes is not the first to be caught with his fingers in the chest freezer. In 1997, Sir Terence Conran's newly opened Bluebird restaurant in London faced snickering press coverage after a McCain lorry was spotted delivering chips to the kitchens. (Fresh, not frozen, they insisted. "A potato is a potato, whether you peel it on-site or not.") Simon Tennet, the award-winning chef of the Fisherman's Wharf in Newcastle, quit in disgust after being asked to replace his fresh puddings with frozen ones. "I had built up a reputation. I could not afford to lose it," he said. (The plan was subsequently abandoned.)

It seems that as British diners become more demanding, the pressure on restaurants - particularly those of supermarket proportions, such as the Conran outlets - is increasing. One junior chef at a top London restaurant reveals that his establishment uses pre-cut factory chips, although he adds that they are not frozen. With more than 200 meals served on a Saturday night, it seems there's no option. "With the sheer number of people, if they had one chef chopping the potatoes, he would be at it all day," he says.

Oven-ready fries might keep profit margins healthy but if customers become suspicious they might not return. Nevertheless, this junior chef understands the predicament faced by chefs in large restaurants. "If you have a restaurant doing that many covers and that is the only thing that they compromise on, it's not so bad. If Marco Pierre White was serving frozen chips, there would be more of an outcry, because of his prices."

Others, however, insist that the Rhodes confession is the thin end of the potato wedge. "I don't see much of an excuse for using frozen chips," says Jim Ainsworth, editor of the Good Food Guide. "They're just fluffy, floury nothingness. I would want to be able to taste the potato."

Jeremy Lee, of the Blue Print Cafe in London, also raps his rival over the knuckles. "It's a bit naughty, and I'm quite surprised. If you set yourself up as the master of British cooking, you should know better. It sets a terrible precedent. The public can be unforgiving."

Rhodes' restaurant managers pleaded the McCain defence - convenience and consistency. "To cater for the volume of chips we serve, it is more economical to serve these chips," the company said. "In his London restaurant, Gary is famed for his mash and that's made not from instant but real potatoes."

Some chefs think that this is the real scandal. While chips at Rhodes in the Square and City Rhodes - both London eateries - are the real McCoy, diners at the Manchester and Edinburgh branches of Rhodes & Co are being served frozen frites. Whether it's a question of local tastes or simply cost (where, apart from the metropolis, would customers pay more than a couple of pounds for a plate of fries?), Rhodes' northern fans might have reason to feel short-changed.

Jeremy Lee believes Rhodes is in danger of displaying regional snobbery. "That's even more insulting than using the frozen chips, to imply that only Londoners know about food. People will take umbrage at that - not very sensible."

In certain instances, however, frozen ingredients are a chef's first choice. Andrew Nutter, of Nutters in Cheesden, Greater Manchester, keeps a supply of frozen peas in the deep freeze, as do many others. "If you use garden peas in pea soup, it goes murky brown and gloopy," he says. "You get round it by blitzing in a packet of frozen petits pois - it turns it an electrifying green. Lee confesses to greater sins than frozen chips: "I make no bones about it; we use tomato ketchup, the odd chicken stock cube. Mainly for the staff meals, but ketchup can add seasoning or flavour." And Nutter predicts that the controversy may have a happy outcome for customers of Rhodes' restaurants. "I think he'll start using fresh chips just to get people off his back."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Contrary to what we said in our front page report, yesterday, headed Soften law on ecstasy, says police inquiry, it is not the Police Federation which has called for ecstasy to be downgraded to a soft drug, but the Police Foundation. The Police Federation, which represents the majority of officers in England and Wales, is opposed to the relaxation of the drugs laws. It believes that more efforts should be made to deglamorise rather than decriminalise drugs. The Federation believes there should be stronger national resolve to enforce anti-drugs laws accompanied by rehabilitation and better education about the dangers of drugs. The inquiry referred to in our report was correctly attributed to the Police Foundation by our home affairs editor but changed in the course of editing. Apologies to the Federation and the Foundation.

webTitle: Top 10 executives lose out in bonus stakes

fields.headline: Top 10 executives lose out in bonus stakes
fields.trailText: Abbey National's top 10 executives will be denied half of their performance-related, long-term bonuses because of the bank's poor share price performance relative to its peers.
fields.body:
Abbey National's top 10 executives will be denied half of their performance-related, long-term bonuses because of the bank's poor share price performance relative to its peers.

Among those affected are chief executive Ian Harley, who will lose £131,250 and Mark Pain, the finance director. They are missing out after the bank chose to rank its share performance against a list of rivals. It was ranked eight out of 10 over the two years to the end of December, below the median which would have allowed the 10 executives to receive 35% of their basic salaries in bonus under the long-term incentive plan.

In the two-year period, they have qualified for that part of the bonus which was dependent on the share performance relative to the wider FTSE 100.

On that ranking they ended the period 18th out of the 100 companies in the top quartile.

Under the terms of the incentive plan, they were entitled to 70% of their salary in bonus, split between their performance relevant to their peers and to the FTSE 100 index.

fields.body:
More than 1,000 emails from small investors expressed disgust:

"Only allocating 20% of shares to registered users is disgraceful. I suppose it has made the developers of the site ultra-rich." - Alan Slade.

"We should all show our disgust. This is our company, we support it, not faceless brokers and I for one will not be supporting this company in future." - Christopher Smith.

"I'm off to find a more appreciative site to spend my time. Wow! 145 shares."Robert Adams.

fields.headline: MBD offers US Meteor deal
fields.standfirst: Europe steals march on Raytheon in missile race
fields.trailText: Europe's guided weapons manufacturers and Boeing yesterday took the wind out of the sails of their US rival Raytheon by offering the US administration a government-led transatlantic cooperation pact on the Meteor missile.
fields.body:
Europe's guided weapons manufacturers and Boeing yesterday took the wind out of the sails of their US rival Raytheon by offering the US administration a government-led transatlantic cooperation pact on the Meteor missile.

The European consortium, led by Matra BAe Dynamics (MBD), and its US partner are bidding against Raytheon to supply the RAF's fleet of 232 Eurofighters with a "smart" missile.

The two have written to Jacques Gansler, under-secretary at the Pentagon, arguing that Meteor offers "the opportunity for real and meaningful transatlantic cooperation, creating genuine competition in the air-to-air missile arena".

The Pentagon is increasingly worried at the lack of competition in US defence procurement, following a spate of mergers among American contractors. Raytheon, the world's biggest missile maker, has already offered the UK access to top-secret programmes to upgrade the missile it makes to match the ramjet-powered capability of Meteor.

The £900m missile contract in the UK, to be awarded early next month by Tony Blair and a cabinet committee, has prompted unprecedented lobbying of the prime minister by President Bill Clinton - in favour of Raytheon - and European leaders arguing for Meteor.

Mr Blair's decision is being seen as determining whether the UK genuinely favours European defence collaboration or the more traditional route of transatlantic alliances. The MBD/Boeing demarche is designed to square that circle.

Alan Garwood, MBD deputy chief executive, said that if Meteor were selected for the British contract, the team would urge the ministry of defence to pursue a pact with the Pentagon with a view to exploiting jointly an export market worth up to £10bn.

MBD is merging with Germany's LFK, part of DaimlerChrysler Aerospace, and Alenia Marconi Systems, the British-Italian joint venture, to vie with Raytheon as the world's top missile maker. With Meteor it would have annual sales of £1.7bn.

Confident of winning the UK contract, Mr Garwood announced a £30m redevelopment of MBD's main site at Stevenage.

 Raytheon has been dropped from a $1.5bn competition to upgrade the Pentagon's premier missile-warning command centre, in Colorado - days after the US Navy cancelled a $200m contract with the firm whose share price has dropped from $79 to barely $20 in a year.

webTitle: Railtrack to spend record £2.5bn on improvements

fields.headline: Railtrack to spend record £2.5bn on improvements
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Railtrack said yesterday it would spend a record £2.5bn on improving Britain's rail network over the coming year - £900m more than in the current year.
fields.body:
Railtrack said yesterday it would spend a record £2.5bn on improving Britain's rail network over the coming year - £900m more than in the current year.

The group's plans, drawn up in the face of threatened fines and the loss of its licence because of the poor state of the rail system, brought a positive response on the markets.

Its shares, which peaked at £16.28 last year, rose almost 10% yesterday to close at 741p.

Railtrack said it had originally planned to spend £2.1bn in the year starting on April 1 but, including work on the first phase of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (CTRL), they now aimed to raise this to £2.5bn.

This compares with the likely outturn of £1.6bn investment in this financial year, a performance that has brought criticism from both the rail regulator and the chief inspector of railways that the network is in a worse state than under state control.

The group plans to spend £1.5bn on renewing track, signals, stations and bridges, with £600m earmarked for the West Coast Main Line and £500m for the CTRL. The first phases of both these projects are due to be complete in May 2002 and 2003 respectively.

Railtrack said it would spend £80m on speeding up the installation of the train protection and warning systems in the wake of the Paddington rail crash in October.

It said that, with a further planned spend of £190m, the £1bn station regeneration programme of upgrading Britain's 2,500 stations would be complete by the end of the year.

But the group said it faced a multi-million pound fine from the regulator, Tom Winsor, for failing to meet his target of a 12.7% reduction in network delays by the end of March.

Gerald Corbett, Railtrack chief executive, said it had achieved 9% by the end of December and January's perfor mance was a 20% improvement on a year ago. But his advisers conceded that Railtrack would achieve at most between 10% and 11%.

The company has set aside £10m to pay off the penalty. "The increase in investment is fundamental to the improvements in safety, train performance, track quality and other outputs that we are striving to deliver," said Mr Corbett.

The group is expected to boost its 10-year investment plans in its next network management statement, due out at the end of March. This is to cope with an anticipated 30% increase in rail travel over the same period.

Analysts said the planned investment could help Railtrack secure a more favourable pricing review when Mr Winsor fixes the group's allowed rate of return in July.

They said the regulator wanted to impose demanding performance and service targets but was under considerable political pressure to make them achievable.

webTitle: Dangers may lie ahead in hyper-speed zone

fields.headline: Dangers may lie ahead in hyper-speed zone
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Channelfly
(Wapit
Durlacher
fields.trailText: Oldies appear to be making a comeback in the new-fangled internet economy. Last weekend, Lord Hanson popped out of retirement and into a column in the Sunday Times to tell us how we must all get the net or risk social and professional exclusion.
fields.body:
Oldies appear to be making a comeback in the new-fangled internet economy. Last weekend, Lord Hanson popped out of retirement and into a column in the Sunday Times to tell us how we must all get the net or risk social and professional exclusion.

Yesterday Geoffrey Chamberlain - running up to his 58th birthday and until 20 months ago widely dismissed as a former City grandee with more professional acronyms than assets to his name -began telling us more about Durlacher, a former fringe stockbroker which he has transformed into what is best described as a British replica of a Silicon Valley venture capital firm.

Over the past year, shares in Durlacher have multiplied 150-fold, stamping a value of just over £2bn on the string of seed equity stakes Durlacher has taken in a string of net-related start-ups. The cyber-punt portfolio stands at 30 distinct investments, ranging from an indie bands promoter (www.channelfly.com) to a mobile phone software specialist (www.wapit.com). Along the way Durlacher has been busy building the sort of accompanying e-research and corporate finance business which many of the firm's big bulge-bracket investment banking rivals can only dream of.

The model is clear: deep research helps identify potential winners and management resources are then shunted in to help these young compa nies grow. But already Mr Chamberlain appears to be bored with the simple "incubator" role and is looking to create what is probably best described as an e-conglomerate, with Durlacher retaining controlling stakes in ventures rather than trading in and out.

The first building blocks are Kvault Software, an email archiving specialist, and 45one.com, which threatens to be the "destination site for decision-critical news, analysis and comment" on the technology and media industries. A number of homegrown internet businesses are also popping out of the Durlacher machine, such as the snappily named nothing-ventured.com, which promises to give private investors access to pre-flotation funding rounds.

Mr Chamberlain says we're looking at "keiretsu synergy" here, a new version of Japan's corporate network system - a system which the Japanese, as it happens, are currently trying to disentangle.

No matter. Durlacher got wind of this new industrial revolution early and there is no reason to start questioning the quality of its touch. In fact, it would not be surprising to see an American rival with deep pockets and a yearning to get to know Europe popping a takeover bid on the table.

But, as Mr Chamberlain and Durlacher head towards the Footsie (they are about halfway there), he will have to watch that his firm doesn't succumb to the pitfalls of hyper-fast growth.

He might start by looking at his share register which, in its current form and with good historical reason, would scare quite a few professional fund managers away. A good 15% of the company is owned by something or someone called M-J Technologies and Mr Chamberlain will only say that this is an offshore vehicle for a private investor who wants to stay that way.

There is nothing questionable about M-J in a legal or stock market disclosure sense, and this cyber-shrewdie certainly knows a thing or two about picking investment winners. But 15% is a significant shareholding, possibly carrying real weight in Durlacher's boardroom, and fellow shareholders in what is a public company have a right (albeit unwritten) to know who they are travelling with. Transparency is a good thing, even in the new economy.

Wood work

Halifax has caught the dot.com bug - and don't we know it. Leaping off an all-time low, the shares have spurted almost 30% this week to 552p, a good portion of the gain coming yesterday after the bank hired Peter Wood, the inventor of Direct Line, to set up an internet insurance business.

That came on top of Wednesday's news that a couple of fresh-faced non-executives -Coline McConville of America's Clear Channel and Charles Dunstone of Carphone Warehouse - will help propel Halifax into the e-world. It seems that the City cares little that esure, the internet insurance arm, will not even launch into a notoriously competitive market until next year.

Of course, two announcements in two days got the conspiracy theorists wondering whether Halifax's annual figures, due today, are so bad that they need to ignite the market beforehand - although the smart money suggested we will just get more e-news, this time on the planned internet bank, codenamed greenfield.co.

The task now for Lord Stevenson, the new chairman, and his youthful chief executive, James Crosby, is to keep the momentum going. With a bit of luck they might even get the share price back above the 1997 flotation price of 774p.

Leaping off an all-time low, the shares have spurted almost 30% this week to 552p, a good portion of the gain coming yesterday after the bank hired Peter Wood, the inventor of Direct Line, to set up an internet insurance business. That came on top of Wednesday's news that a couple of fresh-faced non-executives -Coline McConville of America's Clear Channel and Charles Dunstone of Carphone Warehouse - will help propel Halifax into the e-world. It seems that the City cares little that esure, the internet insurance arm, will not even launch into a notoriously competitive market until next year. Of course, two announcements in two days got the conspiracy theorists wondering whether Halifax's annual figures, due today, are so bad that they need to ignite the market beforehand - although the smart money suggested we will just get more e-news, this time on the planned internet bank, codenamed greenfield.co. The task now for Lord Stevenson, the new chairman, and his youthful chief executive, James Crosby, is to keep the momentum going. With a bit of luck they might even get the share price back above the 1997 flotation price of 774p.

fields.headline: Foster's 'erotic gherkin' takes root
fields.standfirst: Former owners of site likely to lead a legal challenge
fields.trailText: The Corporation of London is set to approve the construction of Norman Foster's 41-storey Swiss Re Tower, dubbed an "erotic gherkin" by some design critics, on the site of the former Baltic Exchange headquarters.
fields.body:
The Corporation of London is set to approve the construction of Norman Foster's 41-storey Swiss Re Tower, dubbed an "erotic gherkin" by some design critics, on the site of the former Baltic Exchange headquarters.

A report drawn up by City of London planning officers has just been completed recommending that the project is allowed to go ahead. A final decision is due on Wednesday, when the corporation's planning committee meets to discuss the report.

A corporation spokesman confirmed planning officers had given the thumbs-up to the project but added: "It's not for me to prejudge what the committee will say."

The all-glass building is likely to cost up to £300m, and will occupy the Square Mile site bombed by the IRA in 1992. However, a legal challenge to halt the construction is likely to come from the Baltic Exchange.

The Baltic Exchange sold the site to Kvaerner, then Trafalgar House, in December 1994 for £10m. At the time Baltic officials were told by English Heritage and the City fathers that their headquarters must be re-assembled in its original form as it was a grade II star-listed building.

The Baltic yesterday declined to comment on what action it would take but told City officials there was no case for completing demolition of the existing structure. The Baltic is also worried that Norman Foster's design involves an ancillary building being constructed to house various support services for the 180-metre tower.

Swiss Re bought the site from Kvaerner and plans to bring in at least 2,500 staff although the building would in theory have capacity to hold up to 4,000 people.

Norman Foster originally proposed a £400m millennium tower - which would have been the tallest building in Europe and dwarf Canary Wharf; but this plan was dropped after complaints.

webTitle: Revived Hanson plans US buying spree

fields.headline: Revived Hanson plans US buying spree
fields.trailText: Hanson, the feared corporate raider of the 1980s, is planning to spend more than £180m a year on acquisitions during the next few years - mainly on brick and aggregates businesses in the United States.
fields.body:
Hanson, the feared corporate raider of the 1980s, is planning to spend more than £180m a year on acquisitions during the next few years - mainly on brick and aggregates businesses in the United States.

The group, which has become one of the world's largest building materials businesses, spent £417m last year on buying 29 businesses and is near completing its £1.6bn agreed cash and shares bid for Pioneer International, an Australian concrete group.

Andrew Dougal, Hanson's chief executive, said the Pioneer deal had been cleared by the Australian and US authorities and that he expected it to get the green light from the European Commission by May.

He said the group would continue to take part in consolidation by making "bolt-on acquisitions" - taking over brick and aggregates companies near its existing operations. It was not planning another big deal like the Pioneer one.

Hanson yesterday reported pre-tax profits before exceptionals had risen 21% to £314.3m, mainly due to a strong performance in the US, where acquisitions, favourable market conditions and improved margins had lifted profit by 54.3% to £199.2m.

Mr Dougal said he expected the US operations to continue to do well, despite the rise in interest rates. He said the US market was underpinned by the government's six-year, $216bn spending programme on infrastructure

"We think that housing starts [in the US] will fall by about 6% this year, but that will be offset by higher public spending," he said.

Hanson's European brick operations saw trading profit fall 6.8% last year because of a weak market.

In the UK a reduction in stock levels had an adverse impact on productivity. A 5.1% increase in the final dividend has lifted the full year payout to shareholders from 12.75p to 13.4p a share. Hanson shares ended the day 19.5p up at 424p.

webTitle: Troubled yen hits low after Moody's warning

fields.headline: Troubled yen hits low after Moody's warning
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A new question mark was placed over the Japanese economy yesterday as Moody's Investors Service warned that it was considering a downgrade of the government's yen denominated debt.
fields.body:
A new question mark was placed over the Japanese economy yesterday as Moody's Investors Service warned that it was considering a downgrade of the government's yen denominated debt.

The news, a reminder of the immense difficulties facing the nation with the world's largest public borrowing, pushed the yen to a five-month low of 110 yen against the dollar.

If the move goes ahead, it will be the second downgrade of Japan's sovereign debt by Moody's. The credit rating agency's last downgrade - from its top triple-A level -came in 1998 during the depths of the country's worst recession since the second world war.

Japan has relied heavily on state spending during the past 10 years to offset the weakness of private consumption and corporate spending. The latest of nine stimulus packages, approved in November, pumped ¥18 trillion (£101bn) into the economy and parliament is now debating a record ¥85 trillion budget.

With tax revenues falling, along with earnings and profits, the government has had to fill the gaping hole in its finances with bond issues and bank loans. In the year from April, public debt is forecast to hit 130% of gross domestic product, the highest among developed nations.

Prime minister Keizo Obuchi has said that economic recovery must come before fiscal reconstruction, but Moody's said it was "unclear" whether Japan would return to a path of higher growth.

The government insists the economy is slowly picking up and finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa said yesterday that Moody's announcement was not worthy of comment.

"The Moody's news has pushed the market to the edge psychologically, but there is unlikely to be real impact in the mid-term," said Yoshi Nishimoto, an economist at HSBC.

webTitle: WPP reaps rewards from dot.com boom

fields.headline: WPP reaps rewards from dot.com boom
fields.standfirst: Firm's internet-related revenues almost double
fields.trailText: The explosion of dot.com companies trying to build brands from scratch helped internet-related revenues at Britain's largest marketing services group WPP to almost double to $500m (£310m) last year.
fields.body:
The explosion of dot.com companies trying to build brands from scratch helped internet-related revenues at Britain's largest marketing services group WPP to almost double to $500m (£310m) last year.

WPP chief executive Martin Sorrell yesterday said the rash of web-based businesses swamping traditional media accounted for a significant part of the 5%-6% growth experienced by the global advertising industry in 1999. Recent estimates suggested that dot.com companies spent $8bn building their brands in the US alone last year.

"These are substantial numbers," Mr Sorrell said. "Although the percentage of the entire market is still relatively low it does account for a significant amount of the growth. In the next year I expect to see a shift from spend on the consumer market to business-to-business."

He said more narrowly defined internet revenues earned from advising online companies on their web marketing strategies were $100m, up from $60m a year ago.

That figure is expected to grow 50% this year but the company added it would become increasingly difficult to strip out a pure internet figure because of the strategic importance of the web to the group's largest clients, Ford, IBM and Unilever.

WPP, which owns the J Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather advertising networks, reported a 13% rise in revenues for 1999 of £2.2bn with pre-tax profits 20% ahead at £255m at the top end of expectations.

The company also said it planned to buy back up to £100m worth of its own shares but that failed to underpin the stock which fell 125p to £10.29.

Analysts said investors were locking in profits after a performance which saw the shares double in value in the past four months.

Mr Sorrell forecast that the continued upwards trend in the cost of television airtime, which he said was rising at up to 10% per annum, would continue to drive marketing budgets into other media.

"The pricing of advertising on network TV by an oligopoly of media owners continues to grow faster than inflation while at the same time audiences are declining," he said.

"This is not a warning or a threat but a statement of fact. As media advertising can represent the most significant cost to many of our clients after their manufacturing expenses, these clients are increasingly considering alternatives to TV advertising. That is why both radio and billboard have doubled their share of the market recently and why the internet is becoming an increasingly attractive proposition."

Last year was the first where WPP's non-advertising activities represented more than 50% of group revenues. Brand ing and direct marketing accounted for more than 25% and public relations, including the Hill & Knowlton agency, accounted for about 8%. Market research was 19%.

The company said it would likely float its combined European e-services business, which will be formed from the merger of three web companies in which has stakes - Syzygy, United Media and Netforce. It is also considering a separate flotation of its German web development company Concept.

During the year, the group set up WPP.com with internet guru Esther Dyson as chairman. The business acts as a parent company housing the groups online interests and providing consultancy to other parts of the group. Part of its remit is to invest in start-ups which it can partner with or gain expertise from - similar to Reuters' Greenhouse Fund.

WPP's full year dividend payout was increased 21% to 3.1p a share.

fields.headline: Name may ring in row
fields.trailText: Telecoms company Kingston Communications could upset local councillors by considering plans to change the century-old company name.
fields.body:
Telecoms company Kingston Communications could upset local councillors by considering plans to change the century-old company name.

The business, which is 45% owned by Kingston-upon-Hull city council, has shortlisted two brand consultancies to begin work on a change of identity. The aim is to come up with a brand that better reflects the company as its focus shifts beyond Hull.

When the flotation of Kingston was first mooted last year it caused a political storm in the local council with many members believing the business should stay in public hands. Councillors argued that local service would suffer at the hands of a public company with its eye on expansion.

Opposition among local people will no doubt have been silenced by the windfalls made on the soaring price of Kingston shares. One-third of homes in Hull subscribed for shares last July at 225p and have since seen the price rise to £12.51, up 30p yesterday. Anyone who bought the maximum £5,000 is now sitting on almost £28,000.

The company is just outside the FTSE 100 with a value of some £4bn - the local council's share is worth around £2bn.

"We are looking at the branding of the group because it is a very different company from the one that existed three years ago and it will be very different again in five or six years time," said Kingston chief executive Steve Maine. "It is right that we should be looking at the way we present ourselves to the market and the City to reflect better the changing values of the company. One of the most significant parts of the company is Torch [Kingston's business-to-business arm] but when people see Torch do they immediately think of Kingston Communications? The answer is no."

Kingston, identified by its distinctive white payphone boxes, was formed in 1902 and was the only local council-run telephone network not absorbed into what became British Telecom.

Last week, Kingston formed a joint venture with BSkyB to broadcast pay television services over its upgraded telephone wires.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Mannesmann plans listing
fields.body:
Mannesmann plans listing

Mannesmann confirmed it plans to list its engineering and automotive division and that a new name for the division will be announced in the coming weeks. It said the listing was also in line with Vodafone AirTouch's plans for the division.

It said Georg Acker, Joachim Rauhut and Peter Prinz Wittgenstein would leave Mannesmann's management board and become management board members of the engineering and automotive unit on March 1.

It also said that on the assumption the Vodafone-Mannesmann merger was approved by the EU Competition Commission four members of Mannesmann's supervisory board would give up their seats in order to allow Vodafone to appoint its own people to the board.

Ford calls in union officials

Ford, which is planning a radical shake-up of its European operations, has called union officials to a meeting with top management today.

The officials said they were sure that it would be bad news for the workforce.

Ford's professional staff recently voted in favour of industrial action in pursuit of a pay claim.

Daft signs up with Coca-Cola

Coca-Cola, the world's largest soft drink maker, announced yesterday it had elected Douglas Daft chairman and chief executive, two months earlier than planned.

Mr Daft was designated as the successor to retiring chairman and chief executive Douglas Ivester in December, but the Australian executive was not expected to formally take over the top position until April.

FSA issues ISAs warning

Investors were yesterday urged to be alert to the charges associated with high-income individual savings plans .

The financial services authority said too few consumers were aware of the fact that fees "are often deducted from capital rather than income".

While clearing the sector of misleading investors, the FSA's consumer relations chief Christine Farnish said: "Firms need to ensure that their marketing literature really does help consumers understand the pros and cons of these products."

PwC proposes spin-offs

PricewaterhouseCoopers, the world's largest professional services firm, yesterday confirmed that it plans to split into two or more parts to capitalise on the huge growth in its consulting business.

The proposal would see the firm's audit and business advisory services and the tax practice remain as PwC, while management consulting, technology, human resources and other activities would spin off.

PwC said it needed to raise capital for e-commerce investments. Moves by the US securities and exchange commission to enforce audit independence rules are also believed to have played a part in the decision.

fields.headline: Novartis unveils new hope
fields.trailText: Swiss drugs company Novartis yesterday announced a new treatment for leukaemia as its brightest prospect for the future, but said the spate of mega-mergers in the industry posed a "challenge" for those left behind.
fields.body:
Swiss drugs company Novartis yesterday announced a new treatment for leukaemia as its brightest prospect for the future, but said the spate of mega-mergers in the industry posed a "challenge" for those left behind.

The company's management also unveiled an 11% rise in annual profits to SFr6.66bn (£2.55 bn). This was despite a collapse in earnings at its seeds and crop protection business, which is about to be combined with AstraZeneca's agro-chemicals operation.

Chairman Daniel Vasella said the imminent deal between Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, together with the planned tie-up of US groups Pfizer and Warner-Lambert, would push the company into the industry's second division.

"It's a fact that they will both be about twice the size of the second-tier companies," he said. "That certainly creates a challenge."

Development director Jorg Reinhardt said Novartis had enough in its pipeline to prosper as an independent company, pointing in particular to "amazing" results in clinical trials of leukaemia drug STI571.

The product targets a genetic change in people with leukaemia - a form of cancer which causes white blood cells to divide uncontrollably.

Novartis has tested STI571 on 620 patients, and at high doses the treatment has so far been 100% successful in restoring the normal number of blood cells.

Dr Reinhardt said: "It works very well. We're confident it will achieve, and even surpass, our ambitions."

If all goes well, Novartis said that it would launch the drug in 2002.

The company blamed a slump in crop prices for a 33% decline in profits at its agro-chemicals arm to SFr737m. Economic crises in Russia, the Ukraine and Brazil worsened the effect.

Mr Vasella said the business was cyclical, admitting that the slump made the decision to spin it off easier.

The deal with AstraZeneca, to create a new company called Syngenta, is due to be completed in the second half of this year.
