fields.headline: Master builder
fields.standfirst: Rick Mather is the American architect charged with transforming London's South Bank, the world's biggest arts complex. He tells  Stephen Moss  why he wants to create a mini-city on the Thames
fields.trailText: Rick Mather is the American architect charged with transforming London's South Bank, the world's biggest arts complex. He tells Stephen Moss why he wants to create a mini-city on the Thames.
fields.body:
As metaphors go, it's useful. A pile-driver is pummelling a piece of steel into the river beneath Hungerford footbridge on London's South Bank. The noise is so loud that lunchtime joggers cover their ears as they pass, and an elderly couple look on as the metal foundations of a new bridge are slowly sunk. The area had better get used to the pandemonium because, if the plan for the regeneration of the area unveiled yesterday goes ahead, the next decade will be as much about construction as concert-going.

It will, however, all be worth it if the plan, masterminded by the US-born architect Rick Mather, works. The South Bank is a shambles at the moment: walkways that lead nowhere, underground areas that even the drunks seem to think beneath them, gravel car parks, metal fences, brutalist facades. The National Film Theatre is tatty; the Hayward Gallery hard to find; the Queen Elizabeth Hall unloved; the spaces that supposedly connect them a disgrace.

It has been a shambles for a long time and architects have been trying to address the problem for almost 20 years. Terry Farrell spent a decade wrestling with a regeneration plan that was eventually sucked into the mire of political intrigue and planning argument that bedevils the site, the largest arts complex in the world. Richard Rogers's famous "glass wave" roof went the same way, deemed too expensive.

Lessons were learned from the Rogers debacle and the scheme announced yesterday is markedly different from Lord Rogers's bold stroke. Rather than being an architectural démarche, Mather's is a so-called "urban design plan" - an idea for what the place should be rather than how it should look.

Mather has laid down the principles that will be given form by architects following a series of competitions to design the key buildings on the 30-acre site. The South Bank's managers are desperate not to be pinned down to precise figures for the development, because it gives opponents an easy target. The issue of cost is, in any case, clouded by the degree to which the development will be self-financing - there will be a large amount of commercial development, with shops, offices, bars and restaurants.

Mather, the urbane, eternally young 62-year-old who was made "master planner" for the site last year, objects to this obsession with cost. "It's beside the point and confirms the awful generality that Britain is a nation of shopkeepers," he says. Mather was born in Portland, Oregon, but has lived in Britain since the mid-60s and loves London. In fact, he loves cities and his notion is to turn the South Bank into a kind of cultural mini-city.

"Ever since I first came to the South Bank I've imagined what I would do to improve it," he says, "so it was wonderful to get the chance to try. The principles with a city are always the same: you start out with the street and with an active frontage on the street. You have a reasonable density so it's convenient for people walking and you have a variety of different types of accommodation. It has to have balance- between the centre and the ouskirts, activity and peace.

"Streets are precious and wonderful things, particularly ones with lots of people on them, and they should be nurtured and reinforced by the public face that the buildings around them present. All the undercrofts will go and all the street-level car parking too - the things that don't give anything to the street. We're trying to urbanise the site, changing it from a sort of suburban business park into a usable public space.

"But we want to keep some of its character, so it is isn't just like any other urban area. I like the way the precise, pristine Festival Hall is set against the picturesque composition of the 60s buildings. The original designers saw those 60s buildings as a landscape, and they made the analogy with the artificial hill in Regent's Park Zoo that the mountain goats climb up."

Many customers at the South Bank have been less keen than the mountain goats on these 60s brutalist "landscapes", and "picturesque" might not be the word that the layman would apply to the concrete overhangs that dominate the Hayward gallery. So why has Mather decided to preserve it?

"I had to keep an open mind about the 60s buildings," he says. "I had to stay neutral on that or it made a mockery of the whole consultaion process. There's been very extensive consultation on the Hayward and the vast majority of people have been in favour of keeping it. But the 60s buildings can't stay exactly as they are. Functionally they don't work and need modification, and urbanistically they don't work because they don't come down to ground level. They have to change."

Mather is a master of the elegant modification of historically important buildings. He loves glass and that is much in evidence in his visualisation of how the new South Bank might look. "Glass is a good way to fill in under the Hayward," he says. "It makes a nice contrast with the heaviness of the existing building."

One interest group that Mather is not attempting to satisfy are car owners. He is cool, charming and laid-back, except when you ask him where the cars are going to go. "There is this myth that if you want to drive your car, all you need is a parking space," he says. "If you want to drive a car you've got to have a route where you're not stuck in a traffic jam. It's rubbish to say there isn't enough car parking space in the plan. If you have more car parking space, you have longer traffic jams."

He likes to walk and cycle - the best ways to experience the city, he insists - and is a vigorous proponent of public transport. There is a gleam in his eye when he mentions a new scheme for a tunnel linking Embankment tube station with Waterloo.

Now comes the test: raising the money, negotiating the planning hurdles, overseeing the competitions, keeping control of his plan. A good deal will depend on the retailers that move in - the target is very much Borders bookshop rather than Burger King, but isn't there a danger that financial pressures will intrude? "Any good shopping centre is careful about who it lets take space. If you establish the right environment, the right mix, people will be falling over themselves to come here. This might, for example, become the place to sell musical instruments."

Does the Millennium Wheel, which borders the site, help the plan - and will it be a disappointment if it is taken down? "The wheel has been wonderful for the South Bank. Its presence has accelerated the realisation that this is central London, the major space, the place to which the rest of the continent comes. Whether the wheel stays or goes doesn't make a lot of difference to the plan, but it's liked by most people and I notice it has a temporary licence for the same number of years as the Eiffel tower had when it opened."

Don't hold me - or him - to this, but 10 years from now I think we will have a buoyant new cultural mini-city on the South Bank, still towered over by that elegant monument to the millennium.

webTitle: Concrete facts:  Why brutalism is back

fields.headline: Concrete facts:  Why brutalism is back
fields.trailText: If you had asked them 10 years ago, the majority of informed commentators and South Bank users would have recommended the demolition of the Hayward Gallery, together with the Queen Elizabeth Hall and the Purcell Room: brutalist concrete juggernauts; ugly, weather-stained blots on the London landscape; gimcrack concrete architecture; carbuncles on the face of the capital. This is not the feeling now.
fields.body:
If you had asked them 10 years ago, the majority of informed commentators and South Bank users would have recommended the demolition of the Hayward Gallery, together with the Queen Elizabeth Hall and the Purcell Room: brutalist concrete juggernauts; ugly, weather-stained blots on the London landscape; gimcrack concrete architecture; carbuncles on the face of the capital. This is not the feeling now.

Elsewhere in London in the early 90s, the tough concrete megastructures of Erno Goldfinger - notably Trellick Tower, the skyscraping housing block looming over Portobello Road - had become fashionable. Age wearies buildings, but it also reduces and even redeems their initial shock value. The Hayward and its lesser brutalist siblings on the South Bank are actually rather fine buildings. Beneath a superficial layer of grime, the Hayward is as solid as a mountain. Its interiors are beautifully built and to the highest specifications.

The Hayward can be criticised, and is by those who work there, for its cramped accommodation. The offices are tiny, and storage and handling facilities are limited. And the entrance lobby is absurdly small. Rick Mather, however, has shown that there is plenty of space below the gallery to furnish it with the new spaces and equipment it needs to further its reputation as one of the best arts venues in Europe. It will still be ugly in many people's eyes because of its wilfully challenging architecture - a mix of heroic Soviet Constructivism of the early 1920s, Le Corbusier in his last raw concrete phase of the 1950s and the solidity necessary to protect the gallery from the helicopter/Rotadyne pad that was to have been nearby when the Hayward was first dreamt up in the mid-50s. It was meant to be a striking addition to the new cultural complex on the South Bank; its architects were young and working for the progressive architects' department of the former London County Council.

My own feeling is that it has some of the qualities of ancient Mayan and Aztec temples, and that its interiors are haunting spaces that encourage architects to respond to the building - no bad thing in a world of standard-issue white box galleries in which the artist's work is autonomous. The Queen Elizabeth Hall and Purcell Room are lesser buildings, yet their entrances in particular are intriguing, untouched 60s interiors and could be transformed into fashionable and engaging public spaces. What these pugilistic buildings need most is for architects and designers to sew them into a more convincing urban fabric than we have yet seen on the all too desolate South Bank. Mather has shown the way. Will the South Bank authorities now follow through?

fields.headline: League snubs £2bn Sky offer
fields.trailText: Sky received a blunt reminder of the new order in televised football yesterday when its multi-billion pound offer for exclusive live rights was snubbed by the Premier League.
fields.body:
Sky received a blunt reminder of the new order in televised football yesterday when its multi-billion pound offer for exclusive live rights was snubbed by the Premier League.

The staggering deal, thought to be worth around £2bn, was presented to a meeting of Premier League chairmen as Sky tried to make a pre-emptive strike for a new four-year contract.

Rupert Murdoch's satellite channel has enjoyed a monopoly of Premiership live coverage since 1992. But it no longer enjoys a monopoly in purchasing power. There are now other major players who can compete with Sky's wealth. So Sky tried to lure the Premier League into signing now.

But the Premier League's position is so strong that it resisted temptation and stuck to its commitment to conduct a tendering process for the new deal, which has to be agreed by June. Sky won the rights to the last four-year deal, which runs out this season, by paying £670m. No other TV company could come anywhere near that. So the Premier League was more than happy to take the money, even though it meant relinquishing some control, notably the decisions on which games would be televised and when.

But now the Premier League is in the driving seat as other companies are eager to get their hands on its product, notably the American cable giant NTL and OnDigital, which has shown it means business by buying the rights to some live Champions League games.

The Premier League meeting received an update from the chief executive Richard Scudamore. He has canvassed clubs individually and is now compiling a tender document for potential bidders.

webTitle: Brazil the deadline as Keegan fears Euro 2000 is too early for Joe Cole

fields.headline: Brazil the deadline as Keegan fears Euro 2000 is too early for Joe Cole
fields.standfirst: Barry in vanguard of rookie revolution
fields.trailText: Unless Joe Cole is picked against Brazil on May 27and has an outstanding match, West Ham's highly talented 18-year-old midfielder will have to wait until the 2002 World Cup qualifiers to begin his international career.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan will announce his final squad of 22 for the European Championship shortly before midnight after England have played Ukraine on May 31. Some things are best done under the cover of darkness. After all, the answer could be a pumpkin.

The Uefa deadline means that the more likely of the lads who have failed to make the party of 24 from whom Keegan will choose a team to meet Argentina in Wednesday's friendly at Wembley now have only one more opportunity, realistically, to go to Euro 2000.

Or to put it another way, unless Joe Cole is picked against Brazil on May 27 and has an outstanding match, West Ham's highly talented 18-year-old midfielder will have to wait until the 2002 World Cup qualifiers to begin his international career.

"By the time we play Brazil I would hope to have decided on eight or nine of the team I will pick for the opening European Championship against Portugal," Keegan said yesterday when he announced the squad, effectively drawing a line between probables and possibles. Cole, seen by many as the answer to England's chronic lack of subtlety and imagination in midfield, has been left in the latter group.

Of Cole, who plays for the Under-21s on Tuesday night, Keegan later said: "His time will come as sure as eggs are eggs. But the clock on the wall is saying that Euro 2000 is going to be a bit tight for him."

Nevertheless, Keegan earlier declared: "I would like to take four or five younger players to Euro 2000." But his squad will have to be ravaged by injuries on a scale comparable to the plague which afflicted Graham Taylor's party for the 1992 European Championship for those who are now below the salt to get a chance.

Not that the wand of youth is likely to be absent from the Argentina game. Emile Heskey, the quick, powerful 22-year-old Leicester striker is set to start for the first time after winning four caps as a substitute.

Martin O'Neill did not want Heskey to appear against Argentina four days before Leicester meet Tranmere in the Worthington Cup final but Keegan has insisted on the player's inclusion. "If Emile Heskey wants to get into the final 22," the England coach explained, "he has to be in the squad and take part in games."

With injury concerns over Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler, Keegan has little time to find the most effective partner for Alan Shearer. Kevin Phillips has been tried but, despite his prolific form for Sunderland, made little impact against Belgium in October.

Steven Gerrard, Liverpool's fast-maturing midfielder, is also in the squad, although his chances of taking part in the Argentina match have been reduced by the recurrence of the groin injury he suffered at Highbury on Sunday. If Gerrard is unable to train by Tuesday he will not be considered.

Nevertheless, the 19-year-old Gerrard's versatility could win him a place in Keegan's final squad. Like Kieron Dyer, his potential is increased by an ability to play with equal competence in a number of positions.

The prospect of Aston Villa's Gareth Barry celebrating his 19th birthday by winning a first full cap on Wednesday will depend in part on the England formation. Normally Barry plays on the left of Villa's back three and if Keegan stayed with a back four he might be asked to operate slightly out of position as a left-back.

Whether or not he plays against Argentina, Barry, too, is a distinct possibility for the summer. "His concentration has improved this season," said Keegan, "and the way he uses the ball, as well his calmness, makes him stand out for me."

Jason Wilcox's inclusion could be an early indicator as to how Keegan intends solving the lack of balance on the left. He is clearly toying with the idea of moving David Beckham to central midfield, which would bring in Dyer on the right.

 The FA is to ask for the Euro 2000 final squad deadline to be put back by at least 12 hours so that any injury concerns can be addressed.

England squad:

Seaman (Arsenal) Martyn (Leeds) Wright (Ipswich) G Neville (Man Utd) P Neville (Man Utd) Barry (Aston Villa) Southgate (Aston Villa) Campbell (Tottenham) Keown (Arsenal) Ferdinand (West Ham) Beckham (Man Utd) Ince (Middlesbrough) Froggatt (Coventry) Wilcox (Leeds) Dyer (Newcastle) Gerrard (Liverpool) Parlour (Arsenal) Scholes (Man Utd) Sinclair (West Ham) Wise (Chelsea) Cole (Man Utd) Phillips ( Sunderland) Heskey (Leicester) Shearer (Newcastle).

webTitle: Barry in vanguard of rookie revolution

fields.headline: Barry in vanguard of rookie revolution
fields.standfirst:
Villa's stylish young defender can restore balance at back for England
Brazil the deadline for Joe Cole
fields.trailText: Aston Villa's manager John Gregory believes the time is right for Gareth Barry as Kevin Keegan calls on the next generation of of internationals.
fields.body:
The more England play, the harder it is to summon any optimism for the outcome. Since the last World Cup, expectation of a decent result has fallen in direct proportion to the increase in the number of palsied performances.

One message flashes with neon brightness through this pall of underachievement: Kevin Keegan must start looking at the next generation of internationals, hoping that they are better than the last.

With memories of defeat by Scotland still fresh in collective minds, the coach also needs to spark some belief that England can achieve a measure of respectability in this summer's Euro 2000 finals, then do more in the next World Cup.

With youth comes hope, and so the selection yesterday of two new teenagers for the squad to face Argentina next week marks a significant step in Keegan's rookie revolution.

Into the midfield reckoning, injury permitting, comes Liverpool's Steven Gerrard, 19, and at the back Gareth Barry goes one better than the invitation to train with the England squad handed him by Glenn Hoddle last season.

That was an early recognition of a cultured and unhurried talent which has gone on to blossom in the Aston Villa first team despite a few wobbles along the way.

Barry is a player noted for his coolness, versatility, a rare and valuable reliance on his left foot, and an ability to attract plaudits from a wide range of judges - despite only turning 19 next Wednesday, the day of the Argentina game.

The Hastings-born youngster first hit the headlines when, as a 17-year-old, he joined Villa from Brighton amid angry exchanges over the compensation due the Third Division club. The approximately £1m eventually paid will represent tidy business for Villa if, as expected, Barry becomes an established international.

His manager John Gregory has already been told the youngster will start at least one of England's four Euro 2000 warm-up games, perhaps alongside his defensive partner at Villa, Gareth Southgate. His natural left bias is a particular bonus for the lop-sided national side. Barry plays on the left of a back three for Villa, but has also slotted in comfortably at left-back. He even played in midfield for England Under-18.

"To be honest he is phenomenal," enthuses Gregory. "I sometimes think that I don't want to heap too much praise on him but he is unfazed by it all and if you look at his face it never alters. You can't tell if he has been to a party or a funeral. He just gets on with things."

Barry burst impressively into the Villa first team at the start of last season and was instrumental in the club's long unbeaten run until fatigue in such a heady atmosphere finally got the better of him. But he has come back even stronger this season, thanks to extra training and the experience of last year.

"When he first started playing for me he was a baby-faced lad," says Gregory, "but now there's a layer of steel about him. But the real beauty about Gareth is his confidence and ability - even to go past people. But it never turns to arrogance. What he has is the confidence that comes from knowing you are good at what you do."

Peter Taylor, who enjoyed a close-up view of Barry as England Under-21 manager, agrees: "Gareth is a terrific player with such a sweet left foot and an amazing confidence on the ball."

That may lead to the odd heart-stopping feint past an attacker in his own penalty area, but it is this cool authority which marks Barry out.

webTitle: Abbey plays catch-up with plan for battery of cyber banks

fields.headline: Abbey plays catch-up with plan for battery of cyber banks
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Abbey National
fields.trailText: Abbey National plans to spend £200m to recruit 1m internet customers for its newly created bank, cahoot, and its own-brand internet bank by the year-end.
fields.body:
Abbey National plans to spend £200m to recruit 1m internet customers for its newly created bank, cahoot, and its own-brand internet bank by the year-end.

Within hours of unveiling cahoot yesterday, Abbey claimed the website was receiving six hits a minute from people wanting to register for the separately branded bank-cum-supermarket before its opening in six weeks' time.

Joining its rivals' race for dot.com credibility, Abbey said cahoot would employ 50 people and might take investment from venture capitalists to help it roll out in Europe. The bank's shares rose 47p to 713p.

Abbey said cahoot - so called because cahoots tend to be formed between friends rather than enemies - would initially offer credit cards and current accounts and would involve links with Blackstart for videos, Boxman for CDs, Thomas Cook for travel and Dell for computers.

As it reported a 17% rise in 1999 pre-tax profits to £1.8bn, Abbey said it would also launch an upmarket bank, which would have a presence on the net and in its branches, later in the year. The business, codenamed Prosper, will target people with more than £50,000 of net assets - a market of more than 4m.

The bank's internet service for existing customers will be begin next month and be accessible on digital television.

Outlining its "multi-channel" approach to customers, Ian Harley, chief executive of Abbey National, said: "We don't believe there's too much room for internet start-ups which don't have a very visible parent."

He played down speculation about Abbey being a takeover target, particularly for Lloyds TSB. He said it was "hard to see" why Lloyds would want such a deal.

Analysts said the profits announced by the bank,were in line with forecasts. Abbey directors said profits outside its core retail bank - where they rose 8% to £996m - were contributing 45% of the overall total and edging towards its 60% target.

It will pay a total dividend of 40.25p. Analysts said the bank had clearly faced a squeeze on mortage market share.

"The bottom line was ahead of expectations but the market share performance was very poor," said Jon Kirk at Fox Pitt Kelton. He said the bank had repriced aggressively in the fourth quarter when its market share was 17%, against 6%for the whole year.

fields.headline: Halifax nets Direct Line founder
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: More than £2bn was added to the market value of the Halifax bank yesterday after it announced an internet insurance venture with Peter Wood, the founder of Direct Line.
fields.body:
More than £2bn was added to the market value of the Halifax bank yesterday after it announced an internet insurance venture with Peter Wood, the founder of Direct Line.

Mr Wood, who cut all ties with Direct Line three years ago, is to take a minority stake in Esure.com, which will be launched next year to sell private motor and household insurance and insurance for small businesses over the internet. The bank expects to create 500 jobs with the move.

The 53-year-old Mr Wood, who was once the UK's highest paid director, turned the traditional car insurance market on its head - using telephones and computers instead of old fashioned insurance brokers. In just a few years, the characteristic little red phone had become the symbol of the country's biggest motor insurer and made him a multimillionaire.

Backed by Royal Bank of Scotland, he eventually agreed a deal with the bank in 1993 for £42m to end his annual bonus payments which were described as "obscene" by the then shadow trade secretary, Robin Cook, and which had by that time reached £18m.

Mr Wood intends to shake up the insurance market again - this time through the internet and Halifax, with the aim of reducing motor insurance by up to 15%.

His arrival at the Halifax reunites him Jim Spowart, who founded Direct Line's telephone bank and who will today announce Halifax's new standalone banking venture, at present code-named "greenfield.co".

Reflecting the stock market's obsession with e-commerce, the surprise announcement about Esure, a brand conjured up personally by Mr Wood, prompted a 22% rise in Halifax's shares to 552p.

"What Halifax has got right is that if you want to impress the stock market you've got to appear innovative. The substance isn't that important at present," said Rob Thomas, a banking analyst at Warburg Dillon Read.

"The stock market has become very polarised - you're either a winner or a loser. Halifax has been trading on a loser's rating," Mr Thomas said, to explain yesterday's price rise.

Halifax chief executive James Crosby, describing his latest recruit as a mold-breaker, said: "He has changed the structure of the British financial services market before, and with Esure we are confident that he will do so again".

Dismissing the impact of new, start-up internet companies, Mr Crosby said: "The era when 23-year-olds set up dot.coms and made an impact has gone. The big boys will take the market apart."

Mr Crosby said Halifax was putting £1.5bn behind e-commerce ventures and was also setting unpublished targets for returns on that capital.

Halifax will hold a significant majority stake in Esure, which Mr Wood said was "a generic name for e-commerce insurance".

His fee will be determined after the venture has produced a certain return on capital for Halifax.

fields.headline: Bank eases rate rise fears
fields.standfirst: January's high-street spending boom is a millennium one-off, says deputy governor
fields.trailText: The Bank of England yesterday calmed fears of a rise in interest rates, predicting a benign outlook for inflation and bringing relief to homeowners and business.
fields.body:
The Bank of England yesterday calmed fears of a rise in interest rates, predicting a benign outlook for inflation and bringing relief to homeowners and business.

A surge in high street sales and average earnings appeared to contradict evidence earlier in the week that inflation was under control.

But the bank's monetary policy committee said the economy's growth rate would slow to a more sustainable rate during the rest of the year due to the strength of the pound and past increases in the cost of borrowing. This would keep inflation in line with the government's 2.5% target over the next two years.

Mervyn King, one of the the bank's two deputy governors, said the inflation risks were "slightly on the upside", implying that rates may rise from the current level of 6%.

But analysts said the overall tone of the report suggested that any increases would be limited.

Ciaran Barr, economist at Deutsche Bank in the City, said: "I think the belief is that the Bank is not now going to go overboard on rates. They are going to continue to tread cautiously."

Mr King took credit on behalf of the committee for raising rates - up four times since September - well in advance of any perceived inflationary threat."Because of the action taken by the MPC since last summer, interest rates will be lower than would have been the case had action been delayed," he said.

The report said the principal upward pressures on inflation came from the tight labour market and strong consumer demand.

But Mr King played down the significance of Wednesday's labour market figures, showing a sharp acceleration in average earnings growth, and data out yesterday revealing a big jump in retail sales last month.

According to the office for national statistics, high street sales volumes increased 1.5% in January from December, to stand 6% higher on the year, the highest annual figure for two years.

Mr King warned that both the earnings and retail sales figures could have been distorted by one-off factors associated with the millennium and stressed that bonus payments were not to be trusted because the way in which they were calculated had been changed, preventing reliable year-on-year comparisons.

"Most of us have had little experience of millennium changes, and to be confident of estimates of seasonal adjustment factors one would require two or three hundred thousand years of data.

"So this is a time to be especially cautious about drawing strong conclusions from one month's data," said Mr King.

The retail sales figures showed that higher sales volumes were achieved mainly through heavy discounting, muting their inflationary potential. Until now, the strength of high street spending has been underpinned by rising house prices, which make people feel wealthier and encourage them to borrow against the value of their property.

But Mr King said there were indications that the housing boom - previously one of the Bank's main inflationary worries - was showing "some signs of moderation".

While prices were still heading upwards, mortgage advances - a forward guide to demand were easing, he said.

fields.headline: Triumph from the trenches
fields.standfirst:
The Silver Tassie
London Coliseum
Rating: * * * * *
fields.trailText:
The Silver Tassie
London Coliseum
Rating: * * * * *
Sean O'Casey's great anti-war play has always had its problems: it was rejected by Yeats for the Abbey Theatre on the grounds it lacked "unity of action" and it has always seemed to be a volatile mix of expressionism and realism.
fields.body:
Sean O'Casey's great anti-war play has always had its problems: it was rejected by Yeats for the Abbey Theatre on the grounds it lacked "unity of action" and it has always seemed to be a volatile mix of expressionism and realism.

But Mark-Anthony Turnage's magnificent new opera and Bill Bryden's production solve the problems musically and visually by treating the work as a comment on the horrors of war and the cruelties of peace.

The standard objection to the play is that the story of Harry Heegan, the football hero who returns from the 1914-18 war confined to a wheelchair, is that it suddenly lurches into a nightmare vision of the trenches in the second act. But Bryden and his designer,William Dudley, brilliantly remind us that the horrors are indivisible.

Behind the fragmented Dublin tenement of the first act we see massed ranks of silent soldiers. In the hospital-set third act even the beds and cabinets are ominously khaki-coloured. And in the final act, while Harry's former friends dance Irish jigs and the maimed are edited into oblivion, we are aware of the shadow of a mighty emplacement gun.

Within the unity created both by the production and Amanda Holden's wondrously taut libretto, there is a rich diversity in Turnage's music. Each act has its own style and character. In the first act the music is restless, febrile, expressive of character.

But in the second act, with its strong echoes of Britten and Tippett, Turnage touches the heart not least with a sombre, repeated choral lament in which the soldiers cry "Shall we die in November?" And in the last two acts, which focus on the despair of the one-time hero who sees his girl filched by his VC-earning rescuer, I heard touches of Berg's Wozzeck alongside the Irish reels. If Turnage's score is referential, it is also bound together by its invisible symphonic structure. It not only marks a major step beyond Greek but also suggests - rare for a new opera - a work destined to enter the repertory.

Inevitably you lose some aspects of the original play: much of O'Casey's wild comedy, for instance, and the harshness that allows a one-time pious nurse to say of war-victims that "if you'd passed as many through your hands as I, you'd hardly notice one". But the bonus of the opera is that it gives the work a tragic unity and, in Bryden's production, it is superbly acted and sung.

Gerald Finley's Harry makes nonsense of Yeats's claim that the work lacks a dominating character: whether exulting in his soccer triumphs, gazing wanly at the hospital image of a Sacred Heart or dashing the silver tassie to the ground, Finley charts the character's progress to impotent despair and makes every word audible. David Kempster as a blinded neighbour, Sarah Connolly as a heartless nurse and Gwynne Howell as a trench Jeremiah also give beautifully sung performances.

But the final triumph belongs to Turnage and his librettist who have taken a difficult play and fashioned from it an opera that speaks urgently to the heart. Miss the BBC2 relay on April 30 at your peril.

fields.headline: A voice for all seasons
fields.standfirst:
Kirsty MacColl
Dingwalls, London
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText:
Kirsty MacColl
Dingwalls, London
Rating: * * *
When a British pop artist does an album of Latin rhythms, my heart sinks a bit. There's an element of forced gaiety about it, a hint of student party-time. Arch songwriter and collaborator with everyone from The Pogues to Johnny Marr, Kirsty MacColl has just released Tropical Brainstorm, an album of "Anglo-Latin pop" that was inspired by frequent trips to Cuba and Brazil over the past five years.
fields.body:
When a British pop artist does an album of Latin rhythms, my heart sinks a bit. There's an element of forced gaiety about it, a hint of student party-time. Arch songwriter and collaborator with everyone from The Pogues to Johnny Marr, Kirsty MacColl has just released Tropical Brainstorm, an album of "Anglo-Latin pop" that was inspired by frequent trips to Cuba and Brazil over the past five years.

At Dingwalls a relaxed, composed MacColl gives it an airing, accompanied by a seven-piece band that includes her main collaborator Pete Glenister on guitar, plus upright bass, congas and a full-on horn section.

Her opener, US Amazonians, is a brash, promising mix of Irish jig and manic Brazilian beats, but this is followed by the more whimsical Here Comes That Man Again (a song about a naughty, anonymous Dutchman on the internet) and Celestine (a flippant ditty about MacColl's "French pop tart" alter ego). The crowd jiggle along patiently. The Latin influence sounds like pastiche, and she's more Victoria Wood at an Ann Summers' party than urban poetess. The fiery horns and percussion work better on England 2 Columbia 0, an edgy take on failed romance where MacColl sings salty, succinct lines like: "You forgot you had three children, you forgot you had a wife".

MacColl is most effective when she lets go of the laid-back, winsome delivery and injects biting passion into those honey-sweet tones. This is evident on the funky Walking Down Madison, the 1991 hit she recorded with Johnny Marr, and on Days, which tonight sounds fulsome and poignant.

MacColl is one of the few artists who can sing a cover version and make it stronger than the original. The evening ends on a high note when she performs Billy Bragg's folk-punk classic A New England, and receives a riotous reception. This is the anthem that the crowd has been waiting for. "It's not true that Londoners are frigid, it's a lie," MacColl declares, as she waves to the audience and departs. It wasn't so much the technically proficient Latin rhythms that got them going, but the fire and tension in her unmistakable voice.

Pop music hasn't thrown up too many surprises recently but a team of obscure, big beat DJs transformed into a chart-topping rock band is surely one of them. fields.body:
Pop music hasn't thrown up too many surprises recently but a team of obscure, big beat DJs transformed into a chart-topping rock band is surely one of them. Equally bizarrely, Death in Vegas find themselves nominated for a Brit award for Best British Newcomer after several years performing, and are led by someone who actually chose to call himself Richard Fearless. It's easy to scoff (and I'm sure his mum does) but no amount of sniping can take away the crew's success.

Last year's dark and brooding The Contino Sessions album received a critical fanfare and the single, Aisha, a fearsome tale about a serial killer, recently made the top 10. If their career volte face invites cynicism, so does the single's use of Iggy Pop as vocalist, although it's worth pointing out that Iggy usually has more trouble getting near the charts than getting into his trousers. The single's real masterstroke is in coupling a killer rock riff with a gigantic groove. It works wonderfully well in clubs.

However, if Death in Vegas think they can present rock music (albeit electro-tinged) as anonymously as they did dance music when they were DJs, they have another think coming. Rock is an entirely different culture, and demands personality, not a soulless experience drenched in big lights. The strobes and psychedelic projections are decidedly old-fashioned (very early Pink Floyd); beneath them, the nine or so musicians look like shadows and certainly don't make up for the fact that none of their celebrity vocalists appear. No Jim Reid, no Bobby Gillespie and no Iggy Pop is fair enough, but not even their voices?

Fearless rallies his troops manfully, but no amount of guitar mauling can disguise the fact that DiV desperately need a frontperson, as opposed to a person who stands at the front. Instead, we're left with instrumental music that obviously lacks the frisson of the vocal, recorded versions. There's an echo of Spiritualised and PiL here, a reggae instrumental there, but nothing really worth leaving home for. Perhaps they should have reverted to DJ type and simply played their own record: it certainly couldn't have made them much worse.

 Death in Vegas play the Forum, London NW5 (0171-344 0044), tonight and Concorde 2, Brighton (01273 325440), on Sunday.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible
